fields.headline: Ron's in the dugout!
fields.standfirst: ...and he's shooting from the hip!
fields.trailText: Ron Manager: 'Though never interested in the England job myself, like everyone else I swallowed hard when Kev leapt in with two feet and accepted the poisoned chalice . . . But won't Kev's cup be brimming over if the lads can do the business for him?'
fields.body:
Euro 2000 . . . isn't it? . . . Hmm? The skirmishing's over! Let's relish the tussle! The real competition starts here! . . . Well, for most of us it starts in Belgium on Monday . . . but here I am in Holland, and blow me if there's not a tournament going on here as well!

But like everyone else, I'm looking out for that key that'll unlock the trophy cabinet! That's Germany's trophy-cabinet, mind you, not our own! So who will do it for England?! Let's round up the usual suspects . . . Colonel Mustard in the conservatory? David Beckham in the library? . . . Bit unlikely, hmmm? . . . Ho ho! Only joking Victoria! More of David in a mo!

But since "Wonderboy" scored his "golden goal" we seem to have become a nation of pundits, and the name tripping off everybody's tongue is McManananamana . . . er, it's McMamananama . . . er, well for me it's Dennis Wise!

Though never interested in the England job myself, like everyone else I swallowed hard when Kev leapt in with two feet and accepted the poisoned chalice . . . But won't Kev's cup be brimming over if the lads can do the business for him? And if anyone can do the business it's Wisey, hmm? Like a little terrier, isn't he? . . . Wouldn't want him doing the business in your back garden, would you?!

But it's not just about doing the business, is it? For many of your East Europeans it's an opportunity for a player to put himself in the shop window . . . and if you can do the business, in the shop window, here in Amsterdam, er . . . then, er . . . hats off to you! Here, what happened to the Ruud Gullit wig, hmmm? Not quite my thing actually. It was hot . . . it was itchy . . . and it made my eczema flare up!

But Euro 2000, hmm? A lot less confusing than the Premiership, isn't it? And for all the talk about "flair",what wouldn't any of your continental squads of petulant superstars give for a little English grit, eh? And if it's a little English grit you want, then Wisey's your man! Someone who will stand up tall when the chips are down! Wise by name! . . . Er, that's about it actually.

But remember his performances amongst the fancy-dans of the Champions League? And didn't the Barcelona midfield find him a handful, hmm? . . . A constant thorn in the side, wasn't he? A right pain in the arse! . . . Marvellous!

I get so annoyed, it makes my blood run wild! People saying these foreign players are more intelligent than our home-grown talent . . . As young boys we were taught: "A little bit of knowledge is a dangerous thing" . . . Hmm? And your average London taxi-driver spends five years of his life doing the knowledge . . . ends up with little Dennis in the cab!

But European competition: marvellous, isn't it? . . . Large boys on the streets . . . unruly . . . often bare-chested . . . a little "je ne sais quoi" . . . crowbars for goal-posts . . . The floodlights! . . . The man-to-man marking . . . Will anyone manage man-to-man marking Macmamammamana . . . Macmammy . . . er . . .

First time I encountered it was Real Madrid in the Sixties . . . wasn't it? . . . Silky skills gave me the slip all night long . . . We swapped shirts at the end of the game . . . and I ended up with the one I started with!

The sound of klaxons! . . . Far cry from the old wooden rattle, isn't it, hmmm? . . . Whooosh! A firework arcs across the night sky . . . Where do your foreign supporters get hold of that kind of thing? . . . Certainly not from the old "football special" on the way to the game! Izal! wasn't it? . . . Cut through the air like a knife! . . . Chafed a little, didn't it? . . . Oh! Someone's thrown a smoke flare! . . . "Man overboard! . . . Man the lifeboats!" What was wrong with the old toilet rolls, hmmm? . . . Two-ply? . . . Kleenex double-quilted? . . . Wife won't have it in the house! . . . For those little bits of mud that come off your studs.

But this is where the tactical team talking, er, stops . . . Starts! This is the time to get behind the lads! . . . Come on England! . . . Relish the tussle! . . . Shoulder to shoulder! All shoulders to the wheel! All hands to the pump . . . the boy stood on the burning deck . . . pants began to burn . . . had to borrow his sister's . . . David Beckham, isn't it? . . . Cometh the hour, cometh the man!

The dead ball? . . . Up he steps and whooof! It's in the back of the net . . . marvellous! And that's what Becks gives to the team, isn't it? . . . Hairless pinpoint accuracy, reminiscent of Glenn Hoddle in his pomp!

They used to say Glenn's feet were like clubs . . . Golf clubs! Not club feet! . . . Could land the ball on a sixpence! . . . Has anyone ever wanted to land anything on a sixpence? . . . But Glenn Hoddle . . . ho ho . . . had a three-wood, a wedge and a putter on each foot! As good as having an extra leg! Er, reminiscent of Rolf Harris in his pomp.

Um . . . where was I? . . . Toss the salad! . . . Er . . . Pass the relish! . . . er . . . Relish the tussle!! Ah yes, I've had a reader's question! . . . Already!

Reader's question Mr Stephen Wedlake of south London writes: "After the recent 1-1 draw at Wembley . . . would you agree that the 'quick-quick-slow' tempo of the Brazilians is more effective than our own 'hoof-hoof-rush'?

Well, if you're talking about the style that made Sir Alf's "wingless wonders" the undisputed champions of the world . . . then I've got to say "if it ain't broke . . . what's your beef!? . . . Hmm?" Wembley 66, wasn't it? The greatest World Cup final ever? . . . Marvellous! . . . Couldn't sit through it again, mind. Someone put it on the other day . . . Bloody awful. And before I go . . .

'One to watch!' Luis Figo, the left-sided playmaker, nickname "The Left-sided Playmaker!" Or, in his native Portuguese, "Pikachu Sinistros!" . . . One to watch! And if you need anything clarified . . . and I don't mean butter! . . . about Euro 2000 . . . drop me a line! See you next week!

fields.headline: Euro bank ratchets up rates
fields.standfirst:
Fears that surprise half point increase will stifle recovery

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The European Central Bank yesterday moved to stamp out the threat of increased inflation in the euro zone with an aggressive half point rise in borrowing costs, ignoring fears that it could choke off Europe's recovery.
fields.body:
The European Central Bank yesterday moved to stamp out the threat of increased inflation in the euro zone with an aggressive half point rise in borrowing costs, ignoring fears that it could choke off Europe's recovery.

Wim Duisenberg, ECB president, said signs of a pickup in price pressures had prompted a rise in rates from 3.75% to 4.25%. He hinted at further rises when he emphasised that monetary policy was still "accommodative".

Market analysts had been braced for a quarter point rise in response to the recovery in growth over the past year, but were surprised when the ECB opted for a tougher stance. They now expect it to take a pause before any further tightening this year.

Paul Bednarczyk, currency strategist at 4Cast, said the half point move "smacked of overkill" when unemployment is only just below 10% and the biggest economy in the zone - Germany - is struggling domestically.

Although the 11-nation euro zone has seen exports boosted by a fall in the single currency on the foreign exchanges over the past 18 months, the ECB is concerned that its weakness threatens its 2% inflation ceiling.

Mr Duisenberg said risks to price stability in the medium term have "clearly continued to increase" in recent months.

When asked whether the ECB saw no risk of choking off economic recovery, Mr Duisenberg said: "The level of interest rates is still such that even after the increase today... it will rather promote growth than stifle it."

The euro jumped half a US cent after the rate announcement but later surrendered all gains sinking to day lows of around $0.955.

"The market was certainly caught on the wrong foot with the move," said Jonathan Bayley at Paribas in Paris.

"I think it's doubtful whether the decision was the best for the euro for several reasons." Markets might have perceived the rise as an effort to prop up the currency.

Yesterday's move by the ECB is the fifth increase in rates since November, when they stood at 2.5%. The combination of low interest rates and a cheap currency strengthened economic prospects in countries in the euro zone, particularly those on the fringes such as Spain, Portugal and Ireland, and in France.

But with inflation in some of the smaller economies threatening to escalate, the ECB has faced a difficult balancing act between promoting growth in the more sluggish regions and capping price pressures. But many analysts suspect concerns about the weakness of the single currency have prompted its aggressive tightening of policy.

Interest rates in the United States are well above those in euroland at 6.5%, and may be pushed higher when the Federal Reserve meets this month.

Following the Bank of England's decision on Wednesday to keep Britain's interest rates on hold, sterling reacted to yesterday's ECB decision by tumbling to a seven month low of 0.6335p to the euro.

"With speeches from Fed officials still on the hawkish side, the Bank of England now seems the only one of the major central banks to be keeping rates on hold, thus giving sterling its negative tone," said Mr Bednarczyk.

webTitle: 800 jobs go as mail order merges with Argos stores

fields.headline: 800 jobs go as mail order merges with Argos stores
fields.standfirst:
GUS bites the bullet after profits fall 15%
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Great Universal Stores yesterday said it would cut 800 jobs as it merged its struggling mail order business with the Argos catalogue shop to try to reverse a slump in profits.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores yesterday said it would cut 800 jobs as it merged its struggling mail order business with the Argos catalogue shop to try to reverse a slump in profits.

GUS, Britain's biggest home shopping group, revealed a 15.7% drop in annual pre-tax profit to £379.6m as turnover grew only 3.5% to £5.66bn. The biggest slide occurred in the British mail order business where pre-tax profit fell by £85m to £21m.

The company said a substantial fall in clothing sales at its mail order business, which has catalogues such as Kays and Great Universal, was caused by fierce competition from discount retailers.

The merger of the businesses is expected to stabilise the profit decline of the British mail order business and deliver cost savings of £80m annually over three years. The savings will be achieved by combining buying and delivery systems and cutting customer recruitment and service costs. The job losses will be mainly in Manchester and Worcester in the home shopping division.

"We think we can lower the risk by combining it with Argos," GUS chief executive John Peace said. "We've looked at selling and at closing the agency home shopping business, but we concluded that the best thing is to fix it."

The company has announced a rollout of its Argos Additions catalogue at all its stores by 2001 and believes it could become a business worth £300m. It intends to launch a credit card in the autumn.

GUS shares fell only 0.75p to 384.5p as analysts said the company had finally bitten the bullet on its problem division.

The double-digit growth in Argos's pre-tax profits was also viewed as positive, rising from £117m to £137.4m.

Sales at Argos jumped 7.2% in the year, though almost a third of this came from new stores.

In the present financial year the company said Argos reported sales growth of 18% in April and May. UK mail order sales dropped 7% in the same months because of a continued lack of demand for clothing. GUS's credit information business, Experian, saw profits expand 3.5% to £200.6m.

Its Burberry business benefited from a new management and repositioning of its brand; its profits in the year doubled to £21.7m. The company has renegotiated its Japanese licence, and this is expected to add £35m to profits by 2006.

fields.headline: Magical bleakness engages
fields.standfirst:
Another Place Tramway, Glasgow
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: Elisabeth Mahoney reviews Another Place
fields.body:
Tramway opens with what it does best: post-industrial bleakness on a vast, seductive scale. Loosely grouped around themes of change, fracture and distortion, this is an admirably cold-hearted show - icily cool works (in style and humour), with a detached, aloof feel to them.

That's not to say this isn't an engaging show; far from it. Tacita Dean's 60mm film Sound Mirrors couldn't have a more evocative setting, with its focus on obsolete, derelict structures, three prototype air-raid warning devices. Their former function redundant, they operate now only as symbols of change, and to reflect sounds in their vicinity - creatures in the nature reserve, trains passing by. The film could have been made for Tramway.

It wasn't, in fact, but Fornebu Drift by Graham Gussin and Jeremy Millar was, just one of several impressive newly-commissioned works in the show. Filmed in a deserted airport, it silently, elegantly reflects back on the old tramshed it is being screened in.

Mike Nelson's installation is a magical fake place, a made-up derelict interior mimicking Tramway prior to redevelopment. A series of musty, dusty corridors and down-at- heel rooms (the dressing room from hell, a small stage with a spotlight still aglow, a bar with nothing behind it), it is both an evocative reminder of what Tramway was and a playful, fantastical reminder of what never was.

These are the show-stealers, dwarfing the other works physically and conceptually. None of them, however, is given the quiet they need to work their poetic magic, thanks to the omnipresence of video artist Alan Currall with his story-telling fabrications and variety of on-screen personae. His voice and ironic trivia spill out into the cavernous space infuriatingly. "I know you're there," he repeats in one. It's a pity it's so hard to forget he is, too.

 Until July 16. Details: 0141-422 2023.

fields.headline: Ever evolving
fields.standfirst:
John Scofield
Jazz Cafe, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: John Fordham reviews John Scofield
fields.body:
"Most of the time I don't know what I'm doing," the guitarist John Scofield confided to a Jazz Cafe audience greeting him like a long-lost relative. Like a lot of throwaway lines, it had a sliver of conviction in it. Though the convenient jazz cliche is that it is all dreamed up on the fly, Scofield often genuinely seems on the edge of what he knows.

In London for the first of only two gigs in the UK this summer to support his excellent crossover album Bump, he was accompanied by an oddly balanced trio with a second guitar plus bass and drums. But a maelstrom of dense funk percussion, the shrewd use of samples and a vigorous two-guitar dialogue caught much of the mood of the disc, and intensified the after-hours atmosphere as the show went on.

The rhythm section, straddling the drum-machine feel of hip-hop and drum'n'bass and the more open and flexible vibe of jazz, did pretty well at leaving the inviting spaces Scofield likes, though he had to carry the show more than he does with a looser drummer like Bill Stewart. The slow features chimed and snarled with Scofield's characteristically warped chords and singing treble figures, the heavy-hitting grooves turned clipped, corner-of-the-mouth themes into flowing improvisations, and imaginative use of microchips allowed him to mimic the garrulous, interrogatory energy of vocal raps. Most gifted jazz improvisers sound uncomfortable, lazy or opportunistic in their funk incarnations, but Scofield always sounds as if he's still developing, and having the time of his life doing it.

webTitle: Mutual message fails to hit home, building societies told

fields.headline: Mutual message fails to hit home, building societies told
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Building societies have failed to convince members that mutuality is beneficial and have become too obsessed with challenges from carpetbaggers, the head of the industry's trade body admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
Building societies have failed to convince members that mutuality is beneficial and have become too obsessed with challenges from carpetbaggers, the head of the industry's trade body admitted yesterday.

David Smith, chairman of the Building Societies Association, said societies had been successful in meeting the challenges posed by carpetbaggers and increasing competition but "must not get complacent".

Addressing the BSA's annual conference in Edinburgh, Mr Smith suggested societies should come up with three pledges highlighting mutuality's benefits and make their message public by holding meetings across the country and organising focus group discussions.

Building societies must prove that mutual status delivers a unique service to customers, he said.

"Mutuals must make them selves relevant to their customers before they complain to the government that the electoral rules [surrounding conversion] are not fair, however strong their case in this respect might be."

The past year has seen the 225-year-old building society movement facing a series of challenges. But there was cause for celebration with the introduction of new anti-carpetbagging rules by the government. "Let those who run the anti-mutual websites be clear on one thing - it is getting harder to convert a building society against the will of its long term members, borrowers and local communities," said Mr Smith.

More than 40 societies now have schemes in place forcing new members to sign away to charity the right to any future windfall, and the sector is continuing to campaign for tougher rules to protect the movement.

webTitle: FSA raises hackles at Standard Life

fields.headline: FSA raises hackles at Standard Life
fields.standfirst:
Insurer attacks regulator's suggestion to ban the use of past performance figures in advertising
Money Unlimited"
fields.trailText: Insurance and investment company Standard Life yesterday attacked the City regulator for suggesting it might ban the use of past performance figures in advertising by investment companies, saying that such a move would be profoundly damaging for the industry.
fields.body:
Insurance and investment company Standard Life yesterday attacked the City regulator for suggesting it might ban the use of past performance figures in advertising by investment companies, saying that such a move would be profoundly damaging for the industry.

The financial services authority is considering overhauling the rules covering investment advertising after concluding that the link between past performance and potential future performance is "extremely weak", and that the figures may mislead consumers.

New league tables for investment products due to be published in spring next year will not carry past performance figures, which the FSA believes are almost meaningless - even though they dominate unit trust and investment savings account advertising.

FSA researchers say they have not been able to identify any statistical correlation between good performance in the past and good performance in the future.

However, the potential ban was criticised by Jim Stretton, chief executive of Standard Life, which has £79bn under management.

Speaking at the Building Societies Association annual conference in Edinburgh, Mr Stretton said the idea that companies such as his should be banned from ever referring to past performance was "sinister", adding that it would put mutuals at a disadvantage.

Mutuals had no external shareholders requiring dividends and this enabled them to run on lower costs, he said. "Mutuals as a class therefore ought to provide better terms to customers. The way this theory has worked in practice is there for all to see in the statistics."

A ban on past performance would therefore hit mutual in stitutions as they would be unable to talk properly about how they could outperform plc rivals, he said.

Mr Stretton added that customer needs were changing and companies would only be able to respond if they were given regulatory freedom to be creative in developing products. The FSA, he warned, risked stifling the industry and causing it "to regress into regimented mediocrity".

Mr Stretton said the job of the regulator was to produce a clean, fair market where all the information was available and where those who made misleading claims were "clapped in irons".

But he added: "Ultimately when someone makes a choice, responsibility for that choice lies with them."

With voting papers dropping through the letter boxes of the 2.3m Standard Life policyholders who will decide its future, Mr Stretton made a last ditch appeal to members to vote to keep the insurer mutual, calling on them not to "destroy" the benefits that would otherwise be enjoyed by future generations of customers for the sake of personal short-term gain.

The result of the vote on whether Standard Life should stay member-owned or convert to a public company and pay windfalls will be announced on June 27.

The ballot was prompted by a challenge mounted by a group of rebel members who claim conversion would unlock windfalls averaging £5,000-£6,300 to with-profits policy holders - figures contested by the company.

Mr Stretton said that present customers might have the vote but the board had a duty to also think about future customers.

When asked whether he was confident of victory he said: "I'm very optimistic. We are in the hands of our members."

fields.headline: Technique and colour
fields.standfirst:
Rambert Dance Company
Sadler's Wells, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: Judith Mackrell reviews the Rambert Dance Company
fields.body:
Merce Cunningham has always refused to tag stories or messages onto his dances, but even he has acknowledged that his 1991 masterwork Beachbirds was influenced by images of the sea. Its choreography is characterised by a light-boned, flickering energy that is sharply evocative of the way birds move, and its fluctuations between solitary activity and collective flocking are like the jottings of a birdwatcher's notebook. Beachbirds is also a work about landscape, though, and you revel in its light-filled spaciousness, and in the serenity with which its horizontal configurations transmute into odd sculptural climaxes.

Rambert has more than justified its expansion into a large-scale repertory company by acquiring this work for its own dancers. The British company don't perform with the votive purity of style that characterises the American company, but Rambert's dancers have easily enough technique for the choreography's stringent demands and I like the way they colour it with their own personalities.

The rest of the programme complements Beachbirds with carefully planned contrast. Glen Tetley's Pierrot Lunaire gives a rare chance for its three dancers to perform as soloists, and for Conor O'Brien, in the title role, to establish his star status. Christopher Bruce's Meeting Point, meanwhile, is a dapper ensemble work that allows all the dancers to glitter. The score is Michael Nyman's Where the Bee Dances, and while Bruce is sometimes content to surf over its zigzag rhythms, there are occasions when the choreography's design ambitiously mirrors the combative sound patterns of Nyman's score.

 Until June 10. Box office: 020-7863 8000.

fields.headline: Fowl behaviour
fields.standfirst: The manager of a butcher's shop is sacked for making unorthodox use of a free range chicken, an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: The manager of a butcher's shop is sacked for making unorthodox use of a free range chicken, an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.body:
I have been reminded this week of a much beloved phrase from my student days. I am now a bit hazy about its genesis - I think it was a bungled translation from a German text by some hopeless literalist (or equally possibly by a deliberate humorist). The phrase was "meatly longings" and tragically it still carries for me the nostalgic charge of past hilarity.

The week started out with a conference with some important folk from a chain of butcher's shops. They had sacked a manager of one of their establishments after an investigation into his activities. Basically meat was going missing, in mysteriously modest but regular quantities. It was always good quality cuts - nice bits of steak mostly. The disconcerting thing was that the papers I had been sent indicated that the surveillance cameras the employers had installed had not shown the manager taking the meat home. Instead, my written instructions suggested in strangled fashion that "he was making use of and disposing of the meat".

Me: "When you say he was making use of the meat, are you saying he was eating it in the shop?"

A bank of middle-aged men stared back at me in silent brick-faced embarrassment. My solicitor intervened hastily: "Perhaps it would help if you saw the video?"

I think I must be not getting enough sleep these days - possibly due to the bad dreams I've been having since I saw The Gladiator. Because it really didn't occur to me until I saw the fuzzy grey figure in the video removing a nice piece of filet steak from the cabinet and conveying it to his crotch that what we were dealing with in this case was vileness of the Portnoy's Complaint variety.

If I'd twigged sooner I could have saved the butchers at least some of their mortification. As it was, we were all so paralysed with horror I didn't manage to get the video paused until the manager was halfway through pleasuring a free range chicken.

Now you might think that discovering someone having sexual relations with the produce was a pretty sound reason for sacking him. I find it hard to think of any tribunal, even amongst the very mad ones, which would decide otherwise. So I was slightly confused as to why the clients seemed determined to settle the case.

Me: "I cannot see that he has any realistic prospect of success."

Solicitor: "We are hoping he will accept £10,000."

Me: "But I don't think he's got any chance of winning..."

Solicitor: "Ahem, well, there's the public relations aspect..."

Me: "?"

Solicitor: "Well, people might not realise that all of the meat that was, umm, used subsequently made its way into the bin..."

I can't really explain why I've been so dumb this week. I'm not sure I can blame it all on The Gladiator, although it has to be said that the level of violence was such as to wholly swamp my meatly inclinations towards Russell Crowe. And then there was that dream I had where Russell emerges into the Colosseum to find a giant free range chicken dressed in an Emperor Commodus suit waving its sword at him...

webTitle: Victor offers Microsoft an olive branch

fields.headline: Victor offers Microsoft an olive branch
fields.standfirst:
US government ready for settlement talks to avoid two-year appeal process
The future of Microsoft: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Joel Klein, celebrating his victory over Microsoft as head of the US government's anti-monopoly division, held out an olive branch yesterday by offering to restart settlement talks with the software group.
fields.body:
Joel Klein, celebrating his victory over Microsoft as head of the US government's anti-monopoly division, held out an olive branch yesterday by offering to restart settlement talks with the software group.

Speaking the day after Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson had agreed with the government that Microsoft should be broken up, Mr Klein said the government was "prepared to engage in meaningful settlement negotiations" to avoid an appeals process that could take a further two years.

He refused to say whether any settlement would be possible without an outright break-up of the company. Instead, he stressed that any settlement would depend on Microsoft's willingness to "live by the law" rather than "continue to abuse its monopoly power".

Settlement talks between the two sides broke down in April after Microsoft rejected any suggestion of a structural reorganisation.

In an interview with the Guardian yesterday, Brad Smith, general counsel for Microsoft, offered a guarded response to the settlement offer. "We have said constantly that we are always interested in any reasonable basis for this case to be settled."

However, he indicated the difficulty of both sides reaching such an agreement when he added that the group would not "compromise" on its belief that consumers were best served by Microsoft integrating new features to its operating system. The group could only do this as a unitary company, he said.

Judge Jackson also urged the two sides to start talking yesterday. In an interview with the Washington Post, he said the government and Microsoft should "swallow their own reluctance to compromise and reach a remedy that both sides, if not elated by, nevertheless are willing to extend".

Microsoft moved quickly to stay the judgment yesterday pending a full appeal, which is expected within days.

Jim Cullinan, a company spokesman, said Microsoft would appeal against the "entire order". Executives have said they are confident that the 25-year-old company would not be broken up.

Steve Ballmer, the company's president, said that the split-up order was unjust.

In his final judgment on the case, Judge Jackson called Microsoft untrustworthy. He said Microsoft might have avoided such a "radical" remedy as a break-up "had mediation been successful and terminated in a consent decree". His scathing indictment of the company suggested that it had no respect for the law, having failed to accept it had done anything wrong even after an earlier ruling that it had broken US anti-monopoly laws.

Mr Klein said it was telling that Microsoft had never set up an anti-monopoly compliance group after signing an earlier consent decree.

Analysts said it was too early to tell whether there would be a settlement. The justice department has filed for an appeal to go straight to the supreme court. If the court decides to accept the case, it could by settled next year.

fields.headline: The 9,307% company
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: After its turnover rose by 9,307% in three years Data Discoveries, an Edinburgh-based software firm, has been named as Britain's fastest growing technology company in a survey by Deloitte & Touche.
fields.body:
After its turnover rose by 9,307% in three years Data Discoveries, an Edinburgh-based software firm, has been named as Britain's fastest growing technology company in a survey by Deloitte & Touche.

But the company, which writes software for companies to access accurate marketing data on customers, refused to celebrate attaining the impressive title.

Founder Marcus Brook insisted the company cannot afford to become complacent, even if it does expect to double turnover every year for the next three years.

"The challenge is really keeping this level of growth," he said yesterday.

"Our focus is software. We are not a dot.com that's very good at spending investors cash and not making profits."

Data Discoveries, which employs 19 staff and started in 1995, expects to report turnover of £1.4m this year and pre-tax profits of £400,000. Clients include Al liance & Leicester, Mercedes Benz and Standard Life.

"The whole point of our software is to get some classic marketing into e-commerce and call centres. It delivers knowledge of what are customers' needs and wants. This is not being done on the web where a lot of marketing is to people who don't want your product."

The survey listed Eurocall, a reseller of telecoms services on other companies' networks, as the second fastest growing company by turnover, with its revenue jumping 9,170%.

Eidos, the Lara Croft computer games maker, saw its revenues leap 4,528%.

Deloitte & Touche partner William Touche said the growth statistics flew in the face of investor criticism lobbed at some technology firms whose stock market valuations have collapsed.

"Although technology shares have slumped from their early year highs, the survey reveals a good level of business optimism and there are many good quality companies considering listing," he said. "Conditions are likely to improve further as a result of the increase taper relief on capital gains tax of business assets announced in this year's budget."

Access to skilled staff, rising interest rates, concern on wage inflation, and sales and marketing strategies remained the key issues affect ing the industry, according to the survey of 2,000 technology companies across the country.

It found the companies were offering high reward schemes and equity options to deal with the problem of staff retention.

Mr Brook said his staff owned 20% of Data Discoveries, with an option to buy out investors Arch Angel Investment Group over time.

Data Discoveries was considering two acquisitions and looking to sell its product into Europe and the US.

However, only a third of the companies surveyed saw mergers or acquisitions as the desired expansion strategy. Most preferred organic growth and considered the US and UK provide the best opportunities.

A quarter of companies expected to be acquired as the environment for raising capital became favourable again for technology companies.

"Longstanding shortage of funding and poor tax incentives are being reversed," Mr Touche said. "The environment for technology entrepreneurs in this country is improving significantly."

webTitle: US cash fuels talk of Liffe flotation

fields.headline: US cash fuels talk of Liffe flotation
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Two United States venture capital companies will inject up to £60m of new capital into the London International Financial Futures Exchange in a move which is expected to result in a stock market flotation.
fields.body:
Two United States venture capital companies will inject up to £60m of new capital into the London International Financial Futures Exchange in a move which is expected to result in a stock market flotation.

The companies, Boston-based Battery Ventures and New York-based Blackstone Group, will end up with a stake of between 25% and 38% in the exchange, which is in the throes of dividing its business between its traditional trading activities and Liffe.com, its computer software arm.

As part of its radical plan to reinvent itself after transferring its business from tightly packed trading pits into computer clicks, the exchange yesterday revealed that it was teaming up with Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, the technology consultants, to try to sell its Liffe Connect electronic trading software to other groups.

Hugh Freedberg, Liffe's chief executive, said the trading technology developed by the exchange could be adapted by any market.

He cited the example of the $60bn natural gas market, of which only 1% is traded electronically.

With the help of Cap Gemini Ernst & Young, Liffe hopes to be able to persuade potential users yet to embrace new technology, as well as established exchanges including arch rival Eurex in Germany, to buy Liffe Connect.

It was the success of Eurex, formerly known as DTB, in grabbing business in Liffe's once dominant German government bond contract Bund that forced the exchange to engage in a desperate fight for survival. It closed its trading pits and moved its contracts to Liffe Connect, the electronic trading system which was cheaper for traders to use, as well as revamping its ownership structure.

Oliver Curme, general partner at Battery Ventures, which specialises in backing e-commerce businesses, said that the stock market flotation of Liffe would not take place quickly.

"We're patient investors," he said, explaining the investment was being made by a 10-year fund and was unlikely to try to start realising its investment within the first five years.

The business most likely to be floated is the Liffe.com software business into which other investors might also join. At at time when stock exchanges around the world are racing to merge - including the exchanges in London and Germany as well as a separate initiative by 10 exchanges around the world - Liffe's chairman, Brian Williamson, said he felt technology partnerships were more important.

"Of course we're talking to other exchanges but we'll be talking to them in another way about technology links," Mr Williamson said.

Liffe will offer its existing shareholders - banks, brokers and traders - the opportunity to take £20m of the £60m of additional financing at £6 a share.

The venture capital firms will put in between £40m and £60m depending on the uptake of Liffe's shareholders whose shares were last valued at £3.85. Battery Ventures and Blackstone Group will also be granted warrants to subscribed for Liffe shares at £12 but prevented from taking a stake of more than 40% in the shares.

Shareholders will need to approve the exchange's plans to alter its share capital at an extraordinary general meeting in August.

It was the success of Eurex, formerly known as DTB, in grabbing business in Liffe's once dominant German government bond contract Bund that forced the exchange to engage in a desperate fight for survival. It closed its trading pits and moved its contracts to Liffe Connect, the electronic trading system which was cheaper for traders to use, as well as revamping its ownership structure. Oliver Curme, general partner at Battery Ventures, which specialises in backing e-commerce businesses, said that the stock market flotation of Liffe would not take place quickly. "We're patient investors," he said, explaining the investment was being made by a 10-year fund and was unlikely to try to start realising its investment within the first five years. The business most likely to be floated is the Liffe.com software business into which other investors might also join. At at time when stock exchanges around the world are racing to merge - including the exchanges in London and Germany as well as a separate initiative by 10 exchanges around the world - Liffe's chairman, Brian Williamson, said he felt technology partnerships were more important. "Of course we're talking to other exchanges but we'll be talking to them in another way about technology links," Mr Williamson said. Liffe will offer its existing shareholders - banks, brokers and traders - the opportunity to take £20m of the £60m of additional financing at £6 a share. The venture capital firms will put in between £40m and £60m depending on the uptake of Liffe's shareholders whose shares were last valued at £3.85. Battery Ventures and Blackstone Group will also be granted warrants to subscribed for Liffe shares at £12 but prevented from taking a stake of more than 40% in the shares. Shareholders will need to approve the exchange's plans to alter its share capital at an extraordinary general meeting in August.

fields.headline: Milking the profits
fields.standfirst:
Mrs Warren's Profession
Royal Exchange, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: Lyn Gardner reviews Mrs Warren's Profession
fields.body:
In Bernard Shaw's first play, Widowers' House, the question of how we must live is raised by the hero's realisation that his income is derived from slum properties. In this play, written a year later but because of censorship laws not publicly performed until 1924, Miss Vivie Warren is horrified to discover that her fine education and monthly allowance have been financed by her mother's career as a brothel-keeper.

Modern audiences are as likely to applaud Mrs Warren's business acumen as much as sympathise with her assertion that prostitution is a sensible career move for young women whose only other prospects are four shillings a week in a factory and an early death from lead poisoning. But the difficulty with the play is that it is the daughter who is the heroine, and Vivie is a young woman quite capable of making the blood run cold. She has all the certainty of extreme youth and one who finds purity easy because she has never lived. Her final denial of flesh and mother, love and her own chance for motherhood has never seemed like a sacrifice.

Until now. Rebecca Johnson breathes real life and warmth into Vivie, suggesting that in her renunciation Vivie has lost what might have been the better part of herself.

Elsewhere, Denise Black captures the vulgarity of Mrs Warren, but not her allure and Ifan Merdith's wastrel Frank has a seductive charm. But some of the other performances are lazy or as over- emphatic as the design.

 Until July 1. Box office: 0161-833 9833.

webTitle: Keegan dares to dream of glory

fields.headline: Keegan dares to dream of glory
fields.standfirst: England fly out with their eyes on the ultimate prize.
fields.trailText: England fly out with their eyes on the ultimate prize. Martin Thorpe saw them off.
fields.body:
The England squad arrive at their Euro 2000 hotel today when, footballers being footballers, they will no doubt be tempted to head straight for the specially installed computer games room. However, in footballing terms, the virtual reality stopped the minute they stepped on to Belgian soil.

The friendlies and the shadow dances are over. The next match they play will be the real thing, against Portugal on Monday when the nation will be able to form a clearer picture of the team's chances of living up to Kevin Keegan's optimism.

The old tub-thumper was in excellent form yesterday as he talked up England's chances in Euro 2000 to the point of winning their first major trophy since 1966.

Since Alf Ramsey famously predicted victory before that World Cup began, almost every England manager since has trodden a similar pre-tournament path: putting a gloss on indifferent warm-up results, claiming that the squad's preparations are perfect and pointing out that there would be no point being here unless they thought they could win.

"I think we can," he said yesterday. "We have to do what we think is right to get the very best out of the players at our disposal. That's my job. If I get that, then we can win it, I really believe that."

Keegan used the example of his early days as manager of Newcastle. "When we just avoided relegation from the First Division, my next programme notes said, 'now for the Premiership'. A director said, 'you shouldn't say that. You put us under pressure'. I said, 'that's the problem with this club - we never set the sights right. That's where we want to go, the Premiership. And we got there and damn near won the title.

"If I had said as Newcastle manager at that time, 'OK, we have to stabilise ourself in the First Division or in the Premiership, you then set a level for your players. But I don't think that with the ability in this squad I should limit them."

The sceptics have been gathering in force this week, but if Keegan is in agreement with any of their views he is keeping that strictly to himself.

"We went to watch France at Le Tournoi before the last World Cup and if anybody had said, 'you are watching the world champions', you'd never believe it. It is not always the favourite that wins the horse race."

Certainly England's form against Brazil, Ukraine and Malta can be put aside to some extent now the tournament is about to start.

The team HQ is the Balmoral Hotel in Spa. The England party will completely take over the 90-bed establishment, which comes with gym, pool, its own grounds, the computer games room and the obligatory table tennis tables.

The all-clear is also about to be sounded on the injury front. Gary Neville and Alan Shearer did not train yesterday, the Manchester United full-back because of blisters, the captain because of the knee injury he picked up in Malta. However, both will resume training today and almost certainly be fit for Monday.

All Keegan and his staff can hope for now is that the team they have picked can knit together sufficiently to produce the right opening result. As for overall victory in the tournament, that remains more in the realms of a dream.

 Paulo Sousa, Portugal's influential midfield player, cut short a second consecutive training session yesterday, fuelling speculation that he could miss Monday's opening game against England in Eindhoven. The Parma player is said to be struggling with a thigh muscle strain.

fields.headline: Wright sends himself off
fields.trailText: Ian Wright yesterday brought the curtain down on one of the most colourful and controversial careers of recent times by announcing his retirement from football at the age of 36.
fields.body:
Ian Wright yesterday brought the curtain down on one of the most colourful and controversial careers of recent times by announcing his retirement from football at the age of 36.

The striker, who played for Burnley last season but has already established a new career as a television chat-show host, made the announcement on the Jerry Springer show, to be broadcast on ITV tomorrow.

"It's a really hard decision because I've got all the people in Burnley, the manager is a close friend and I've made really close friends up there," he said.

"My family are the major factor in me not playing any more, plus I have had a very good career and it is other people's turn now."

Wright, who helped Burnley gain promotion to the First Division, won 33 England caps and scored nine times. He had made his professional breakthrough relatively late, at 22, and helped Crystal Palace to the 1990 FA Cup final, coming off the bench to score twice and take Manchester United to a replay which Palace lost.

He joined Arsenal a year later and became part of Highbury folklore by breaking Cliff Bastin's long-standing club scoring record with 185 goals. During his spell there Arsenal won the FA Cup and the Cup Winners' Cup, and in his final season they did the Double. After that he signed for West Ham and Celtic, both for brief periods, before ending up at Turf Moor.

Long before the advent of his Friday Night's All Wright TV show he had become a cult figure, bridging the divide between football and pop culture, and his advert for a telephone company, depicting an imaginary conversation with Martin Luther King, underlined a significant contribution to race relations.

His career, however, was littered with fines and suspen sions; a year ago he was fined £17,500 for trashing a referee's dressing room and last season he was banned for two games after shoving a fourth official. Nevertheless at the start of the year he was awarded an MBE.

fields.headline: Liverpool sign Diomede
fields.trailText: Liverpool have completed the £3m signing of the winger Bernard Diomède from Auxerre. The 26-year-old passed a medical at Anfield and signed a three-year contract before jetting back to France.
fields.body:
Liverpool have completed the £3m signing of the winger Bernard Diomède from Auxerre. The 26-year-old passed a medical at Anfield and signed a three-year contract before jetting back to France.

"I am very happy to join a club with a French coach who I respect and know well," said Diomède, a World Cup squad member who played under Houllier for France. "I had been told that Liverpool wasn't the nicest of places to move to, but I have seen the city and have found the people and the place very nice."

Martin O'Neill's first task as manager of Celtic will be to try to persuade the temperamental Australian forward Mark Viduka that he should spurn the opportunity to join Leeds United.

The Leeds manager David O'Leary has opened negotiations with Celtic in the hope of finalising a deal which would see Viduka move to Elland Road for £6.5m. Viduka joined Celtic from Croatia Zagreb for £3m 15 months ago but has said he wants to leave Glasgow despite O'Neill's appointment.

Brazil are believed to have pulled out of the running for the 2006 World Cup, amid rumours that they have pledged their support to South Africa in return for South African backing in a renewed bid for the 2010 competition. "If this report is true it would be nothing but good news for us," said the England campaign director Alec McGivan. "Not only would it simplify the whole process but I feel certain it would increase our support."

The French international midfielder Christian Karembeu yesterday confirmed he will be moving to Middlesbrough from Real Madrid after Euro 2000.

The England midfielder Nick Barmby, 26, who has one year of his contract to run at Everton, has rejected the offer of a new deal.

fields.headline: Windows without pains
fields.standfirst:
Essex 263 & 22-2
Gloucestershire 268
fields.trailText:
Essex 263 & 22-2
Gloucestershire 268
fields.body:
Matt Windows yesterday broke the pattern of a match that had never seemed in much of a hurry or possessed of too much meaning.

Spectators were relatively few, as if saving up their pounds for a visit to the Benson & Hedges final on Saturday. Windows it was who gave point and pleasure to the cricket, which in atmosphere was a good deal more than 120 miles from Lord's.

Small, compact and supremely confident, Windows scored his third hundred in a row off Essex. He was fluent from the start of the second day yesterday, off-driving with a stylish sweep of the bat or clipping through midwicket. Once on seven and again in the 90s he was close to being caught at slip, but who was counting?

When he is going well like this Windows rekindles his candidature for test consideration. If he was inclined occasionally to be too eager outside the off stump, it could perhaps be put down to rehearsal time for the looming match with Glamorgan. There were 20 boundaries, all pugnaciously directed from his sturdy forearms - and then he whacked straight to cover.

Gloucestershire were all out for 268, a modest lead of five runs. It was better than looked likely when Tim Hancock was out to the fifth ball of the day, soon to be followed by Rob Cunliffe, a talented, nervous and under-achieving batsman, and Mark Alleyne. Just as well Chris Taylor came in next, ready to stay for an hour and a half in partnership with Windows.

Last week Taylor created history by scoring a century at Lord's on his county debut. He looks younger, though he is 23, than anyone else on the circuit and has the neat, slim appearance of a boy soprano. As someone who by nature goes for his shots, he paraded here a thoroughly defensive bat. He knows he is in the squad of 14 and he wanted to avoid any untimely aberration.

A succession of savaged schoolboy and club bowlers will vouch for his deceptive stroke play.

Gloucestershire are a team lacking in inches though not team spirit, and Jeremy Snape is no taller than Windows or Taylor. His carefully made half-century, augmented by Mike Cawdron's assured runs and Reggie Williams's dogged blocking, helped take them past Essex's total.

The Essex bowling was not particularly penetrative after the early inroads by Ronnie Irani and Mark Ilott. Stuart Law's catching was strangely fallible. And when it was their turn to bat again they lost Paul Prichard and Barry Hyam to second slip, leaving them with a fragile lead of 17.

webTitle: You've no chance, Mark, now that I've put the mockers on Lord's

fields.headline: You've no chance, Mark, now that I've put the mockers on Lord's
fields.trailText: Frank Keating Had they played for more fashionable, à la mode sides it is a safe bet that both Gloucestershire's Mark Alleyne and Glamorgan's Matthew Maynard would have been given tenfold more chances to play for England.
fields.body:
Two of domestic cricket's most vibrant and popular talents will lead their counties to Lord's on Saturday for the summer's first cup final. Had they played for more fashionable, à la mode sides - the home counties quartet, say, or the two northern "roses" - it is a safe bet that both Gloucestershire's Mark Alleyne and Glamorgan's Matthew Maynard would have been given tenfold more chances to play for England, and I daresay one or the other would probably have been long established as the Test captain.

The particular irony here is that Alleyne was born in Tottenham, which was once part of Middlesex, and Maynard in Oldham, which is still in Lancashire.

From a devoted "Glawster" viewpoint, this piece should have been printed last summer. In order, as they say, to lay the bogy.

Down more years than I care to count, this little column has very occasionally been given allowance to swell with pleasure and give Gloucestershire an expectant write-up as they have embarked on what seemed a serene last cruise to a championship title or a cup final place. Every time the piece provided the kiss of death as the "certainty" evaporated.

That is until last summer, when this superstitious corner resisted all commissions for previews of either the Benson & Hedges or NatWest finals - and a reined-in and glorious augury it proved because Gloucestershire won them both.

Wonder of wonders, now they are up for a third successive Lord's final - so even this handful of words does severely tease and taunt the fates.

My but Alleyne has been a wonder down in the west. I remember reporting in these pages in 1986 this product of London's Haringey cricket college becoming, at only 18, the youngest-ever Gloucestershire batsman - which took in Grace and Jessop, Hammond and Graveney - to score a century; and not knowing a remote thing about him to bump up a rave profile, I remember being embarrassed at having to mention that his Barbadian parents stood out exotically in the county Who's Who entry as Euclid Clevis and Hyacinth Cordeilla. Three summers later he became the youngest to score a double hundred for the county.

So he was special all right. But not super-duper deluxe extra-special until 1997, when out of the blue he was appointed the club's fourth captain in as many years, after the county's acrimony over two of its most durable and faithful grandees and former leaders, Courtney Walsh and Jack Russell.

Encouraged by the unfussy down-to-earth strengths of the new Kiwi coach John Bracewell, Alleyne accepted power with boyish enthusiasm. Since when his authority has grown alongside an increasing tactical verve and control.

His riveting Lord's century in last year's B&H final against Yorkshire, and his 10-0-37-3 against Somerset at the death in the NatWest final, italicised his all-rounder's flair. Sir Garfield Sobers at Trent Bridge, or even Walsh himself, may have been black skippers of distinction but Alleyne was the championship's first English-born black Briton to be a regular and permanent county captain.

Glamorgan make for tasty rivals. The last time this corner counted its chickens for Gloucestershire was in Alleyne's first year as captain. In 1997, the county led the championship by a street after beating Sussex in Hove in mid-August. But they folded in the run-in - and Maynard's Welshmen famously won the pennant and the silverware.

It was just the same all those aeons ago, in 1969 - when we were irresistibly "Proctershire", remember? By the end of that July, crazily, Gloucestershire were already 51 points in the clear before Tony Lewis's Glamorgan gave belated chase.

In the middle of August, first up at the Cheltenham festival, an innings win over Worcestershire demanded a "hooray, we're home and dry" from this column. But that day Glamorgan had remarkably beaten Middlesex in a thriller in Swansea - and came to Cheltenham for, in effect, the decider.

Although Mike Procter took his 100th wicket of the season, Gloucestershire's official history mournfully logs the tragedy: "The game was lost even before its first lunch when a psychological paralysis gripped all the leading batsmen." Gloucestershire lost by an innings - and it was Glamorgan's title.

Vengeance is also on this Saturday's menu at Lord's.

fields.trailText: COUNTY CHAMPIONSHIP First Division (Second day of four; today 11.0)
fields.body:
COUNTY CHAMPIONSHIP First Division (Second day of four; today 11.0)

Somerset v Kent

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: They may be dab hands at turning out seamers and quicks down by the Riverside, but what of the impact those encouraging pitches are having on Durham's supposedly fine young batsmen? Judging by the latest exploits of Jimmy Daley and Nick Peng, the answer reflects the view of life expressed by Woody Allen in Annie Hall: when it's not terrible, it's horrible.
fields.body:
They may be dab hands at turning out seamers and quicks down by the Riverside, but what of the impact those encouraging pitches are having on Durham's supposedly fine young batsmen? Judging by the latest exploits of Jimmy Daley and Nick Peng, the answer reflects the view of life expressed by Woody Allen in Annie Hall: when it's not terrible, it's horrible.

Yesterday, as Yorkshire challenged Lancashire for the leadership of the First Division by dismantling Durham for 189, Matthew Hoggard was rising through the queue of quicks vying with Steve Harmison for an England place against West Indies by taking five for 67. Peng fell for nine and Daley made 16, equalling his campaign best.

Hailed as an England shoo-in when he emerged as an 18-year-old in 1992, Daley began the season with three first-class centuries in 125 innings; so far his average is barely 10. Since attracting superlatives for a 98 on his debut against Surrey, Peng, a 17-year-old Geordie, has failed to scale even the most meagre heights.

Doubtless peeved that Shoaib Akhtar failed a test on his side strain, denying him the chance to warm up for Courtney and Curtly, Graeme Hick made an exemplary job of disguising his disappointment, making 122 for Worcestershire against Nottinghamshire.

The day was less kind for others scrapping for batting berths in next week's 100th Lord's test. Hick's team-mate Vikram Solanki, fresh from a confident fifty against the tourists, had to be content with 27, while Mark Ramprakash of Middlesex and Graham Thorpe of Surrey, found a subject ripe for a mutual grouse: both made ducks.

As the champions folded for 138 at Derby, Thorpe was one of seven scalps for Tim Munton. Having seen off Mark Butcher and Thorpe with successive balls, Munton also dislodged Alec Stewart in the first hour. An admirable recovery all round: not only had he recently suffered a head wound requiring 40 stitches, his previous three championship strikes for his new employers had cost almost 95 runs apiece.

Matching Hoggard and Alex Tudor, whose five Derbyshire wickets swelled his season's bag to 22 - was David Masters, owner of the smoothest action this side of a Gillette Mach 2. Having destroyed Zimbabwe on his first-class debut and Durham last round, the lad from Chatham strung up four more victims at Bath. He may not need those bricklaying and plastering qualifications after all.

Not that he could stop Somerset from leading Kent by 34. Crucially, Graham Rose, 36 going on 21 and a mite miffed at initially being demoted below new-boy Ian Blackwell, made 45 not out back at his customary No7. Still blooming after all these years.

webTitle: Lara puts his Test place in jeopardy

fields.headline: Lara puts his Test place in jeopardy
fields.standfirst:
West Indians 176 & 97
Glamorgan 140
fields.trailText:
West Indians 176 & 97
Glamorgan 140
fields.body:
The second day at Sophia Gardens closely followed the pattern of the first. Batsmen struggled. The pitch played tricks. Brian Lara failed.

Coming in at four for two in the third over of West Indians' second innings, he drove his first ball from Owen Parkin sweetly through the covers for four, followed it with another in Parkin's next over, gathered three singles and then padded up to Robert Croft. At least he managed double figures.

In Lara's defence it is questionable whether the ball would have hit the stumps, normally a key element in any lbw decision. The umpire John Steele had no doubt, though, and made him the 10th leg-before victim of the match.

With the first Test now just a week away, Lara has a maximum of two more innings to find some form. Failure against Zimbabwe at Arundel will present his captain with a tricky decision before Edgbaston: stick with the team that beat Pakistan last week or bring in a player who can barely score a run.

Before then, West Indies still have work to do to prevent defeat here, Glamorgan needing 134 to win on the final day. Bowling last on an unreliable pitch could yet be sufficient insurance for the tourists, but careless batting at the start of their second innings allowed Glamorgan to reassert themselves after conceding a first-innings lead of 36.

Sherwin Campbell was expertly caught and bowled by Alex Wharf, and Wavell Hinds drove Parkin to mid-on. Only Ridley Jacobs, who attacked judiciously for 43, looked secure on a pitch that tests a batsman's patience, technique and luck.

Eighteen wickets fell on the day, two in the first over. Nixon McLean, considered the quickest of the current crop of West Indies fast bowlers, dismissed Dean Cosker and Wayne Law after Glamorgan had resumed their first innings at 44 for two. He followed that up with the wicket of Adrian Dale, leg-before to a delivery that got up only shin-high. His morning's work, three for 19 from 10 overs, made Glamorgan reconsider thoughts of a handy first-innings lead.

McLean's opening partner in this match, Reon King, is also no slouch. When he found Steve James's inside edge and pad, the wicketkeeper Wayne Phillip had to be at his sharpest to hold a fizzing catch to his right.

The other quick bowler on display, Corey Colleymore, was the friendliest of the three. With West Indies, however, these things tend to be relative. The pitch is playing low enough to convince the cannier fast bowler to keep his fireworks in the box for more promising days.

Refreshing to English eyes after two decades of relentless pace was the wrist-spinner Mahendra Nagamootoo. He persevered with impressive control and was rewarded with three wickets in four overs. Adrian Shaw, one half of a stubborn seventh-wicket stand of 43 with Keith Newell, cut a ball into the hands of Chris Gayle at slip, Newell was leg-before playing no stroke to a googly and Wharf was caught at the third attempt by Lara at mid-wicket.

fields.headline: Flintoff finds his touch
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 95 & 45-3
Lancashire 269
fields.trailText:
Hampshire 95 & 45-3
Lancashire 269
fields.body:
It has been a difficult week in the young career of Andy Flintoff, but he was smiling again yesterday evening. Not only were the Lancashire team of which he is such a popular member progressing steadily towards victory over hapless Hampshire but he had relocated the middle of his bat in a typically entertaining personal contribution.

A brace of embarrassing dismissals in the Trent Bridge test had led to widespread and uncomplimentary discussion of his technique. Bob Simpson, the Lancashire coach, thought much of that was unfair. Flintoff simply believed that he was badly out of form.

That was the reason, he said, why he applied himself so visibly when he resumed his innings on the second day of this First Division match. But even in extra-responsible mode Flintoff is a good deal more watchable than most of his contemporaries.

Alan Mullally's loosener, a wide long hop, was thumped through the covers. There were four more boundaries off the former England left-armer, one a stunning off-drive, and three off Shane Warne, two from consecutive balls to reach an 82-ball half-century.

Flintoff still looked focused as he munched on a pork pie at lunch. Not that it did him much good, as he was the first of three afternoon victims for Mullally, given lbw in the first over after the break. But 73 from 108 balls should send him to Edgbaston to face Curtly, Courtney and co next week in much better spirits. "I needed that," he said with a grin.

Mullally later dismissed Warren Hegg and Chris Schofield with consecutive swinging deliveries, twice removing the middle stump. But Neil Fairbrother was unbeaten even though he had to work hard for his 77, hampered by the calf strain he suffered in the Benson & Hedges Cup semi-final defeat in Bristol last week. It was a valuable innings, helped by Will Kendall's dropped catch when he was on 30, which ensured a first-innings lead of 174.

Warne took four of the last six wickets for 32, and more than half of those runs were thumped by Lancashire's last man Mike Smethurst in a 10th-wicket stand with Fairbrother which secured a second batting point.

Smethurst's spirited knock ended in the ignominy of leaving a googly which hit his middle stump, but he offered further evidence of his potential for Lancashire by showing the imagination to start his second-innings spell with a slower ball which surprised Robin Smith and had the Hampshire captain lbw.

Jason Laney and Giles White had already gone, and Hampshire still need another 129 to avoid their third innings defeat of the season.

webTitle: Symcox tells inquiry that Cronje discussed bribery approach in 1995

fields.headline: Symcox tells inquiry that Cronje discussed bribery approach in 1995
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje approached his team-mate Pat Symcox to discuss an offer for throwing a match during his first season as South Africa captain, it was claimed yesterday on the opening day of the King commission into match-fixing.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje approached his team-mate Pat Symcox to discuss an offer for throwing a match during his first season as South Africa captain, it was claimed yesterday on the opening day of the King commission into match-fixing.

Symcox alleged that Cronje had discussed with him an approach to throw a one-day game against Pakistan in 1995 - almost two years before the much-publicised offer made to the team in India which Cronje maintains was the first and only offer he received.

"It was the day before the Mandela Cup match at Newlands, in Cape Town [January 10, 1995], and Hansie called me to his room and we chatted about the match and a few things," said Symcox, the former test off-spinner.

"Then he said he had been made an offer to lose the match and wanted to know whether he should put it to the team. I told him it was a bad idea and that he shouldn't worry about it.

"I said I thought we could beat Pakistan anyway and we should just concentrate on the cricket." South Africa went on to win the match by 37 runs.

Cronje, who is not expected to take the stand for two weeks, has previously stated that he has never approached a team-mate with an offer.

Symcox, testifying under oath, then revealed that a further offer of a bribe was made during that same Indian tour in December 1996 by "a current international player, not a South African", whom he referred to as Mr X.

"He approached me in the lobby of our hotel in either Bombay or Delhi and asked if I was interested in getting involved in a bit of gambling," Symcox said. "I said no, I couldn't."

The United Cricket Board of South Africa's advocate, Jeremy Gauntlett, asked Symcox why these offers had not previously been reported, either at the time or subsequently. "I don't know," Symcox replied.

The 40-year-old veteran of 20 tests also shed further light on the much-reported offer made in Mumbai in December 1996, which the South Africans turned down at a team meeting.

Symcox said he believed the offer was for $250,000 [£160,000]. "It was the first time any of us, especially myself, had this sort of thing thrown at us. We thought: 'It's quite a lot of money, maybe we should look at it'."

He said the offer came at the end of a "very tough tour" for a match which the South Africans did not believe was worthy of official one-day international status.

"Hansie called a meeting in his room. It was just the players, no management were involved. He said an offer had been received to lose the game."

Symcox said the opener Andrew Hudson had rejected the offer on principle and was backed by Daryll Cullinan and Derek Crookes. At that point Cronje said it was "no go".

But Symcox said that he and some other players, including Dave Richardson and the all-rounder Brian McMillan, had stayed in Cronje's room. "We laughed and joked about it. Then someone said, 'Why not see if we can get something more out of it?' "

Symcox said Cronje picked up his telephone and made a call. "Then he said there was another $100,000 (£65,000). But Hansie then said if the whole team was not involved he would not be comfortable about it."

Cullinan and Crookes are due to appear today before the inquiry headed by Judge Edwin King. Cronje, whose father Ewie was in the court yesterday, was sacked as captain on April 11 after confessing he had accepted up to $15,000 from bookmakers for providing match information.

fields.headline: Welcome to Euro 2000
fields.standfirst: This year's European Championship is going to rememberedfor manyyears to come, predicts David Lacey
fields.trailText: This year's European Championship is going to rememberedfor manyyears to come, predicts David Lacey.
fields.body:
The first European Championship of the 21st century should be a memorable experience. Whether or not it will be remembered for the right reasons, however, is hard to tell.

For the tournament to be an unqualified success three things need to happen. The football has to be of a high technical level while at the same time being imaginative and positive, the refereeing should combine discipline with commonsense, and the Armageddon threatened by multinational hooligan mobs converging on the Low Countries must be a non-event.

The matches themselves ought to have the least difficulty meeting these criteria. Most of the finalists will field the best talents of the Champions League apart from South Americans, Africans and the odd antipodean.

France, the World Cup holders, will vie with Holland, arguably the best team in 1998, for the position of favourites, and much will depend on the form, mood and fitness of such outstanding individuals as Zinedine Zidane and Dennis Bergkamp, Laurent Blanc and Patrick Kluivert. Thierry Henry is a major threat since Arsenal converted him into a striker, David Trezeguet is in equally good scoring form and perhaps Nicolas Anelka will emerge from his latest slough to take Euro 2000 by storm.

European Championships have a habit of producing ill-considered finalists who sometimes win the prize: Czechoslovakia in 1976, for example, or Denmark, reinstated after Yugoslavia's disqualification, in 1992. Few thought Belgium would finish runners-up in 1980 and the Czech Republic only lost the 1996 final at Wembley to Oliver Bierhoff's winner for Germany in sudden-death overtime.

The dark horses this time are not so much the Czechs, who won all their qualifiying games, as teams like Yugoslavia, Portugal and, yes, England, whose overall record in this competition is so wretched (only four victories in the tournament proper) that Kevin Keegan's side might suddenly surprise everybody, not least themselves.

Certainly England will not fail for a lack of maturing talent. What would Germany not give for a David Beckham, a Michael Owen, a Paul Scholes or even a Steven Gerrard? Maybe Erich Ribbeck's team are the darkest horses of all but when Jens Jeremies, industrious and perceptive though hardly another Franz Beckenbauer, is Germany's most consistent player there is clearly a lot of work to do.

Italy and Spain will carry shorter odds than England or Germany even though neither has won a European Championship since the 60s. In fact both have a tendency to punch below their weight in this competition, witness Italy's collapse in 1996 after Arrigo Sacchi had mucked about with his team in the first round.

The Czech Republic would appear to be the best bet to become only the third team from eastern Europe to win the tournament, although Romania and Yugoslavia can match them for quality of players. For sustained quality and excitement no European Championship, before or since, has equalled the semi-finals and final of 1976 when Yugoslavia, West Germany and Czechoslovakia produced enthralling football at a breathtaking pace before Antonin Panenka's nonchalant penalty, after Uli Hoeness had missed in the shoot-out for the Germans, took the Henri Delaunay Cup to Prague.

Add Gunther Netzer's inspired performance for West Germany when they beat the Soviet Union 3-0 in the final four years earlier, Marco van Basten's remarkable volley which completed Holland's 2-0 victory over the Soviets in the 1988 final, the sheer joy of the Danish triumph against Germany in 1992 and Bierhoff's history-making "golden goal" last time and there you have some of the best European Championship memories.

For England, of course, 1996 was all about football coming home and chariots swinging low, Paul Gascoigne's outrageously impudent goal against Scotland, the sudden fusillade against Holland, David Seaman's save in the shoot-out with Spain and Darren Anderton coming within a post's width of beating German in extra time in the semi-finals, before Gareth Southgate met his calvary when the game went to penalties.

Overall it was not the greatest of European Championships. Too many players fell below expected form with the Dutch and the French not least among them. The introduction of sudden death if scores were level after 90 minutes did not prevent two quarter-finals and both semi-finals being decided on penalties. For once the better matches were seen in the opening groups.

Refereeing howlers are unavoidable but it is to be hoped that none will be as blatant as the moment in Euro 96 when Dorinal Munteanu's shot for Romania struck the Bulgarian crossbar and bounced down well behind the line only for a goal to be refused. Or the trip by Gascoigne on Alfonso which sent the Spaniard tumbling in the England penalty area without a penalty being given.

The refereeing this time should take its cue from the Champions League, which this last season has generally struck a proper balance between the need for strict control and an unnecessary preponderance of yellow and red cards. The referees in Euro 2000 should emulate the more sensible aspects of the easing-up on cards in England since the New Year, while ignoring the absurd lengths to which this leniency has sometimes stretched.

Then there are the noises off. It is a sad fact that since 1980 every European Championship in which England have been involved has been accompanied by hooliganism in varying measures. Even the amiable, carnival atmosphere of Euro 96 was let down by the violence in central London which followed England's defeat on penalties by Germany in the semi-finals.

Not that the English fans have always been responsible for the violence. The teargas riot which halted England's game against Belgium in Turin in 1980 was instigated by local Juventus supporters. In West Germany 1988 and again in Sweden in 1992, the worst outbreaks of mayhem involved Germans, but in each case it was England's long-standing association with hooliganism which caught the media's attention.

With Fifa voting to decide who will host the 2006 World Cup only four days after the European Championship final, this would be a bad time for television pictures of English skinheads engaged in running battles with Dutch or Belgian police having smashed up bars in Eindhoven or Charleroi to be flashed around the globe.

Insisting that England and Germany meet in tiny Charleroi, instead of Brussels or Rotterdam, could be a fateful error by Uefa which may affect the whole tournament. Such fears may prove groundless, but this time too many troublemakers are within commuting distance of getting, and giving, their kicks.

European Championship winners
