fields.bodyText: The first European Championship of the 21st century should be a memorable experience. Whether or not it will be remembered for the right reasons, however, is hard to tell. For the tournament to be an unqualified success three things need to happen. The football has to be of a high technical level while at the same time being imaginative and positive, the refereeing should combine discipline with commonsense, and the Armageddon threatened by multinational hooligan mobs converging on the Low Countries must be a non-event. The matches themselves ought to have the least difficulty meeting these criteria. Most of the finalists will field the best talents of the Champions League apart from South Americans, Africans and the odd antipodean. France, the World Cup holders, will vie with Holland, arguably the best team in 1998, for the position of favourites, and much will depend on the form, mood and fitness of such outstanding individuals as Zinedine Zidane and Dennis Bergkamp, Laurent Blanc and Patrick Kluivert. Thierry Henry is a major threat since Arsenal converted him into a striker, David Trezeguet is in equally good scoring form and perhaps Nicolas Anelka will emerge from his latest slough to take Euro 2000 by storm. European Championships have a habit of producing ill-considered finalists who sometimes win the prize: Czechoslovakia in 1976, for example, or Denmark, reinstated after Yugoslavia's disqualification, in 1992. Few thought Belgium would finish runners-up in 1980 and the Czech Republic only lost the 1996 final at Wembley to Oliver Bierhoff's winner for Germany in sudden-death overtime. The dark horses this time are not so much the Czechs, who won all their qualifiying games, as teams like Yugoslavia, Portugal and, yes, England, whose overall record in this competition is so wretched (only four victories in the tournament proper) that Kevin Keegan's side might suddenly surprise everybody, not least themselves. Certainly England will not fail for a lack of maturing talent. What would Germany not give for a David Beckham, a Michael Owen, a Paul Scholes or even a Steven Gerrard? Maybe Erich Ribbeck's team are the darkest horses of all but when Jens Jeremies, industrious and perceptive though hardly another Franz Beckenbauer, is Germany's most consistent player there is clearly a lot of work to do. Italy and Spain will carry shorter odds than England or Germany even though neither has won a European Championship since the 60s. In fact both have a tendency to punch below their weight in this competition, witness Italy's collapse in 1996 after Arrigo Sacchi had mucked about with his team in the first round. The Czech Republic would appear to be the best bet to become only the third team from eastern Europe to win the tournament, although Romania and Yugoslavia can match them for quality of players. For sustained quality and excitement no European Championship, before or since, has equalled the semi-finals and final of 1976 when Yugoslavia, West Germany and Czechoslovakia produced enthralling football at a breathtaking pace before Antonin Panenka's nonchalant penalty, after Uli Hoeness had missed in the shoot-out for the Germans, took the Henri Delaunay Cup to Prague. Add Gunther Netzer's inspired performance for West Germany when they beat the Soviet Union 3-0 in the final four years earlier, Marco van Basten's remarkable volley which completed Holland's 2-0 victory over the Soviets in the 1988 final, the sheer joy of the Danish triumph against Germany in 1992 and Bierhoff's history-making "golden goal" last time and there you have some of the best European Championship memories. For England, of course, 1996 was all about football coming home and chariots swinging low, Paul Gascoigne's outrageously impudent goal against Scotland, the sudden fusillade against Holland, David Seaman's save in the shoot-out with Spain and Darren Anderton coming within a post's width of beating German in extra time in the semi-finals, before Gareth Southgate met his calvary when the game went to penalties. Overall it was not the greatest of European Championships. Too many players fell below expected form with the Dutch and the French not least among them. The introduction of sudden death if scores were level after 90 minutes did not prevent two quarter-finals and both semi-finals being decided on penalties. For once the better matches were seen in the opening groups. Refereeing howlers are unavoidable but it is to be hoped that none will be as blatant as the moment in Euro 96 when Dorinal Munteanu's shot for Romania struck the Bulgarian crossbar and bounced down well behind the line only for a goal to be refused. Or the trip by Gascoigne on Alfonso which sent the Spaniard tumbling in the England penalty area without a penalty being given. The refereeing this time should take its cue from the Champions League, which this last season has generally struck a proper balance between the need for strict control and an unnecessary preponderance of yellow and red cards. The referees in Euro 2000 should emulate the more sensible aspects of the easing-up on cards in England since the New Year, while ignoring the absurd lengths to which this leniency has sometimes stretched. Then there are the noises off. It is a sad fact that since 1980 every European Championship in which England have been involved has been accompanied by hooliganism in varying measures. Even the amiable, carnival atmosphere of Euro 96 was let down by the violence in central London which followed England's defeat on penalties by Germany in the semi-finals. Not that the English fans have always been responsible for the violence. The teargas riot which halted England's game against Belgium in Turin in 1980 was instigated by local Juventus supporters. In West Germany 1988 and again in Sweden in 1992, the worst outbreaks of mayhem involved Germans, but in each case it was England's long-standing association with hooliganism which caught the media's attention. With Fifa voting to decide who will host the 2006 World Cup only four days after the European Championship final, this would be a bad time for television pictures of English skinheads engaged in running battles with Dutch or Belgian police having smashed up bars in Eindhoven or Charleroi to be flashed around the globe. Insisting that England and Germany meet in tiny Charleroi, instead of Brussels or Rotterdam, could be a fateful error by Uefa which may affect the whole tournament. Such fears may prove groundless, but this time too many troublemakers are within commuting distance of getting, and giving, their kicks. fields.headline: Lothar's escape from New York
fields.standfirst: Michael Ellison  on the German sweeper's path to Euro 2000
fields.trailText: Michael Ellison reports on the German sweeper's path to Euro 2000
fields.body:
Lothar Matthäus could have found a more obscure stage upon which to rehearse Germany's challenge for Euro 2000 but it might well have meant using a beach, a plastic ball and two sets of denim jackets.

Allow no one to persuade you that professional football - or soccer - is anywhere near taking off in the United States. The success of the World Cup here in 1994 was testament to the country's expertise in staging big events, not to the emergence of a sport to challenge baseball, basketball and the National Football League; the excitement generated last year by the US team's victory in the women's version is remembered mainly for Brandi Chastain removing her shirt after scoring a penalty.

Try calling Giants stadium, home of the New York/ New Jersey MetroStars, where Matthäus has enjoyed/endured a short dalliance before returning to Europe to take part in the world's second biggest tournament. The public affairs office at the ground where the infinitely more popular New York Giants and the New York Jets American football teams also play seemed unaware of who Octavio Zambrano was, even when informed that he was the coach of the stadium's soccer franchise.

Zambrano flew to Spain a few weeks before the Major League Soccer season started to make sure that the 39-year-old holder of a record 146 international caps knew what he was letting himself in for when he quit Bayern Munich in March.

"I went with the mission to really and truly spell it out to him," said Zambrano. "Lothar was told very clearly that this was not going to be Bayern Munich or Inter Milan or the German national team. I wanted to make sure he got the clear picture, that he was not painted a rosy picture. I wanted to bring him to reality."

Whatever effect this mercy dash might have had - and Matthäus arrived more than two months later than initially planned - reality cannot have bitten until the veteran of five World Cups had slung his bags into Trump Tower, his home on Manhattan's west side, and made his way to the stadium 15 minutes away across the Hudson river in New Jersey.

If Giants stadium is only reputed to be the last resting place of the Teamsters union boss Jimmy Hoffa, there is no doubt about the form of the soccer team who play there. The MetroStars have been dismal and last year's record was seven wins and 25 defeats, the worst in the MLS's four full seasons.

"This is a very difficult situation for me," said Matthäus. "At Bayern Munich we were always in first place or second place. Inter Milan was the same. This is a new situation."

Right enough. Matthäus's last game for Bayern was a 4-1 win over the soon-to-be European champions Real Madrid before a crowd of 64,000.

When the MetroStars score - and they have actually done better since Matthäus left to join the Germany side - the celebrations are led by footage on giant screens of Jackie Gleason performing what looks like an elephant dance in the 1950s sitcom The Honeymooners. Among the biggest cheers are those at half-time when freebies are catapulted into the crowd.

Matthäus has not lasted long on his initial foray into the US game but he and his coach say he will be back to fulfil a reported $1.5m (£1m) contract for the season. Nor was it a spell of unalloyed joy for the German sweeper, a temperamental conductor with too many passengers on his bus.

He lost it completely five weeks ago in the course of defeat by Kansas City, tearing off his captain's armband and throwing it at an official, then declining to play for a few minutes. Zambrano and the MetroStars' general manager Nick Sakiewicz had words with him afterwards.

Matthäus made it plain that he was not willing to tolerate team-mates who played well in training and lost their nerve during matches, and that he had lost patience with the players' tendency to lump the ball upfield at every opportunity. But there is another problem: English. Matthäus concedes that he cannot speak the language well, but the team's Colombian strikers Adolfo Valencia and Alex Comas cannot understand it at all.

"My English is not very good but I understand when a guy says to me, 'Lothar, go right.' When I play a good ball and I say, 'Comas, go right,' and he goes left I lose the ball."

Zambrano, a 42-year-old from Ecuador, is a man blessed with forbearance. "The whole issue with Lothar... it's not a big issue. I see it as part of the transition this club is going through. He had a tough time adjusting to the soccer culture in this country."

The coach refuses to accept that Matthäus might have damaged his chance of having a good Euro 2000 by playing in the US. "I don't think he's been short-changed at all. He trains in the same way; everything is the same. The only thing that makes a difference is the level of the players.

"He says some things that may offend people but at least he says it straight out. I think I know him well enough to know that is just the way he is."

Despite his recent travails and the national team's indifferent form Matthäus remains confident about what must surely be his final top-level tournament. "I want to leave on a high note," he said. "I'm going to play like I never played before. I've given my soul to this team. I'm not going to let it die."

He has been troubled by a thigh strain and limped out of last night's 8-2 victory over Liechtenstein after half an hour as a "precaution". But it will take a lot to keep him out of Germany's encounter with England on Saturday week.

His club coach, meanwhile, was sounding an optimistic note about the future of football in the US. "Without a doubt we need a generation of fanatics," said Zambrano. "Once this becomes a 20-year league, another 15 years, I think the league will grow and be healthy." By then Lothar Matthäus will be only 54.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 Shorts
fields.trailText: Germany's coach Erich Ribbeck has been criticised for claiming that black players have more natural ability than whites. "It is like with dancing," he told Die Zeit. "A black person simply has different movements, it's not just a question of training. You'd have to be colour blind not to see the truth." But Piara Power, national co-ordinator for Kick Racism Out of Football, calls the coach "misguided". "One can't make these generalisations," he said. "Similar comments were made about black players in England in the 70s - all of which have been proved wrong."
fields.body:
Germany's coach Erich Ribbeck has been criticised for claiming that black players have more natural ability than whites. "It is like with dancing," he told Die Zeit. "A black person simply has different movements, it's not just a question of training. You'd have to be colour blind not to see the truth." But Piara Power, national co-ordinator for Kick Racism Out of Football, calls the coach "misguided". "One can't make these generalisations," he said. "Similar comments were made about black players in England in the 70s - all of which have been proved wrong."

 Portugal's assistant manager Rui Cacador is drawing hope from England's poor defence in the run-up to Monday's game: "We are now focusing on the England game. They are a very strong team but not without their weaknesses, like in defence. We will try to take advantage of their weak points such as goalkeeping problems."

 The Dutch police yesterday made the first arrest of a football fan. The man, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was apprehended after painting his rented house orange. "When the police arrived he was painting the sidewalk in the colours of the Dutch flag," said Fons Catau, a director of the De Woonplaats housing agency in Enschede. "We cannot tolerate people who cause irreparable damage to our property. We understand the excitement about the tournament, but he was a little too enthusiastic."

 More good news for the Portuguese: the Brazilian legend Pele believes they could be the surprise team of Euro 2000. He also told the Spanish sports daily Marca that Holland, the 7-2 favourites, would flop. "My worry is that [the Dutch coach, Frank Rijkaard] has included Edgar Davids and Clarence Seedorf in the midfield and Marc Overmars and Dennis Bergkamp in attack. This does not seem like the way to win games." He also dismissed German's chances - "they are just too old" - and tipped Spain and England as possible winners.

 Sweden's players have been banned from having sex during the tournament. The move has been welcomed by the Arsenal midfielder Fredrik Ljungberg: "After having sex the night before [a match] I lose all feelings in my feet. I'm totally empty. I can't control the ball. Instead I watch erotic movies the night before. That doesn't affect my power."

 Britain will supply almost a fifth of the players in Euro 2000. Sixty-nine players currently based in Britain - all but six of whom play in England - will be there, 19.6% of the total.

 If, after the game against Malta, England's fans are questioning Kevin Keegan's managerial capabilities, they should ask David Ginola's opinion. The Tottenham winger, who first came to England under Keegan at Newcastle, said: "When he talks the players listen, because they know he is speaking from experience. He is passionate about the game and the players like that. He is a special man. He is loved by everyone and that is almost an impossibility for a manager because if he's not picking you for the team you don't want to like him. Somehow with Keegan it was different; he seems to be blessed with unique qualities.

webTitle: Ribbeck's racial wide of the mark, says campaign chief

fields.headline: Ribbeck's racial wide of the mark, says campaign chief
fields.trailText: June 8 Germany coach Erich Ribbeck has been accused of making "misguided" comments after claiming black players have greater natural ability at football than whites.
fields.body:
Germany coach Erich Ribbeck has been accused of making "misguided" comments after claiming black players have greater natural ability at football than whites.

The comments by Ribbeck, who is preparing the defending champions for their opening match against Romania, appear in the forthcoming issue of the weekly Die Zeit.

"It is like with dancing, a black person simply has different movements, it's not just a question of training," he is quoted as saying.

"You'd have to be colour blind not to see the truth. For example: five black players dominate the Dutch national team."

But Piara Power, national co-ordinator for Kick Racism Out of Football, insists Ribbeck is wide of the mark.

He said: "I think Ribbeck is misguided. One can't make these generalisations. I don't think he means his comments in a negative sense but it is wrong to go down that road.

"I think he meant them positively but similar comments were made in a negative sense about black players in England in the 1970s.

"It was said black players were very skilful but that they could not defend, could not cope with the hurly-burly of the British game and did not like the cold - all of which has been proved wrong."

Power added that the high proportion of black players in English football was down to "socialisation", with teachers pushing black youngsters towards sporting excellence rather than academic achievements.

Power, in Brussels today at the launch of the Football Against Racism in Europe, also accused UEFA of failing to recognise the problem of racist abuse.

He said: "UEFA really does not seem to show any sign of recognising the problem and the concern is that if there is racist chanting and abuse in stadiums UEFA stewards are not going to be on top of it.

"We are concerned about the possibility of racist abuse and violence being part of the hooligan problem in Holland and Belgium this summer, particularly when you look at the abuse British players received in Europe last season."

fields.trailText: June 8 Sweden coaches Tommy Soderberg and Lars Lagerback have slapped a strict sex ban on their players as they embark on their Euro 2000 campaign.
fields.body:
Sweden coaches Tommy Soderberg and Lars Lagerback have slapped a strict sex ban on their players as they embark on their Euro 2000 campaign.

Arsenal midfielder Fredrik Ljungberg was quick to leap to the defence of the management duo when he admitted: "After having sex the night before (a match), I lose all feelings in my feet.

"I'm totally empty. I can't control the ball any more. Instead I watch erotic movies the night before. That doesn't affect my power."

fields.headline: Walerian Borowczyk: Blanche
fields.trailText: film is a kind of fairytale dance of death where tragedy is probable, even if a happy outcome isn't entirely out of the question...Borowczyk's art, which often looks like a carefully animated painting, and has the pessimistic urge one associates with Franz Kafka, is invariably about sex, love and death
fields.body:
Walerian Borowczyk, if remembered at all nowadays, is recalled for the wrong reasons. He has been regarded in this country as a pseudo-cultured pornographer ever since The Beast, which ends with a sexual encounter in a forest between something that looks like a well-hung ape and a woman, was shown at the National Film Theatre to a pretentiously horrified audience. The film then came out commercially, minus most of the coupling, thanks to the censor of the day.

It is true that Borowczyk, a Polish film-maker who has a small museum of historic erotic implements, seems to have spent his last years in France, working in the soft-porn genre. But if it is indeed true, as the novelist Vladimir Nabokov says, that the letter "s" is the only difference between the cosmic and the comic, especially as far as sex is concerned, some of us are right to regard him as a precious talent. Indeed, David Thomson, in his Biographical Dictionary of Film, calls Borowczyk one of the major artists of modern cinema.

Born in 1923, he started off as an animator of pinpoint delicacy and the kind of surreal edge that reminded one of Dada and Luis Buñuel considerably more than Walt Disney. When he went into features there was the same eye for miniaturist detail. If his most infamous films were Immoral Tales and The Beast, his most famous were Goto, Isle of Love and Blanche. Both are classics of their kind, starring Ligia Branice, his wife and collaborator.

My favourite is Blanche, which also contains one of the last performances on film of the great Michel Simon. When I showed it to a class of students who had never heard of Borowczyk or Simon, the film completely up-ended them. Admittedly, it is weird enough to make them sit up and pay attention, and the musical score, just about the first to use period instruments, would almost certainly be fashionable if put on record today.

Blanche is set in 13th-century France where Simon, who must have been well over 80 at the time, plays an almost senile baron with a simple but beautiful young wife (Branice) who everyone, including the King, lusts after. There is a lecherous page and a handsome but rather vacant lover too, and the film is a kind of fairytale dance of death where tragedy is probable, even if a happy outcome isn't entirely out of the question.

Almost the whole film takes place in the Baron's castle, where the king comes to stay. And its winding stone staircases, gloomy corridors and rooms full of bizarre decor and mechanical devices are as important as any characters in the film. Once again, every tiny detail is made to count double.

Blanche, who climbs naked out of her bath early in the film, has a pet white dove in a cage, which is almost her alter ego as she flutters round her admirers, half frightened and half fascinated. She is a creature made for trouble and it isn't a total surprise when she is bricked into one of the castle walls.

Borowczyk's art, which often looks like a carefully animated painting, and has the pessimistic urge one associates with Franz Kafka, is invariably about sex, love and death - the ape in The Beast eventually dies of pleasure. But his eye is so sharp and his ironic sense of humour so audacious that even the worst of his films, such as Emmanuelle 5, are worth something. The best inhabit a world you are unlikely to forget.

He has been regarded in this country as a pseudo-cultured pornographer ever since The Beast, which ends with a sexual encounter in a forest between something that looks like a well-hung ape and a woman, was shown at the National Film Theatre to a pretentiously horrified audience. fields.headline: Greece: the ambivalent ally
fields.standfirst: Foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall traces Greece's uneasy association with anti-western terrorism
fields.trailText: Foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall traces Greece's uneasy association with anti-western terrorism.
fields.body:
The murder of the British defence attache in Athens today by unidentified gunmen said to belong to the November 17 urban terrorist group will deepen concerns in the United States, shared by some European governments, that Greece - despite its protestations and its membership of the EU and Nato - is simply not doing enough to combat terrorism.

The killing will also serve as a reminder of the strong under-current of anti-Americanism which extends to close US allies like Britain and which persists in Greece more than a quarter of a century after violent uprisings against the US-backed military junta which was then in power. November 17 owes its name to student protests in 1973 which were bloodily suppressed. Since then, the group has been blamed for 22 deaths and hundreds of bomb and arson attacks, many on "western" targets.

The US National Commission on Terrorism, an independent panel set up Congress two years ago, singled Greece out for harsh criticism in a report published earlier this week. "Greece has been disturbingly passive in response to terrorist activity. Since 1975 there have been 146 terrorist attacks against Americans or American interests in Greece. Only one case has been solved and there is no indication of any meaningful investigation into the remaining cases," the panel said.

The commission claimed that Greece allowed representatives of a militant Kurdish group blamed for the deaths of four US citizens to maintain an office in Athens and had given shelter to other Kurds suspected of terrorist activity. This is a complaint energetically echoed by fellow Nato-member Turkey which is fighting a brutal war against Kurdish separatists on its south-east borders.

The panel went on to recommend that Greece be classified as country "not cooperating fully" with international anti-terrorism efforts. It recommended that Greek citizens continue to be required to obtain visas before travelling to the US, even on short trips and holidays - an unusual measure for residents of an EU country or other "friendly" country.

The report followed a similar assessment made by the US State Department earlier this month. "Greece remains one of the weakest links in Europe's efforts against terrorism," the department said. Greece was the only European country identified as a risk in a group of terrorism "suspects' which included Pakistan, Libya, Iraq, Iran, Sudan, Syria, Afghanistan, North Korea and Cuba.

The Greek government angrily rejected the US Terrorism Commission's findings, claiming the assessment was "anti-Greek" and "not based in reality". The Clinton administration said it would study the recommendations but would not impose sanctions on Greece.

US government officials pointed to ongoing talks on security issues between the two countries, and to a draft police cooperation agreement. Ironically, however, the agreement, which was due to be signed during the visit last November to Greece by President Bill Clinton, was set aside when the trip was curtailed. The reason? Ferocious anti-American protests which closed down much of the centre of Athens and caused an enormous security headache for the Clinton entourage.

The claim that Greece is "soft" on terrorism is not new. Nor does it appear to others in Europe and the US to be entirely without foundation. Greece's position as a crossroads of Europe, the Balkans, and the Middle East makes it especially vulnerable to external as well as internal terrorist activity and subversion.

But today's pitiless murder may have to be considered in the broader context of the Greeks' continuing ambivalence about their relationship with the US, Nato, and their more powerful, northern European neighbours.

webTitle: Is the net healthy for doctors?

fields.headline: Is the net healthy for doctors?
fields.standfirst: Websites offering medical advice are appearing all over the net. But, asks  Patrick Barkham, can they benefit patients and practitioners?
fields.trailText: Websites offering medical advice are appearing all over the net. But, asks Patrick Barkham, can they benefit patients and practitioners?
fields.body:
You can hardly take a train or visit your favourite website these days without tender inquiries into your health from intrusive adverts. Embarrassing itch? Sexual impotence? Are you a healthy eater? There is a rash of new British health sites blowing a substantial wad of venture capitalists' cash on their push for the online medical market.

Meanwhile, many of their US counterparts are in critical condition. Can anxious consumers really hope to find good health advice online?

If health portals were a disease they would have been declared an epidemic in the UK by now. Hot on the heels of Health In Focus and the launch of the internet arm of NHS Direct last December came Surgery Door and NetDoctor, offering the latest health news, medical advice, self-testing questionnaires, email services and online chats with doctors. Doctors can switch on the Medical Channel, a new digital television channel for health professionals, which buys its news from Health-Media.Net, another flourishing online health information provider.

These new ventures have been encouraged by the excellent prognosis for the online health industry - worth $10bn by 2004, says Jupiter Communications. Forrester Research's calculations are closer to $37bn, suggesting that a money-spinning 8% of all retail health sales will have moved online by 2004.

Yet the latest news from the US sounds less lucrative. Despite a million registered users and quarterly revenue of more than $5m, Drkoop.com, a health portal founded by a former US surgeon general C Everett Koop, has funds for only another four months.

Healthshop.com recently laid off workers and halted sales, despite having more than 1.1million unique users each month and receiving $25m last autumn.

Unable to subsist on advertising alone, these sites' wait for the predicted boom in medicinal e-commerce may be a long one. The internet appears an ideal medium for dispensing medical advice (and pills): interactive and, crucially, for those embar rassing itches, anonymous. But more than half 1,600 consumers surveyed by Jupiter Communications prefer the convenience of the high street when buying drugs.

More importantly, they are likely to trust their chemist more than the internet, which is renowned for its virulent rumours and scare stories. An investigation by American gastroenterologists concluded that one in 10 sites in the field contained treatment information that was "unproven or outright quackery".

In the UK, an investigation by the Consumers Association this week found online chemists only too willing to dole out drugs without thoroughly checking patients' medical histories. Five UK prescription drug sites supplied a slimming drug to a researcher posing as someone whose medical history made it an inappropriate treatment.

Another site supplied Viagra to a researcher, when a doctor would have looked at his record of nitrate therapy for heart trouble and declared the drug too risky. The Health Which? report also criticised sites for not naming doctors or showing their qualifications.

The US online health industry fell sick by failing to involve medical professionals, says Tim Nater, executive director of Health on the Net Foundation (Hon), a not-for-profit web watchdog based in Geneva. "In the States, e-health has been built up largely in the absence of doctors and nurses," he says. "A lot of companies are rising to the wrong challenge. They are in it for the money and not for the public service."

A Hon study found lack of time to be the biggest obstacle to doctors and nurses getting involved in e-health. With a couple of days a week in his Stroud surgery and media work for BBC1, Radio 2, the Sunday Mirror and Women's Realm, it is surprising Dr Mark Porter has any time to devote to Surgery Door, the UK health portal of which he is medical editor.

Porter's consumer friendly face is the lynchpin of Surgery Door's appeal for the trust of the British consumer. "His career would be dead overnight if we overstepped the line between ethical health and commercialism," says managing director Paul Blackburn.

UK health sites could learn from American mistakes. Dr Koop's professional standing was tarnished when his website got its knuckles rapped for failing to label clearly advertising content. US sites were also hit by a recent privacy scare, after the California HealthCare Foundation discovered that many, including Drkoop, OnHealth and WebMD, were sharing information about their users with third parties. This could be used to compile medical profiles of those who turned to the net precisely because of its supposed anonymity.

Surgery Door "doesn't collect any information about users", says Blackburn. Porter is equally anxious to ensure that commercial imperatives do not cloud its health information. "We go great lengths to show who we are involved with and why we are pukka," says Porter. "Good sites provide information and services for free. Alongside that we'll run links, sponsorship and advertising, but that should not interfere with any of the content, exactly the same as with a newspaper."

Nater hopes "there is no way the American e-health model is going to be picked up and used in Europe". But the NHS's online offering has, so far, disappointed doctors. Medical advice and content is thin and earlier this month it was still promoting an event held on March 20.

Online health provision should not go too far, suggests Porter, dismissing the possibility of online consultations: "I don't know a decent doctor who reckons he or she could do a proper job during an online consultation. To pretend you can and charge money for it is wrong."

Nevertheless, the internet's potential to improve health services is "unlimited", he believes. For example, patients could book their own appointments online or use a Wap phone to find out where their nearest hospital is and who sells aspirin at 1am.

In the meantime, while the public is faced with fairly ordinary online health services which Porter admits "are still finding their feet" in the UK, medical professionals can access information of cast-iron integrity on sites such as US-based Medline and Health-Media.Net. Alongside the question of how online health services can benefit those without internet access, the success of exclusive professional sites suggests the web may not be the hoped-for panacea for reducing the inequalities in public health.

However, health professionals say there has to be some separation between what they and the public can get on the net. Gill Shearer, editor-in-chief of subscriber-based Health-Media Net, says they must offer a private platform for doctors. "We can't have consumers entering [online] discussions they would be confused and misled by. There are patient confidentiality issues as well," she says. Porter agrees, pointing out that professional sites also have to be restricted because many contain adverts which would break the strict UK rules for advertising medicines direct to the public.

But Nater believes global rules are really needed to shape up the internet. Four years ago, Hon "recognised the need for a basic ethical standard"; 3,000 sites now subscribe to its code in 36 different countries. Three similar ethics codes have been published in the US this year and Nater fears this proliferation risks confusing users.

"We should work for a single global code," says Nater, although he hopes for more. Ethical standards are all very well, but "what is much more important is compliance and enforcement".

Until we have this, punters seeking good health online had best beware.

Health warnings: Dos and don'ts

Do look for the Health on the Net Foundation (Hon) guarantee on the website. All reputable UK sites have got it or are applying for it.

Do consult the site's privacy policy - it could be collecting information about you.

Do check the date of publication of health advice. Medical information which is several years old could be out of date. Reliable websites should date their material.

Don't buy drugs from websites based abroad. Foreign sites may prescribe drugs not tested or licensed in the UK.

Don't risk paying for an online consultation.

Remember that online tests, questionnaires and health advice are no substitute for a face to face diagnosis by a proper doctor.

Useful links

www.hon.ch
NHS Direct
www.nhsdirect.nhs.uk
The Surgery Door
www.surgerydoor.co.uk
DrKoop
www.drkoop.com
Netdoctor
www.netdoctor.co.uk
Health Media Net
www.health-media.ne
The British Medical Journal
www.bmj.com

webTitle: 'I allowed Satan and the world to dictate terms to me, rather than the Lord'

fields.headline: 'I allowed Satan and the world to dictate terms to me, rather than the Lord'
fields.trailText: The South African inquiry into match-fixing allegations against former national captain Hansie Cronje on Thursday received a copy of his hand-written midnight confession made in April.
fields.body:
The South African inquiry into match-fixing allegations against former national captain Hansie Cronje on Thursday received a copy of his hand-written midnight confession made in April.

The confession was handed to United Cricket Board (UCB) security chief Rory Steyn in the early hours of April 11 2000, after news had broken in India that Cronje was to be charged on the basis of a recorded telephone discussion about match fixing.

Here is a partial text of the statement:

"I have been a Christian since childhood days when I grew up in the house of two wonderful people, Ewie and San-Marie Cronje. I was reborn after the tragic death of a four-year-old girl on the north coast road to Stanger. I tried to live a Christian life and walk the way the Lord wanted me to walk...

"I would like to apologise to all my family members who stood right behind me through this, especially (his wife) Bertha and all the other Christians who prayed for me.

"It has been a tough weekend but also a great weekend for me in that I now have the opportunity to face myself in the mirror again for the first time since the (1999/2000) Indian tour.

"On my way to the nets (before the first one-day international against Zimbabwe in January) I was stopped by Hamid (Cassim), a bloke who has been hanging around the team for a few years now, always handing out biltong (dried meat) to the guys in return for some tickets. He told me that if only he knew I was going to declare (in the fifth test against England at Centurion Park) he could have made himself some good money and my reply was: 'Why don't you ask?'

"Since that day, in a moment of stupidity and weakness, I allowed Satan and the world to dictate terms to me, rather than the Lord. Hamid called me almost four times a day from then on.

"He later introduced me to a friend called Sanjay during the one-day international series with England and Zimbabwe. Together, they told me that I could also make some cash if we could maybe cook a match. I told them that I was not prepared to do this unless we were assured of a place in the final.

"Of course, we only narrowly got through to the final and the opportunity never came. I had in my possession at that stage 10,000 to 15,000 U.S. dollars that Sanjay gave me just in case I had a change of mind.

"I told him that maybe (in) the first one-day international in India I could see what could be done, thinking that if we could get the match out of the way, we'd get rid of them and could then focus purely on cricket. My idea was never to involve other players.

"I would like to make it absolutely clear to any member of the South African team, whether player or management, about this: I lied to him (Sanjay) by saying certain players were involved when in fact I had never spoken to any of them. I couldn't face asking them to do it. I can't recall all the names that I mentioned and I can't remember the figures that were mentioned.

"I ignored him the night before the (opening India) match but early the next morning, Hamid phoned me again and urged me to go ahead with the plan. I phoned him up and suggested we go for it. All this time, I had in the back of my mind: Pride to play for South Africa and my team mates, whom I all respect. It was a difficult period for me before the match and I then decided I won't not try, I'll give it my best shot and see what happens.

"As it happened, we got 301 for three. I got 19 off 20 balls and India knocked it off quite comfortably after (Mornantau) Hayward got injured. I can honestly say that I tried to win the match, even at that stage.

"When I got back to the hotel, Sanjay was upset because we got too many runs and I blamed the Indian keeper for three chances that he missed. I did not accept any money for that match.

"I feel that I can bring something good out of all this.

"I have been a role model for many people in South Africa and this was a lesson for all of you out there: When Satan comes knocking on the door, always keep your eyes on the Lord Jesus Christ and ask him to protect you from any wrong.

"The moment I took my eyes off Jesus, my whole world turned dark and it felt like someone had stuck a knife through my chest.

"Be thankful for family and friends. No matter what you go through, they will always stand by you. My parents have been through hell during my life and this has been their worst weekend ever. I want them to know that it was only because of their example that I am writing this letter and also want to be proud one day when I am their age.

"Thank you Mom and Dad, Frans( Brother) and Sus (Sister) and all the other family. I apologise for letting you down.

"To Bertha: She deserves better than me. Yet she has been patient and trying her utmost to keep me on the right track. She is a devoted Christian and I lied to her about this whole issue.

"I'll be back. Better off than I am now, once I have been punished."

"On my way to the nets (before the first one-day international against Zimbabwe in January) I was stopped by Hamid (Cassim), a bloke who has been hanging around the team for a few years now, always handing out biltong (dried meat) to the guys in return for some tickets. He told me that if only he knew I was going to declare (in the fifth test against England at Centurion Park) he could have made himself some good money and my reply was: 'Why don't you ask?' "Since that day, in a moment of stupidity and weakness, I allowed Satan and the world to dictate terms to me, rather than the Lord. Hamid called me almost four times a day from then on. "He later introduced me to a friend called Sanjay during the one-day international series with England and Zimbabwe. Together, they told me that I could also make some cash if we could maybe cook a match. I told them that I was not prepared to do this unless we were assured of a place in the final. "Of course, we only narrowly got through to the final and the opportunity never came. I had in my possession at that stage 10,000 to 15,000 U.S. dollars that Sanjay gave me just in case I had a change of mind. "I told him that maybe (in) the first one-day international in India I could see what could be done, thinking that if we could get the match out of the way, we'd get rid of them and could then focus purely on cricket. My idea was never to involve other players. "I would like to make it absolutely clear to any member of the South African team, whether player or management, about this: I lied to him (Sanjay) by saying certain players were involved when in fact I had never spoken to any of them. I couldn't face asking them to do it. I can't recall all the names that I mentioned and I can't remember the figures that were mentioned. "I ignored him the night before the (opening India) match but early the next morning, Hamid phoned me again and urged me to go ahead with the plan. I phoned him up and suggested we go for it. All this time, I had in the back of my mind: Pride to play for South Africa and my team mates, whom I all respect. It was a difficult period for me before the match and I then decided I won't not try, I'll give it my best shot and see what happens. "As it happened, we got 301 for three. I got 19 off 20 balls and India knocked it off quite comfortably after (Mornantau) Hayward got injured. I can honestly say that I tried to win the match, even at that stage. "When I got back to the hotel, Sanjay was upset because we got too many runs and I blamed the Indian keeper for three chances that he missed. I did not accept any money for that match. "I feel that I can bring something good out of all this. "I have been a role model for many people in South Africa and this was a lesson for all of you out there: When Satan comes knocking on the door, always keep your eyes on the Lord Jesus Christ and ask him to protect you from any wrong. "The moment I took my eyes off Jesus, my whole world turned dark and it felt like someone had stuck a knife through my chest. "Be thankful for family and friends. No matter what you go through, they will always stand by you. My parents have been through hell during my life and this has been their worst weekend ever. I want them to know that it was only because of their example that I am writing this letter and also want to be proud one day when I am their age. "Thank you Mom and Dad, Frans( Brother) and Sus (Sister) and all the other family. I apologise for letting you down. "To Bertha: She deserves better than me. Yet she has been patient and trying her utmost to keep me on the right track. She is a devoted Christian and I lied to her about this whole issue. "I'll be back. Better off than I am now, once I have been punished."

webTitle: Time and water run out for China

fields.headline: Time and water run out for China
fields.standfirst: Years of neglect and modern life have led to a devastating drought
fields.trailText: China is struggling to cope with a catastrophic drought that has turned the Yellow river into a trickle, dried up deep wells and turned vast areas of farmland into arid waste.
fields.body:
China is struggling to cope with a catastrophic drought that has turned the Yellow river into a trickle, dried up deep wells and turned vast areas of farmland into arid waste.

After decades in which politics took precedence over the environment, China's prime minister, Zhu Rongji, is trying desperately to reverse the balance. He has been appalled by what he has seen on trips into countryside ruined by overfarming and tree-felling.

"Let trees sprout on mountains again, stop growing grain on hilly land and keep your livestock in its pens," he said recently in a written edict to farmers.

Much of the urban drought is caused by reckless overuse as China's new consumer society demands more water. Two-thirds of China's cities, including Beijing, face severe water shortages.

"Beijingers do not appreciate their precious resource," said the Beijing Youth Daily in a survey of the city's water crisis. The three most wasteful outlets, it concluded, are the "bottled water industry, on-street car-washes and luxury bathing and beauty salons".

The drought area covers most of north and central China in the interior provinces stretching from the Yellow river to the Yangtze.

The northern province of Hebei, which surrounds Beijing, has been worst hit. About 12,000 square miles of farmland will bear no summer crops and planting has been delayed on another 2,000 square miles. In the next province of Henan, rainfall last year was only 14% of the average.

Rainfall in Henan and Anhui provinces last week came too late to save threatened crops and it is no comfort that flood warnings are being issued for the summer in central China. Much of the water is expected to run off uselessly.

Experts have warned that China's plans to develop the less-advanced western provinces could wreak further damage. The western area provides the source waters for the Yellow, Yangtze and other main river systems.

But Mr Zhu, who heads the government task force for western development, is insisting that the ecological balance be maintained.

China is finally having to reckon with the hidden cost of massive hydroelectric schemes which have interfered with the natural flow of its great rivers, allowing more water to be diverted and lost by evaporation.

The Yellow river has been worst hit, with no more than a trickle of water flowing in its bed from Henan to Shangdong province on the coast. Authorities at the Xiaolangdi hydroelectric plant are now opening their sluices to let the water run freely and save the farmers' fields downstream.

No solution has yet been found to the well-known paradox that southern China has a surplus of water and has been hit by increasingly severe floods. But long-discussed plans for a south-north water transfer are being revived.

"By the year 2010," said Wang Xucheng, the water conservancy minister, "city-dwellers in Beijing are likely to be drinking Yangtze river water."

And some cities are at last beginning to charge water users according to consumption. Weihai in Shandong has taken the lead, raising the price in the past year from 7p a cubic metre to £3.

Residents have been forced to reuse the same water to wash themselves and flush out their lavatories. There are complaints that some restaurants are cleaning dirty dishes with just rags.

The most tragic stories come, as always, from the countryside. A reporter from the popular newspaper Southern Weekend - which devoted an entire issue to the drought - found villagers in Henan queueing for a trickle that took half an hour to fill a bucket.

Other peasants told of vain attempts to save the lives of thirsty water buffalo by putting damp blankets on their backs.

As fields dry up, desperate farmers are planting their crops in river waterbeds although they know that these may suddenly flood when the weather breaks.

The drought in north China comes after weeks of sandstorms in the early spring, blamed on the loss of tree cover and excessive reclamation of natural waterlands.

Much of the damage was done in the 1950s and 1960s when peasants were mobilised in campaigns to increase immediate crop yields without considering the long term.

The new economic reforms of the 1980s, which allowed peasants to shift to profitable cash crops, have also led to overuse as boreholes are drilled ever deeper.

Most of the water is wasted - only about 40% is used effectively in dry areas. Some farmers continued to irrigate crops which had no chance of ripening before the water ran dry.

The Yellow river flow is rationed to the provinces through which it passes, according to a fixed formula, but this is widely ignored.

In a message at the weekend, on World Environment Day, Mr Zhu said that this year's sandstorms were an alarm call for the nation. "It is a long and arduous task for us," he warned, "to protect the ecology and improve the environment." He held out the vision of a cleaner China in which "the sky will be more clear and the landscape more beautiful".

But there are fears that with an ever-rising population and increasing economic demands on water and other scarce resources, the picture will become darker first.

webTitle: Big requests, High hopes and Great deals

fields.headline: Big requests, High hopes and Great deals
fields.trailText: VILLA-FIED
fields.body:
VILLA-FIED

For some time now, John Gregory has been known in these pages as football's Mr Angry. His inability to stop shooting his mouth off - "They can keep charging me and fining me, but it's not going to shut me up" - combined with a complete absence of sensitivity - anyone recall an incident involving a shotgun? - endeared him to the Fiver no end. Sadly for John, it doesn't appear to have had the same affect on his players, who are jumping ship faster than you can say "no European place for a second season running".

"I have given everything to Villa over the last few years but if I am to achieve what I want to achieve in my career it is time to move on." That's what Gareth Southgate had to say this morning after he faxed his transfer request to the club. "It is not a decision that has been easy but my mind is made up," said the skipper who is as synonymous with Villa as Ian Wright is with chicken. Southgate is valued (who by? Christie's?) at £8m and everyone from Man Utd to Paris St Germain are said to be interested. Not the best news for Aston Villa Football Club.

Neither is the (admittedly slightly less significant) news that Julian Joachim is also on his bike. "I just feel that I cannot play for John Gregory anymore and don't want to," said Joachim, who claims Gregory reneged on an agreement to improve his contract after the 1998-99 season. "I am disappointed at the manager and the club." Add this to Ugo Ehiogu's transfer request (caused by a "personality clash" with the manager), and the likely prospect of neither Paul Merson nor Benito Carbone playing at Villa Park this season and you get the general idea. Well done John.

SUBSCRIBE TO THE EURO

It arrives very early in the morning, so no wonder it's a bit tired. It's the Euro. The latest one can be found at http://www.footballunlimited.co.uk/theeuro/1,6986,,00.html - read it and subscribe.

KING KOOGAN'S RALLYING CRY

The England squad were given a rousing send-off as they flew out from Heathrow this afternoon. Well, a Sky TV crew and a couple of American tourists turned up (everyone else had gone to Luton by mistake). Although Kelvin Koogan tried to keep the spirits up in the style of Henry V - "We're going out there to try to do the business for all these wonderful fans who've come to give us a send-off" - the rest of the squad didn't seem too happy. Especially Michael Owen.

"Hopefully when we come back there will be more people cheering a winning side," was the refreshingly honest verdict of England's boy wonder, before he succumbed to Koogan-itis (ie: his utterances took a turn towards the vacuous). "It's been a long build-up," Owen continued. "We've had our plusses and minuses and we just want to get cracking now. A lot can happen but I'm hopeful of playing."

But who he'll be playing alongside is a moot point, because Alan Shearer is still not at full fitness. "I had a scan this morning just as a precaution to see if there's anything in there," revealed Shearer, talking, we presume, about his injured left-knee rather than Phil Neville's left boot. "We'll wait for the results and take it from there. I don't think it will be a problem." And Koogan agreed. Asked when the deadline would be for Shearer to prove his fitness, Koog said: "When's the kick-off? The deadline is the kick-off. I think he will be fine. He's confident and we're confident." If only the Fiver could say the same thing.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We'll be signing Elvis Presley next" - Busy Peter Ridsdale responds to this morning's reports that Leeds were set to sign Celtic striker Mark Viduka.

THE SECRET LIFE OF BUILDINGS

Hello there. I'm Filbert Street, the home of Leicester City. I'm glad I've got your ear. People don't talk to buildings very much, you know, which is a real shame, because we've got plenty of things to tell you. Take this morning, for example. There I was, standing dead still and minding my own business, when all of a sudden my doors were prised open and several Leicester board members and some representatives from cable company NTL inserted themselves into me.

As I housed them within my walls, they struck a deal. NTL will give the club an £11.5m interest-free loan, which they will be able to convert into a 9.99% stake in the club next year. The cable guys, who already have similar stakes in Aston Villa and Newcastle, will also pay the Foxes £1m for media and sponsorship rights. Once the deal was finalised, out they all popped, quicker than Leicester suit Steve Kind could say the cash would be spent on "strengthening of the professional playing squad, development of youth academy and training facilities, and the enhancement of stadium capacity".

Now, that may not seem too important to Leicester fans on a day which saw Celtic target Matt Elliott sign a 12-month extension to his contract which will keep him with the club until 2004. And it may seem trivial compared to Muzzy Izzet's denial of reports that he will leave on a Bosman free at the end of next season - "I want to stay with Leicester. Once Euro 2000 is out of the way I plan to resume negotiations with the club," he insisted today. But look at it from my point of view: stadium enhancement is stadium enhancement, and I love a lick of paint, me.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Lee Clark could be set to join the third North-eastern club of his career by joining Middlesbrough for £2.5m. Fulham midfielder Clark is believed to be unhappy in London and would jump at the chance of a move to the Riverside.

Bobby Robson has been linked with a £7m move to bring Carl Cort to St James Park. The 22-year-old striker, who scored 15 goals last term, submitted a transfer request to Wimbledon last week.

Legendary French defender Lilian Thuram is believed to have had preliminary talks with Arsene Wenger over a summer move to Highbury.

NEWS IN BRIEF

The Swedish squad have denied there is a sex ban in their training camp. "It's just a rumour. I don't know where it comes from. When we are in the camp here we don't have any wives so obviously there's no sex either," claimed Fredrik Ljungberg. And striker Henrik Larsson was flummoxed when asked what the players' reaction had been to the reported ban. "A ban on sex? What do you mean?" he said. "It's hard when your wife's not here," he added, unnecessarily.

Rangers have signed Danish youngster Peter Lovenkrands after the striker was advised to commit himself to the Glasgow giants by former Ibrox star Brian Laudrup.

Ian Wright's career may not be over after all, according to close friend Mark Bright. "It's not true, I spoke to him yesterday," said Bright. "He's got to have an operation on Monday on his ankle and once that is done and he sees how his recovery is then he will make a final decision."

Marc Overmars has resumed training with the Dutch squad, easing fears about his thigh injury. "I think I should be completely ready in two or three days," Overmars said. "I want to make history with this team and win the European Championships."

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.30am)

Two very big things.

Channel 4: Schoolboy Football (3.15am)

A chance to stare at some little boys.

Channel 5: Gazza v Gaddafi (8pm)

This isn't footage of Middlesbrough playing in Tripoli. It really is a showdown between Paul Gascoigne and the Libyan leader - they wrestle naked in a mud bath.

US Major League Soccer (4.30am)

Dallas Passionless Match v Los Angeles Empty Stadium.

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (6.30pm, 10.45pm)

Sepp Blatter and Lennart Johansson reprise the roles of Noel Edmonds and Posh Paws in Swap Shop, a remake of Swap Shop.

Six-a-side Football - Live (7.30pm, 12.30am)

Old men stumbling about.

Sky Sports 3: World Cup Classics (10pm)

West Germany winning the 1974 World Cup. Great!

British Eurosport: European Championship Legends (8pm)

Germany winning the 1996 European Championships. Really great!

Road To Euro 2000 (9pm)

Austria losing 9-0 to Spain. If only we could see Germany winning 9-0, eh?

Gillette Dream Team (12midnight)

Well, ours would be full of German players, of course.

webTitle: Britain 'ready to go the distance' in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Britain 'ready to go the distance' in Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Britain will pull its troops out of Sierra Leone next week but is "ready to go the distance" to achieve lasting stability in the war-torn country, foreign secretary Robin Cook promised today.
fields.body:
Britain will pull its troops out of Sierra Leone next week but is "ready to go the distance" to achieve lasting stability in the war-torn country, foreign secretary Robin Cook promised today.

"I have assured President (Ahmad Tejan) Kabbah that Britain wants to be a longterm partner in securing a stable, successful, enterprising Sierra Leone," Mr Cook declared after talks with the president in the capital, Freetown.

Mr Cook said British troops would depart next week, as previously agreed, because they had ensured that British nationals left the country in safety and that UN forces were able to get in.

Hundreds of marines are currently stationed around Freetown and at Lungi international airport. 108 will remain to help train government forces, along with two ships a little way off the Sierra Leonean coast. Around 13,000 UN peacekeeping troops are expected to arrive in the country by the end of June. Mr Kabbah had asked British troops to stay in Sierra Leone last week, but said he now accepted their decision to leave. "It is something I totally agree with, (it is) totally logical," said Kabbah. "The British people have done a lot for us. We appreciate it... I am fully on board."

Mr Kabbah's army recaptured the military town of Lunsar yesterday. Situated on the road to a rebel base and the diamond fields in the east, Lunsar is an important strategic gain.

Meanwhile, in an attempt to stem the illegal flow of diamonds which has been funding the Revolutionary United Front rebel forces, Britain is instigating an international embargo on Sierra Leonean diamonds which lack an official government certificate.

fields.bodyText: Britain will pull its troops out of Sierra Leone next week but is "ready to go the distance" to achieve lasting stability in the war-torn country, foreign secretary Robin Cook promised today. "I have assured President (Ahmad Tejan) Kabbah that Britain wants to be a longterm partner in securing a stable, successful, enterprising Sierra Leone," Mr Cook declared after talks with the president in the capital, Freetown. Mr Cook said British troops would depart next week, as previously agreed, because they had ensured that British nationals left the country in safety and that UN forces were able to get in. Hundreds of marines are currently stationed around Freetown and at Lungi international airport. 108 will remain to help train government forces, along with two ships a little way off the Sierra Leonean coast. Around 13,000 UN peacekeeping troops are expected to arrive in the country by the end of June. Mr Kabbah had asked British troops to stay in Sierra Leone last week, but said he now accepted their decision to leave. "It is something I totally agree with, (it is) totally logical," said Kabbah. fields.headline: Stay away, Keegan tells troublemakers
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan yesterday appealed to England's hooligans to stay away from Euro 2000 and not undermine his side's chances of success in the tournament.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan yesterday appealed to England's hooligans to stay away from Euro 2000 and not undermine his side's chances of success in the tournament.

Speaking on the eve of their departure to Belgium, the England manager said it was time for football to make a stand against troublemakers.

"It's not helpful for me or the team," he said. "We don't want anything to distract us. I think in the back of the players' minds, things like this don't sit comfortably with them.

"I would like the focus to be on the football.

"What I desperately don't want is the wrong sort of people going for the wrong sort of reasons to do the wrong sort of things.

"It has got to the point now where everyone is saying: 'Hey, this is our game; this is the biggest game in the world and we're not going to let the hooligans walk all over it.'

"I would like to see any fans going over for the wrong reasons turned back. They're not helpful to us. We want the support behind the team but we don't want the stupidity. Law-abiding England fans feel exactly the same and we're at one with them. We want to create the carnival spirit of Euro 96."

Keegan revealed that he had held a 20-minute telephone conversation with the home secretary, Jack Straw, on Tuesday to discuss the security situation.

"It was important that Mr Straw and I had a chat about the situation. I wanted to know his feeling and he wanted to know mine. I found it very interesting and enlightening. From talking to him, they are going to do everything within their powers to make sure that it goes off in the right way."

fields.headline: Early result for anti-hooligan strategy
fields.standfirst: Two English fans turned back at Dutch border as advance planning pays off
fields.trailText: Two suspected English football hooligans attempting to travel to Euro 2000 were turned back at the Dutch border yesterday as an international police operation intended to stamp out violence at the tournament swung into action.
fields.body:
Two suspected English football hooligans attempting to travel to Euro 2000 were turned back at the Dutch border yesterday as an international police operation intended to stamp out violence at the tournament swung into action.

The two men, suspected of travelling with the intent of causing trouble, are believed to be the subject of domestic banning orders preventing them from attending football matches in England.

One of the men was turned back after landing at Schipol airport in Amsterdam and the other was intercepted at the Hook of Holland ferry port.

The action by Dutch border authorities was welcomed by Jack Straw, the home secretary, as the first success of a joint intelligence effort by British, Dutch, Belgian and French police designed to avoid outbreaks of violent disorder at the three-week tournament.

The two men are among more than 1,000 known or suspected hooligans whose names have been passed to Dutch, Belgian and French authorities by the National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS).

The 1998 World Cup in France was marred by riots involving English fans in Marseille and Lens, and recent violence involving supporters of Arsenal and Leeds and the Turkish club Galatasaray has heightened tension.

Anticipating familiar scenes, particularly at England's match with Germany in Charleroi a week on Saturday, the Home Office and the NCIS have been keen to demonstrate this week that they have done everything within their power to prevent hooligans reaching Euro 2000.

Yesterday, however, Mr Straw was criticised by the chief executive of the European football association (Uefa), Gerhard Aigner, for failing to pass legislation allowing the courts to remove the passports of known hooligans.

Confirming that the England-Germany match will go ahead in Charleroi despite misgivings about safety inside the 30,000-capacity stadium and crowd control around it, Mr Aigner said: "It is regrettable that the government in the United Kingdom has not introduced legislation which would make it possible to stop registered hooligans from travelling."

This week Mr Straw blamed "maverick Tories and a pusillanimous Conservative front bench" for blocking the legislation when it was introduced last year. It was not reintroduced prior to Euro 2000 because the legislative time was not available, he said.

Mr Aigner defended the decision to stage the England-Germany game in Charleroi, claiming its suitability as a venue was not questioned until it was too late. "Over the last three years, both Uefa and the organisers, together with the authorities in both host countries, have carefully prepared the event," he said. "At no time did the authorities make any reservations with regard to the use of the stadiums, including the one in Charleroi, for the matches to be played there."

Reacting to Mr Aigner's criticism, Mr Straw said the NCIS had launched the most extensive and sophisticated operation ever for a big overseas tournament.

Officers from 19 regional police forces have been seconded to the football unit and will work closely with spotters on the ground in Belgium and Holland to monitor the movement of English hooligans.

The unit has identified 99 people against whom there are international banning orders, 416 subject to domestic banning orders and hundreds with no football-related convictions but suspected of being involved in related violence.

All those subject to domestic orders have been sent a letter from the NCIS informing them that if they travel to the low countries there is every chance they will be turned back. Those subject to international orders will have to surrender their passports or report on a daily basis at a police station from today.

Bryan Drew, head of the NCIS, emphasised that Dutch and Belgian police were determined to arrest, charge and convict those involved in violence. He said that on returning to England those hooligans convicted would be arrested again and banned from football grounds for at least 10 years.

International banning orders can only be imposed on hooligans if they have been convicted in a foreign court. There was dismay within the NCIS and the Home Office last month when hooligans in violent clashes between Arsenal and Galatasary supporters before the Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen were deported without charge by Danish authorities.

The Belgian justice ministry yesterday announced that 150 prisoners are to be released for the duration of the tournament to make room for hooligans in the country's overcrowded prisons. Though the scheme is voluntary, sex offenders, lifers and convicts in the process of being charged for other offences were not allowed to apply.

Further space is to be created by delaying the sentencing of non-dangerous criminals until after the tournament. Belgium's prisons can hold a maximum of 8,500 people and are already full. Police garages in Charleroi have already been converted into makeshift cells.

"Anyone who is arrested under the fast-track procedure can be detained for five days before appearing in front of a judge. Granting prison leave will allow us to keep suspects locked up effectively," a spokeswoman said.

The Dutch authorities are also willing to release inmates coming to the end of their sentences for the same reasons.

fields.headline: No 3: John Arne Riise
fields.trailText: Appearance: The Norwegian Paul Scholes.
fields.body:
Appearance: The Norwegian Paul Scholes.

And the reality? He could turn out even better. The 20 year-old Riise was a key member of Monaco's French championship winning team, and earlier this year he made his full debut for the Norway side.

A precocious little fellow isn't he He certainly is. When Riise signed for Monaco for £700,000 as a 17 year-old from Norwegian second division Aalesund it caused uproar in the domestic media, but Riise soon proved his worth at the French club. In fact he's been so good he now has the nickname of 'The Norwegian Carlos'.

Ahh! You mean the electro-shock haired Columbian, Carlos Valderama don't you? More like Brazilian banana-bender Roberto Carlos, because Riise plays both as left back and left midfield and possesses a powerful (and accurate) free kick.

So what does the young gunslinger think of Norway's Euro 2000 chances? "Our team is still very young and we don't have much experience," he admits. "We'll give it our best shot but it is perhaps still a little early for us. The 2002 World Cup should remain our main objective. Then we will be ready and dangerous."

He's very honestYou should hear what he says about Norway's strengths. "Everything is based on physical power" he acknowledges. "We do have a few players who are good on the ball, but that is not really part of our culture. We prefer long balls to a big striker who creates pressure with knock downs."

Any chance of him coming to England? It's unlikely. Leeds were reported interested but balked at the £7m fee.

But they've just signed Oliver Dacourt for that? The words 'football' and 'funny old game' come to mind.

And isn't he a big mate of Leeds' Eirik Bakke? He is, but for some unfathomable reason the French Riviera holds more appeal than the Yorkshire Dales. "I have always wanted to play in England but I don't want to leave France for at least another three years," he says. "I am having a great time here. Besides, my fiancee is moving down in the summer, so my life is pretty much here at the moment."

Not to be confused with: Thomas Arne (composer of 'Rule Britannia),' Jan Arge Fjortoft, Neil Lennon.

fields.headline: EU to end VAT-free downloads
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Consumers who download software and music over the internet could be hit with higher prices after the European commission yesterday closed a tax loophole for American firms.
fields.body:
Consumers who download software and music over the internet could be hit with higher prices after the European commission yesterday closed a tax loophole for American firms.

Online businesses based outside the European Union have up to now got away without levying VAT because current legislation takes no account of the internet.

EU firms face VAT rates of 15% to 25% depending on where they are based. Frits Bolkestein, the Dutchman in charge of the single market, has acted to close the omission. His proposals, vigorously opposed by large US music firms, must be approved by all member states before they can take effect. This is not expected to happen until later this year.

Once the new rules become law, US and other non-EU firms selling services over the internet to private customers will, for the first time, have to register in the EU for tax.

US companies will still be better off than their European counterparts, however, since they can choose which EU country they want to be registered in.

Luxembourg, where at 15% VAT is the lowest in Europe, is expected to benefit most from the move. The new rules do not cover tangible goods such as CDs, for which non-EU firms are already obliged to levy VAT. The proposals do, however, cover subscription-based and pay-per-view radio and television broadcasts and all electronic services.

fields.headline: Out with the old . . .
fields.standfirst:
Stop! Don't throw away that sofa you're tired of - get some money for it. Claire Phipps on the advantages of trading in and part-exchanging

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Stop! Don't throw away that sofa you're tired of - get some money for it. Claire Phipps on the advantages of trading in and part-exchanging
fields.body:
Major "investment" purchases such as sofas and dining tables can be built to last for an awful lot longer than your passion for them. You might expect to be able to trade in your camera for a snappier new model, but if that problem item is a sofa, most of us would be inclined to sit and bear it for a few years at least.

Not so Mary Ley. Ley has owned five sofas in the past three years, but then she is the owner of Change of Heart, based in north London, the UK's only furniture and furnishings agency. Here, customers receive 60% of the eventual selling price when their old sofa is bought, the shop taking a smaller commission than on clothes, in recognition of the larger initial expense of buying furniture.

Jacki Dunlop, a regular customer, first became a Change of Heart devotee when she decided to get rid of a hated piece of furniture: "The first thing I sold was a footstool. Everyone has something they don't like, but you don't do anything about it. I took it in, thinking that nobody would be interested, it sold immediately - and I got some money for it."

From then on, she was hooked. "It's an inexpensive way of changing the way your house looks," she explains.

But before you head off with the rejects from this year's spring clean, it is worth taking the time to get clued up on the kind of items you're selling. "People are often not aware of the gems they have in their record collections," says Gavin Bailey, at the Notting Hill-based Music and Video Exchange. "We don't refuse anything legal, so people can bring in a box of records, knowing that they can get rid of it all. We employ people with knowledge of a massive spectrum of music, so that they can spot those gems if they do come in."

Kevin Allcoat, owner of Tarka Books in Barnstaple, agrees. "A lot of people walk in through the doors with an armful of books. Some do have an idea about the trade, and some don't. Some just want to get rid of the books, and some want a good price. But you have to be realistic in what you expect."

The Tarka Books website has a guide to the standard descriptions used in the second-hand book trade to give both buyers and sellers an idea of what to expect - a useful piece of ammunition for the novice dealer.

"If you don't know the value of what you've got, you could end up selling it at a car-boot sale for much less than it's worth," warns Martyn Pearce, the manager of the London Camera Exchange in Guildford. "Unless you really know your stuff, it's likely that you're going to need an expert opinion before you part with your potential valuables."

That doesn't mean you shouldn't do your homework first. "There is no duty on the buyer to tell you if something is valuable," advises Martin Fisher, of the the Institute of Trading Standards. "You have to do your own research, or go to somebody you trust. It is exceedingly difficult to get reliable facts - there's no ready reference to check values. It is worthwhile pretending to have a bit of knowledge and going to a number of dealers. But ultimately it's the rules of the market: you either take their offer or you don't."

The internet is a good place to start your research. "It's more and more a source of information, with sellers' lists and practical advice," says Fisher. Magazines can also give an idea of how much second-hand goods are selling for. For more impressive collections, a valuation by an auctioneer could prove useful, but beware: this can take time, costs money and you could end up out of pocket if the books turn out to be worthless.

Most straightforward is the part-exchange, as practised at the London Camera Exchange, where the trade-in value of your unwanted goods is instantly wiped off the cost of your new purchase. Other stores will offer a flat fee - especially bookshops - or, as at the Music and Video Exchange, a fixed percentage of the estimated resale price.

Less instant returns - but an opportunity to take your slice of the final selling price - come from places such as Change of Heart and the Curtain Exchange, where the shop takes a commission of up to 50% on sales. The rest comes back to you, the seller.

A sale price will be decided between the store owner and the seller, but if your goods refuse to budge from the shelves, there is always the possibility that the price - and your return - may drop. What you do avoid, though, is seeing the goods you sold for a few pounds on sale a week later for five times that price.

Sally Parkes, who lives in the mid-Welsh borders, has bought and sold curtains for several years through Curtain Exchange, which has 16 stores from Glasgow to Bath - in fact, she claims not to have bought any furniture new since the late 1950s (that was a Liberty dining table).

"When I moved to this house, there were no curtains, so I just got hold of anything that was agreeable at the time," says Parkes. "And then when something better comes along, or eventually you change, you take them back. There's really nowhere else to take them; maybe the local auction house, but that gives you little money."

Liz Meston, co-founder of Curtain Exchange, agrees: "If you have curtains which have cost money, they are usually still of value. To just throw them away when you can turn them into money is not sensible."

Curtain Exchange, tel: 020-7731 8316 for branches; London Camera Exchange, tel: 01483 504040 (or go to www.lcegroup.co.uk); Music and Video Exchange, tel: 020-7727 2040 or go to www.mveshops.co.uk Tarke Books, http://members.aol.com/tarkabooks/
