webTitle: 'What once was unthinkable is now a court order'

fields.headline: 'What once was unthinkable is now a court order'
fields.trailText: The hammer has dropped on Microsoft what once was unthinkable is now a court order.
fields.body:
Broken Windows
The hammer has dropped on Microsoft what once was unthinkable is now a court order.

Critics, including this page, will continue to question this approach. Jackson's order seems excessive and flawed in many specifics.

In Redmond, the mood must be a blend of shock and anger, and a feeling that all this is undeserved. Microsoft has brought tremendous benefits to the computing industry and to the public. Locally, it has enriched the economy and attracted a host of people whose energy, ideas and philanthropy have set new standards.

Microsoft has evolved into an icon of Seattle's success, a stop for the tour busesMicrosoft may yet win on appeal, but this is a huge moment.
The Seattle Times

Stern Justice for Microsoft
Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's order to split Microsoft into two independent companiesis the proper remedy for repeated violations of the antitrust laws.

A less drastic remedy would prove ineffectual or horribly intrusive.

The uncertainty over Microsoft's future is sure to complicate business judgments in the fast-changing world of high-tech industry, the company's monopolistic practices have been egregious, and the nation deserves a speedy resolution of this struggle by the highest court in the land. There is no need to drag it out with an intervening appellate review.

Though the content of Judge Jackson's ruling was unsurprising, the tone was startlingly stern. Microsoft, he says, has been "not credible," "untrustworthy," "disingenuous."

Judge Jackson sided completely with the government in part because he mistrusts the company. Yesterday Microsoft reaped the well-deserved consequences.
The New York Times

Microsoft, R.I.P.
Last Will and Testament Of Microsoft Corporation

I, Microsoft Corp., being of relatively sound mind and very sound financial body hereby declare that this is my last will and testament. Whereas I have acquired virtually all of my target market and whereas the Department of Justice has deemed that a bad thing, I sense that the end is near.

I revoke all previous wills and codicils although I am sure you won't find any since I always thought I'd live forever.

Although I never wanted children, it appears that I may have two issues. I therefore appoint Bill Gates and Paul Allen as guardians of my two baby Microsofts.

I bequeath my operating system and all versions of Windows to Baby Bill. I bequeath all other product lines to Baby Paul including, but not limited to, Explorer, Word and Excel.

As my final wish, I direct that my incorporating documents be buried with my remains near my home in Redmond, Wash. I would like a simple grave marker with the following inscription:

Microsoft Corporation (1981-2000)
"You have performed an illegal operation.
Abort, restart or retry?
At least I gave users an option."
The Washington Post

Split Would Be Boon for Industry

Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's ruling that Microsoft Corp. must be split up is not only good for the future of technology and the U.S. economy. It could be the best medicine for Microsoft too.

Why? Because splitting Microsoft could energize parts of today's company and let talented people range widely to develop applications for office and home software rather than constantly trying to control the marketplace through Microsoft's Windows operating system.

Just as we all should learn from history how antitrust actions in the past have benefited U.S. industry and the companies affected, so Gates should take lessons for himself and his company.
The Los Angeles Times

fields.headline: Scrap double jeopardy say MPs
fields.standfirst:
The full report
The home affairs select committee
Stephen Lawrence special report
fields.trailText: The double jeopardy rule, which prevents people from being tried twice for the same offence, should be scrapped in cases concerning the most serious crimes, MPs said today.
fields.body:
The double jeopardy rule, which prevents people from being tried twice for the same offence, should be scrapped in cases concerning the most serious crimes, MPs said today.

Although the reforms proposed by the influential home affairs select committee would in theory allow for a retrial of the suspects in the Stephen Lawrence murder, in practice this would be unlikely as the government and the law commission are believed to be opposed to retrospective application of new legislation.

The committee recommended that the principle should be altered to allow retrials if new evidence in serious crimes is uncovered. The proposal will be welcomed by the Conservative party, which last month promised to abolish double jeopardy when it returns to government.

Last year the law commission indicated that it favoured amending the rule in exceptional cases. The home secretary, Jack Straw, is expected to endorse this suggestion when the commission's full recommendations are published early next year.

Today's report by the Labour-dominated committee advises that the new rules should apply to past cases, which could allow for a second prosecution of the Lawrence suspects. There are currently 35 cases where the police investigation has been closed because the offenders have been acquitted, the National Crime Faculty told MPs.

Three suspects in the Stephen Lawrence case, Neil Acourt, Luke Knight and Gary Dobson, were cleared of the black teenager's murder after the collapse of the family's private prosecution and cannot be retried under existing legislation.

The double jeopardy rule also prevents M25 road rage killer Kenneth Noye being retried for killing Detective John Fordham in 1985. A jury accepted the stabbing was in self-defence after Noye found the policeman in his garden.

The committee, chaired by Labour MP Robin Corbett, said that changes were needed in the interests of justice for victims and their families, because the current legislation meant that wrongful convictions could be quashed but not wrongful acquittals.

Scientific advances, particularly in DNA testing, mean strong evidence can be uncovered long after an initial acquittal, leaving victims feeling cheated.

The committee recommended the removal of double jeopardy in cases such as manslaughter, rape, grievous bodily harm, robbery, aggravated burglary, arson and supplying class A drugs as well as murder.

Limiting the principle, part of English law since the 12th century, is widely opposed by legal and civil rights groups.

The committee said its proposals should be debated by MPs, with the law commission's findings, as soon as possible after those conclusions have been produced.

webTitle: Microsoft tries to delay breakup order

fields.headline: Microsoft tries to delay breakup order
fields.standfirst: Full ruling
fields.trailText: Microsoft will seek court action to delay the judge's order to break up the company, chief executive Steve Ballmer said in Rotterdam today.
fields.body:
Microsoft will seek court action to delay the judge's order to break up the company, chief executive Steve Ballmer said in Rotterdam today.

Keeping up Microsoft's defiant front, Mr Ballmer called yesterday's ruling by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson an "unjustified and unwarranted intrusion into the market" that would harm consumers. He said breaking up Microsoft in two would mean higher prices, less choice and less user-friendly products.

Analysts said Microsoft has decided to fight on despite a series of legal defeats in the hope that George W Bush will win the presidential election in November. The Republican presidential candidate is considered to be more friendly towards Microsoft than vice-president Al Gore, his Democratic rival.

In his landmark decision yesterday, judge Jackson gave the company four months to come up with a detailed blueprint for a breakup into two separate companies. One would own the Windows operating system and the other would handle applications such as its Word programme and internet browsers.

Judge Jackson told the Washington Post today he would still prefer to see a settlement, but he had little choice other than to accept the proposal of the US justice department and the 17 states in the antitrust case because he wanted to avoid a "conduct-restraining order that required an onerous regulatory scheme".

"I'd much prefer to have market forces accomplish as much of the remedy as could be done," he said. "I've always thought the best remedy was the one the parties could have negotiated between themselves." The judge said that rather than see a breakup imposed, the lawsuit could be settled out of court - even now. He urged both sides to "swallow their own reluctance to compromise and reach a remedy that both sides, if not elated by, nevertheless are willing to extend."

Judge Jackson's ruling was a devastating judgment on Microsoft's behaviour, which he called "untrustworthy". He said: "A structural remedy has become imperative: Microsoft as it is organised and led is unwilling to accept the notion that it broke the law or accede to an order amending its conduct."

Microsoft could drag out the appeal process for years as the case winds its way to the supreme court, allowing time for the possible election of Republican George W Bush as US president, who, Microsoft hopes, will put pressure on the justice department to drop its case. Mindful of Microsoft's delaying tactics, the department of justice is expected to ask for the case to go straight to the supreme court.

Bill Gates, Microsoft's founder, yesterday suggested that the judge had failed to understand the dynamics of the industry.

webTitle: British defence attache shot dead in Athens

fields.headline: British defence attache shot dead in Athens
fields.standfirst: November 17 guerrillas blamed
fields.trailText: A senior British diplomat was shot and fatally wounded by two men on motorbikes as he was driving to work in Athens, Greece, this morning.
fields.body:
A senior British diplomat was shot and fatally wounded by two men on motorbikes as he was driving to work in Athens, Greece, this morning.

The victim, defence attache Brigadier Stephen Saunders, was rushed to a local hospital with head and chest wounds, but died about three-and-a-half hours after the shooting.

There was no claim of responsibility for the attack but police said it bore the hallmarks of the November 17 urban guerrilla group, which has killed 23 Greeks and foreigners since 1975. Police said the spent shells of an automatic pistol found at the scene indicated it was the same weapon as that used by the extreme leftwing group in previous attacks.

Police launched a manhunt, setting up roadblocks all over the capital and sending out scores of plainclothes officers to search for the two attackers, who had stopped their motorbike in the middle of a busy avenue and fired several times at the driver through the passenger-side window of his white Rover car. The car had normal Greek licence plates and no diplomatic insignia, a safety precaution taken by most western embassies in Athens, police said.

Britain condemned the attack, while the US joined in calling for Greece to tighten security arrangements and be tougher on terrorists.

Prime minister Tony Blair said: "It was an act of terrorism, it was contemptible as it was senseless." Foreign secretary Robin Cook, in Sierra Leone on an official visit, said he was "appalled and deeply saddened" by the diplomat's death.

US defence department spokesman Ken Bacon said: "This highlights again that Greece needs to take a tougher stance against terrorism, and we have made that point repeatedly with the government of Greece." According to a Nato diplomat, Athens is considered a "danger post" for US and other Nato representatives.

In its last attack, November 17 fired a rocket at the German ambassador's residence in Athens last year but hurt no one. The group, named after a bloody student uprising in 1973 against the junta then ruling Greece, emerged with the murder of the CIA station chief in Athens in 1975 and has since killed Greeks, Americans and Turks.

Brigadier Saunders leaves a widow and two teenage daughters.

fields.headline: The breakup of Microsoft
fields.standfirst: Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has ordered the breakup of Microsoft in the latest setback for the software giant. Mark Tran and Leon Forde explain the latest development in this landmark antitrust case.
fields.trailText: Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has ordered the breakup of Microsoft in the latest setback for the software giant. We explain the latest development in this landmark antitrust case.
fields.body:
What was the ruling?
In April Judge Jackson found Microsoft guilty of breaking America's anti-monopoly laws, enshrined in the 1890 Sherman Act, which prohibits powerful companies from using their dominance to damage the competition and limit customer choice. Yesterday, he agreed with the government that Microsoft should be broken in two. One company will own the Windows operating system, the other will own applications such as Word and Office.

Why did Judge Jackson think Microsoft should be split up?
He said Microsoft was unwilling to to accept the notion that it had broken the law and had refused to comply with a court order to change its behaviour. Microsoft is defiant, accusing the judge and the government of making an "unwarranted and unjustifiable intrusion in the software marketplace". Bill Gates, Microsoft's founder, suggested that the judge had failed to understand the dynamics of the industry. Microsoft refuses to concede that it is a monopoly despite its overwhelming dominance of operating systems - the brains of the computer.

What will Microsoft do now?
Microsoft chief executive Steve Ballmer said Microsoft would appeal not only against the breakup decision but also against the restraints on its behaviour that the judge imposed while the substantive issue is being resolved. The case is expected to go all the way to the supreme court. Microsoft will try to drag this out as long as possible in the hope that the next administration - possibly led by Republican George W Bush - will put pressure on the US justice department to drop the case.

What does the decision mean for consumers?
In the short run, there should be little change. Microsoft controls 90% of the market for operating systems and it will take years for other companies to break this stranglehold, even if the company is split up. In the long run, Microsoft's breakup should stimulate innovation so there will be more choice.

How did Microsoft abuse its power?
Judge Jackson said the company had used its monopoly of operating systems to stifle competition in the internet browser market. He agreed with the US government and the 17 states that brought this case that Microsoft illegally bundled its Internet Explorer browser with Windows, in an attempt to crush its main internet browser rival at the time, Netscape. Judge Jackson said: "Microsoft placed an oppressive thumb on the scale of competitive fortune, thereby effectively guaranteeing its continued dominance in the relevant market."

Will the decision really harm Microsoft?
On past experience, a breakup should benefit the smaller parts of Microsoft. In the last big breakup, when the AT&T phone giant was broken up in the 1980s, a slimmer AT&T subsequently emerged as a stronger company. That decision also galvanised the whole US telecommunications industry, leading to cheaper rates for consumers. In the short term though, Microsoft can expect to take another hit on its share price.

fields.headline: The twilight of the Wagners
fields.standfirst: The descendants of Germany's most controversial composer are battling for control of his Bayreuth festival. The result may change it for ever, says  Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: The descendants of Germany's most controversial composer are battling for control of his Bayreuth festival. The result may change it for ever, says Martin Kettle
fields.body:
In the beginning, as with all sagas, it was simple, like the E flat that begins the Ring of the Nibelung. There was a genius, Richard Wagner, who built a theatre at Bayreuth to perform his music dramas in conditions of his own choosing. Then the genius died, so his wife Cosima took over the theatre, before handing it over to their son Siegfried, who died in turn, passing the theatre on to his own wife, Winifred.

Then things got very nasty, as happens in all sagas. Winifred Wagner, though born in Hastings, was a German nationalist, a Nazi, an anti-Semite and, to the day of her death in 1980, an admirer of Adolf Hitler. Hitler in turn loved Wagner's operas, and perhaps Winifred too. Bayreuth became a Nazi shrine and the Wagner legacy became forever intertwined with that of the Third Reich.

The other complication is that families expand as time goes on, and the Wagner family is no exception. Siegfried and Winifred Wagner had four children, two of whom, Wieland and Wolfgang, reopened the denazified Bayreuth festival in 1951. Wieland, the eldest and most talented of his generation of Wagners, died prematurely and greatly mourned in 1966. Wolfgang, now 80, remains in charge at Bayreuth to this day.

Wolfgang's immediate problem, much reported over the past week, is that there are 12 Wagners in the next generation. Even if they all saw eye to eye about the future of Bayreuth, which they do not, the succession decision has become more complex as the moment nears when a fourth generation takes over the theatre in which Richard Wagner mounted the premiere of the Ring back in 1876.

The battle for the succession is partly about soap opera. Will Wolfgang get his wish and pass Bayreuth on to his second wife, Gudrun, 56, and ultimately their 22-year-old daughter, Katharina? Or will the children of Wolfgang's first marriage, Eva and Gottfried, win the prize? What about Wieland's four children, especially Wolf-Siegfried and his sister Nike?

But this battle is not just about soap opera but about real opera too. It is about the priorities and values of 21st-century Bayreuth. It is about whether the Bayreuth that Wolfgang will ultimately relinquish will remain the Bayreuth that he inherited, a festival dedicated to the annual re-creation of his grandfather's 10 mature stage works - and nothing else.

This summer, as every summer since 1951, Bayreuth will present a group of Wagner's works. The centrepiece will be a new staging of the Ring directed by Jürgen Flimm and conducted by Giuseppe Sinopoli. In addition, there will be a revival of Keith Warner's production of Lohengrin and revivals of two of Wolfgang's own productions, Die Meistersinger and Parsifal, the latter the work most indissolubly associated with Bayreuth.

Bayreuth and conservatism are words that fall naturally together, but the association is by no means the whole story. Unquestionably, Bayreuth is a place of traditions - the Wagner family, the Wagner repertoire, the musical excellence, the high seriousness, the performance and audience rituals, the uncomfortable seats - and it has always attracted Germany's richest and most powerful elite, who make up the bulk of the audience for the 30 or so performances, which start in late July and continue through August. Unquestionably too, Wolfgang Wagner is a political and cultural conservative.

He has spent his whole life in Bayreuth, dedicated to the perpetuation of the family festival. His first memory of the Bayreuth Festspielhaus is of a Gotterdammerung dress rehearsal as long ago as 1925. He was dangled on Cosima Wagner's knee, embraced and photographed with "Uncle Wolf" Hitler, was present in the town when his grandfather's historic home at Wahnfried was bombed by the Allies in 1945, and has been a highly visible and energetic presence at all 50 of the postwar festivals.

Wolfgang's own productions at Bayreuth have never had the radicalism, vision or acclaim of his elder brother Wieland's. Wolfgang's productions have been generally derivative of Wieland's "New Bayreuth" style, though some have seen touches of Albert Speer in his Parsifal designs. Where Wieland's Meistersinger was touched with menace, Wolfgang's exuded reconciliation and bonhomie, which struck many radical critics as culpably naive.

No one who reads the devastating book Twilight of the Wagners by his estranged son Gottfried can be in much doubt either about Wolfgang's conservative politics, his anti- liberalism and anti-communism, and his long habit of ducking and concealing the full truth of the Nazi era.

"Hitler cured unemployment and restored worldwide respect for the German economy. He freed our people from a moral crisis and united all decent forces. We Wagners have him to thank for the idealistic rescue of the Bayreuth festival," Gottfried reports his father telling him in the 50s. His treatment of the Jews "was the only real mistake Hitler made".

Yet Wolfgang has certainly adapted with the times, even managed to reinvent himself in some ways. His decision to open Bayreuth to outside directors in 1969 was both inescapable and revolutionary. While his own productions have not been innovative, he has consistently encouraged a series of ever more radical re-evaluations of Wagner's operas by others, beginning with Götz Friedrich's 1971 Tannhäuser and Patrice Chereau's 1976 centenary Ring and continuing up to the present day. These have routinely outraged the conservatives. He, more than anyone, has internationalised Bayreuth, bringing in French, British, Italian, American and Israeli conductors. In the past two decades, most of the criticism of Bayreuth has been that it has been too left-wing, not too right-wing.

What Wolfgang has not done is respond to the challenges posed by the two most radical Wagners of the next generation. His son Gottfried and his niece Nike both focus their hostility on the terms of the Richard Wagner Foundation of Bayreuth, which runs the festival on terms drafted by Wolfgang in 1973. Under its charter, Bayreuth is run by a 24-person council representing the Wagners, the German and Bavarian governments, the city of Bayreuth and the local authorities of Franconia. But the foundation's aims are restricted to the preservation of "the artistic legacy of Richard Wagner in perpetuity". The Festspielhaus is to be used "solely for the solemn performance of the works of Richard Wagner".

"To focus the festival solely on Richard Wagner precludes any end to the Wagner cult, the horrifying consequences of which have already been shown," Gottfried Wagner says. Instead, he proposes that Wagner's early works before the Flying Dutchman, none of which is ever performed at Bayreuth, should all be performed in the festival. So, he says, should the works of composers who had a major influence on Wagner, such as Weber and Marschner, and perhaps even Mozart. The Bayreuth festival should be a much more open event, encouraging other art forms, and should constantly re-examine all aspects of Wagner's legacy, including his political and cultural influence.

In her manifesto published in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung last month, Nike Wagner made several of the same points as her cousin. She also suggested that Bayreuth should itself commission new works. "The festival risks becoming repetitive," Nike wrote. "It is always resorting to its old-fashioned roots."

Nike and Gottfried Wagner are surely right. Bayreuth clearly needs to heed once again Richard Wagner's famous injunction to always do something new. But it also needs to remember Hans Sach's warning not to despise the best of its own traditions.
fields.bodyText: In the beginning, as with all sagas, it was simple, like the E flat that begins the Ring of the Nibelung. There was a genius, Richard Wagner, who built a theatre at Bayreuth to perform his music dramas in conditions of his own choosing. Then the genius died, so his wife Cosima took over the theatre, before handing it over to their son Siegfried, who died in turn, passing the theatre on to his own wife, Winifred. Then things got very nasty, as happens in all sagas. Winifred Wagner, though born in Hastings, was a German nationalist, a Nazi, an anti-Semite and, to the day of her death in 1980, an admirer of Adolf Hitler. Hitler in turn loved Wagner's operas, and perhaps Winifred too. Bayreuth became a Nazi shrine and the Wagner legacy became forever intertwined with that of the Third Reich. The other complication is that families expand as time goes on, and the Wagner family is no exception. Siegfried and Winifred Wagner had four children, two of whom, Wieland and Wolfgang, reopened the denazified Bayreuth festival in 1951. Wieland, the eldest and most talented of his generation of Wagners, died prematurely and greatly mourned in 1966. Wolfgang, now 80, remains in charge at Bayreuth to this day. Wolfgang's immediate problem, much reported over the past week, is that there are 12 Wagners in the next generation. Even if they all saw eye to eye about the future of Bayreuth, which they do not, the succession decision has become more complex as the moment nears when a fourth generation takes over the theatre in which Richard Wagner mounted the premiere of the Ring back in 1876. The battle for the succession is partly about soap opera. Will Wolfgang get his wish and pass Bayreuth on to his second wife, Gudrun, 56, and ultimately their 22-year-old daughter, Katharina? Or will the children of Wolfgang's first marriage, Eva and Gottfried, win the prize? What about Wieland's four children, especially Wolf-Siegfried and his sister Nike? But this battle is not just about soap opera but about real opera too. It is about the priorities and values of 21st-century Bayreuth. It is about whether the Bayreuth that Wolfgang will ultimately relinquish will remain the Bayreuth that he inherited, a festival dedicated to the annual re-creation of his grandfather's 10 mature stage works - and nothing else. This summer, as every summer since 1951, Bayreuth will present a group of Wagner's works. The centrepiece will be a new staging of the Ring directed by Jürgen Flimm and conducted by Giuseppe Sinopoli. In addition, there will be a revival of Keith Warner's production of Lohengrin and revivals of two of Wolfgang's own productions, Die Meistersinger and Parsifal, the latter the work most indissolubly associated with Bayreuth. Bayreuth and conservatism are words that fall naturally together, but the association is by no means the whole story. Unquestionably, Bayreuth is a place of traditions - the Wagner family, the Wagner repertoire, the musical excellence, the high seriousness, the performance and audience rituals, the uncomfortable seats - and it has always attracted Germany's richest and most powerful elite, who make up the bulk of the audience for the 30 or so performances, which start in late July and continue through August. Unquestionably too, Wolfgang Wagner is a political and cultural conservative. He has spent his whole life in Bayreuth, dedicated to the perpetuation of the family festival. His first memory of the Bayreuth Festspielhaus is of a Gotterdammerung dress rehearsal as long ago as 1925. He was dangled on Cosima Wagner's knee, embraced and photographed with "Uncle Wolf" Hitler, was present in the town when his grandfather's historic home at Wahnfried was bombed by the Allies in 1945, and has been a highly visible and energetic presence at all 50 of the postwar festivals. Wolfgang's own productions at Bayreuth have never had the radicalism, vision or acclaim of his elder brother Wieland's. Wolfgang's productions have been generally derivative of Wieland's "New Bayreuth" style, though some have seen touches of Albert Speer in his Parsifal designs. Where Wieland's Meistersinger was touched with menace, Wolfgang's exuded reconciliation and bonhomie, which struck many radical critics as culpably naive. No one who reads the devastating book Twilight of the Wagners by his estranged son Gottfried can be in much doubt either about Wolfgang's conservative politics, his anti- liberalism and anti-communism, and his long habit of ducking and concealing the full truth of the Nazi era. "Hitler cured unemployment and restored worldwide respect for the German economy. He freed our people from a moral crisis and united all decent forces. We Wagners have him to thank for the idealistic rescue of the Bayreuth festival," Gottfried reports his father telling him in the 50s. His treatment of the Jews "was the only real mistake Hitler made". Yet Wolfgang has certainly adapted with the times, even managed to reinvent himself in some ways. His decision to open Bayreuth to outside directors in 1969 was both inescapable and revolutionary. While his own productions have not been innovative, he has consistently encouraged a series of ever more radical re-evaluations of Wagner's operas by others, beginning with Götz Friedrich's 1971 Tannhäuser and Patrice Chereau's 1976 centenary Ring and continuing up to the present day. These have routinely outraged the conservatives. He, more than anyone, has internationalised Bayreuth, bringing in French, British, Italian, American and Israeli conductors. In the past two decades, most of the criticism of Bayreuth has been that it has been too left-wing, not too right-wing. What Wolfgang has not done is respond to the challenges posed by the two most radical Wagners of the next generation. His son Gottfried and his niece Nike both focus their hostility on the terms of the Richard Wagner Foundation of Bayreuth, which runs the festival on terms drafted by Wolfgang in 1973. Under its charter, Bayreuth is run by a 24-person council representing the Wagners, the German and Bavarian governments, the city of Bayreuth and the local authorities of Franconia. But the foundation's aims are restricted to the preservation of "the artistic legacy of Richard Wagner in perpetuity". The Festspielhaus is to be used "solely for the solemn performance of the works of Richard Wagner". "To focus the festival solely on Richard Wagner precludes any end to the Wagner cult, the horrifying consequences of which have already been shown," Gottfried Wagner says. Instead, he proposes that Wagner's early works before the Flying Dutchman, none of which is ever performed at Bayreuth, should all be performed in the festival. So, he says, should the works of composers who had a major influence on Wagner, such as Weber and Marschner, and perhaps even Mozart. The Bayreuth festival should be a much more open event, encouraging other art forms, and should constantly re-examine all aspects of Wagner's legacy, including his political and cultural influence. In her manifesto published in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung last month, Nike Wagner made several of the same points as her cousin. She also suggested that Bayreuth should itself commission new works. "The festival risks becoming repetitive," Nike wrote. "It is always resorting to its old-fashioned roots." Nike and Gottfried Wagner are surely right. Bayreuth clearly needs to heed once again Richard Wagner's famous injunction to always do something new. But it also needs to remember Hans Sach's warning not to despise the best of its own traditions.

webTitle: The best teenage party scene: The Virgin Suicides

fields.headline: The best teenage party scene: The Virgin Suicides
fields.trailText: Grosse Pointe, Michigan. The mid-70s. Cecilia Lisbon (Hannah R Hall) - at 13, the youngest of the five Lisbon sisters - has recently been discharged from hospital after an unsuccessful suicide attempt. Tim Weiner (Jonathan Tucker), one of the adolescent boys who idolise the sisters from across the street, speaks in voiceover.
fields.body:
Grosse Pointe, Michigan. The mid-70s. Cecilia Lisbon (Hannah R Hall) - at 13, the youngest of the five Lisbon sisters - has recently been discharged from hospital after an unsuccessful suicide attempt. Tim Weiner (Jonathan Tucker), one of the adolescent boys who idolise the sisters from across the street, speaks in voiceover.

"Two weeks after Cecilia returned home, Mr Lisbon persuaded his wife to allow the girls the first and only party of their short lives."

Cut to the Lisbon house, as the boys - dressed in their Sunday best of bow ties and sports jackets - troop up to the front door. They knock. Mrs Lisbon (Kathleen Turner) answers.

"Good evening, Mrs Lisbon."

"Welcome. Come on in. The party's in the basement - go on, first on the left, and then down the stairs..."

The boys descend to the basement, where the girls are sitting neatly on a pair of sofas. The Carpenters play in the background.

"Hi," say the boys.

"Hi," reply the girls.

The eldest Lisbon sister, Therese (Leslie Hayman), stands beside a cut-glass bowl full of orange liquid.

"Would you like some punch?"

"Yeah. Thank you."

"You're welcome."

Awkward conversation fills the room.

"So, how did your SATs go?"

"Good."

"Great. Have you applied to college yet?"

Cecilia, sitting in the corner, her wrists bandaged, silently rises and heads upstairs alone...

See also: Over The Edge, Dazed And Confused, American Pie

Don't See Also: Porky's

Pointless trivia: Kathleen Turner was the subject of a 1986 single - The Kiss Of Kathleen Turner - by the late German electro star Falco.

webTitle: Adams and Walsh take Windies to last-gasp win over Pakistan

fields.headline: Adams and Walsh take Windies to last-gasp win over Pakistan
fields.standfirst: Part III of our guide to this winter's Tests. To find out how these results have affected the world order, click here for the updated Wisden World Championship table
fields.trailText: West Indies v Pakistan
fields.body:
West Indies v Pakistan

First Test, Georgetown, May 5-9
Drawn
Pakistan 288 (Inzamam-ul-Haq 135, Abdur Razzaq 87, Ambrose 4-43)
West Indies 222 for 7 (Mushtaq Ahmed 3-91)
Toss West Indies

Rain wiped out the last two days, adding to the already dreadful record of weather at Georgetown. It came as a relief to the home side, who had been playing catch-up after Inzamam-ul-Haq's masterly century put Pakistan in charge. The early signs had been good for West Indies as Pakistan lost five for 39 in the first 17 overs as Ambrose and Walsh quickly warmed to their task. But Inzamam - who had hit 86 and 138 in his previous Test, against Sri Lanka - again showed his class with a broad selection of shots in his 117. He fell early on the second morning - lbw to Reon King's first ball of the day - after putting on a priceless 206 in 84 overs with Abdur Razzaq. Next morning was slow going and the innings subsided after Abdur Razzaq fell 13 runs short of a maiden Test hundred. In reply, West Indies, boasting eight left-handers, stumbled to 139 for six, then Shivnarine Chanderpaul proved the model of dogged defiance, cautiously compiling an unbeaten 46 in just over four hours. Nixon McLean matched Chanderpaul's score in almost half the time as the pair put on 74, before McLean tickled a Waqar Younis delivery to first slip. But, as West Indies crept closer to Pakistan's benchmark, the heavens opened. Terminally.
Wisden verdict Chanderpaul's runs marked another step in the Windies' rehabilitation, but the way they allowed a huge partnership to build up between two collapses showed that the bowling is still not what it was.

2nd Test, Bridgetown, May 18-22
Drawn
Pakistan 253 (Yousuf Youhana 115, Walsh 5-22) and 419 for 9 decl. (Mohammad Wasim 82, Imran Nazir 131, Abdur Razzaq 72, King 4-82)
West Indies 398 (Campbell 58, Hinds 165, Sarwan 84*, Saqlain Mushtaq 5-121) amd 132 for 4 (Hinds 52)
Toss Pakistan Debuts Sarwan (West Indies)
A see-sawing match finally came to a balanced end when West Indies, set 275 to win, closed on 132 for 4. After winning the toss, Pakistan had slumped to 37 for 5 before Yousuf Youhana's second Test century took them to respectability. Courtney Walsh seized the opportunity to top up on his world record with his 18th five-wicket haul in Tests. Sherwin Campbell and Wavell Hinds then added 133 for the second wicket, and Hinds, in his fourth Test, went on to a superbly aggressive maiden hundred, striking 24 fours and a six in his 165. Another newcomer, debutant Ramnaresh Sarwan stroked 84*. Trailing by 146, Pakistan fought their way back into the game with a first-wicket stand of 219, as Imran Nazir became the second player in the game to hit his maiden Test ton, but again West Indies fought back to leave themselves an unlikely victory target of 275 in 54 overs. With one game to go, it was all-square. Wisden verdict Forget Brian Lara (for the moment). West Indies now have two new left-handers to bolster an ailing line-up. Look out for Hinds and Sarwan in England.

3rd Test, Antigua, May 25-29
West Indies won by 1 wicket
Pakistan 269 (Inzamam-ul-Haq 55, Yousuf Youhana 103*, Walsh 5-83) and 219 (Inzamam-ul-Haq 68, King 4-48)
West Indies 273 (Chanderpaul 89, Adams 60, Wasim Akram 6-61) and 216 for 9 (Hinds 63, Wasim Akram 5-49)
Toss West Indies Debuts none
This had to be seen to be believed. West Indies needed 216 to avoid their first series defeat at home to Pakistan, and, with Wavell Hinds playing another classy innings, were cruising at 144 for 3. But Hinds was bowled by Wasim Akram, and West Indies panicked, losing five more wickets as they crept to 197 for 9. Courtney Walsh, the world's worst batsman, joined his captain and fellow Jamaican Jimmy Adams at the crease. Nineteen were needed. What followed were scenes of pandemonium rarely seen in a Test match. First Adams appeared to nick Wasim to Moin Khan behind the stumps, but with the Pakistanis already celebrating, home umpire Billy Doctrove ruled not out. Then Walsh squeezed Saqlain Mushtaq onto his pads and was comfortably held at short leg. To the Pakistanis' astonishment, New Zealander Doug Cowie refused to raise the finger. Finally, and most excruciatingly of all, Walsh and Adams found themselves at the same end after Adams had trotted quietly (too quietly) through for a leg-bye. But Saqlain, attempting to execute the easiest of run outs at the other end, dropped the ball, and Walsh gallopped home to safety. Soon after, Adams took two to midwicket to level the scores, grinned from ear to ear, then played and missed at Wasim next ball, before dropping a short single the delivery after and sparking wild scenes of jubilation (not to say relief). The pair had added 19 runs in 13.1 overs, while Adams had eaten up 212 balls for his 48*. He didn't score more than two off any ball. It was all so harsh on man of the match Wasim, who finished with 11 wickets days after being implicated in the match-fixing scandal by the Qayyum report. Earlier, Yousuf Youhana had made a second consecutive hundred and Inzamam-ul-Haq had hit two typically beefy fifties. But the Gods were smiling on the other side. West Indies' 1-0 series win meant they stayed third in the Wisden World Championship; defeat would have pushed them down to fifth. Wisden verdict Undeserved? Maybe. Lucky? Probably. Vital? Definitely. Jimmy Adams is now unbeaten in five Tests as captain, while two of his three wins have been a case of back from the dead. He could be just the man West Indies need to kickstart the renaissance.

West Indies v Zimbabwe

First Test, Port-of-Spain, Mar 16-20
West Indies won by 35 runs
West Indies 187 (Streak 4-45) and 147 (Streak 5-23)
Zimbabwe 236 (Andy Flower 113*, Ambrose 4-42) and 63 (Rose 4-19)
Toss Zimbabwe Debuts Gayle, Hinds (West Indies), Murphy (Zimbabwe)

West Indies' bowlers have saved face in the fourth innings before. But it's unlikely that they've ever done so under as much pressure - and as spectacularly - as here. Defending 99 to avoid defeat and further scorn in their inaugural meeting with Zimbabwe, Curtly and Co bowled with unremitting accuracy on a pitch that, even by Trinidad's standards, was doing a bit. A shellshocked Zimbabwe were shot out for 63 - their lowest total, and the first time a side had failed to chase a double-figure score in a Test since 1882. Jimmy Adams, leading West Indies for the first time after Brian Lara's self-imposed exile, was jubilant.Earlier, Heath Streak and Andy Flower seemed to have put Zimbabwe on course for their fourth Test win. Streak made the most of a damp, uneven wicket to take nine for 68, while Flower, fortunate to survive an appeal for caught behind before he had scored, moved to his seventh Test hundred. He was the only man in the match to pass fifty. But with the crowd turning against them and their biggest humbling yet on the cards, the West Indies rose from the dead: Franklyn Rose took four in quick succession and Ambrose (age 36, bowling figures 11-6-8-3) cleared up amid dramatic scenes and under dark skies.
Wisden verdict The Windies may be in decline. But they can still roll back the years when it matters - especially in the Caribbean.

Second Test, Kingston, Mar 24-28
West Indies won by 10 wickets
Zimbabwe 308 (Goodwin 113, Andy Flower 66, King 5-51) and 102
West Indies 339 (Adams 101*, Rose 69) and 75 for 0 (Griffith 54*)
Toss Zimbabwe Debuts none

One for the romantics. In front of his adoring home crowd, and with one Zimbabwean wicket still to fall, Courtney Walsh stood level at the top of the world with Kapil Dev on 434 Test wickets. The last man was Henry Olonga, one of the world's most celebrated rabbits, and when Walsh lifted one into his ribs, Olonga steered it into the hands of Wavell Hinds at short leg - and the celebrations began. The fact that West Indies had won a Test match, a series and moved back into third place in the Wisden World Championship was largely forgotten. A Windies victory had looked unlikely after Murray Goodwin and Andy Flower, with a fourth-wicket stand of 176, had lifted Zimbabwe to a first-innings total of 308. And when West Indies stuttered to 170 for 7 in reply, a drawn series was on the cards. But Jimmy Adams hit his first Test century for four years and was kept company by Franklyn Rose, who made contact with enough speculative swishes to hit a career-best 69 and help add 148 for the eighth wicket. Zimbabwe never recovered, and with Heath Streak unable to bat because of an injury, slumped to 102 all out. Left 72 to win, the usually sedate Adrian Griffith (0, 0 and 6 in the series so far) thundered an unbeaten 54 off just 41 balls. In the end it was too easy.
Wisden verdict Walsh's feat akin to Geoff Boycott scoring his 100th hundred in front of his Headingley acolytes - but better. And Adams could just be the captain to lead West Indies out of the doldrums.

New Zealand v Australia

First Test, Auckland, Mar 11-15
Australia won by 62 runs
Australia 214 (Mark Waugh 72*, Vettori 5-62) and 229 (Gilchrist 59, Vettori 7-87)
New Zealand 163 (McGrath 4-33) and 218 (McMillan 78, Miller 5-55)
Toss Australia Debuts none

There aren't many bowlers who are outperformed by their opposite number and still steal the headlines. But Shane Warne is no ordinary bowler. When he claimed Paul Wiseman caught behind in the second innings ("As soon as I saw him sweep I was appealing") he at last passed Dennis Lillee's Australian Test record of 355 wickets - and a nation celebrated. Almost incidentally, it gave Australia their eighth Test win in a row, equalling the record set by their 1920-21 compatriots. And it meant that the feats of New Zealand's slow left-armer Daniel Vettori were virtually forgotten. He returned a career-best match analysis of 12-149 (Warne took 5-148); only Richard Hadlee (15-123 v Australia, at Brisbane in 1985-86) has done better for the Kiwis. Vettori also became the third youngest bowler, at 21 years and 46 days, to reach 100 Test wickets, behind Kapil Dev and Waqar Younis. But on a turning wicket, the crucial innings was played by Adam Gilchrist, now firmly established as the world's best wicketkeeper-batsman: he hit 59 in Australia's second innings to leave New Zealand a victory target of 281. After the fourth day was lost to rain, they began the fifth on 151 for 5, but Chris Cairns went immediately, and Craig McMillan was left to fight a lone battle, as Colin Miller returned career-best figures. But for once, one individual was bigger than the game.
Wisden verdict The Aussies haven't been this inconvenienced since Murali had them in trouble in Sri Lanka in August.

Second Test, Wellington, Mar 24-27
Australia won by six wickets
New Zealand 298 (Astle 61, Cairns 109, Warne 4-68) and 294 (Fleming 60, Cairns 69)
Australia 419 (Slater 143, Steve Waugh 151*, Martyn 78) and 177 for 4 (Langer 57)
Toss New Zealand Debuts none

Australia moved inevitably to a ninth Test win in a row - a new national record - and captain Steve Waugh became the first man to pass 150 against all the other eight Test teams. But this game will be remembered for the batting of Chris Cairns. Coming in at 66 for 5 on the first day he took a high-class century - his third in Tests - off a high-class attack to lift New Zealand to 298. Then, with NZ five down in their second innings and still 33 runs in arrears, Cairns did what his father Lance used to do, and hit one six after another: three off Shane Warne (including two in an over), two off Brett Lee (including a law-of-physics-defying back-foot drive over the sightscreen) and one off Greg Blewett. He made 'only' 69, in 83 balls, but he had given his side a chance - and reminded the rest of the world that these Aussies could be rattled. In between, Michael Slater (with his 14th Test hundred) and Steve Waugh (with his 22nd) rescued Australia from 51 for 4, adding 199 for the fifth wicket, before Damien Martyn made the most of Ricky Ponting's injury-enforced absence with a blistering 78. Set 174 to win the series after Cairns's fireworks, Australia lost Blewett early, but Justin Langer settled in and Australia had won again. It extended their lead at the top of the Wisden World Championship to 0.14 over South Africa. New Zealand stayed sixth - but were only 0.01 ahead of India.
Wisden verdict Cairns glittered but Australia's allround superioity shone through.

Third Test, Hamilton, Mar 31-Apr 3
Australia won by six wickets
New Zealand 232 (McMillan 79, McGrath 4-58, Lee 5-77) and 229 (Cairns 71)
Australia 252 (Martyn 89*, Gilchrist 75, O'Connor 5-51) and 212 for 4 (Langer 122*)
Toss Australia Debuts Tuffey (New Zealand)

Not content with simply winning, Australia won in style, scoring at five an over as they knocked off their target of 210 with the ease of a side that suspects it can't lose. Justin Langer finished with an unbeaten run-a-ball 122, having reached 50 in 42 deliveries - the quickest officially recorded half-century by an Australian. Afterwards, Steve Waugh called him the best batsman in the world. It was hard to disagree. Until Langer let loose, the game had been evenly balanced. Brett Lee's pace undermined the Kiwis on a good wicket in the first innings, before Australia stuttered to 29 for 5 in reply. Damien Martyn came to the rescue again with a career-best and Adam Gilchrist whacked 16 fours in an 80-ball 75. Debutant seamer Daryl Tuffey was the man who suffered, returning figures of 9-0-75-0. Chris Cairns - who else? - then dragged NZ back into it with another rumbustuous innings; his two sixes took his tally in the series to a Bothamesque 13. But Gilchrist showed he can keep as well as bat, holding an Aussie-best 10 catches (one behind Jack Russell's world record), and Langer went into overdrive. Australia had taken a series 3-0 for the third time, and had now won 10 in a row. It's a good job they're such an attractive side.
Wisden verdict Australia are now past being on the verge of something great. West Indies, their next opponents, will be hard-pressed to stop the Aussies taking their own world record of 11 wins in a row.

Earlier, Yousuf Youhana had made a second consecutive hundred and Inzamam-ul-Haq had hit two typically beefy fifties. But the Gods were smiling on the other side. West Indies' 1-0 series win meant they stayed third in the Wisden World Championship; defeat would have pushed them down to fifth. Wisden verdict Undeserved? Maybe. Lucky? Probably. Vital? Definitely. Jimmy Adams is now unbeaten in five Tests as captain, while two of his three wins have been a case of back from the dead. He could be just the man West Indies need to kickstart the renaissance. West Indies v Zimbabwe First Test, Port-of-Spain, Mar 16-20 West Indies won by 35 runs West Indies 187 (Streak 4-45) and 147 (Streak 5-23) Zimbabwe 236 (Andy Flower 113*, Ambrose 4-42) and 63 (Rose 4-19) Toss Zimbabwe Debuts Gayle, Hinds (West Indies), Murphy (Zimbabwe) West Indies' bowlers have saved face in the fourth innings before. But it's unlikely that they've ever done so under as much pressure - and as spectacularly - as here. Defending 99 to avoid defeat and further scorn in their inaugural meeting with Zimbabwe, Curtly and Co bowled with unremitting accuracy on a pitch that, even by Trinidad's standards, was doing a bit. A shellshocked Zimbabwe were shot out for 63 - their lowest total, and the first time a side had failed to chase a double-figure score in a Test since 1882. Jimmy Adams, leading West Indies for the first time after Brian Lara's self-imposed exile, was jubilant.Earlier, Heath Streak and Andy Flower seemed to have put Zimbabwe on course for their fourth Test win. Streak made the most of a damp, uneven wicket to take nine for 68, while Flower, fortunate to survive an appeal for caught behind before he had scored, moved to his seventh Test hundred. He was the only man in the match to pass fifty. But with the crowd turning against them and their biggest humbling yet on the cards, the West Indies rose from the dead: Franklyn Rose took four in quick succession and Ambrose (age 36, bowling figures 11-6-8-3) cleared up amid dramatic scenes and under dark skies. Wisden verdict The Windies may be in decline. But they can still roll back the years when it matters - especially in the Caribbean. Second Test, Kingston, Mar 24-28 West Indies won by 10 wickets Zimbabwe 308 (Goodwin 113, Andy Flower 66, King 5-51) and 102 West Indies 339 (Adams 101*, Rose 69) and 75 for 0 (Griffith 54*) Toss Zimbabwe Debuts none One for the romantics. In front of his adoring home crowd, and with one Zimbabwean wicket still to fall, Courtney Walsh stood level at the top of the world with Kapil Dev on 434 Test wickets. The last man was Henry Olonga, one of the world's most celebrated rabbits, and when Walsh lifted one into his ribs, Olonga steered it into the hands of Wavell Hinds at short leg - and the celebrations began. The fact that West Indies had won a Test match, a series and moved back into third place in the Wisden World Championship was largely forgotten. A Windies victory had looked unlikely after Murray Goodwin and Andy Flower, with a fourth-wicket stand of 176, had lifted Zimbabwe to a first-innings total of 308. And when West Indies stuttered to 170 for 7 in reply, a drawn series was on the cards. But Jimmy Adams hit his first Test century for four years and was kept company by Franklyn Rose, who made contact with enough speculative swishes to hit a career-best 69 and help add 148 for the eighth wicket. Zimbabwe never recovered, and with Heath Streak unable to bat because of an injury, slumped to 102 all out. Left 72 to win, the usually sedate Adrian Griffith (0, 0 and 6 in the series so far) thundered an unbeaten 54 off just 41 balls. In the end it was too easy. Wisden verdict Walsh's feat akin to Geoff Boycott scoring his 100th hundred in front of his Headingley acolytes - but better. And Adams could just be the captain to lead West Indies out of the doldrums. New Zealand v Australia First Test, Auckland, Mar 11-15 Australia won by 62 runs Australia 214 (Mark Waugh 72*, Vettori 5-62) and 229 (Gilchrist 59, Vettori 7-87) New Zealand 163 (McGrath 4-33) and 218 (McMillan 78, Miller 5-55) Toss Australia Debuts none There aren't many bowlers who are outperformed by their opposite number and still steal the headlines. But Shane Warne is no ordinary bowler. When he claimed Paul Wiseman caught behind in the second innings ("As soon as I saw him sweep I was appealing") he at last passed Dennis Lillee's Australian Test record of 355 wickets - and a nation celebrated. Almost incidentally, it gave Australia their eighth Test win in a row, equalling the record set by their 1920-21 compatriots. And it meant that the feats of New Zealand's slow left-armer Daniel Vettori were virtually forgotten. He returned a career-best match analysis of 12-149 (Warne took 5-148); only Richard Hadlee (15-123 v Australia, at Brisbane in 1985-86) has done better for the Kiwis. Vettori also became the third youngest bowler, at 21 years and 46 days, to reach 100 Test wickets, behind Kapil Dev and Waqar Younis. But on a turning wicket, the crucial innings was played by Adam Gilchrist, now firmly established as the world's best wicketkeeper-batsman: he hit 59 in Australia's second innings to leave New Zealand a victory target of 281. After the fourth day was lost to rain, they began the fifth on 151 for 5, but Chris Cairns went immediately, and Craig McMillan was left to fight a lone battle, as Colin Miller returned career-best figures. But for once, one individual was bigger than the game. Wisden verdict The Aussies haven't been this inconvenienced since Murali had them in trouble in Sri Lanka in August. Second Test, Wellington, Mar 24-27 Australia won by six wickets New Zealand 298 (Astle 61, Cairns 109, Warne 4-68) and 294 (Fleming 60, Cairns 69) Australia 419 (Slater 143, Steve Waugh 151*, Martyn 78) and 177 for 4 (Langer 57) Toss New Zealand Debuts none Australia moved inevitably to a ninth Test win in a row - a new national record - and captain Steve Waugh became the first man to pass 150 against all the other eight Test teams. But this game will be remembered for the batting of Chris Cairns. Coming in at 66 for 5 on the first day he took a high-class century - his third in Tests - off a high-class attack to lift New Zealand to 298. Then, with NZ five down in their second innings and still 33 runs in arrears, Cairns did what his father Lance used to do, and hit one six after another: three off Shane Warne (including two in an over), two off Brett Lee (including a law-of-physics-defying back-foot drive over the sightscreen) and one off Greg Blewett. He made 'only' 69, in 83 balls, but he had given his side a chance - and reminded the rest of the world that these Aussies could be rattled. In between, Michael Slater (with his 14th Test hundred) and Steve Waugh (with his 22nd) rescued Australia from 51 for 4, adding 199 for the fifth wicket, before Damien Martyn made the most of Ricky Ponting's injury-enforced absence with a blistering 78. Set 174 to win the series after Cairns's fireworks, Australia lost Blewett early, but Justin Langer settled in and Australia had won again. It extended their lead at the top of the Wisden World Championship to 0.14 over South Africa. New Zealand stayed sixth - but were only 0.01 ahead of India. Wisden verdict Cairns glittered but Australia's allround superioity shone through. Third Test, Hamilton, Mar 31-Apr 3 Australia won by six wickets New Zealand 232 (McMillan 79, McGrath 4-58, Lee 5-77) and 229 (Cairns 71) Australia 252 (Martyn 89*, Gilchrist 75, O'Connor 5-51) and 212 for 4 (Langer 122*) Toss Australia Debuts Tuffey (New Zealand) Not content with simply winning, Australia won in style, scoring at five an over as they knocked off their target of 210 with the ease of a side that suspects it can't lose. Justin Langer finished with an unbeaten run-a-ball 122, having reached 50 in 42 deliveries - the quickest officially recorded half-century by an Australian. Afterwards, Steve Waugh called him the best batsman in the world. It was hard to disagree. Until Langer let loose, the game had been evenly balanced. Brett Lee's pace undermined the Kiwis on a good wicket in the first innings, before Australia stuttered to 29 for 5 in reply. Damien Martyn came to the rescue again with a career-best and Adam Gilchrist whacked 16 fours in an 80-ball 75. Debutant seamer Daryl Tuffey was the man who suffered, returning figures of 9-0-75-0. Chris Cairns - who else? - then dragged NZ back into it with another rumbustuous innings; his two sixes took his tally in the series to a Bothamesque 13. But Gilchrist showed he can keep as well as bat, holding an Aussie-best 10 catches (one behind Jack Russell's world record), and Langer went into overdrive. Australia had taken a series 3-0 for the third time, and had now won 10 in a row. It's a good job they're such an attractive side. Wisden verdict Australia are now past being on the verge of something great. West Indies, their next opponents, will be hard-pressed to stop the Aussies taking their own world record of 11 wins in a row.

webTitle: BMA must back moves to weed out the Ledwards

fields.headline: BMA must back moves to weed out the Ledwards
fields.standfirst: The disgraced gynaecologist's lack of remorse underlines fears of consultants' arrogance, says Sarah Boseley, health correspondent
fields.trailText: The disgraced gynaecologist's lack of remorse underlines fears of consultants' arrogance, says Sarah Boseley, health correspondent.
fields.body:
What does it take to humble a man like Rodney Ledward? Most of us would creep away and hide after a public flaying of the sort Jean Ritchie QC administered to the former gynaecologist whose nickname in Kent, where he worked, was "the butcher".

This consultant was struck off the medical register by the General Medical Council for a series of botched operations - 10 complaints against him were upheld. Women have been left with permanent disabilities thanks to the speed and apparent carelessness with which he operated on them.

Yet today, Ledward is buoyant and unabashed, telling Radio 4 that he can stand full-square in front of the mirror and without conceit say that the NHS ousted, in him, a first-rate consultant. He is no worse than anyone else.

The Ritchie report? He says he hasn't read it. Perhaps he should. Over a year of hard work went into the analysis of the failings of Ledward, self-styled "fastest gynaecologist in the south-east", and the culture of fawning and fear in hospitals that prevented anybody putting a stop to the wholesale mutilation of women.

The report said he was arrogant and lacking in compassion. His manner with patients and junior staff was intimidating and frightening. "There was something slapdash and unmethodical in his character; an element of seeing what he could get away with," the report said. Unfortunately, all the women who suffered at his hands thought they were an isolated case, and nobody within the hospital told them otherwise.

Ledward says he is no different from his colleagues. We have to hope he is very wrong. But we will not know for certain until the government-led reforms are in place and spitting out unacceptable practice. Annual appraisal leading to five-yearly revalidation - a big tick from the GMC that the doctor is up to scratch - are vital to restore the faith in doctors that men like Ledward undermine. Yet consultants within the British Medical Association - the profession's trade union - have begun to drag their feet over this rigorous assessment procedure. Last week they passed a vote of no confidence in the GMC. They would do well to rethink their stance, before the public starts to wonder whether they are not still more interested in protecting themselves than protecting patients.

fields.headline: November 17: Europe's most deadly militants
fields.trailText: The search for the killers of Brigadier Stephen Saunders in Athens is focused on a small but ruthless militant Marxist group which has claimed up to 23 lives in as many years, together with carrying out a clutch of rocket attacks and other violent acts.
fields.body:
The search for the killers of Brigadier Stephen Saunders in Athens is focused on a small but ruthless militant Marxist group which has claimed up to 23 lives in as many years, together with carrying out a clutch of rocket attacks and other violent acts.

The group calls itself Revolutionary Organisation November 17. It takes its name from a student-led uprising against the then military dictatorship on that date in 1973.

November 17 takes a low-key approach, shunning publicity and striking only infrequently - but with deadly effect. Not a single member has ever been arrested.

Its victims include a CIA station chief in Athens and three other Americans. Brigadier Saunders could have been targeted simply because Britain is a staunch ally of the USA, especially in counter-terrorist strategy.

A more specific reason could be the role that Britain played in last year's dramatic abduction of Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan.

Ocalan was smuggled through Greece to a supposed safe haven in Kenya, by Greek diplomats and other officials keen to embarrass Turkey. Their ploy misfired when Turkish special forces snatched the rebel leader and flew him back to Turkey to face trial. He is now under sentence of death.

Following the dramatic kidnap, November 17 issued one of its rare communiques, blaming the Greek government for Ocalan's arrest.

Like most Greek factions, whether right or left, November 17 holds passionately anti-Turkish views, and has pledged its support to Ocalan's PKK militant group.

The Greek cell was undoubtedly angered when, following the Ocalan abduction, 79 supporters of the Kurdish leader were arrested during rowdy demonstrations in London. Britain also suspended and later revoked the broadcast licence of Med-TV, a Kurdish satellite TV station with links to the PKK.

November 17 has also been stirred to violent action by recent events in the Balkans, which have led to a surge of anti-US and anti-Nato feeling in Greece.

According to the US authorities, there were 40 attacks on Western interests in just three months last year, including seven rocket attacks and bombings attributed to November 17.

The US Commission on Counter Terrorism is scathingly critical of Greece's failure to tackle the cell and other militant groups. In its 1999 report it notes: "Greece remained one of the weakest links in Europe's efforts against terrorism. Greece led Europe in the number of anti-US terrorist attacks in 1999 and ranked second worldwide only to Colombia... The absence of strong public government leadership and initiatives to improve police capabilities and morale contributed to the lack of breakthroughs against terrorists. Popular opinion makers generally downplayed terrorism as a threat to public order, even as terrorists continued to act with virtual impunity."

webTitle: Computer system kicks off by proving its worth

fields.headline: Computer system kicks off by proving its worth
fields.trailText: The exclusion from the Netherlands of two English hooligans was greeted with relief by police officers at the bi-national intelligence command centre, which has been set up by the police forces of Holland and Belgium, the two countries hosting Euro 2000.
fields.byline: Vivek Chaudhary  in Dribergen, the Netherlands
fields.body:
The exclusion from the Netherlands of two English hooligans was greeted with relief by police officers at the bi-national intelligence command centre, which has been set up by the police forces of Holland and Belgium, the two countries hosting Euro 2000.

The command centre, at the headquarters of the Netherlands national police agency in Dribergen, near Utrecht, uses the latest technology and information available on all known and suspected hooligans from the 16 countries taking part.

Officers began working on a detailed computer system three years ago. It allows every police station in Holland and Belgium to access the names of all troublemakers, to run checks on fans suspected of taking part in football violence in their own countries, and obtain a detailed profile of large groups of fans, where they will be staying and how they will be travelling.

The central computer system will also allow police resources to be diverted to areas where there is likely to be serious trouble. The 35,000 police officers on duty in Holland and 25,000 in Belgium will be able to feed new information and names into the computer. Foreign police forces are also able to gain access to the computer system and feed the latest information into it.

If, for example, a group of Germans are staying at a campsite, the details will be entered into the computer and police spotters in plain clothes, who track the movements of hooligans, will be alerted via computer and sent to compile a risk assessment of the fans.

All supporters travelling to Euro 2000 are being categorised according to their willingness to take part in violence. Fans who avoid violence have been categorised as A, those who take part in violence category B, while those who start and organise it have been categorised as C.

The central computer has already compiled a risk assessment of all fans who have pre-booked their accommodation.

The system, known as Fimes (Football intelligence message exchange system), played a crucial role in ensuring that two English hooligans did not make it into Holland.

When one arrived at the Hook of Holland, his passport was scanned and a computer at the border control showed that his name appeared on a list of known hooligans. As a secondary measure the name was also fed into the computer in Dribergen.

Officers at the central command immediately sent a message back via computer, warning border control officials that the person should not be allowed into the country. The hooligan at Amsterdam airport was turned back using the same system.

Chief superintendent Wim van Oorschot, who has been working in the bi-national intelligence centre, said: "You could say that we have had our first success but there is still a lot of work to be done. We are working very closely with police forces all around Europe and with the border police.

"A lot of work has gone into Fimes and the overall security arrangements. We are not afraid but we expect problems. You cannot have a tournament of this size and not expect any problems."

The intelligence centre is the largest and most sophisticated set up for a football tournament and up to 80 officers, including those from the 16 countries taking part, will be working in it 24 hours per day once the tournament starts.

Dutch authorities have already re-introduced border controls and have warned that any fans causing trouble will be prosecuted and forced to serve prison sentences before being allowed to return home. Legislation has also been introduced allowing police to detain suspected trouble- makers for 12 hours.

webTitle: Blair adds his fire to U-571 blasting

fields.headline: Blair adds his fire to U-571 blasting
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has joined in the condemnation of the second world war thriller U-571 for its rewriting of history.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has joined in the condemnation (see yesterday's story) of the second world war thriller U-571 for its rewriting of history.

Speaking in the Commons, the prime minister claimed that U-571 was an "affront" to the British sailors that were killed during the war and added "I hope that people realise these are people that, in many cases, sacrificed their lives in order that this country remained free."

The film - a massive success in the United States and riding high in the British box office at number 4 - portrays the capture of the German Enigma coding machine which marked a vital turning point in the war. At the time, the British-planned and executed action was described by George VI as the single most important event in the war at sea. The Hollywood version, however, re-casts the British war heroes as a group of hardy American naval officers.

At the end of the film, it is made clear that the movie is fictional but inspired by real events. Culture secretary Chris Smith however, has already said he will raise the issue in Hollywood, and added: "I think one of the things we need to make clear to Hollywood is, yes you're in the entertainment business but the people who see your movies are going to come away thinking that's information, not just entertainment."

webTitle: June 8: In brief and casting couch

fields.headline: June 8: In brief and casting couch
fields.trailText: Harry Potter to be filmed in UK, Richard Loncraine set for Douglas's Godspeed, Mike Myers hits back, new feature for Imax, and Scorsese sneak preview
fields.body:
 It was confirmed yesterday that Harry Potter, the Warner Bros £25m feature based on the children's book by British author J K Rowling, is to be filmed in the UK. This shot in the arm for the British movie industry should provide employment for up to 250 crew and craftsmen once filming gets underway in the autumn. The production will occupy Leavesden Studios in Hertfordshire (last used 6 years ago for the James Bond movie Goldeneye) for 18 months.

 Richard Loncraine, director of the acclaimed Richard III, has been brought in to direct the Michael Douglas-produced feature Godspeed, Lawrence Mann. The film tells the story of an astronaut who is believed dead when his capsule is found empty, only to return 40 yeas later. It looks likely that Douglas will also take the lead role. Although MGM are keen to get going on the project, Douglas, currently starring with wife Catherine Zeta-Jones in Steven Soderbergh's Traffic, will take time off from work when she gives birth to their first child in August.

 Following yesterday's news that actor-comedian Mike Myers is being sued by Universal Pictures for bailing out of his latest feature Dieter, lawyers for the star have wasted little time in hitting back. Myers's attorneys claim the studio were trying to 'bully' the star into doing the film even though the script did not meet with his approval. The Universal lawsuit is seeking about $5m for pre-production costs, as well as lost profits and seeks to bar Myers from any film or TV project for the period he is committed to work on the movie. Myers has said he is "shocked" by the lawsuit and claims that he merely sought to delay filming on Dieter because "the script does not work and it needs more time to be fixed."

 New animated film Shrek, which features the voices of Mike Myers, Cameron Diaz and Eddie Murphy, is to be released in Imax's digital 3-D cinemas in the US as well as in traditional cinemas. The $10m cost for the additional computer programming will be paid for by Imax. The Imax version of the film - a story of an ogre whose swamp has been overrun by troublesome fairytale creatures - will also boast an alternative ending to the regular theatrically-released version.

 US site Ain't it Cool News has got its hands on a sneak preview of the new Martin Scorsese script The Gangs of New York. The film, set in 1846, stars Leonardo DiCaprio as Amsterdam, an angry young man who vows to avenge his fathers death.

fields.headline: Invisible burdens
fields.trailText: Girls enrolled in rural Sindh usually say "yes" when asked if they like primary school. They belong to the literate minority in Pakistan. But their eyes darken as they start to talk about the "daily charges for invisible things", in exchange for an education.
fields.body:
Girls enrolled in rural Sindh usually say "yes" when asked if they like primary school. They belong to the literate minority in Pakistan. But their eyes darken as they start to talk about the "daily charges for invisible things", in exchange for an education.

They pay for teacher attendance, fees for fake school committees, and for text books and tuition that are supposed to be free. Some girls have to do domestic favours in the homes of their male teachers if they can't make the cash payments.

Petty corruption is less in the news than grand corruption of contract rigging and fraud. In petty corruption the individual amounts may be small, yet put together they add an invisible but crippling financial burden to public services. Unofficial charges, non-attendance of service providers and sale of supposedly free drugs were found to drain away no less than 70% of public resources invested in the health sector in one country.

In Pakistan, as in many other countries where petty corruption is commonplace in public services, unofficial extra charges add a cost that puts education out of reach for many of the country's poor. Together with teacher absence and phantom payrolls, this leaks educational resources away from their intended use.

In settings like this an overall increase in aid earmarked for education, as called for by United Nations secretary-general Kofi Annan, will make less difference than is needed.

Clare Short, the UK's minister responsible for international development, has declared bluntly that an annual contribution of $4bn from donor governments will not get all children into school by 2015, at least not if it is spent on a multitude of isolated education projects under the umbrella of a global initiative. Instead, she told the World Education Forum in Dakar in April, money for education should be part of poverty reduction and development strategies on a country-by-country basis.

It is easy to overstate the case. More money for individual education projects can help in the short term but, as Ms Short declared to an unreceptive audience at Dakar, another separate fund for education will have little effect unless it goes hand in hand with meaningful reform.

But the alternative, as she pointed out, is not to let the world's 113m children go uneducated, waiting passively for corrupt governments to mend their ways. Resources must be invested in education in a way that increases accountability, reduces poverty, and puts communities and civil society in a stronger position to pressurise decision-takers for change.

At first glance this might sound like a cop-out for policymakers who don't want to pay their share. Investing in accountability is less straightforward than paying for books, building schools or training teachers. But one international nonprofit organisation has disentangled the concept of accountability through 15 years of experience in more than 40 countries. It has established that support for good governance can be "projectised" to allow for donor countries to contribute. Its three-step approach is to get detailed local evidence on service delivery, to build local skills and to put the evidence to work to put pressure on for change.

Community Information, Empowerment and Transparency (Ciet) started as a postgraduate medical research centre in Mexico, supported by the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, in the 1980s. Its social assessments, designed to support good governance, are rooted in the science of epidemiology. This is usually thought of in the context of diseases and their cause, but its founding executive director, Neil Andersson, and his colleagues have adapted it to tackle what they see as the social cancer of corruption, an illness that cuts off the poor from access to basic services.

With the scientific rigour of formal epidemiological research, large household surveys document the use of public services, such as education, and their costs, official and unofficial. A second part of the assessment covers the views of public service workers. Once data are analysed, they are shared in group discussions in the communities, often leading to local action to make things work better. The media play an important role in making evidence and local solutions known to a larger audience, putting pressure on policymakers for reform. Repeated assessments monitor progress, which encourage people to be still more active as they see that their opinions count.

In the hands of national governments these assessments can locate the leaks of public resources, find local ways to plug them, and check progress through follow-up assessments. They also give people a say in decisions that affect their lives.

Education has been the focus of Ciet assessments in Costa Rica, Nepal, Nicaragua, Uganda, South Africa and Pakistan. Despite official policies to remove fees in these countries, educational costs were substantial.

In the Nicaraguan Ciet assessment, 86% of parents said they had to pay bribes to the teachers on top of an unofficial enrolment fee. A similar assessment in Uganda, where school fees were supposedly eliminated, showed parents of nearly half of the children attending government primary school paid for "extra tuition".

In Pakistan the increase in school enrolment over the past decade has been slow and patchy. In three of the country's four provinces, the Ciet assessment found that less than half of girls enrol in school compared with 50-80% of boys, depending on the province. It does not have to be this way. In Rawalpindi district, in Punjab, not a typical district but very much part of Pakistan, nearly 90% of children go to school, and there is no gender gap in enrolment, attendance or drop-out rates.

Successive education reforms in Pakistan have eliminated enrolment and tuition fees, paid for free text books and removed obligatory uniforms for primary school. fields.bodyText: Girls enrolled in rural Sindh usually say "yes" when asked if they like primary school. They belong to the literate minority in Pakistan. But their eyes darken as they start to talk about the "daily charges for invisible things", in exchange for an education. They pay for teacher attendance, fees for fake school committees, and for text books and tuition that are supposed to be free. Some girls have to do domestic favours in the homes of their male teachers if they can't make the cash payments. Petty corruption is less in the news than grand corruption of contract rigging and fraud. In petty corruption the individual amounts may be small, yet put together they add an invisible but crippling financial burden to public services. Unofficial charges, non-attendance of service providers and sale of supposedly free drugs were found to drain away no less than 70% of public resources invested in the health sector in one country. In Pakistan, as in many other countries where petty corruption is commonplace in public services, unofficial extra charges add a cost that puts education out of reach for many of the country's poor. Together with teacher absence and phantom payrolls, this leaks educational resources away from their intended use.
