webTitle: After the jeers, PM finds friends in the cheep seats

fields.headline: After the jeers, PM finds friends in the cheep seats
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report
Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: After the slow handclap and barracking at the WI, Tony Blair must have been delighted to get back to the relative peace and quiet of prime minister's question time - and a nice, soft, easy audience, the Conservative party.
fields.body:
After the slow handclap and barracking at the WI, Tony Blair must have been delighted to get back to the relative peace and quiet of prime minister's question time - and a nice, soft, easy audience, the Conservative party.

He was helped in this by many of his colleagues, who made chicken noises. Rather well, I thought. They were responding, in their measured and thoughtful way, to an intervention from David Amess, the Tory MP for Southend, who used to be member for Basildon.

Mr Amess is often jeered for having taken the "chicken run" and for the fact that he endlessly praises the astonishing wisdom, maturity and perception of whichever voters he happens to represent this week.

Taunted repeatedly, most recently on Tuesday, he yesterday made the fatal error of praising the voters of Basildon, almost as if they were as astute as those who have the good fortune to live in Southend. It was a temptation too far for Steve Pound, Labour MP for Ealing North.

"Quark, quark, quark, kwup, kwup, kwup, kweep," he remarked. Other Labour MPs quickly joined in.

"Will the prime minister study the election results in Basildon, where Labour lost overall control... " bellowed Mr Amess. "Kwoor, kwoor, wuck, wuck, waaark!" commented various Labour members.

Betty Boothroyd was appalled. Everyone tells her that prime ministers' questions sounds like a barnyard, but they don't mean it literally. "Mr Amess will be heard!" she thundered, in a tone which might have been apt if he had been delivering the Gettysburg address rather than a feeble piece of party political drivel.

Madam Speaker resumed her seat and began to glower at the Labour benches, trying to see who was making the noises, assisted by one of the clerks, who appeared to be murmuring names in her direction. As her gaze swept over them, the noise level was reduced to a discreet "wuck, wurrrp, wuck, wuck, wook", with several guilty members hiding their mouths behind their hands.

When she turned away the noise level suddenly shot up with a loud, joyous "Wark, wark, wuck, WRURK!"

(Meanwhile Mr Amess was still banging on, seemingly forever. He ran through a list of all Labour MPs who had said something remotely discouraging about the government's performance over the past few weeks. "Guggble, guggble, kwok" said the MPs in reply.)

Then the Speaker moved her gaze once more to scan for the avian miscreants, and the noise dropped off again. "It was like the Doppler effect," one Labour MP told me afterwards, before returning to peck at his seed.

All of which rather hid the fact that the prime minister had a good afternoon to follow his terrible morning. Mr Hague tried to insert a jemmy between him and his most powerful rival. Complimenting him on the birth of baby Leo, he said: "We all know how difficult it can be: sleepless nights, bags of noise, a refusal to settle down, and that was just the chancellor!" he said, but the punchline was predictable and gave Mr Blair no trouble.

And he'll know what to do if he ever addresses the WI again: flap his arms and wave his wattles at them.

(Meanwhile, in a rare moment of silence, I heard the voice of my friend Mickey Fabricant shout, "Three wasted years!" Mr Fabricant should be careful. I have just been sent pictures of him wearing a pirate hat and playing with plastic boats in the company of various small children. It is not a pretty sight. There are many Guardian readers in Lichfield, and they don't miss anything.)

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Don't call us . . .

At the end of last week Oftel published its second report naming the most complained about service providers. All our best friends are there. Cable & Wireless Communications, which was mopped up by ntl last week, makes fourth place with 0.54 complaints per 10,000 customers reaching Oftel in the six months since October (the figures don't include complaints made directly to the companies). In third place is Cellular Operations and its trading partner 1st Line, with 5.69 complaints per 10,000. Second, with 192.4, came Next Call. And top for the second time is LocalTel (now part of World Online), which has managed an eye-catching 321.6 complaints per 10,000. Chief among them is the difficulty in contacting its call centres and total inaction should the customer succeed.

This sounds familiar to Alan Grahame of London, a LocalTel customer whose phone suddenly stopped working shortly after his son was put in intensive care. He spent three hours trying to contact LocalTel's customer services and a further 25 minutes being passed around its phone network before someone agreed to act. Afterwards, Grahame was promised a conciliatory call from a senior official but has heard nothing.

LocalTel's somewhat leisurely approach to communications appears to have improved little, despite the fact that their free phone number has switched to local call rates. "Their complicated menu system takes up to five minutes to inform you that all its operators are busy," says Grahame. "As LocalTel gets a cut of the call price that makes a nice little earner."

Consumer contacted LocalTel's press officer five weeks ago for a comment but has heard nothing to date, despite two reminder messages. The interesting question is, what does the regulator, which has already admonished LocalTel for its tardy responses, propose to do about under-performing companies? The answer is very little other than post up bulletins about their misdemeanour. "We speak to them on an informal basis about problems, but their licences are not dependent on standards of service because competition is the best regulator," says a spokeswoman. "It's not for the government to try to run commercial companies; we want consumers to vote with their feet."

Gas goof

Those who have escaped a head-on with their phone company might find themselves enduring a practice run courtesy of the gas giants. As with telecoms, the privatised industry has led to some exotic interpretations of customer service. For 19 months Keith Taylor of Southampton has been receiving increasingly threatening demands from Scottish Power, culminating in a letter from its solicitors claiming unpaid electricity bills. The difficulty is that Taylor has never been a customer of the company, but phone calls and letters have failed to convince it of the fact. In desperation Taylor contacted the gas watchdog Ofgem and the result was another bill, this time for a non-existent gas account.

"They've gone and signed up the wrong chap by keying in the wrong postcode," says a weary spokesman from Scottish Power. "Mr Taylor was transferred to us and by the time we cottoned on to the fact, he was legally a customer. We have made a poor show of it and the matter has been resolved."

Lack of energy

David Parker of Redhill in Surrey is, in contrast, longing to be billed by Independent Energy. He signed up in June last year and has yet to hear a peep, despite several imploring letters and phone calls.

Independent Energy blames computer problems that messed up its billing system. They are, it says soothingly, "close to being resolved". Parker will soon get his bill and an unpleasant shock it will be with a year-long debt to settle. "But there's no way that we'll make him pay at once," says a spokesman. "We're prepared to take an understanding approach."

Oops, wrong account

Georgia and Phil Bailey are also facing a crippling debt through no fault of their own. The latter arranged for £350 of household money to be transferred from his account at the Halifax to Georgia's account at Lloyds each month, but first time round the Halifax paid it into the wrong account. It re-credited Phil promptly, then re-credited him a second time and only demanded it back when the Baileys had unwittingly spent it. "They've finally agreed to let us repay it at £25 a month which, as our budget is so tight, means we'll exceed our overdraft limit with each payment," says Bailey. "The Halifax has refused to increase our limit which means we'll go further into the red every month."

Consumer massages the bank's conscience and the result is a fulsome apology for its inefficiency and the promise of a doubled overdraft to ease the payments.

Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Matthaus fit for opening match
fields.trailText: Veteran sweeper Lothar Matthaus will be fit to play in Germany's opening Euro 2000 match against Romania on Sunday - despite again injuring a thigh in the friendly against Liechtenstein.
fields.body:
Veteran sweeper Lothar Matthaus will be fit to play in Germany's opening Euro 2000 match against Romania on Sunday - despite again injuring a thigh in the friendly against Liechtenstein.

Germany's team doctor Hans-Wilhelm Muller-Wohlfarht said: "There is no problem. Lothar can play - his substitution was simply a precautionary measure."

The 39-year-old former skipper tore a muscle in his right thigh 11 days ago, but it was muscle tightness on the other leg which ended his participation in the Liechtenstein game after just 30 minutes.

Matthaus said that he would start training again today, when the Germans get to their headquarters at Vaals in the Netherlands

fields.headline: A bedside companion
fields.trailText: Louis de Bernières is just home from a week in Italy. Yes, a lovely week, thank you, though the weather was disappointing. Not that it made much difference to Louis, since he spent the whole week on a bedside table, sandwiched between Roy Hattersley and the Michelin guide.
fields.body:
Louis de Bernières is just home from a week in Italy. Yes, a lovely week, thank you, though the weather was disappointing. Not that it made much difference to Louis, since he spent the whole week on a bedside table, sandwiched between Roy Hattersley and the Michelin guide.

But by now he is used to that, since it's happened so often since I acquired him in late 1997. That was just too late for Louis to come on our trip to Florence in October, which I see from my list was pleasantly occupied by Sebastian Faulks - that must have been Birdsong - and David Newsome's The Victorian World Picture. He was due to have gone to Jordan early the following year along with Thomas Love Peacock and Ted Hughes's version of Ovid, but that got cancelled.

Never mind: our next port of call was Pembrokeshire, where there's plenty of time for reading since it rains so much of the time. An ideal climate, surely, for starting on Captain Corelli. Except that I found in a bookshop at St David's cathedral Giraldus Cambrensis's ripe account of his journeys through Wales in the late 12th century. As assertive in death as in life, he pushed his way to the front of the queue, and that was the end of Louis.

For several months he sat patiently on the pending shelf while his next move was plotted. And, sure enough, when we set off for Lake Garda, Louis was booked for a place in the travelling bag. Except that when the moment came to pack him, he'd gone missing and Thomas Love Peacock had the week to himself. Next up were Vienna, Prague and Budapest, with coach journeys linking the cities. Ideal to get down to Captain Corelli. But only when I had finished a new life of Lewis Carroll, begun before the holiday started. And I'd also packed Giles Foden's novel about Idi Amin. Somehow between them Lewis and Idi squeezed out poor Louis.

That brought him back to the top of the list for Lake Maggiore this May. But one often needs - don't you think? - to get into the way of reading novels after some time away from them, and for any journalist nothing does that so well as a book about Fleet Street. So the book for the plane was Ink, by John Preston, which lasted a further couple of days. After which it seemed wrong not to use the chance of prime time on the balcony in the early mornings to read something substantial, of the kind one cannot attempt during the working round. That meant one of two books about great Victorians: Karl Marx, by Francis Wheen, or Roy Hattersley's Blood and Fire, the story of William and Catherine Booth and their Salvation Army. But the Wheen had somehow unpacked itself, which left the floor to Hattersley. And very good it is too: hugely researched, right down to the Nottingham Weekly Gazette and the East London Evangelist, and for someone you'd never expect to find in the Coach and Horses flogging copies of War Cry, stupendously fair to the Booths.

Once you get in the mood, of course, you can run two books in tandem: the Hattersley for the early mornings and a novel for wet afternoons. Which of course was going to be Louis: except that I'd also brought An Equal Music, by Vikram Seth. So before I settled down with the Captain I took a quick peek at the crits on the back of the Seth. "The finest novel about music ever written in English" - the Daily Telegraph. Could that really be true? Has the Telegraph read all the others? "A masterpiece... as clear, lovely and civilised as a Schubert quartet" - the Mail. Only one way to find out if such wild claims were true. So I tasted the opening chapter. Then the second, then the third. And was hooked. What empathy; what a sense of music; and above all what faultless judgment, just like one of those Haydn trios adored by Seth's hero, where you cannot imagine one note being changed for the better...

So now Louis is back on the pending shelf. Not back among other novels, like E Annie Proulx, whose The Shipping News accompanied us on most of our trips in the middle 90s, always returning unread; but on the shelf which contains those books I still really intend to get round to. (This is not the same as the guilt shelf, which mainly contains valued presents too big to start on until retirement and books by one's friends which one ought to have read but now possibly never will). Louis is now enjoying a favoured spot on the pending shelf along with the memoirs of Berlioz (£3 second-hand from Darcy Books of Devizes) Andrew Roberts's life of Lord Salisbury, Ted Hughes's version of Ovid (still) and quite a lot more. The sun through the front room window just touches Louis lightly at around 11 o'clock, which is more than it ever did in Italy.

Once you get in the mood, of course, you can run two books in tandem: the Hattersley for the early mornings and a novel for wet afternoons. Which of course was going to be Louis: except that I'd also brought An Equal Music, by Vikram Seth. So before I settled down with the Captain I took a quick peek at the crits on the back of the Seth. "The finest novel about music ever written in English" - the Daily Telegraph. Could that really be true? Has the Telegraph read all the others? "A masterpiece... as clear, lovely and civilised as a Schubert quartet" - the Mail. Only one way to find out if such wild claims were true. So I tasted the opening chapter. Then the second, then the third. And was hooked. What empathy; what a sense of music; and above all what faultless judgment, just like one of those Haydn trios adored by Seth's hero, where you cannot imagine one note being changed for the better... So now Louis is back on the pending shelf. Not back among other novels, like E Annie Proulx, whose The Shipping News accompanied us on most of our trips in the middle 90s, always returning unread; but on the shelf which contains those books I still really intend to get round to. (This is not the same as the guilt shelf, which mainly contains valued presents too big to start on until retirement and books by one's friends which one ought to have read but now possibly never will). Louis is now enjoying a favoured spot on the pending shelf along with the memoirs of Berlioz (£3 second-hand from Darcy Books of Devizes) Andrew Roberts's life of Lord Salisbury, Ted Hughes's version of Ovid (still) and quite a lot more. The sun through the front room window just touches Louis lightly at around 11 o'clock, which is more than it ever did in Italy. david.mckie@theguardian.com

webTitle: Rape Me passed uncut in France

fields.headline: Rape Me passed uncut in France
fields.trailText: Those on the look-out for the next big movie controversy would be well advised keep close tabs on the explicit French movie Rape Me, which has just been passed for cinematic release by the French censors.
fields.body:
Those on the look-out for the next big movie controversy would be well advised keep close tabs on the explicit French movie Rape Me, which has just been passed for cinematic release by the French censors. The latest word from those connected with the film is that negotiations are currently underway to distribute the film in the UK at some point later this year.

Rape Me was one of the few genuine talking points at this year's Cannes Film Festival, where it was subsequently bought up for distribution in 35 countries, including Italy and Spain. But there had been speculation that the French censors were poised to slap the film with a prohibitive X-rating. In the event, its surprisingly lenient certificate excludes only those viewers under 16. Vincent Maraval, head of the movie's sales agent, Wild Bunch, hailed the decision as a triumph of forward-thinking. "It shows that France is a civilised country," he said. "The censors realise the film is good, that it represents a certain subculture in France and it's aim isn't to excite people like a porn film."

That said, Rape Me boasts some impeccable porn credentials. Taking its title from a song by grunge gods Nirvana, the movie is the feature debut of cult author Virginie Despentes (pictured), who co-directed it with former porn-star Coralie Trinh-Thi. Furthermore, it stars two adult-movie actresses in the lead roles as two wild-child nymphomaniacs on a "sex hunt" through France's seedy underbelly. Viewers who caught Rape Me at Cannes testify that the movie contains scenes of explicit sex and violence.

Rape Me is the latest of a recent crop of French-language pictures to have whipped up controversy in the UK. In the last couple of years there has been the release of nihilistic Seul Contre Tous (which featured genuine porn-movie footage), Sitcom (erect genitalia) and Catherine Breillat's Romance (ditto, plus the hulking presence of porn star Rocco Siffredi). Rape Me has its work cut out if it is to out-shine such illustrious company. But early word suggests that it might just succeed.

webTitle: Black armbands, Graham Yallop and Radio 4 plays

fields.headline: Black armbands, Graham Yallop and Radio 4 plays
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Why were the Zimbabwean players all wearing black armbands during the second Test at Trent Bridge? asks Vid Gunapala
fields.body:
Why were the Zimbabwean players all wearing black armbands during the second Test at Trent Bridge? asks Vid Gunapala

There were actually three reasons. On the first morning of the match, the team heard that Tony Oates, a farmer, had been killed in a shoot-out defending his home. He was well-known to the tourists because his son, Jason, has played first-class cricket in Zimbabwe (and one match for Zimbabwe A). He is also reported to have been a great party-giver who often entertained the team. Then news came through that Guy Whittall's aunt, Julia, had died of cancer. She was the mother of Andy Whittall, the Test offspinner who missed this tour but had been commentating on the Tests for Channel 4. Finally, allrounder Gary Brent (who spent quite a lot of time on the field at Trent Bridge as 12th man after Stuart Carlisle broke a finger) learned that his mother had suffered a fatal heart attack.

What was the Test and first-class record of Graham Yallop, that elegant Australian batsman from the 1970s and 1980s? asks Dennis Glover from Canberra, Australia

Yallop, a hard-hitting left-hander, won 39 Test caps, scoring 2756 runs at an average of 41.13. He made eight Test centuries, the highest 268 against Pakistan at Melbourne, his home ground, in 1983-84. In all first-class cricket he made 11,615 runs at 45.90, with 30 centuries. Despite those more-than-useful batting statistics he is probably best remembered, rather unfairly, as the captain who lost an Ashes series 5-1. That was in 1978-79, when many of the leading Australians were banned because of their involvement with World Series Cricket. Yallop's second-stringers struggled against Mike Brearley's England side. He later went on a rebel tour of South Africa.

I am writing a play for Radio 4 and need to know the most famous player(s) of 1913 for a bit of dialogue. Can you help? asks Jan Hartman

There weren't any Tests in 1913, so cricket-lovers in England would probably have been talking about the County Championship, which was won by Kent, captained by the amateur EW Dillon. For many years the tall, elegant left-hander Frank Woolley was the pick of Kent's batsmen, and in 1913 he made 1760 runs at 45 (and also took 83 wickets at 18). But he wasn't Kent's leading runscorer that year: it was HTW "Wally" Hardinge, with 2037 runs at 41. Hardinge was an interesting character who also played football for England, and worked for John Wisden & Co (publishers of the Almanack) for many years as a sales rep. Kent's leading bowler was Colin "Charlie" Blythe (167 wickets at 16), a slow left-arm bowler who was killed at Passchendaele in 1917. Kent (110 points) won the Championship by 15 points from runners-up Yorkshire, whose outstanding performer was Major Booth (Major was his name, not his rank), who scored 1228 runs and took 181 wickets, more than anyone else that season. He also died in the Great War, by which time Major Booth had become a Second Lieutenant.

Overall English cricket's "megastars" of 1913 were probably the Surrey opener Jack Hobbs Ð in the early stages of a career that would see him still playing for England at rising 50 Ð and the controversial bowler Sydney Barnes, who had given up county cricket by then, in favour of a lucrative club contract, but was still good enough to play for England (the following winter, 1913-14, he took a record 49 wickets in only four Tests in South Africa).

I am trying to find out some information about an Australian cricketer called Andrew Ian Butcher. I believe that he played a few games for South Australia in the late 1980s and a couple of one-dayers for Australia in about 1989. Do you have any record of his statistics? asks Stephen Wise

There's no trace of an Andrew Ian Butcher in the Wisden records. No-one of that name seems to have played first-class cricket in Australia (and certainly not a Test or one-day international). Gideon Haigh, the editor of "Wisden Cricketers' Almanack Australia", has looked through available records for youth teams and can't find him either, although he cautions that there are a few gaps in the records in the 1980s.

Can you explain the complicated points system in the English County Championship? asks Giles Venn

The points system has changed a lot over the years - and, predictably, has changed again for the current season. The easy part is that the side winning the match gets 12 points, and both sides receive four points in a drawn game (six points each for a tie; no points for losing). The complicated bit is the bonus points, which are only available in the first 130 overs of each side's first innings. You can earn a maximum of five batting bonus points, for passing 200, 250, 300, 350 and 400. And you get bowling points - a maximum of three - for taking three, six and nine wickets. So the maximum number of points a county can score in a game is 20.

Where was Bill Ponsford noted for fielding? asks Michael Ford

Bill Ponsford, who was born in 1900, was a prolific batsman - the only man to have scored two quadruple-centuries in first-class cricket. His first-class average is 65.18, one of the highest on record. In 29 Tests he made 2122 runs at 48.22, with 110 in his first Test (v England, Sydney, 1924-25) and 266 in his last (v England, The Oval, 1934), and five other centuries besides. Ponsford is often described as a heavy-footed batsman, so you might assume he would field close to the wicket (he was also a top-class baseball player, specialising as a catcher). However, the noted Australian writer Ray Robinson, in his book "Between Wicket", talks of Herbert Sutcliffe being caught at Brisbane in 1928-29 by "the sure-handed Ponsford at long leg". And the 1935 "Wisden Almanack", in making Ponsford one of the Five Cricketers of the Year for 1934, noted that: "If tending towards the end to lose some of his pace, he was for a long time splendid in the deep field, and, like nearly all Australians, could throw beautifully."

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read his latest Ask Steven, which tells of how Viv Richards missed out on a triple-century,click here

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Your daily diet of transfer talk, with a sneaky side-order of gossip 'n' chips
fields.trailText: Gareth Southgate wants out of Aston Villa. The England international faxed a transfer request to Villa Park last night after talking to manager John Gregory. Southgate told the Daily Telegraph: "It is not a decision that has been easy, but my mind is made up. I want to play in the biggest games possible and challenge for the Championship." Manchester United, Leeds and Chelsea are all expected to compete for the 29-year-old's signature.
fields.body:
Gareth Southgate wants out of Aston Villa. The England international faxed a transfer request to Villa Park last night after talking to manager John Gregory. Southgate told the Daily Telegraph: "It is not a decision that has been easy, but my mind is made up. I want to play in the biggest games possible and challenge for the Championship." Manchester United, Leeds and Chelsea are all expected to compete for the 29-year-old's signature.

The Sun suggests that Villa could also be about to lose striker Julian Joachim. They quote the 25-year-old as saying: "I just feel I cannot play for John Gregory anymore and I don't want to. I'm disappointed in the manager and club."

Leeds are looking to partner Harry Kewell with Australian team-mate Mark Viduka next season. The Daily Mail believes that the Yorkshire club are close to completing a £6.5m deal for the Celtic striker, while Teamtalk quote him as saying: "The English Premiership is one of the most high profile leagues in the world and anyone would like to play in it." New Celtic manager Martin O'Neill is to talk to Viduka in the next few weeks in an attempt to persuade him to stay at Parkhead.

Lee Clark is set to return to the North East in a £2.5m move to Middlesbrough. The Sun reports that Fulham midfielder Clark is desperate to leave London and that Bryan Robson will grant his wishes after failing to complete Juninho's permanent transfer from Atletico Madrid.

Bobby Robson wants to play Carl Cort up front with Alan Shearer next season. The 22-year-old submitted a transfer request to Wimbledon this week and, according to the Daily Express, Newcastle are willing to pay £7m to sign him.

The Mirror reports that Peter Schmeichel could be the man to fill Fabien Barthez's gloves at Monaco. The paper suggests that the former Manchester United star almost joined the French champions last season, before Barthez decided to stay at the club. Monaco are believed to be ready to offer Schmeichel £40,000-a-week to sign.

Muzzy Izzet intends to leave Leicester when his contract expires at the end of next season. The Mirror believes the Turkish international's decision could force the Foxes to cash in on him this summer.

Chelsea are to offer George Weah a new one-year contract at the club, Planet Football reports.

fields.headline: Pass Notes: Douglas Murray
fields.standfirst: The lowdown on the precocious author of a new Bosie biography
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
Age: 19.

Status: Undergraduate at Magdalen college, Oxford.

I know what this is about. Young Douglas went to inner-city comp, made it through the tortuous interview process to the dreaming spires and is now being held up as . . . Stop it! This is not an Oxbridge elitism pass notes!

What is it, then? Well, the second-year student has written a biography of that paragon of anti-elitism, Bosie, Lord Alfred Douglas; it's available in all good bookshops today.

Gordon Brown will love this. So why this fascination with Oscar Wilde's young lover? Certainly he has few literary merits. Actually, young Douglas finds Bosie's sonnets to be "astonishingly fine".

Clearly a man with intellectual pretensions. Indeed. While his Etonian mates were raving it up at Glastonbury and in Notting Hill, Murray was sniffing out information on the the little-trodden Bosie trail.

And do we expect much from this biography? The publisher, Hodder & Stoughton, certainly does. It is already claiming that this is "one of the most eagerly awaited biographies of the year".

Wait a minute - Magdalen college, precocious youth, good God! They even share the name Douglas! Yes, Hodder is gleefully playing up the parallels. Murray, however, insists: "I never wanted to be Bosie."

Surely the public would never buy that guff. Well, the Daily Telegraph was caught yesterday describing Murray as "nicely raffish". It also gushed about his musical talent - he plays a mean bassoon, apparently.

Worrying. It gets worse. From the age of 14, Murray spent two years persuading Jack Straw to release Bosie's prison correspondence. Once the book was written he was wooed by superstar editor Tina Brown for Miramax's fledgling publishing arm.

Ah, his parents must be proud. Probably. But he claims they were expecting him to pen a symphony rather than a biography.

Do say: "How wonderful when true talent rises to the top."

Don't say: "Bleeding Oxford toffs."

fields.headline: 'Now what was I saying again?'
fields.standfirst: Nothing really happens in Harland Miller's debut novel. But that hasn't stopped him becoming the new star of BritLit, bagging a £150,000 advance in the process.  Emma Brockes  tries to follow his conversation
fields.trailText: Nothing really happens in Harland Miller's debut novel. But that hasn't stopped him becoming the new star of BritLit, bagging a £150,000 advance in the process.
fields.body:
Harland Miller is dressed as if illustrating a lecture entitled Fashion: a brief history. He enters the Maison Bertaux in Soho carrying a copy of Gunter Grass's Local Anaesthetic. He's in Larry Hagman shades, big as wing-mirrors, a tight V-neck sweater and the pointed, slip-on shoes that were fashionable among the new romantic bands of the early 80s. His hair is a tribute to the blond icons of the jazz age. His voice, nasal and effete, is a cross between Jarvis Cocker's and Derek Draper's. He is a 36-year-old artist who has just published a novel and tends to his image as to one of his wacky installations.

The effect Miller has had on both the publishing world and the celebrities who rely on it to supply them with intellectual party guests, has been explosive. His charms are amplified by the £150,000 advance he received for his first novel, Slow Down Arthur, Stick to Thirty, a coming-of-age story set in York in the 70s, encompassing such issues as teenage drug taking and wanting to be David Bowie. He has an ear for the visceral simile. A character hocking up phlegm is said to "cradle the oyster on his tongue" before spitting it into the sink. He can knock out a good epigram too. "Kid Glover was 16," he writes, "trying to make one coffee last for ever and shortly about to collapse face down in the snow."

What he can not do is provide a written-through narrative that prevents the reader from drifting away at page 10, suddenly reminded of how short life is. Slow Down Arthur is at best a wry reminder of the coach journey back from a school trip, at worst a directionless ramble stuck on the myth that the secret of cult literature is to forgo any semblance of plot.

None of this matters, however, when one is confronted with the spectacle of Miller in the flesh. If he brings credibility to his novel, it is by raising the possibility that it is not a piece of cynically written BritLit, but a more straightforward distillation of his personality. The book has no linearity because Miller cannot get to the end of a sentence without indefinitely stalling on a lost word or entangling himself in an endless domino run of anecdotes, each one further removed from the point of the conversation. In response to a question about how he came to write the novel, he comes out with the following.

"It started off in quite a jokey way, when I was using text as part of my artwork. There's a . . . I can't remember the name now. There was a comedian who had a tragic life. He spoke like this." Tony Hancock?

"Yes. He always wanted to be an intellectual. He did something called the Missing Page which was a famous sketch with that other bloke . . . what was his name?" Sid James?

"Yeah. So I got this idea of having a crucial page that you read. That introduced you to the plot."

What was on the crucial page? "I don't think it really worked in that way. It was more like a sort of a, sort of a . . ." (he pauses for an age, before abandoning the sentence and zooming in on the context in which he was writing the mysterious, missing page.)

"I was living in Berlin with a guy called Fergus Bremner. Berlin reminded me a bit of Salford in Manchester - the trams. We had this huge flat, so huge that we had an old bike we used to ride from one end to the other when the phone rang. We fell out, so I was often at the furthest end of the studio from him, so that when the phone went, he'd get on the bike and yell, Harland, it's the bloody phone."

He continues: "There was a squat, with people who made vehicles into mad affairs, put insect's heads on the front of them. For them, expression was like, part of their lives. But what happened was that they became commercial, because the government was in the process of turning the buildings into restaurants, so those with their eyes on the main chance started doing commercial art. Gentrification."

A popular reading of this inarticulacy, if it is accompanied by good bone structure and a sufficiently iconic dress sense, is that it is the mark of unschooled genius. Miller has been seized on in certain quarters as an Andy Warhol-type figure, a man tongue-tied by the sheer depth of his brilliance. "Harland is a dream package," gushes an anonymous but "very fashionable" friend of his in Vogue this month. "He's an artist, he's handsome, he's stylish, he knows everyone there is to know in cool London and they all think he's divine." What's more, he's from Yorkshire. His father used to work in a sweet factory. He has the pluck and romance of the dirty-faced angel and like his friend Jarvis Cocker, speaks in the authentic voice of a man who has known real poverty.

At the age of 17 Miller moved south to Epsom, on the outskirts of London, and tried to establish himself as an artist. His memories of the period are eccentrically selective. "It was out in the middle of nowhere," he recalls. "My landlady was Chinese and had this skin condition; the pigmentation didn't take and her skin was like camouflage. Different colours." Suddenly he jumps forward to the landlady he had while living in Berlin, 10 years later. "She was the widow of Bertold Brecht's official biographer. Her son was a really tall guy and the room was full of Brecht posters, fantastic, one on top of the other so that there was no wall showing. They said 'You can't move in for a week', so I went to stay in a squat."

A lengthy description of the squat follows, before Miller brings home the punchline. "I went back to the room after a week, wondering why they'd made me wait. When they opened the door, I saw that they had covered over the beautiful walls with white woodchip and put up a shelf, in my honour. I had to pretend I liked it."

There are other anecdotes, told in this fashion, attending Miller's vagabond journeys through Morocco and Tangiers, New York and the north circular. When asked what he was pursuing on these travels, he refers to an episode that happened to him as a child. He had his appendix out and was kept in hospital for three months, during the summer. His mother used to visit him every day and read aloud the short stories of Somerset Maugham. He would drift in and out of consciousness to the lull of her voice. "It was hot and everything and because of the morphine, it was all a bit William Burroughsey, hearing bits of Maugham interspersed with the Famous Five books I was reading."

The experience did two things: forced a state of introspection on him that he never shook off, and persuaded him that mild delirium is a natural state for the artist. "My life used to be characterised by space and time. I'd look in a shop window and wonder how long I'd been looking in." This feeling of "lost time", he says, was identified by Danny Boyle, whose production company is making the film version, as the primary strength of the book. "The production guys said that the fact that nothing really happens is the book's strength, which I thought was great. I was worried that they would make each character go through an evolution, so that this character has to get the girl, or this one has to die or kick drugs."

He hates west London, finds the idea of "having to go for cappuccinos the whole time" irksome and would rather hang around north London with his wife Jane and his nine-month-old baby. "I live in Mornington Crescent. I looked all over the place and when I found Mornington Crescent I thought, yeah, because it's a nowhere place, I like the anonymity. I like to go out and buy milk without bumping into people. The train station is like a ghost station, you go straight through it. It's like, subliminal." But he still dresses like a man who wants to be noticed.

webTitle: Orange prize winner rejects claims of plagiarism

fields.headline: Orange prize winner rejects claims of plagiarism
fields.trailText: Linda Grant, who on Wednesday won the Orange prize for her novel When I Lived in Modern Times, last night rejected allegations that she plagiarised the work of an American academic.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Linda Grant, who on Wednesday won the Orange prize for her novel When I Lived in Modern Times, last night rejected allegations that she plagiarised the work of an American academic.

"What should have been the happiest day of my life has been completely destroyed," she said last night. "Instead of celebrating, I spent it literally with my stomach lurching."

Her novel, about a young London woman who becomes enmeshed in Zionist politics in Tel Aviv in the aftermath of the second world war, confounded the bookmakers on Tuesday night, beating the favourite, Zadie Smith's White Teeth, to take the £30,000 prize. Ms Grant's novel was the unanimous choice of the judges.

Within hours of her success anonymous faxes were circulating to individuals and at least one national newspaper, alleging that Ms Grant, who is also a Guardian journalist, had stolen the work of American academic and author A J Sherman, by quoting verbatim chunks of his book Mandate Days, British Lives in Palestine 1918-1948, and would be sued for plagiarism.

Her agent, Derek Johns, said: "This looks like harassment, after Linda winning the big prize. The anonymity makes it all the more reprehensible."

In fact the paperback edition of When I Lived in Modern Times is printed with a prominently displayed, acknowledgement of Sherman's work, agreed after weeks of discussions between his publishers, Thames and Hudson, and Ms Grant's publishers, Granta. The acknowledgment reads: "I am greatly indebted to A J Sherman's invaluable research on this period. Some of the dialogue given to my colonial characters has come directly from letters, memoirs and diaries, from which he quotes."

Ms Grant said last night: "I used the sentences - never whole chunks - only as quotes from material he himself was quoting, to give colour and character to the dialogue. I never used a single original word of A J Sherman's, and I estimate that what I used amounted in total to about 0.04 per cent of the entire book."

She explained that her original text contained two and a half pages of acknowledgements of her many sources, including the Sherman book, and others, and taped conversations and interviews. After much discussion Granta decided that this scale of acknowledgement was uneccessary, since the book was fiction.

However, she did acknowledge Mandate Days in a piece she wrote for the Guardian Weekend, about the novel and her research for it. She subsequently received "a friendly letter" from A J Sherman, she said, saying he had read her book and enjoyed it, but had recognised the quotes from his own work and felt it should be acknowledged.

"I said yes, right, absolutely, and explained what I had originally done."

Protracted and detailed exchanges followed between the two publishers to agree the exact form of the acknowledgement, which will be included in all subsequent editions.

"I thought it was all done, finished, settled. I felt sick when it kept coming back. There was never any threat to sue, because there was never anything to sue about.

"I feel that this is now malicious harassment of me, and I cannot understand it."

It was not possible to contact a representative of Thames and Hudson last night.

Ms Grant was a surprise choice for the award. Many thought Zadie Smith's bravura survey of multicultural London, White Teeth, was a dead cert to take the title. But she had stirred controversy by references to the Tory leader William Hague's attacks on asylum seekers.

More on the Orange prize shortlisted books on the Guardian network at www.booksunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Gregarious tenant sought for the Woolfs' lair

fields.headline: Gregarious tenant sought for the Woolfs' lair
fields.trailText: The National Trust is seeking a tenant for the original "room of one's own", the writing room Virginia Woolf built on to the farmhouse in Sussex where she lived for more than 20 years until her death in 1941.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The National Trust is seeking a tenant for the original "room of one's own", the writing room Virginia Woolf built on to the farmhouse in Sussex where she lived for more than 20 years until her death in 1941.

Monk's House, at Rodmell in Sussex, is to let for £850 a month, roughly the rent of a one bedroom flat in a not particularly salubrious part of London, and £150 more than Leonard and Virginia Woolf paid for the house in 1919. The tenant will have the run of the glorious gardens, and a private wing of the house including main bedroom, guest rooms, kitchen and living room, and, of course, a study.

The house has a distinguished but tragic literary history. Woolf wrote most of her best known works there, including To The Lighthouse, and A Room of One's Own, sleeping with a pencil and paper by the bed in case inspiration struck in the night. She tried out what she had just written by speaking it aloud in her morning bath, to the bemusement of the cook in the kitchen directly below.

Writers and artists of the Bloomsbury set often gathered in the house, and her sister, Vanessa Bell, having painted every possible and impossible surface at nearby Charleston farmhouse, advised on the decor. There were weekend novel and play readings and criticisms of work in progress by many visiting writers. E M Forster came to stay, and got so cold he burned his trousers huddling close to the oil stove.

Woolf wrote that Monk's House would be their home "for ever and ever". In March 1941, having battled with mental illness all her life, she walked out through her cherished garden, followed the route of a favourite walk across the fields to the river Ouse, filled her pockets with stones, and drowned herself. Her ashes are buried in the garden.

Leonard Woolf lived on in the house until his death in 1969, when he left the property to the National Trust.

The ideal tenant would be literary, garden loving, and extremely sociable - half the house, not included in the lease, is preserved as the Woolfs had it. For six months of the year, the house and the gardens are open to the public three days a week, and can attract up to 250 visitors a day.

Even in winter tenants have to be able to cope with a constant stream of literary pilgrims trying to peer through the windows.

Paul Pontone, of the National Trust's regional office, said: "We are looking for very special people. It does bring incredible benefits, and it is a marvellous place to live in. Monk's House in particular really does have the feeling that Virginia Woolf might just have wandered out in to the garden and might come in again at any moment. But it does bring responsibilities, and we have to find tenants happy and willing to share their homes."

The previous tenants gave up the lease reluctantly last year due to job relocation. The house is temporarily being cared for by a member of the trust staff who is on maternity leave, and a new tenant is being sought from next winter.

A green-fingered tenant could earn a £5,000 rent rebate in return for maintaining the "size and shape and fertility and wildness" of the acres of garden, the feature which persuaded Woolf to buy the house - despite her misgivings about the small rooms, lack of hot water and electricity, and "distinctly bad" kitchen. "As for the earth closet, I was never shown it," she wrote. Prospective tenants will be reassured to learn that with the royalties earned from the novel Mrs Dalloway paid for two new lavatories and a bathroom. By 1931 Woolf was telling friends that Monk's House was now luxurious "to the point of electric fires in the bedrooms".

fields.headline: DeFreitas delighted, Munton morose (until yesterday)
fields.standfirst: This time, wisden.com turns the spotlight onto two former England seam bowlers. Both are veterans who changed counties over the winter: Phil DeFreitas and Tim Munton. If you have a candidate for this slot, email us at wisden@johnbrown.co.uk.
fields.trailText:
GOOD FORM
Phil DeFreitas Leicestershire
fields.body:
GOOD FORM
Phil DeFreitas Leicestershire

Phil DeFreitas's career turned full circle when he rejoined his first county, Leicestershire, during the winter. Boosted by a four-year contract, Daffy has been in the wicket-taking groove since the start of the Championship season, grabbing 20 wickets. In times past, early-season form like this was met with a recall to the England side but now, aged 34, he must content himself with trundling his way around the counties smug in the knowledge that, before the latest round of matches, he was sitting comfortably on top of the Championship wicket-takers' list (Anil Kumble was second with 16).

At a glance
2-85, 0-36, 2-84, 1-32, 3-49, 3-48, 3-36, 4-41, 1-22, 3-99, 0-40

In detail

34-7-85-2
v Leics, Ch'ship Div 1, Derby 9-2-36-0
 v Sussex, NUL Div 1, Leicester
34-13-84-2
v Lancs, Ch'ship Div 1, Manchester 9-1-32-1
v Lancs, NUL Div 1, Manchester 24.5-10-49-3 and 27-11-48-3
v Somerset, Ch'ship Div 1, Leicester 20.3-6-36-3 and 21-7-41-4
v Hants, Ch'ship Div 1, Leicester 9-2-22-1
v Kent, NUL Div 1, Leicester 38-9-99-3
v Durham, Ch'ship Div 1, Chester-le-Street 23-6-40-0
v Yorks, Ch'ship Div 1, Headingley

First-class wickets 20 at 24.10
One-day wickets 2 at 45.00
Total wickets 22 at 26.00

BAD FORM
Tim Munton Derbyshire

When Warwickshire veteran Tim Munton jumped ship in January, seduced by the prospect of kickstarting Derbyshire's Division One campaign, he was given DeFreitas's boots to fill at the county ground. New captain Dominic Cork hailed his arrival as "...a great signing for us - his experience and will undoubtedly bring us plenty of wickets." All looked rosy during Derbyshire's first four B&H matches when picking up six wickets for 77 runs in 36 overs. But then Durham belted him for five an over in the last match - and his form in May (just four wickets) went out of the window. Then, in June, something happened: Munton wrecked champions Surrey's first innings at Derby with figures of 7-34 off 19.5 overs - back to his economical and wicket-taking best. Rumours that he is a wisden.com user are unconfirmed.

fields.headline: Freddie, films and furtive foibles
fields.standfirst: Del Piero's mercy plea; Freddie's lonely nights; Karel's complicated system
fields.trailText: Del Piero's mercy plea; Freddie's lonely nights; Karel's complicated system.
fields.body:
A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"England have the class to go all the way" - Gary Lineker in the Sunday Telegraph

"England cannot win this summer's tournament" - Lineker yesterday

Inspires you with confidence, does it not?

THE EURO-TORIAL

Kevin Keegan has got it lucky. The England coach may have had to endure criticism from all quarters in the last week about tactical vagaries, defensive frailties, attacking failings and probably some midfield problems too, but he is by no means alone. The Germans were criticised again last night for only beating Liechtenstein 8-2. Much-fancied Spain are still without Raul, and were only capable of beating Luxembourg 1-0 yesterday. And as for the Italians, well...

"I have the feeling that if we were given more support we would do better," said Alessandro del Piero, as the fantastically fanatical Italian press continue to turn up the heat on the Azzurri after their 1-0 friendly defeat against Norway last weekend. "It's normal for journalists to be critical. It's their job," Del Piero rationalised with about a hundred cameras poking in his face. "It's also true that we have not been fantastic, but if you kill us with criticism it won't help us."

Of course, at the same time as chiding Dino Zoff's side, the press are also trying to predict who Italy will play in the quarter-finals. The fact that they have to get there first having seemingly passed the hacks by. "Everyone in Italy keeps talking about who we would prefer to play in the quarter-finals, England or Germany", Del Piero said. "But we do not always play as we should, and there is no reason why England and Germany will be the teams to qualify from their group." A necessary dose of realism, and the Euro couldn't agree more. Apart from that last bit of course.

SWEDISH MOVIE

Sweden coaches Tommy Söderberg and Lars Lagerback may have imposed a sex ban on their squad, but that's not going to stop saucy Arsenal reserve Freddie Ljungberg getting his rocks off, baby.

Freddie is all too aware that congress with a consenting adult ruins his performance on the pitch. "After having sex the night before I lose all feelings in my feet," he explained candidly. "I'm totally empty. I can't control the ball anymore."

Luckily, the selfless Ljungberg is willing to spend more time by himself for the good of his country. "I watch erotic movies the night before," he gently shuddered. "That doesn't affect my power." Hats off to Freddie's mature attitude, because you're no good to anyone when you're completely out of juice.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

OUR SPONSOR WRITES

Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. And £200 behind the bar. perfect. Win a £200 bar tab for Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Germany coach Erich Ribbeck, not content with giving Liechtenstein a good beating, took the opportunity yesterday to claim that blacks are better than whites at football. "It's like with dancing," he told Die Zeit. "A black person simply has different movements." What sort of dance movements the average tubby middle-aged white men can manage remained unclear.

Gerhard Aigner, Uefa's chief executive, last night flew into the Charleroi debate on an Acme jet pack which tragically ran out of fuel before he could get to the other side of a gorge. "At no time over the past three years did the authorities make any reservations with regards to the use of the stadia," he said from the middle of a cloud of dust.

"It is regrettable that the government in the United Kingdom has not introduced legislation which would make it possible to stop registered hooligans from travelling", Mr Aigner went on on the same day that the first registered English hooligans were turned away at the Dutch border. Mr Aigner then took receipt of a ticking brown package marked 'Lots of love, HM Government'.

The Czech Republic's star midfielder Pavel Nedved was forced out of training yesterday after his left ankle flared up. "Why are you always coming home so late," the ankle said. "I haven't seen you all week. Something's missing from this relationship and I'm this far from walking out." Nedved is expected to be fit for the Czech's first game against Holland on Sunday.

The first Euro 2000 arrest has been made. A Dutch supporter has had his collar felt after painting his rented house orange. "When the police arrived he painting the sidewalk in the colours of the Dutch flag," said Fons Catau, a director of the De Woonplaats housing agency in Enschede. "We cannot tolerate people who cause irreparable damage to our property. We understand the excitement about the tournament, but he was a little too enthusiastic."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Yawn... Karel Poborsky here. I'm right knackered, me. I've been up all night constructing a complicated rope, pulley and cage system to ensure Patrik Berger doesn't get anywhere near my Eurorumours again. If he tries yesterday's fresh tricks again he'll get what's coming to him and no mistake...

Gareth Southgate has faxed a transfer request to Aston Villa. "I have given everything to Villa over the last five years," he explained. "But if I am to achieve what I want to achieve in my career it is time to move on, I want to play in the biggest games possible and challenge for the championship." Chelsea, Arsenal, Leeds and Manchester United are all willing to pay £6m for the 29-year-old England defender.

Juventus are preparing a £30m bid for Real Madrid's Nicolas Anelka. They are prepared to sell Yugoslav striker Darko Kovacevic to Valencia for £14m to fund the deal.

Peter Schmeichel is being tipped to replace Manchester United-bound Fabien Barthez at Monaco. Schmeichel's side Sporting Lisbon have qualified for the Champions League, but tax-free wages of £40,000 a week may be too tempting to resist.

Muzzy Izzet has confirmed that he will leave Leicester when his contract expires at the end of next season. Chelsea will make an offer to the Filbert Street club for the Turkish international, but Izzet intends to take full advantage of the Bosman ruling.

What was that noise? I think I heard a scream. Hey, perhaps I've bagged me a Berger! Guffaw!

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

British Eurosport: European Championship Legends (8pm)
Relive that wonderful moment when Andreas Moller put Germany in the 1996 final and minced over to the crowd.

Road To Euro 2000 (9pm)
Watch Spain score an average of 43 goals per qualifying match.

Gillette Dream Team (12midnight)
A programme presumably about a razor-wielding centre back.

fields.headline: It's not curtains for Windows
fields.standfirst: The breakup of Microsoft is good news for the software giant and for the rest of the industry, writes Online editor Victor Keegan
fields.trailText:
The breakup of Microsoft is good news for the software giant and for the rest of the industry, writes Online editor Victor Keegan.
Special report
fields.body:
The decision to break up Microsoft into two parts - one company owning the Windows operating system and the other the software applications and browser - is good for the computer industry and, quite likely, for Microsoft itself in the long run. But it won't have any immediate impact on the real world. This is because of the company's decision to appeal not only against the breakup decision but also against the restraints on its behaviour that the judge imposed while the substantive issue was being finally resolved.

And then? The success of a split will critically depend on human behaviour. If it merely produces two Siamese twins, or parallel monopolies, each instinctively - one might almost say genetically - knowing what the other will do then the monopoly situation could worsen.

In the short run Microsoft's operating system will still reside on well over 90% of the world's personal computers and software packages such as the Excel spreadsheet and Word word processor will still have a similar market share. The system and the software will create demand for each other's products. Being two corporate units rather than one might tempt them to raise their prices faster (or reduce them less fast) than if they remained one integrated whole with the justice department breathing down its neck.

If Bill Gates decided to run the applications company, it is difficult to imagine him trying to undermine the Windows operating system he built up and protected for so long by trying aggressively to sell products to other emerging platforms such as the free alternative, Linux. And will the two companies still be based on the same campus at Redmond with the same or adjacent canteens?

Yet, properly handled, this judgment could unleash submerged creative forces among the thousands of highly skilled Microsoft employees. As Walter Mossberg of the Wall Street Journal has pointed out, some of Microsoft's best products, such as Internet Explorer and Money, have emerged when the company has faced real competitive pressures.

The breakup of Microsoft would open countless new opportunities for software developers all over the world. At the moment no venture capitalist is going fund startups trying to sell rival spreadsheets, word processors or browsers against the might of Microsoft's integrated monopoly. New products in these areas have very little chance against the integrated packages that Microsoft offers locked into its own operating system.

What beggars belief is Microsoft's almost total inability to see, let alone admit, that it has done anything wrong despite the devastating catalogue of uncompetitive practices that the department of justice has unearthed.

Microsoft's self-interest dictates that it will oppose this judgment. The longer it delays the start of the split, the longer it will take to finish it. And even when the split is completed it will be years before effective competition can undermine the armlock that both new companies will have on their customers. It will be a major decision for companies to abandon the Windows system they are locked into. During this time, the industry Microsoft has dominated for so long will be shifting its field of battle to the internet, which Microsoft hopes will strengthen its argument that the justice department does not understand the dynamics of the industry.

Above all, Microsoft has reason to stall because the longer it does the longer it hangs on to its monopoly profits. Remember, the bottom line of all this is that Microsoft has been earning far higher profits than it should have been in virtue of its monopoly position. Should some of them not be handed back so they do not continue to give the two companies an advantageous war chest?

If the judge started to threaten huge backdated fines based on the scale of its monopoly profits Microsoft might have a vested interest in taking the judgment of the court more seriously.

fields.headline: 'I'm first class' says disgraced doctor
fields.trailText: Disgraced gynaecologist Rodney Ledward today dismissed claims that he had killed six patients and described himself as a "first class consultant".
fields.body:
Disgraced gynaecologist Rodney Ledward today dismissed claims that he had killed six patients and described himself as a "first class consultant".

Nearly 200 patients have filed claims against the consultant, who was struck off the medical register two years ago after being found guilty of bungling 13 operations.

A government inquiry last week found that a litany of failings had allowed him to botch operations and endanger lives for years.

But Mr Ledward said from his home in Cork, Ireland: "In one sense the profession has got rid of a first class consultant."

"I put that without any hesitation, feet on the ground, looking in the mirror and no conceit whatsoever," he told the Today programme.

Dr Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, called Mr Ledward's interview with the Today programme "arrogant, conceited and deluded".

Mr Ledward claimed he made no more mistakes than any other consultant. "I have done a thousand and one operations over the last 30 years and, yes, I have had my share of mistakes," he said. "But you may find you have a similar picture in very many of my colleagues."

Mr Ledward, who formerly worked at hospitals in Kent, dismissed allegations that he had been responsible for the deaths of patients as "journalese".

He confirmed that he had recently qualified as a locum chemist in Ireland, but said that he was not currently practising. He said he wants to write a book to publish his side of the story.

fields.headline: Cook issues new euro warning
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday warned that the debate on the single currency would be changed when the Greeks were admitted to   the euro in a few weeks' time, leaving sterling isolated.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday warned that the debate on the single currency would be changed when the Greeks were admitted to the euro in a few weeks' time, leaving sterling isolated.

Mr Cook, who spoke before the foreign affairs select committee yesterday, is one of a group of ministers trying to step up campaigning on the euro. He fears Britain will lose international influence if it does not seem inevitable that it will join. Mr Cook expects the Greeks to be admitted formally to the euro group at the summit of EU heads of government at Feira later this month.

A meeting of the economic finance ministers is due to decide before the summit hosted by the Portuguese presidency.

Mr Cook said: "Plainly it is a consideration for the British debate, the extent to which the balance of forces shifts further every time someone else joins and we are left in a smaller minority."

The Foreign Office is aware that the Danes and Swedes may also be on the verge of joining shortly. This would leave sterling as the only currency inside the 15-strong EU but outside the euro.

Ministers are also increasingly alarmed that the countries inside the eurozone are intent on taking more and more decisions on the future of the European economy without consulting the outer group excluded from the euro.

In an assertion of Britain's rights, Mr Cook insisted yesterday: "Anything that effects the economy of the 15 is for the 15 to decide." Member states inside the euro could only discuss separately technical monetary issues, he said.

Mr Cook also told MPs that he was confident that the proposed EU charter of fundamental rights would not become a legal document enforceable in the European court of justice. The charter is due to be agreed at the EU summit in Nice in December.

Mr Cook stopped short of vowing to use the veto, but he said: "One of our concerns about the charter becoming legally binding is that it would have the perverse effect of undermining human rights in that there would be a conflict between the European court of justice, the EU's supreme court, and the European court, the body that oversees the European convention on human rights."

He said he did not think anyone would object to existing EU rights being covered in one document.

But he added: "It should not be the basis for rolling forward new rights."

fields.headline: Sterling turns a corner
fields.standfirst:
With the pound falling and the economy operating at capacity, the Bank of England is watching eagle-eyed for the first signs of inflation

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: With the pound falling and the economy operating at capacity, the Bank of England is watching eagle-eyed for the first signs of inflation
fields.body:
When the minutes for the Bank of England's decision yesterday to hold interest rates are released in two weeks, they will undoubtedly contain a detailed discussion of the state of sterling. Lately, the nine members of the Bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) have been thinking about little else. But the emphasis this month is different.

In previous meetings, debate focused on the implications of the pound's strength. Now the problem is a falling currency. In early March, the pound was more than 17% above its average 90s' value against a trade-weighted basket of currencies. Since then, it has fallen by around 7%.

A weaker pound comes as a relief to exporters, including manufacturers in Labour's heartlands. But it poses a dilemma for the MPC, increasing the cost of imports and pushing up inflation. With rates left unchanged now for four months in a row, the MPC sees that the pound's strength is continuing to outweigh the possible inflationary implications of the strength of domestic demand, highlighted by falling unemployment and rising earnings.

But for how much longer? Financial markets reckon that the falling pound could soon force the MPC to begin a round of interest rate rises to ensure the government's 2.5% inflation target is not breached.

The arguments for a rate rise were certainly rehearsed yesterday. Even MPC members classed as doves are concerned about the inflationary dangers of a falling currency. In September 1992, the rapid fall in sterling's value following the UK's forced exit from the exchange rate mechanism had almost no inflationary impact because there was ample spare capacity after the recession to prevent inflation taking off. But with the economy now operating at or near its full potential, a sharp fall in the value of sterling could ignite a wage-price spiral.

That prospect is still a long way off. Sterling is falling from a very high peak and cannot yet be described as weak. The pound is still worth more against the euro than it was for most of last year, ending yesterday at around the equivalent of 3.10 German marks and more than 10 French francs.

Meanwhile the domestic economy is showing signs of slowing down. Apart from the sluggishness of industry, highlighted by new figures showing a 0.2% decline in manufacturing output in April, house prices are levelling off. In the first quarter of this year GDP grew by just 0.5%, less than its long-term average. With the disinflationary impact of a slowdown in domestic demand offsetting the limited inflationary implications of a falling currency, there is no compelling reason for the MPC to do anything. Only if the pound's slide accelerates and growth picks up would it be forced to act.

Until then the MPC is likely to welcome sterling's decline. It helps redress the imbalance between depressed manufacturing and more buoyant services.

In the longer term, sterling's descent will also be welcomed by supporters of British participation in European monetary union. As Giles Radice, chairman of the Commons' Treasury committee, pointed out this week, sterling is still at least 20% overvalued against the euro. Although the rate at which sterling enters the euro will be determined by negotiation between the UK and its European Union partners, it is clearly helpful if the pound falls to a more competitive level before any decision is taken. Otherwise, the UK would risk being locked into the euro at a rate that destroys jobs.

As it is, there is every prospect of the UK and euroland currencies and economies realigning themselves into a more favourable position early in the next parliament. With the markets waking up to the fact that the American boom cannot go on forever, and with economic prospects in euroland brightening, the tide appears to be turning for the euro against both the dollar and the pound. As long as it does not overshoot in the other direction, the euro/sterling exchange rate could soon settle to a level that is (permanently) acceptable on both sides of the English Channel.

If the UK does join, the exchange rate's capacity to wreak havoc will be undermined. While the UK monetary authorities would still have to keep a close eye on the euro/dollar rate, they would no longer have to fret about destabilising currency-related fluctuations in costs and prices between the UK and the rest of the EU - no small concern when we import four times the value of goods from the EU that we do from the US.

This is not to say all that the UK's economic problems will be solved by joining. As senior Treasury officials point out, the UK had problems even when the exchange rate was fixed - because costs have tended to rise faster than in competitor countries. Inside the euro, it will be even more important to maintain a tight grip on wage and other costs because the escape route of devaluation will be blocked off.

Chancellor Gordon Brown obviously realises the risks of joining the single currency prematurely. It is one of the reasons he is working hard to improve UK productivity and ensure that the culture of low inflation is deeply entrenched, before considering ditching the pound. The irony of his position is that once his objectives are achieved, it could be harder than ever to convince sceptical voters that the euro is good for them.

fields.bodyText: When the minutes for the Bank of England's decision yesterday to hold interest rates are released in two weeks, they will undoubtedly contain a detailed discussion of the state of sterling. Lately, the nine members of the Bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) have been thinking about little else. But the emphasis this month is different. In previous meetings, debate focused on the implications of the pound's strength. Now the problem is a falling currency. In early March, the pound was more than 17% above its average 90s' value against a trade-weighted basket of currencies. Since then, it has fallen by around 7%. A weaker pound comes as a relief to exporters, including manufacturers in Labour's heartlands. But it poses a dilemma for the MPC, increasing the cost of imports and pushing up inflation. With rates left unchanged now for four months in a row, the MPC sees that the pound's strength is continuing to outweigh the possible inflationary implications of the strength of domestic demand, highlighted by falling unemployment and rising earnings. But for how much longer? Financial markets reckon that the falling pound could soon force the MPC to begin a round of interest rate rises to ensure the government's 2.5% inflation target is not breached. The arguments for a rate rise were certainly rehearsed yesterday. Even MPC members classed as doves are concerned about the inflationary dangers of a falling currency. In September 1992, the rapid fall in sterling's value following the UK's forced exit from the exchange rate mechanism had almost no inflationary impact because there was ample spare capacity after the recession to prevent inflation taking off. But with the economy now operating at or near its full potential, a sharp fall in the value of sterling could ignite a wage-price spiral. That prospect is still a long way off. Sterling is falling from a very high peak and cannot yet be described as weak. The pound is still worth more against the euro than it was for most of last year, ending yesterday at around the equivalent of 3.10 German marks and more than 10 French francs. Meanwhile the domestic economy is showing signs of slowing down. Apart from the sluggishness of industry, highlighted by new figures showing a 0.2% decline in manufacturing output in April, house prices are levelling off. In the first quarter of this year GDP grew by just 0.5%, less than its long-term average. With the disinflationary impact of a slowdown in domestic demand offsetting the limited inflationary implications of a falling currency, there is no compelling reason for the MPC to do anything. Only if the pound's slide accelerates and growth picks up would it be forced to act. Until then the MPC is likely to welcome sterling's decline. It helps redress the imbalance between depressed manufacturing and more buoyant services. In the longer term, sterling's descent will also be welcomed by supporters of British participation in European monetary union. As Giles Radice, chairman of the Commons' Treasury committee, pointed out this week, sterling is still at least 20% overvalued against the euro. Although the rate at which sterling enters the euro will be determined by negotiation between the UK and its European Union partners, it is clearly helpful if the pound falls to a more competitive level before any decision is taken. fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Catching Kakworm | Brought to account
fields.body:
Catching Kakworm
I have taken the view that email-borne viruses are only a danger if one intentionally opens an attachment, and I proceed only after seeing who it is from and its title in the preview pane of Outlook Express.

Recently I have received emails from Microsoft, eFax.com and others which initiate an internet connection to their website by automatically starting a dial-up networking connection.

I understand the reason for this, but I realise that someone with a malicious intent could do considerable damage using this type of embedded code. How can I disable it?
John Mathias
London j.mathias@ntlworld.com

Jack Schofield: The quick answer is to go to Internet Explorer's Tools menu, pick Internet Options, go to the Connections tab and click to select "Never dial a connection". However, this does not remove the potential problems with web-style mail, coded in HTML, which can run scripts and can carry viruses such as VBS/Bubbleboy and VBS/Kakworm.

Merely reading a message infected with Kakworm allows it to put a file called KAK.HTA into Windows' Start-up folder. The next time Windows is started, it creates a file called C:\WINDOWS\ KAK.HTM which changes the Microsoft Outlook Express registry settings to add the virus to your outgoing email as a signature.

The last of these fortnightly columns explained how to disable the Windows Scripting Host program that runs Visual Basic Scripts (VBS).

It's also possible to disable scripting in Internet Explorer. In IE5, go to the Tools| Internet Options|Security tab (remember, Outlook Express is part of the Internet Explorer suite) and raise the default security level or click Custom Level and do it manually.

However, Bubbleboy and Kakworm actually exploit one of Microsoft's mistakes, which was to mark two small files (scriptlet.typelib and Eyedog) as being "safe for scripting" when they aren't. Microsoft published a patch to fix this on August 31: see www.microsoft.com/technet/security/bulletin/fq99-032.asp

Users of IE4 and IE5 for Windows 95/98 should have downloaded the fix but we didn't. Now Kakworm is becoming widespread, it's a good idea.

Brought to account
My wife and I have separate ISP/email accounts, and I am unable to set Outlook Express so that I can just see my emails when I log in and she can see only hers when she logs in. In fact, at the moment only I can send emails and I can see her emails in my intray. She thinks its a conspiracy and I am unable to provide a valid answer. Help! Keith Shapley
Keith.Shapley@tesco.net

JS: With Outlook Express 4, you have to "enable user profiles" so that you each log on to and log off from Windows before running the program. (For this to work, you also have to enable user profiles before you install OE4 in Windows 95/98, but that's a longer story.)

Go to the Control Panel, double-click Passwords, and select the User Profiles tab. Click: "Users can customize their preferences and desktop settings. Windows switches to your personal settings whenever you log in."

Outlook Express 5 is much better because it introduces the concept of Identities. Simply pull down the File menu, point to Identities, and click Add New Identity. Creating a new identity automatically creates a new mail folder.

The outlook for Macs
I've succeeded in getting online on a Mac which is networked to two PCs using Windows 98SE's Internet Connection Sharing. The problem is, I'd like to use Outlook Express on the Mac, but I'm running OS 7.6 and the latest version of Outlook Express (5.02) only runs on 8.1 or later.

Could you tell me where I might be able to download an earlier version of Outlook Express that will run on OS 7.6?
Donald Gunn
donald@culloden5.freeserve.co.uk

JS: Outlook Explorer 4.5 runs on PowerPC-based Macs with Mac OS 7.5.3 or above (7.5.5 or above is recommended). You can download it from www.microsoft.com/msdownload/iebuild/ie45_mac/en/ie45_mac.htm
