webTitle: Blair treads lightly between gobbledegook and platitude

fields.headline: Blair treads lightly between gobbledegook and platitude
fields.standfirst:
The rhetoric of inclusiveness is a mask for failure in practical politics

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is New Labour's chef de cuisine. He alone sets the oven and measures the salt. He strives for meals of perfect balance.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is New Labour's chef de cuisine. He alone sets the oven and measures the salt. He strives for meals of perfect balance. In his absence, the chief sous-chef began boiling up one of the ingredients too fast. So yesterday the leader set about turning down the gas under the pan, to restore the equilibrium that is the hallmark of his party's cooking. It may not have been wise to choose the massed ranks of the Women's Institute, an audience readily available for a Tory stunt, as the scene for the demonstration. But symmetrical blandness, on which nobody could choke, is safely back on the table.

Gordon Brown had startled the appetite for something tastier. His attack on the Oxford entrance system reawakened intimations of class war. We learned quite a lot about New Labour in the process. The party, Brown thought, needed to be galvanised by the sight of one of its ministers remembering what they were for. He was loose with the facts, grotesquely defamatory of Magdalen College, but he made a point about social injustice and the persistence of unequal opportunities at the top of British society. There was something in what he said - in general, if not in particular. Briefly, we remembered that Labour cared about this sort of thing far more than the Tories.

Blair's own recipe for Labour permits the occasional similar astringency. His dishes are not required to be insipid. Part of him - it's a part that boils away under the surface, and was what brought him into politics in the first place - abominates the forces of conservatism, and is not afraid to say so. His attack on them at the last party conference, which took friend and enemy aback, was both calculating and sincere. When talking to the party, both Blair and Brown think they have finished the task of educating it towards the right, and now wish to explain how this does not mean abandoning every element of the left.

But there is a bigger audience. The meal is for wider consumption. The master culinarist was yesterday at his most unthreatening. The perfection of balance came close to being self-cancelling. Labour was new. But it was also old. The "new" was "necessary in order to 're-new' the old". History is good: "We love British history, Britain's cultural heritage." But change is also good, while being in no way an obliteration of history, while at the same time again not being an affront to values that have to be considered timeless. Between history and change there was a false choice, Blair said. For New Labour, in fact, the harsher the choice, the falser it often seems to be.

Where this speech did not verge on gobbledegook, it trod close to platitude. But it was indubitably inclusive. New Labour philosophy tries to square all the circles. The contemporary Blair opts to speak for "values", and especially "community"; to challenge materialism in the name of values, while doing nothing to worry materialists; to make the case for marriage without demonising the unmarried; to profess in favour of excellence, while scorning the elites that produce it; to be friends with everybody except the few - they really are quite few, even in the Tory party - who exhibit a belief in hierarchy or class prejudice. In addressing the country at large, there must be no abrasion, no enemy except rump and malign Tories, nothing to sting the palate.

This, it should be said, is the genuine Blair. He believes a vast company of Brits can be swept into his tent, if only they hear what he says. Unlike Brown, he rejects most of the old lines that have divided societies and politics. He is therefore the epitome of the post-ideological leader. But it should also be noted how much of this is about positioning. It's about asserting ownership of the words that will strike the heartlands' chord without worrying middle England. And vice versa. This is a politics of tone and mood, of labels reducing the complexities of life to propositions that make things easy for everyone to understand which side they should be on.

Blair is not alone in attending so closely to the politics of words. William Hague has found his own way of doing it. He's not so interested in being inclusive. His appeal is antagonistic. But he is developing his counter-demon to the forces of conservatism, namely the liberal elite. This, too, is all about positioning. Education was first in the frame: ruined, says Hague, by a group he can define, when challenged to identify it, only by saying: "We know it when we see it." Other policies are about to follow schools into the dock where the liberalism of unnumbered decades is on trial. Immigration, welfare, and the NHS are being lined up for early speeches that attribute their defects to the soundbite label which new Conservatism has decided is most appealing.

It's a remarkable charge. Swept within it are 18 years of Thatcherite responsibility for all these public services. Hague seems oblivious of the recent facts of history beneath the image he has seized on to exploit. Coming to modern times, we have a government in which two of the relevant ministers, Jack Straw and David Blunkett, are proud to declare in the most public places that they are not, and never have been, liberals. As for Tony Blair, the label would betray the borderless politics he has made his own. He does not use it. He proposes himself as a liberal no more often than he calls himself a socialist, which is to say never. But this is unimportant in the politics of mood, where impressions are regarded as all that matter. Labour is not a liberal elite, just as Magdalen College devotes itself to not being a social elite. But facts, in these political concoctions, are less important than convenient fantasies.

What is the voters' defence against the dominance of positioning over reality, which is becoming the alpha and omega of political argument? Only to look at what is going on. Take the case where this began. Blair is, after all, the leader of a government, Brown his most important deputy. They are not opposition politicians, whose job is to rail against the state of things. Their job is to act. In three years, they've done little to address the problem that ignited Brown's rage over Magdalen. The availability of Oxford places to working-class students is much affected by money, which the government has taken away not handed out. It is also affected by belief: do the best students, from unfashionable schools, have the nerve to apply? The government has done little about that either, certainly much less than Oxford has. Now Brown's political attack guarantees that Magdalen will seem not more but less accessible.

Likewise Hague. Positioning himself against a fantasy liberal elite doesn't build more schools or advance a concrete solution to the crime problems for which it is his scapegoat. The more these men ask us to consider the fine tuning, the calibrated cooking, of their words, the more we must ignore them.

hugoyoung@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Any answers?
fields.standfirst: Notes and queries
fields.trailText: Notes and queries
fields.body:
Why is it always necessary to destroy valuable racehorses after a bad fall? Could they not be put out to stud?

* Horses which suffer bad falls are generally jumpers, and jumpers tend to happen rather than be bred - most hurdlers are gelded males with no stud value, and even if they are entire (or mares) there is no guarantee that their ability would be passed on.

A bad fall is not in itself a reason for destroying a horse but a broken leg is: they can't use crutches for obvious reasons, and though it is possible for a horse to be supported in a sling while its leg heals, this is a long and expensive operation and only really an option for a horse with great stud potential (or a very sentimental and rich owner).

Jan Holden, Clitheroe, Lancs.

Assuming that the spinning of the earth would, but for gravity, have a tendency to throw things outwards into space, does it follow that gravity is stronger at the poles than at the equator?

* The weight of an object does increase significantly the further one moves it away from the equator. If the earth were a perfect non- rotating sphere, then gravity would be equal at all points. However, the earth is neither a perfect sphere nor non-rotating. The effect of the earth spinning is to reduce the force of gravity acting on a person. As the spin is greatest at the equator, the reduction is greatest.

In addition, the earth is slightly flattened, with the radius at the poles being less than the equator, and the force of gravity drops off as the radius increases. However, this is slightly offset by the increased mass at the equator. The overall effect being that gravity at the equator is approximately 0.5% less than at the poles.

Dr Paul Rollin, Wolverton, Milton Keynes.

* Equatorial gold exporters have been able to exploit this phenomenon to their fiscal advantage. The enhancement in the price of a mass of gold due to its increased weight between the equatorial and temperate zones is enough, with something to spare, to pay for transport costs between the two regions.

Martyn Giscombe-Smith, London NW5.

Did the withdrawal of free school milk by Margaret Thatcher in the early 70s had an adverse effect on child health?

* The idea that milk is bad for teeth and the notion that Lady Thatcher is thus responsible for improved oral health (Notes & Queries, May 4, 18) is, like many of her so-called Victorian values, completely fallacious. Enamel is more than 95% (by weight) calcium mineral, so a source of calcium, such as milk, is required for healthy teeth.

It is true that bacteria can ferment lactose to lactic acid; however, the resulting acid levels are much less than those produced by fermentation of the main decay-causing sugar, sucrose.

What's more, the upshot of destruction of the NHS wrought by the former PM is that British dental care is universally regarded with a degree of derision and scorn normally reserved for the English cricket team.

Richard Lamont, Professor of Oral Biology, University of Washington, US.

Why do wine bottles have a large indent in the base?

* Ray Cobbett is right and T George is wrong (Notes & Queries, May 4, 25): vintners "cannot exploit the punt because the volume of wine is stated on the label". Sure, the law permits a tolerance on individual bottles to allow for variability in the performance of bottling machines, but there is an overriding requirement that the average of all bottles in a batch must not be less than the quantity declared on the label. So for every bottle found to be underfilled, there will be another which is overfilled - with no profit to the vintner.

If Mr George has evidence to the contrary, he should pass it forthwith to his trading standards authority for legal action.

Michael Ranken, Hythe, Kent.

Can anyone tell

Me if this

Is a poem or

not?

* I shan't

as I can't.

But I would

if I could.

Simon Maddison, Hitchin, Herts.

* Yes

it is

not.

Dan Usiskin, London N12.

* It's a poem if the line format imparts a different meaning, emphasis, or sonority. Otherwise, it's just a fancy layout. You might try passing it off as "Art", though.

Norman Henderson, Southampton.

* It is not a poem as it has none of the essential elements of poetry: subject, meaning, theme, mood, imagery, language which draws attention to itself, rhyme, rhythm and form. But this is:

Can anyone tell me

if this is a poem or not?

- Well, is it memorable

Or easily forgot?

Prof Edward Black, Sydney, Australia.

* According to Jeremy Bentham, it would be a poem. He is reported to have said: "Prose is when all the lines except the last go on to the end. Poetry is when some of them fall short of it" (quoted in M St J Packe, The Life of John Stuart Mill).

Carrie Osborne, Alstonefield, Derbyshire.

How wrong can you be?

* You could vote Tory and support Man United.

Martin Hunt, Aberdesach, Gwynedd.

* The last reported words of Union Army general John Sedgwick (1813-1864) before being shot by a sniper were "They couldn't hit an elephant at this dist-".

Rod Bladen, Stockport.

How did captains of ships develop the tradition of going down with their vessel? Is there any sense in it and, given the value of experienced seamen in a war, has the navy ever issued orders forbidding it?

Tig Thomas, Halford, Warks.

Has an ordinary member of the public ever used the English libel laws successfully against a rich and influential opponent?

T Hollingsworth, Morpeth, Northumberland.

One Canderel sweetener makes a cup of tea as sweet as I prefer. However, if the cup cools and I reheat it in the microwave, I need to add more sweetener. Does the sweetening agent get destroyed in the microwave?

G D Forrester, Hitchin, Herts.

Recently the Russian forces in Chechnya used "vacuum bombs". What are they, how do they work, and has Britain ever used them?

Mark Moorhouse, Edinburgh.

Walk anywhere and you see masses of birds, but you rarely see a dead one. Is the food chain incredibly efficiently at having them all gobbled up, or do they all go to a secret place to die?

Norman Harris, Mortlake, London SW14.

fields.bodyText: Why is it always necessary to destroy valuable racehorses after a bad fall? Could they not be put out to stud? * Horses which suffer bad falls are generally jumpers, and jumpers tend to happen rather than be bred - most hurdlers are gelded males with no stud value, and even if they are entire (or mares) there is no guarantee that their ability would be passed on. A bad fall is not in itself a reason for destroying a horse but a broken leg is: they can't use crutches for obvious reasons, and though it is possible for a horse to be supported in a sling while its leg heals, this is a long and expensive operation and only really an option for a horse with great stud potential (or a very sentimental and rich owner). Jan Holden, Clitheroe, Lancs. Assuming that the spinning of the earth would, but for gravity, have a tendency to throw things outwards into space, does it follow that gravity is stronger at the poles than at the equator? * The weight of an object does increase significantly the further one moves it away from the equator. If the earth were a perfect non- rotating sphere, then gravity would be equal at all points. However, the earth is neither a perfect sphere nor non-rotating. The effect of the earth spinning is to reduce the force of gravity acting on a person. As the spin is greatest at the equator, the reduction is greatest. In addition, the earth is slightly flattened, with the radius at the poles being less than the equator, and the force of gravity drops off as the radius increases. However, this is slightly offset by the increased mass at the equator. The overall effect being that gravity at the equator is approximately 0.5% less than at the poles. Dr Paul Rollin, Wolverton, Milton Keynes. * Equatorial gold exporters have been able to exploit this phenomenon to their fiscal advantage. The enhancement in the price of a mass of gold due to its increased weight between the equatorial and temperate zones is enough, with something to spare, to pay for transport costs between the two regions. webTitle: Step-up in bombing of Iraq questioned

fields.headline: Step-up in bombing of Iraq questioned
fields.standfirst: Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: British bomber pilots have dramatically increased their strikes on Iraq in the "secret war" against Saddam Hussein, official figures reveal.
fields.body:
British bomber pilots have dramatically increased their strikes on Iraq in the "secret war" against Saddam Hussein, official figures reveal.

An estimated 150 bombs - 78 tonnes of weapons - have been dropped on southern Iraq by British aircraft since December 1998. This compares with 2.5 tonnes over the previous six years.

"There is now persuasive evidence that there is an attritional campaign against the Iraqi ground-based air defence systems that has gone way beyond the original purpose of the no-fly zones," Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, said yesterday. "This represents a significant policy shift, which has never been announced or explained to parliament."

Mr Campbell was given the figures by Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, in response to a series of written parliamentary questions. Mr Hoon admitted that on two occasions since December 1998, ordnance unleashed by British aircraft "appears to have hit unintended targets".

He also disclosed that the British commander in the southern no-fly zone had asked the government to "attack targets beyond his delegated authority".

He refused to explain the circumstances but sources suggested yesterday that permission was sought to hit Iraqi aircraft moving north, away from the no-fly zone.

In military action which is rarely reported, Mr Hoon says that while Iraqi aircraft violating the no-fly zone accounted for 51% of the "threats" to British and US war planes, 95% of the targets attacked consisted of ground-based air defence systems.

Two no-fly zones, policed by British and American planes, were agreed by the UN after the 1991 Gulf war. They were established to protect the Shia minority in southern Iraq and Kurds in the north.

"It's very good training but it is not achieving anything," Andrew Brookes, of the International Institute for Strategic Studies, said yesterday. He described it as a "sterile political mission of people who can't think of anything better to do".

Mr Hoon said Britain and the US went to "exceptional lengths to ensure that the right target is hit, including the employment of very strict target clearance procedures and precision-guided munitions". However, he acknowledged: "In practice, it is extremely difficult to give estimates of civilian casualties despite the painstaking battle damage assessment that the coalition routinely carries out".

Britain has 14 Tornado bombers stationed in Kuwait and Bahrain, and four Jaguars based at Incirlik in Turkey.

webTitle: Data watchdog warns parties after Labour mailing fiasco

fields.headline: Data watchdog warns parties after Labour mailing fiasco
fields.standfirst:
Party members to be warned their details may be passed on

Livingstone's London: special report
fields.trailText: Political parties are to be warned to advise members that their names and addresses might be handed to numerous officials, in the light of the fiasco over Frank Dobson's campaign to be Labour's candidate for mayor of London.
fields.body:
Political parties are to be warned to advise members that their names and addresses might be handed to numerous officials, in the light of the fiasco over Frank Dobson's campaign to be Labour's candidate for mayor of London.

After a six month inquiry, Elizabeth France, data protection registrar, told the Labour party to advise members that their details were likely to be disseminated widely.

She ruled that there was "insufficent evidence to substantiate a prosecution against the campaign, or anyone acting on its behalf, in respect of non-registration", after complaints that Mr Dobson unfairly received confidential information.

The former health secretary's campaign used confidential information to send letters to Labour's 68,000 London members in his ill-starred fight against Ken Livingstone.

Mr Dobson maintained that the details were legally supplied by two Euro MPs and at a late stage offered to supply them to Mr Livingstone and fellow challenger for the nomination, Glenda Jackson.

The fact the campaign is over and the alleged abuse has ended is believed to have played a part in the decision.

Failure to comply with data protection legislation to protect privacy carries a £5,000 fine, and Mr Dobson's camp paid a £75 licence fee as a "precautionary" measure after complaints were lodged.

The ruling is expected to concentrate minds in the other main parties. Labour regularly sends membership lists to 650 constituency and 4,500 branch secretaries and to MPs and MEPs. Mr Dobson was alleged to have gained an unfair advantage by receiving information early on in the nomination battle deprived to his rivals.

Ms France disclosed her decision not to take legal proceedings in a letter to a Labour member, Andy Walker, of Ilford, Greater London, who said: "I'm not happy with the result. They will just find another way to rig it."

But a Labour spokeswoman said: "We insisted throughout that everything had been handled correctly, and so we welcome the outcome of the investigation. We are already committed to a full review of how we select candidates in mayoral and other elections."

fields.headline: The garden of mutants
fields.standfirst: Sanjida O'Connell on how flawed snapdragons are helping to solve the mystery of how plants grow
fields.trailText: Sanjida O'Connell on how flawed snapdragons are helping to solve the mystery of how plants grow
fields.body:
Brendan Davies can spot a mutant a mile off. He saw one in his mother's garden the other day, and last year he planted several hundred in his flowerbed. Sadly they haven't reappeared this year.

Dr Davies, from the University of Leeds, studies mutant snapdragons because he is interested in how plants form. Unlike animals, plants have to adapt to life as they are forced to live it and must retain a certain degree of plasticity - grow more or less leaves, flower earlier or later depending on the environmental conditions.

"How is it possible to write an instruction in genes to make something so fantastic," says Davies gesturing towards a snapdragon, "when it takes me more words than it has genes just to describe it?"

According to Professor John Maynard Smith, one of the greatest living evolutionary biologists, this is one of the last unsolved problems in biology: how the seed of a plant, or an egg, turns from a small ball of uniform cells into a sheep, a snake or a snapdragon.

Davies mainly works with Antirrhinum, the common snapdragon, which is flowering at this time of year. The reason he chose the snapdragon stems from one man's obsessive hunt for mutants.

During the early part of this century, a German scientist, Hans Stubbe, subjected snapdragons to radiation, chemicals, X-rays, anything to warp their development. He meticulously categorised and described every possible mutant - and there were many - from plants that form one single flower on the top of their stalk like a sunflower, to double-petalled symmetrical blooms, to sadder specimens that never flower and grow low and close to the ground in tiny rosettes.

Stubbe was trying to find out what makes plants grow? How do they know how to make a leaf, a flower, a seed? As Johann Wolfgang Goethe said: it is only through "our acquaintance with this abnormal metamorphosis, we are enabled to unveil the secrets that normal metamorphosis conceals from us".

"Stubbe was too early," says Davies. "No one could have foreseen the advances we'd make in molecular biology. We look at his mutants and see things that seem obvious now. It wasn't that he wasn't clever, he didn't have the right tools."

After Stubbe's death, the gardeners at the Gatersleben Institute in East Germany looked after his mutants, planting them year after year. Only after the reunification of Germany did the west access this forgotten hoard of plants and information. Davies heard about Stubbe during post-doctoral research in Cologne; on his return to England, he requested seeds from Stubbe's legacy and picked up where he had left off.

Davies has isolated the genes that cause these deformities and worked out which genes do what. One mutant forms tiny cup-shaped leaves. It looks more like a minuscule mushroom than anything floral. This plant has lost the ability to set boundaries. Something has to tell the plant to put forth a leaf and where the edge of the leaf should be. Even if this plant manages to get past the circular leaf stage, it produces fused leaves, and thick masses of swollen, undifferentiated green tissue: a fleshy clump of plant matter.

Davies has recently discovered another gene which causes flowers to form with sterile male parts; he named it Farinelli after the eighteenth century castrato singer.

One of Davies's colleagues, Dr Cathie Martin, from the John Innes Centre in Norwich, worked on a mutant that possibly only the sharp-eyed Stubbe might have noticed. It is identical to all others except in one respect: the colour of the petals is dull. Examining the cells under a scanning electron microscope, she discovered that a conical projection normally seen in the middle of petal cells was missing. This pro jection reflects light, giving petals their characteristic brightness and sheen. Martin has discovered the gene which controls the petal projection and managed to insert it and turn it on in tobacco plant leaves.

Many of the genes Davies has been examining are MADS-box genes which control a number of other genes. There are about 90 MADS-box genes that regulate the genes which control reproductive organs, flowering time, root and seed development and fertility. For instance, two genes are mainly responsible for flower formation; if they mutate, the plant is unable to flower. Cauliflower, like broccoli and romanesco, is really the tip of the plant on the verge of flowering but unable to form flowers and is likely to have been formed by a mutation in one of these two MADS-box genes, probably during the 15th century.

Not all mutants are aesthetically unpleasant or could end up on the table: an old set of primula mutants has been retained since Elizabethan times because of the attrac tiveness of their flowers. Margaret Webster, a student at Leeds, holds the National Register of Anomalous Primulas; some have quaint names such as Jack in the Green and Hose in Hose. Once a year, Professor Phil Gilmartin, one of Davies's colleges and Webster's supervisor, has the task of visiting Naples to collect mutants from one of the larger Italian seed growers who specialise in primula production.

This "mutant" research started off as pure science for the sake of furthering our own understanding, but could have implications for food production. "If we understand how something is built, we can modify it," says Davies. MADS-box genes could be manipulated to control flowering time, root development, or even prevent plants, like lettuce, from flowering at all. We may find gourmet restaurants of the future serving cauliflower-like mutants: the messed up flowers of larkspur, lavender, love-in-the-mist, tossed in olive oil and garnished with full blooms.

webTitle: Blade of light that now spans the Thames

fields.headline: Blade of light that now spans the Thames
fields.trailText: A sabre of light, a sprung structure of filigree lightness, the Millennium Bridge spanning the River Thames between St Paul's Cathedral in the City of London and Tate Modern, Southwark opens on Saturday.
fields.body:
A sabre of light, a sprung structure of filigree lightness, the Millennium Bridge spanning the River Thames between St Paul's Cathedral in the City of London and Tate Modern, Southwark opens on Saturday.

This is the first new bridge in central London in more than 30 years: the last was the anodyne London Bridge that replaced the one sold to the Americans who thought, so the legend goes, they were getting Tower Bridge. Unlike the gloriously over-the-top gothic Tower Bridge - the last London bridge with any real character - the Millennium Bridge is all but invisible until you get close. It is more like a long-legged river fly than the Zeppelin of traditional London bridges, with their weighty engineering, countless tonnes of concrete, ambitious steel cables and stone facing.

No more than 320 metres long, the bridge is tiny compared with the 10-mile Oresund Link that, when it opens on July 1, will connect Copenhagen to Malmo and thus Denmark to Sweden. The Millennium Bridge is David to the Oresund Link's Goliath, but it is in the subtlety, indeed the revolutionary nature of its design, that it wins hands down over the Viking bridge's bludgeoning, battleaxe engineering. The Oresund Link is an impressive achievement yet a conservative structure that could have been built at any time over the past 25 years.

As Lord Foster, architect of the Millennium Bridge, says, the London project could not have been built even a decade ago. Why? Because it is the world's first horizontal suspension bridge of any real note: it does not need the familiar gateway pylons that hold up such well known suspension bridges as those that span the Severn and the Humber, and which can rise more than 200 metres above morning mists. Instead the cables are stretched as low as possible over the tidal Thames, allowing the bridge to be as unobtrusive as possible.

This quietness on the part of the architect and the engineer (Ove Arup and Partners) gives the bridge its special quality: those who cross it feel as though they are walking in the air over swirling water. Any sense of agoraphobia should, however, be allayed by the stainless steel handrails that project from the four metre-wide deck. These ought to keep unsteady nerves on an even keel.

The bridge looks glorious at night, reduced to no more than the designers' "blade of light". Fibreoptics ensure that the lightbeams emitted from the bridge are as fine as current technology allows; there is no leakage and no glare. This poetic effect is the result of a close collaboration between architect, engineers and Sir Anthony Caro, the sculptor and third member of the Millennium Bridge team.

The bridge is a very modern design, yet the spirit of its construction harks back to that of the two cathedrals at either end of its span, St Paul's and Southwark. Both are the work of architects, engineers and artists working together.

The bridge is a practical and symbolic link between the plutocratic City and the up-and-coming borough of Southwark, a way of linking St Paul's and Tate Modern, and a generous nod to the pedestrian lobby. It is also the only truly modern structure built in central London with millennium money to mark the millennium. Neatly and light-footedly, it bridges the gap between the millennium projects we have got to date, and those many of us have dreamed of.

The bridge is a very modern design, yet the spirit of its construction harks back to that of the two cathedrals at either end of its span, St Paul's and Southwark. Both are the work of architects, engineers and artists working together. The bridge is a practical and symbolic link between the plutocratic City and the up-and-coming borough of Southwark, a way of linking St Paul's and Tate Modern, and a generous nod to the pedestrian lobby. It is also the only truly modern structure built in central London with millennium money to mark the millennium. Neatly and light-footedly, it bridges the gap between the millennium projects we have got to date, and those many of us have dreamed of.

webTitle: Neill attacks bill's lobbying inquiry curbs

fields.headline: Neill attacks bill's lobbying inquiry curbs
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Neill yesterday attacked Jack Straw's freedom of information bill for setting up "formidable obstacles" to prevent the disclosure of secret meetings between government ministers, civil servants and lobbying companies.
fields.body:
Lord Neill yesterday attacked Jack Straw's freedom of information bill for setting up "formidable obstacles" to prevent the disclosure of secret meetings between government ministers, civil servants and lobbying companies.

The surprise attack by the chairman of the committee of standards in public life was made during a hearing of the Commons public administration committee to discuss his latest report on changing the ministerial code of conduct and reforming Whitehall.

Lord Neill, who made it clear that he was speaking in a personal capacity, backed up assertions by Tony Wright, Labour chairman of the committee, that his proposed reforms to open up secret contacts by lobbyists trying to influence government policy would be more or less scuppered by the new bill.

Lord Neill's committee has called for Britain to follow the United States and Canada and keep public registers of meetings with lobbyists and for the talks to be fully minuted. He has not gone as far to say that the minutes should be fully released. Mr Wright pointed that such procedures could be prevented under at least five exemptions in the act - including preventing disclosure of any procedures in ministerial offices; discussions of public policy; and confidential communications between outside individuals and government.

Lord Neill said that just two alone of these restrictions - the supply of information in confidence and discussions about public policy - created " formidable obstacles" to the introduction of his reforms.

He went on to warn the prime minister that he expected the government to strengthen the language in the present ministerial code of conduct to make it clear that the PM and nobody else would carry the can for erring ministers, agreeing with Mr Wright's assertion "that the buck stops here".

Citing but not naming the two scandals involving Neil Hamilton and Jonathan Aitken, he pointed out that complaints to then prime minister John Major were merely passed to a minister to answer, who prompted denied them. "We have to end this circularity," he said. Instead he suggested that in future cases the prime minsiter should appoint a lawyer or an accountant to carry out a confidential investigation. Lord Neill also expressed disappointment that the government had after five months failed to reply to a wide range of recommendations to reform Whitehall. "Rapid changes are in train in the public service,and I believe that our recommendations - such as those relating to a civil service act, lobbying, special advisers and task forces - have an important role to play in sustaining public confidence that change is carried out with propriety."

"In our inquiry we concluded that there was a danger, not so much of politicising the civil service, as of marginalising neutral policy advice by bringing in a very siginifcant proportion of external advisers."

Lord Neill said he wanted the government to at least start consultations on the need for a new civil service act. "It would help to increase public confidence in the process of public sector reform, if, like most other democracies, this country could have legislation to clarify the role and status of the civil service.

"The government has supported such an act both in opposition and since taking office, but has not yet found time even to start the consultation process. We continue to find this disappointing."

webTitle: Heckled, jeered, booed - Blair bombs at the WI

fields.headline: Heckled, jeered, booed - Blair bombs at the WI
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: In an extraordinary error of political judgment, Tony Blair tried to use the Women's Institute's national conference in Wembley yesterday as a platform to reposition Labour as a party of traditional values in a changing world.
fields.body:
In an extraordinary error of political judgment, Tony Blair tried to use the Women's Institute's national conference in Wembley yesterday as a platform to reposition Labour as a party of traditional values in a changing world.

The audience of 10,000 women representing the backbone of Britain responded first with sporadic heckling, then slow handclapping and finally undisguised jeering from sections of the hall.

If it had not been for an appeal for politeness from the chair, the prime minister might not have been able to scamper through to the end of an ill-advised speech that later drew taunts in the Commons from William Hague.

"It is the mark of an out of touch prime minister that you don't know why you're out of touch," the Tory leader said.

Mr Blair's mistake was to use the fiercely non-party-political WI as the backdrop for making political points that might have appeared almost bland in another setting.

There was no evidence at the outset that the women were hostile to Mr Blair or to Labour. They gave a warm welcome to the father of four, fresh from paternity leave, and seemed more flattered than offended by his suggestion that they were "the most terrifying audience I have seen".

The institute prides itself on its ability to move on from the jam-making image of its founders in 1915. To the speechwriters in Downing Street it must have seemed the ideal example of blending tradition and modernity - the recipe Mr Blair now wants to present as Labour's political vision for Britain.

But yesterday it was the prime minister who got into a jam of his own making and ended in a pickle when he ignored advice to be non-political that was given when Downing Street approached the WI last week, requesting an opportunity for him to speak. The trouble started half way through the speech, with heckling from part of the hall where West Midlands delegates were clustered.

Mr Blair had been trying to defuse the row between the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and Oxbridge colleges over university admissions policies. "Let's hear no more about class war ... We are unashamed supporters of excellence," he said.

But the audience reacted badly when he started on a list of examples of government action to extend opportunity. He began with the unemployed and sport in schools. Then came the disabled, lone parents and childcare. As he moved through internet access, the minimum wage and family tax credits, the heckling started.

Members later described it as a party political broadcast.

Mr Blair appeared not to understand what the problem was as he ploughed on about NHS reform. As the slow handclapping grew in volume, Helen Carey, the WI's chair, appealed for calm.

The penny seemed to drop after he was heckled during references to cuts in interest rates since Labour took power in 1997. Forced off his stride, he said: "Well, I'm glad we're having a good debate anyway." Women responded with tut-tutting that this was a party lecture not a debate.

Mr Blair managed a brief recovery. He won applause for references to children turning up at school in the morning, fathers taking responsibility for their children's upbringing and paying women the same as men for the same job. But there were more shouts when he returned to the political language of collective responsibility, and sounds of incredulity when he gave support to the WI's campaign to save rural post offices.

At the end there was polite applause from perhaps as many as half the women present. Others sat impassively.

"When he asked last week for time on our agenda he was told we are a non-political organisation," said the institute's spokeswoman, Sangeeta Haindl. "Our chair warned that if he tried to make it political he would get short shrift."

Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's spokesman, told reporters after Mr Hague and Charles Kennedy had exploited the PM's embarrassment at Commons questions: "I have no intention of getting into a war of words with the WI."

What the WI hated...

 List of government initiatives (heckled)

 Explanation of plans for NHS reform (slow handclap)

 Interest rates cut since last election (heckled)

 Mention of collective responsibility (cries of No, No)

 Effect of technology on rural postal services (heckled)

... and what it liked

 Fathers should help to bring children up

 Defaulting fathers should lose driving licences

 Benefit claimants should attend job interviews

 Equal pay for women doing same job as men

 Help for women who stay at home with pre-school children

Links

Labour Party

fields.headline: The sticking point
fields.standfirst: Henry Gee on the surprising secrets of one of nature's stickiest surfaces - the gecko's atom-powered feet
fields.trailText: Henry Gee on the surprising secrets of one of nature's stickiest surfaces - the gecko's atom-powered feet
fields.body:
Robert Full's laboratory is more than usually full of gizmos, even for a modern biologist. Full is a biological engineer. Like an industrial espionage outfit, he and colleagues at the University of California, Berkeley, look at nature and try to reverse-engineer it - taking nature's solutions to pieces, learning how they work then putting them together in robot form, in new and exciting ways.

A big man with big enthusiasm, Full shows me a video of his team's latest robot. This six-legged machine moves with all the natural assurance of an insect; the cartoon face painted on the front makes the creature (for that's what it is) look animated. It crosses terrain that overturns other robots or stops them dead in their (caterpillar) tracks. How does it do it? By doing what insects do naturally: a bit of springiness engineered into the legs, combined with mechanical responses at a local level (rather than always being centralised through a "brain") make for a flexible, robust system.

Some feet, however, are the very opposite of springy; they are sticky with a vengeance. Full's latest mission has been to understand what makes the feet of geckos so adhesive. No hot tropical night is complete without one of these small lizards darting up walls and across ceilings.

For decades, scientists have studied this trick. The anatomy is incredible. Each foot of a Tokay gecko (Gekko gecko) is clothed with a fine pile of microscopic hairs, around 5,000 per square millimetre - or around two million per gecko. These hairs have split ends, each dividing into as many as 1,000 frayed strands - the total, per lizard, running into billions.

As they show in today's Nature (June 8, 2000), Full and colleagues have measured the force acting on isolated hairs as a gecko runs. The hairs on the foot point backwards. As the gecko takes a step and gains a purchase, the hairs are driven backwards and down, engaging with the surface. The force on each hair is minuscule, but the effect is cumulative: a totally stuck gecko would clamp on to a surface with a force equivalent to 10 atmospheres of pressure. No wonder they can stick to ceilings. But how does a gecko not get bogged down?

The answer is that the gecko doesn't yank its feet off the surface all at once, but peels off its toes at a certain angle, rather like peeling off a strip of adhesive tape, or Velcro.

The puzzle is what makes them stick. Simple suction is out, because gecko feet work perfectly, even in a vacuum.

Clinging to very fine cracks or imperfections is also out: geckos can cope with polished glass.

It could be electrostatic attraction, like toy bal loons which, when rubbed vigorously on your shirt or sweater, can be suspended from a wall or ceiling.

But gecko feet work in ionised air, which would cancel out the electrostatic effect. That leaves old-fashioned glue: except that gecko feet have no suitable glue-secreting glands.

Back to square one, then - except that in the 1960s, a German scientist, Uwe Hiller, wondered whether gecko feet might work by tap-dancing their way into the molecular landscape of the surfaces they crossed. Many molecules have a slight electrical polarisation. Rather than being balanced throughout, they have spots of excess negative or positive charge. These allow different molecules to bind together very loosely, through a weak kind of electrostatic interaction called the van der Waals force. Although very weak, this force is highly important. It holds the strands of DNA together, and some of the unusual properties of water - such as its high boiling point - are connected to the fact that its molecules form loose, ever-changing associations, bound by the van der Waals force.

Uwe Hiller wondered if the fine hairs of gecko feet might exploit van der Waals forces. Supporting evidence came from an unusual finding: that geckos got stickier in proportion to the "free energy" - the degree to which surfaces have loose molecular ends - of the surfaces they crossed. Measurements by Full and colleagues on single gecko foot hairs are consistent with this idea: it sounds crazy, but geckos make their way by a kind of atomic energy.

How to reverse-engineer gecko feet into something useful? Forget Duck tape - Gecko tape could stick anything to anything else as securely as molecular bonds would allow, yet peel off gently, leaving no stain or trace. Sounds wonderful. Except that Full and colleagues admit defeat, at least for now: human technology is just too crude to manufacture structures as exquisitely tiny and precise as gecko foot hairs.

But, they suggest, the very contemplation of such structures could inspire those souls driven to create the perfect dry adhesive. After all, stranger things have happened: legend has it that the hooked burrs of plants inspired the invention of Velcro. And, these days, we'd certainly come unstuck without that.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature. His book, Deep Time: Cladistics, the Revolution in Evolution, is published by Fourth Estate, price £20

fields.headline: French fury over financial crimes
fields.trailText: French MPs went to London yesterday to complain about what their country's police describe as the "exceptionally poor" level of judicial cooperation from British authorities in fighting money laundering and serious financial crime.
fields.body:
French MPs went to London yesterday to complain about what their country's police describe as the "exceptionally poor" level of judicial cooperation from British authorities in fighting money laundering and serious financial crime.

The French group's leaders, Vincent Peillon and Arnaud Montebourg, two Socialist MPs, have statistics from their justice ministry showing that between January 1996 and June last year France made 100 formal requests to the British authorities for judicial assistance in cases of suspected financial crime.

Over the same period, six similar requests were sent to Lichtenstein, 36 to Holland, 68 to Luxembourg and 374 to Switzerland. Britain's cooperation was the worst - only 47% of requests involving suspected financial crimes, and only 24% of those to do with money-laundering, were acted on.

"It's a very serious problem," said one Paris magistrate. "I know of half a dozen major French financial cases that have completely broken down because of a repeated lack of cooperation from the British."

The delegation to London will visit the Home Office, the Financial Services Authority, the Metropolitan police, the Inland Revenue, and the Serious Fraud Office.

The French are especially concerned about the openings for financial crime through Britain's offshore tax havens. A French case involving £20m of fake invoices fell apart last year after Jersey police said the island's laws did not let them help over money laundering.

French police are also concerned about other serious crimes, such as the Algerian-sponsored GIA terrorist bombings in Paris in 1995. Rachid Ramda, the alleged financier of the attack, has not been extradited from his UK jail, despite the evidence against him.

Toby Graham, a London lawyer, told Le Monde newspaper that the problem might be a personnel shortage in the Home Office unit dealing with foreign judicial requests.

webTitle: Policeman 'carried out sex attacks in cell'

fields.headline: Policeman 'carried out sex attacks in cell'
fields.standfirst: Sergeant denies raping two women and assaulting three others as prosecution alleges he used his job to take advantage of vulnerable females
fields.trailText: A police sergeant abused his position of power to systematically rape and sexually assault vulnerable women in police cells and at their homes, a jury heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A police sergeant abused his position of power to systematically rape and sexually assault vulnerable women in police cells and at their homes, a jury heard yesterday.

Paul Banfield, 33, a custody sergeant in Cambridge, is accused of raping two women, one while she was held prisoner in a police cell at Parkside police station and another after he broke into her home while he was on duty. He is also charged with indecently assaulting three other women, two of them while they were held overnight in police cells while he was the custody sergeant on duty.

Banfield has pleaded guilty to three charges of indecent assault against two of the women, the jury at Nottingham crown court heard yesterday.

Roy Amlot QC, prosecuting, told the jury of eight men and four women that the attacks had all taken place between September 1998 and October 1999. He said Banfield, from St Neots, Cambridgeshire, was based at Parkside, the main police station in Cambridge, during that time and was on duty when all but one of the offences were committed.

Mr Amlot said Banfield was not accused of an isolated assault but a series of incidents "within a comparatively short period of time". He said the officer was "taking advantage of his position of authority with vulnerable female prisoners in the cell at his police station".

Mr Justice Morland and the jury heard that the first victim, referred to as Ms B, was a 45-year-old woman who was raped in her home at Waterbeach, just outside Cambridge, in the early hours of September 13 1998, after she returned home from a night out to celebrate a friend's birthday.

Giving evidence yesterday, Ms B, a divorcee, said she had walked with friends to Market Square, in the centre of Cambridge, to find a taxi home. She and a male friend chatted with Banfield, who was sitting alone in a police van in uniform, during the course of which she gave the officer her address in relation to a burglary at her home.

When Ms B returned to her home in Waterbeach, a village near Cambridge, at about 3am, she fell asleep fully dressed on her sofa in front of the television. "When she woke up, she was upstairs in her bed, on her face with a man on top of her having sexual intercourse," Mr Amlot told the court.

Ms B broke down in tears as she told the jury: "Someone was on top of me and he was inside me. I thought it was a dream. Then he got off and put his clothes on and I heard a police radio come on. It was the policeman who I was talking to in Market Square."

Ms B told her friends about the rape later that day, one of whom told a police officer, and she was later contacted by two officers but never made a formal complaint because, she said, she was "scared".

The court heard that Banfield later claimed that Ms B had flirted with him in Market Square, and he had overheard her telling a friend that she "fancied him and wanted to chat him up", before inviting him to her home. When he arrived he was unable to wake her and climbed in through an open window and woke her. She made him a cup of coffee before they had consensual sex. Police computer records show that Banfield failed to answer a call for back-up from a fellow officer at 4am, the court heard.

Under cross-examination by Robert Fischel QC, for the defence, Ms B denied she had been drunk and only claimed she had been raped because she "bitterly regretted" cheating on her boyfriend with Banfield. She also denied writing her telephone number on Banfield's hand, inviting him to her home and initiating consensual sex.

The court also heard details of the charges concerning the other four alleged victims.

The second, referred to as Ms C, was a 28-year-old legal worker and former girlfriend of Banfield, who alleged she was indecently assaulted at her home in August last year. After the assault, Mr Amlot said, Banfield "used the rather chilling expression, 'What are you going to do? Call the police?'."

Banfield later told police that the woman had made sexual overtures to him.

The third alleged victim was a prisoner at Parkside police station, Ms F, a 23-year-old woman who had been arrested for shoplifting in September last year. The court heard that Banfield visited her a number of times in her cell, telling her she was pretty and kissing her on the lips and groping her. webTitle: ITV set to reduce regional shows

fields.headline: ITV set to reduce regional shows
fields.trailText: Regional programmes on ITV appear likely to be cut back as the network moves towards consolidation into a single company.
fields.body:
Regional programmes on ITV appear likely to be cut back as the network moves towards consolidation into a single company.

The independent television commission said yesterday that it favoured a more flexible approach to ITV's commitment to the regions, adding that an "overall decrease [in hours] might be acceptable".

The views were published in a consultation paper on regional programming which followed a separate ITC report last week conceding that ITV's public service role would be hard to maintain in today's competitive environment.

The ITV companies have long lobbied behind the scenes for a lighter regulatory touch, although in public they shy away from suggestions that they consider regional programming onerous. The maximum number of hours devoted to regional programming in an average week is 18.3 in the Scottish region.

The ITC's chief executive, Peter Rogers, maintained that the proposals were more about maintaining quality and diversity in regional programming than diminishing it.

Under current regulations the 14 regions have to specify the hours they dedicate to regional news, sport and entertainment. But the report expressed concerns that much regional programming was low budget and given "dead" slots in the afternoon or late evening. The ITC added it would redefine the commitments to "allow more flexibility and creativity" and aimed to set new peaktime targets for programmes with a strong regional flavour.

It commended networked series including Coronation Street, Peak Practice and Emmerdale.

The categories to which minimum amounts of time must be allocated will be reduced to news, current affairs and an all-embracing "other".

A Granada spokesman welcomed the report. "Regionality has been at the heart of ITV and it is very important that it should be preserved and regulated properly, but regulation needs to move with the times and we are pleased the ITC is shifting toward a more flexible approach."

The map of ITV regions was first drawn some 40 years ago. Ownership of the licences has become dominated by just three companies - Granada, United News & Media and Carlton Communications - after a wave of consolidation in the past decade.

The ITC acknowledged that consolidation into a single ITV company would be inevitable when legislation allowed. A communications white paper is expected to pave the way in the autumn.

Mr Rogers said: "The ITC believes that regional and national identities across the UK are stronger than ever, and that viewers identify with, and wish to be informed on, aspects of local life, particularly with the introduction of devolved assemblies."

webTitle: Threats to witnesses see inquest cancelled

fields.headline: Threats to witnesses see inquest cancelled
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A public inquiry into the sectarian murder of a Catholic man in Portadown, Co Armagh, in front of armed RUC officers three years ago, moved closer yesterday, after a coroner decided against holding an inquest because of threats to witnesses' lives.
fields.body:
A public inquiry into the sectarian murder of a Catholic man in Portadown, Co Armagh, in front of armed RUC officers three years ago, moved closer yesterday, after a coroner decided against holding an inquest because of threats to witnesses' lives.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, expressed deep concern and demanded a full report after the Belfast coroner John Leckey cancelled the inquest into the death of Robert Hamill, 25.

Mr Hamill's family and legal team will step up their fight for an independent inquiry when they meet the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, in Dublin tonight. He is backing their demand.

Campaigners compare the RUC's approach to the assault on Mr Hamill to the Metropolitan police response to the stabbing of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence in south London seven years ago. They accuse the RUC of institutional sectarianism against Catholics.

Barra McGrory, solicitor for the Hamill family, refused to divulge the witnesses' identities or speculate on who was behind the threats. But the witnesses are understood to be civilians.

Mr McGrory said a public inquiry would be better suited to protect witnesses from intimidation. He backed Mr Leckey's decision.

Mr Leckey said in a statement he regretted his decision, but he believed there was no point in holding an inquest without the witnesses' testimony, because it would add little to evidence already in the public domain after a criminal trial last year.

The statement issued on his behalf said: "He is satisfied that their lives would be placed in danger if the evidence were to be given out, or placed in documentary form before an inquest."

Mr Hamill died from head injuries in May 1997, 12 days after a 30-strong loyalist mob attacked him as he was walked home from a dance club used by Catholics. According to witnesses, some jumped on his head, shouting "Kill!" and "Die, you Fenian bastard!"

Mr Hamill, who was with three relatives, chose to walk the short distance home despite having to pass through the town centre, dangerous for Catholics in the early hours, because he saw a police Land Rover in the street. Four armed RUC officers were in the Land Rover, but they failed to intervene to stop the assault, about 20 yards away.

Prosecutions against RUC personnel were ruled out last September. There is no announcement on whether they will face disciplinary action.

Murder charges against five men were dropped when two witnesses, believed to be the same people at the centre of yesterday's development, withdrew their evidence. Because of that, the prosecution decided there was no reasonable chance of conviction.

A sixth man, Marc Hobson, 22, was cleared of murder in March last year, just after the loyalist assassination of Rosemary Nelson, the Hamill family's lawyer. He was jailed for four years for affray.

All the men were placed at their own request on the Loyalist Volunteer Force wing at the Maze prison while on remand. Hobson is set to be freed next month under the Good Friday agreement.

At Hobson's trial, Lord Justice McCollum was unable to say whether the police had stayed in their vehicle during the attack on Mr Hamill. He ruled that even if they had been alerted at the earliest moment, it was unlikely they could have saved him.

But Dara O'Hagan, Sinn Fein assembly member for Upper Bann, said yesterday: "What happened to Robert Hamill is a regular occurrence in Portadown. The difference was that he died. The RUC sat by because it believed he was just another Taig being beaten."

The RUC initially claimed that Mr Hamill was the victim of a fight between rival mobs.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

British beef farmers: Agriculture minister Lady Hayman told the Lords that Malta and Ghana have now lifted the ban on the export of British beef. She described France as "now completely isolated" in Europe as the only country not accepting our beef.

Bad day

Hollywood: Tony Blair added his voice to the criticism of the new movie U571 agreeing it was an "affront" to British sailors. The film portrays the capture of the Enigma coding machine - an event which changed the course of the second world war - as an American operation when it was actually a British exploit.

Farm noise of day

The chicken: Labour MPs merrily clucked away at prime minister's questions as Tory David Amess (Southend) tried to speak. In 1997 Mr Amess, fearing he would lose his Basildon seat, chose to fight Southend in the general election.

Today

Commons: Education and employment questions. Opposition debates on pensions and GM crops. Short backbench debate on grants in Newark for manufacturing. Lords: Postal services bill, committee.

fields.headline: The perfect man's chiselled squint
fields.trailText: For centuries it has been the standard by which male beauty has been judged. But now laser scans of Michelangelo's David have revealed that the statue has a squint. Far from being the paragon of physical perfection, the artist deliberately skewed the statue's eyes so that from the ground David appears to be eyeballing his enemy, Goliath.
fields.body:
For centuries it has been the standard by which male beauty has been judged. But now laser scans of Michelangelo's David have revealed that the statue has a squint. Far from being the paragon of physical perfection, the artist deliberately skewed the statue's eyes so that from the ground David appears to be eyeballing his enemy, Goliath.

The trick of perspective - which has taken 500 years to rumble - was a typical stroke of Michelangelo genius, according to Marc Levoy, the computer scientist from Stanford University, California, who made the discovery. He suspects it went unnoticed for so long because David's more obvious attribute - his genitalia - blinded successive generations to the "flaw". The statue after all was meant to represent the virility of the Florentine republic which had only recently thrown off the yoke of the despotic Medicis when Michelangelo finished the work in 1504.

Levoy, who spent nearly a year making precise, computerised images of several of Michelangelo's most famous sculptures, also found that the David in Galleria dell'Accademia in Florence is a metre taller than the museum's own measurements for him.

The statue was moved from the city's Palazzo Vecchio in the 19th century and replaced with a cast because of fears of vandalism as the age of mass tourism dawned. Levoy picked up the squint when he bathed the head in a thin sheet of laser light and then raised a gantry so he could point a scanner straight into its face. Standing at 23ft on its pedestal, looking sideways into a gallery wall, the face was difficult to see from the ground.

Levoy told New Scientist magazine that the squint was a typical Michelangelo trick. "He optimised each eye for its appearance as seen from the side," he said. Levoy claims his examination technique is so detailed it reveals the tiny natural cracks in the marble and also the marks made by Michelangelo's chisel.

Peta Motture, a renaissance expert at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, which has a cast of David, said it was a fascinating discovery. "I might need to go away and have another look at him now."

Adrian Searle, the art critic of the Guardian, said this was "another ridiculous and irritating example of scientists second-guessing artists' intentions when they really don't know what were the conditions of the time"

He added: "It is so easy to do this 500 years later and come up with easy explanations. Particularly when you are working with marble, which is full of imperfections, cracks and subtle variations in density, you just cannot assume these things".

Scientists, he said, had also tried to ascribe El Greco's strange perspectives to the fact "he had a squint or some other problem with his eyes" without looking at the effect Greek icon painting had on the painter's style.

Levoy has now turned his attention to digitally reconstructing the 1,800-year-old Forma Ubis Romae, a giant map of the ancient world carved on to marble slabs, which has shattered into more than a thousand pieces.

fields.headline: Player's hips may save goalkeeper
fields.trailText: The goalkeeper's fear of the penalty may be at an end.
fields.body:
The goalkeeper's fear of the penalty may be at an end.

Researchers have found that the direction of a penalty taker's hips just before he kicks the ball betrays which side of the net he is aiming at, New Scientist magazine reported yesterday.

Mark Williams, head of science and football at Liverpool John Moores University, said: "If the taker's hips are square-on to the goalkeeper in a right footed kicker, the penalty tends to go to the right hand side of the keeper. If his hips are more 'open' or angled away from the goalkeeper, the kick tends to go to the left of the keeper."

Dr William's findings, outlined to a conference on science and football in Kuala Lumpur last month, came after he played goalkeepers life-sized video footage of penalty kickers approaching and striking penalties. The films were taken from the point of view of a goalkeeper standing at the centre of the goal mouth.

The film was stopped 120 milliseconds before the kick, 40 milliseconds before, at the point of impact, and 40 milliseconds afterwards. Goalkeepers who played semi-professionally were consistently better than unskilled amateurs at predicting which of four target spots in the goal the ball would hit.

A questionnaire about what visual clues keepers used to predict the direction of shots revealed the key importance of kicker's hip position.

At 120 milliseconds before impact, half the semi-pro keepers guessed correctly. The success rate rose to 62% 40 milliseconds before, and 82% at impact. At each stage the experienced keepers were 10 percentage points ahead of the amateurs.

The angle of the run-up, orientation of the non-kicking foot, position of the lower leg and the lean of the trunk were also significant.

webTitle: Rivals cry foul at Sportal's Euro 2000 coup

fields.headline: Rivals cry foul at Sportal's Euro 2000 coup
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: For the past six months the special projects room at Sportal's offices in Battersea in south London has been crammed with journalists and programmers racing to build the official internet site for Euro 2000.
fields.body:
For the past six months the special projects room at Sportal's offices in Battersea in south London has been crammed with journalists and programmers racing to build the official internet site for Euro 2000.

The 40-strong team aims to produce the most visited site during the 21-day festival of football. The offer will include news, comment and ball by ball analysis as well as highlights of every game from previous tournaments.

As with most sports, it is best to be close to the action. So the Euro 2000 team transferred to offices in Rotterdam last week end in time for the tournament's kick-off on Saturday.

As workers for the official site - Euro2000.org - they will be the only web journalists with access to all the games, and in the competitive sports website market that is an important advantage.

But rivals at organisations such as Sports.com, 365 Corporation, PlanetFootball, the Guardian's Football Unlimited and Soccernet have no intention of conceding the battle for the sports addicted "eyeballs" that bring advertising, sponsorship and e-commerce revenues.

The web has seen tremendous growth since Euro 96, when sports sites were in their infancy. Today, up to the minute news, views, statistics and results will be crucial in satisfying the information cravings of web users, as will be the ability to cope with what are predicted to be record levels of traffic.

"Euro2000.org will undoubtedly be our most important and highest profile test yet," said Sportal chief executive Rob Hersov.

He refused to say how much it has cost to build the site for Uefa, European football's governing body. Features include replays of every goal scored in every previous European championship. In return Sportal has received a platinum sponsor package which has cost Coca-Cola and others around $10m. Included is plenty of pitch-side advertising space and corporate hospitality packages.

Mr Hersov believes it is money well spent. Sportal's business model is based on acquiring exclusive online rights to major sports organisations and in effect denying rivals access. Clients include Juventus, AC Milan and South African rugby team the Springboks.

"If you are a football fan looking for information on Euro 2000 we will offer exclusive content and get you closer to the action than anyone else," Mr Hersov said.

Some of his rivals are less sure that fans will go to the official site. Almost all are unhappy that Uefa has limited accreditation to Sportal. "Sports fans want the good, the bad and the ugly of the game and I don't think the Sportal site will offer that," said Tom Jessiman, the managing director of Sports.com.

"Do a search on the word 'hooliganism' on their site and I bet it returns with nothing. All the independent sites are examining the issue seriously. Anyway, I'm not sure we would want to risk that much investment on a three-week event."

Sports.com, whose backers include Reuters, Intel and Sportsline.com in the US, and is valued at $210m, employs around 100 people in Britain. Its last audited figures showed monthly page impressions totalling 31m.

Soccernet, the ESPN and Associated New Media-owned site, will cover Euro 2000 from England, principally using con tent from the Daily Mail and London Evening Standard. Jason O'Sullivan, director of ESPN, said the tournament was important, but company insiders suggest a relaunch of the site before the new football season is the priority.

Eamonn Watson, editorial director of Planetfootball.com, part of the Sports Internet group recently bought by BSkyB for £300m, concedes that the day when fans are able to watch games live on the web could be some way off. "The technology is essentially there but it's difficult to put a handle on when it will actually happen. You also have the thorny issue of rights to deal with."

Part of the logic behind the BSkyB deal was to give Planetfootball access to a digital platform. Together they are likely to be one of the lead bidders for the Premier League's online rights, due for sale shortly.

webTitle: Blair links 'old' values to new agenda

fields.headline: Blair links 'old' values to new agenda
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The message Tony Blair was trying to get over against the heckling of the Women's Institute yesterday was that Labour's passion for modernisation is not at odds with the popular love of tradition.
fields.body:
The message Tony Blair was trying to get over against the heckling of the Women's Institute yesterday was that Labour's passion for modernisation is not at odds with the popular love of tradition.

He coupled this with a response to criticism of government control freakery when he said: "We in government - and that means me - have to trust people more. We don't need to fight over every headline. We should put more faith in people's desire to engage in a conversation about the future."

The prime minister said: "At the heart of my beliefs is the idea of community. I don't just mean the local villages, towns and cities in which we live. I mean that our fulfilment as individuals lies in a decent society of others. My argument... is that the renewal of community is the answer to the challenges of a changing world.

"The way we do it is to combine the old and the new, traditional British values of responsibility and respect for others; with a new agenda of opportunity for all in a changing world...

"The world seems in a state of perpetual revolution. It is no wonder people feel insecure, frightened for their future.

"We all share the anxieties of today's world: the fear that our child will be bullied or worse offered drugs in the playground. The worry that children are exposed to too much sex and too much violence too young. The struggle of balancing work and family.

"Lives of honesty, struggle, decency, responsibility. People who have hopes for themselves and high hopes for their children. Lives that cry out for the helping hand of an active community, not the cold shoulder, the cruelty, of those who say 'you're on your own'. A community there for them when they need it, helping them cope with change, supporting their families, making sure their effort is rewarded."

Mr Blair said these were "good old British values". But the spirit of the age was democratic. "We won't rebuild community on the basis of doffing your cap or hierarchy. The rich man in his castle, the poor man at his gate: it won't wash any more."

Mr Blair distinguished between the "genuine" old-fashioned values that underpinned his parents' generation and "attitudes and values we can safely leave behind". The enduring values included good manners, respect for others, courtesy, giving up your seat for the elderly, saying please and thank you. Attitudes for jettisoning included his father's fierce opposition to his mother working.

He reasserted education as Britain's No.1 priority. Referring to the debate about widening access to Oxbridge and other top universities, he said: "Let's hear no more rubbish about class war, as if we had to choose between caricatures of Little Lord Fauntleroy or Karl Marx. Gordon Brown and I believe passionately in extending opportunity for all. But neither of us will have any truck with old-fashioned egalitarianism that levels down. We are unashamed supporters of excellence. But we need to give far more of our kids a shot at it."

webTitle: TV cricket to the sound of music

fields.headline: TV cricket to the sound of music
fields.trailText: A performance by reggae band Third World and Jools Holland at Lord's this month will launch Channel 4's "Caribbean summer" in an attempt to woo a younger audience to the sport during the Test series between England and the West Indies.
fields.body:
It is enough to make an MCC member choke on his cucumber sandwich and spill his tea on the floor of the Long Room. Instead of the traditional marching band, the sound of drum'n'bass and Jamaican ragga will resound around the traditionally staid surroundings of some of England's most famous cricket grounds this summer.

A performance by reggae band Third World and Jools Holland at Lord's this month will launch Channel 4's "Caribbean summer" in an attempt to woo a younger audience to the sport during the Test series between England and the West Indies.

The Lord's opener on June 29 will see bands play on the pitch during the lunch interval. Further shows will take place at Old Trafford in Manchester, Headingley in Leeds and The Oval in London later in the series.

Performers taking part include the drum'n'bass guru, LTJ Bukem, Jamaican ragga star Beenie Man and brass band the Black Dyke Band.

David Brook, Channel 4's director of strategy, said: "When Channel 4 first acquired the cricket we planned to bring a fresh approach to the game and to bring new audiences in. So the arrival of the West Indies is a great way to a introduce a Caribbean flavour."

As well as the shows within the grounds, the channel is planning to set up giant screens in public parks where cricket fans will be able to watch the action free. There will also be swimming pools and sandpits to recreate island life.

The first event will be at Roundhay Park in Leeds from August 17 to 20 during the Headingley game, while discussions are continuing for a similar event at Clapham Common in south London during the Oval Test from August 31 to September 3.

Among Channel 4's season of programmes will be Caribbean Mate, a Barbados version of the dating show Street Mate, and a look at nationalism and independence on the Caribbean islands in Darcus Howe: Trouble In Paradise.

A special Richard Blackwood Show and Rebel Music, a tribute concert for reggae legend Bob Marley, are also lined up.

webTitle: Fearless WI reveals its radical side

fields.headline: Fearless WI reveals its radical side
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Members of the Women's Institute have gradually changed from their jam and cake making image of old.
fields.body:
Members of the Women's Institute have gradually changed from their jam and cake making image of old.

In recent years they entered the debate on one of the most emotive issues, GM foods, and demanded a five-year moratorium. Members in North Yorkshire stripped off for a charity calendar, while others became eco-warriors protesting against the erecting of pylons. The WI was against nuclear power before the TUC and opposed bus deregulation by the Conservatives.

The WI has needed to modernise. Membership is today down from a post-war peak of 500,000 to 250,000, though it is still the largest women's organisation in the UK.

It was formed in 1915 as a progressive countrywomen's movement and more recently the radicalism its organisers say has always nestled beneath its middle Britain respectability has come more to the fore.

Sangeeta Haindl, spokeswoman for the National Federation of Women's Institutes, said: "The Women's Institute has always been very modern and radical. What's happened is that people have woken up to that fact."

Ms Haindl said the jam making image that has hung like a set of fake pearls round its neck was not its fault. She said the government had asked WI members to make jam during the war. Beforehand, it had talked about the dangers of marine pollution in the 1920s and better pay and conditions for nurses in 1938.

"What's happened is that during the last couple of years the WI has enhanced its image and married the traditional with the new.

"We've been getting better at raising our profile and selling ourselves."

She cites two examples of the WI's sharper profile. One was a report on the change in rural communities which received national television and newspaper coverage. The other was its decision on GM foods: "It showed the WI had consumer power."
