webTitle: PR disaster as No 10 fails to get the message

fields.headline: PR disaster as No 10 fails to get the message
fields.standfirst:
Blair and the WI: Re-entry after paternity leave founders at first fence as prime minister proves 'too political'

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Back in February last year two women from Downing Street made what emerges nearly 18 months later to have been a fateful journey to 104 New Kings Road, London SW6 - the headquarters of the National Federation of Women's Institutes.
fields.body:
Back in February last year two women from Downing Street made what emerges nearly 18 months later to have been a fateful journey to 104 New Kings Road, London SW6 - the headquarters of the National Federation of Women's Institutes.

Siobhan Kenny from the Downing Street strategic communications unit and Fiona Reynolds, director of the Cabinet Office women's unit, were looking for new ways to convey the Blair message, circumventing the traditional cynicism of parliamentary journalists.

They had alighted on women's mass market magazines, and also the Womens Institute's own magazine, Home and Country, with its potential readership of 250,000.

Ms Kenny explained to the then WI chairman, Eileen Meadmore, that the government was taking initiatives in areas of interest to the WI. Ms Meadmore, no leftwinger, had been instrumental in trying to modernise the image of the WI, even endorsing members who posed for a nude calendar. She also supported the efforts of Tessa Jowell when Labour was in oppositon to create a relationship between Labour and the supremely traditional WI.

Ms Kenny recalls at the meeting that she asked Ms Meadmore whether there was anything else the government could do to further its relationship with the WI. Ms Meadmore then suggested, according to Ms Kenny, that the prime minister speak at their annual conference later in the summer. Ms Kenny suggested that might be difficult since Tony Blair's diary might be very full.

The trail went cold until February this year when Ms Jowell suggested to the new WI chairman Helen Carey that Mr Blair might be willing to take up the standing invitation.

Correspondence ensued in which the WI suggested the prime minister speak on health, transport, the post office and community values. Ms Carey, a member of the women's national commission and a past critic of Labour women MPs, stressed they did not want a party political speech, pointing out no prime minister had ever spoken to the WI since the federation was formed in Wales in 1915.

Yet Ms Carey still sounded enthusiastic earlier this week. She told the Times that Mr Blair's address would be "a marvellous morale booster" and prove the WI's radical edge had returned. But in a warning Downing Street clearly misread, she added: "I can honestly say that if anyone chooses to use the address as a political platform it would backfire".

Clearly Downing Street and the WI had a different view of what represents a political speech. The prime minister's spokesman admitted yesterday afternoon as the PR disaster gathered pace: "We have been racking our brains - if that was a political speech - what the prime minister could have said other than reading out the phone book. It's beyond us." He added: "If a politician speaks on any subject, it is represented as political. If you don't like that, don't invite him".

The problem may have been that Mr Blair came to regard the speech as an increasingly important chance to reconnect the government with the people. At the same time the WI may have been getting cold feet over the invitation.

Mr Blair wrote the bulk of the speech at Chequers where he became increasingly alarmed at the accusations that the party was returning to class war. He was also concerned by focus group work showing that voters not just in WI Middle Britain, but in working class seats felt the government was out of touch. He wanted to emphasise tradition, not modernisation. He stressed the need to revive the church. He admitted the perspective of a few weeks away from the front line of politics had changed and relaxed him.

"I think we in government - and that means me - have to trust people more. We don't need to fight over every headline. We should put more faith in people's desire to engage in a conversation about the future." Ironically yesterday's PR disaster, and its preceding misjudgements, will only make Mr Blair and his inner circle even more intent to fight over every headline.

webTitle: It's toff at the top and - I should know

fields.headline: It's toff at the top and - I should know
fields.standfirst: I certainly had advantages over those who hadn't been at boarding school
fields.trailText: I certainly had advantages over those who hadn't been at boarding school.
fields.body:
I was educated for a lifetime of painting my toenails. Yet this has not proved to be quite the disadvantage I once feared. It was disturbing to have to teach myself one of my A-levels. But academic knowledge is much easier to acquire than the public school confidence that Laura Spence was said to lack. It is this gilt on the gingerbread that drives men like Gordon Brown into paroxysms of envy, desire and despair.

When I arrived at Oxford there must have been two or three times more state- educated men than there were women from any kind of school. But this didn't exactly leave me feeling crushed. I read "minority" as "interesting" or "exclusive" rather than "insignificant" or "second tier". And, after seven years locked up in a convent, I wanted to get down and party as soon as possible. In this I had two advantages over those who hadn't been at boarding school since early childhood. I wasn't paralysed by homesickness - and my social contacts weren't limited to one area of the country.

The products of the major public schools are linked by formative experiences, blood, snobbery and ambition. We couldn't help but gravitate towards each other. I rapidly found myself part of a network of undergraduates that spanned the colleges. It was at least a year before I started to form friendships with people from a different background. Others never did, but I had at least one thing in common with those from less affluent families. Strange though it may seem, I had no money. I can't pretend that I am grateful for that. I would be happy not to have first-hand experience of how penury limits your options and leaves you debilitated by fear.

However, if the poor little posh girl had to live off alternate meals of cabbage and porridge, she also felt at home drinking champagne in the quads at New College. For others the experience was a little uncomfortable and stayed so until the day came when they woke up to find they had changed from working-class children into upper-middle-class adults. The regional accent had gone (although I notice William Hague's seems to have come back again) and they had become strangers to their own parents. A friend from the north of England described to me how her family had come to see her after her final exams bearing a bottle of naff medium-sweet wine. Her first reaction was one of contempt for their poor taste. Her second was to despise herself for her reaction.

My friend eventually went to work in London, delivered by the university with no obvious past before Oxford but a great future to follow it. I never asked her how she felt about this rebirth, but I do remember another woman worrying that the remnants of her Mancunian accent might deprive her of a job in the City. It seemed an absurd and completely unnecessary concern to me.

But then Gordon Brown's belief that the Britain is being run by a secret ring of Bufton Tuftons seemed barking too - until I gave it further thought. I know plenty of men and women who went to public school and are now living on benefits, or trying to raise their families on Mcwages. I have plenty of other friends who are self-made millionaires. But despite such evidence, few really believe that we live in a meritocracy. "Merit" is never enough.

I rarely hear an English regional accent in London. Everyone I meet talks with the same BBC-style received pronunciation. That way, I suppose, they can be understood by the aristocrats that attend any party thrown by the metropolitan elite. It seems the rich and powerful need to have access to a class that you have to be born into to feel really special. And if they fail they become very angry. Mohamed Al Fayed bought Harrods because he thought it would open doors mounted by broken pediments. When he discovered it hadn't he came over all resentful. If only he had realised he could satisfy his social ambitions by sending his children to Eton instead. It has worked wonders for half of Fleet Street.

If there is no upper-class mafia pulling the levers of power, the aspirational middle classes have found it necessary to invent one. Toffs like Tara Palmer-Tomkinson, Zac Goldsmith and the Marchioness of Worcester are placed on pedestals to give the middle classes one more rung to climb. Thus it is that the social advantages bequeathed by my limited schooling continue. I don't have GCSE maths, but I don't have the burden of worrying about what's U and non-U either. If it's me, it's U - and I have the hanging baskets to prove it. If only Gordon felt as confident. Playing second fiddle to a public school educated Oxford graduate is clearly getting him down. He's all brain and no signet ring and in the corridors of power, that's not good enough. Pass the nail varnish, Alastair.

However, if the poor little posh girl had to live off alternate meals of cabbage and porridge, she also felt at home drinking champagne in the quads at New College. For others the experience was a little uncomfortable and stayed so until the day came when they woke up to find they had changed from working-class children into upper-middle-class adults. The regional accent had gone (although I notice William Hague's seems to have come back again) and they had become strangers to their own parents. A friend from the north of England described to me how her family had come to see her after her final exams bearing a bottle of naff medium-sweet wine. Her first reaction was one of contempt for their poor taste. Her second was to despise herself for her reaction. My friend eventually went to work in London, delivered by the university with no obvious past before Oxford but a great future to follow it. I never asked her how she felt about this rebirth, but I do remember another woman worrying that the remnants of her Mancunian accent might deprive her of a job in the City. It seemed an absurd and completely unnecessary concern to me. But then Gordon Brown's belief that the Britain is being run by a secret ring of Bufton Tuftons seemed barking too - until I gave it further thought. I know plenty of men and women who went to public school and are now living on benefits, or trying to raise their families on Mcwages. I have plenty of other friends who are self-made millionaires. But despite such evidence, few really believe that we live in a meritocracy. "Merit" is never enough. I rarely hear an English regional accent in London. Everyone I meet talks with the same BBC-style received pronunciation. That way, I suppose, they can be understood by the aristocrats that attend any party thrown by the metropolitan elite. It seems the rich and powerful need to have access to a class that you have to be born into to feel really special. And if they fail they become very angry. Mohamed Al Fayed bought Harrods because he thought it would open doors mounted by broken pediments. When he discovered it hadn't he came over all resentful. If only he had realised he could satisfy his social ambitions by sending his children to Eton instead. It has worked wonders for half of Fleet Street. If there is no upper-class mafia pulling the levers of power, the aspirational middle classes have found it necessary to invent one. Toffs like Tara Palmer-Tomkinson, Zac Goldsmith and the Marchioness of Worcester are placed on pedestals to give the middle classes one more rung to climb. Thus it is that the social advantages bequeathed by my limited schooling continue. I don't have GCSE maths, but I don't have the burden of worrying about what's U and non-U either. If it's me, it's U - and I have the hanging baskets to prove it. If only Gordon felt as confident. Playing second fiddle to a public school educated Oxford graduate is clearly getting him down. He's all brain and no signet ring and in the corridors of power, that's not good enough. Pass the nail varnish, Alastair. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •The victory of Tony "Robinson" Baldrick in the Minor Television Personality section of the NEC ballot was a delight for all who believe that what New Labour needs is more second-rate actors sucking up to Mr Tony. One's suspicion that Mr Baldrick is an important political thinker in the making was reinforced when he celebrated his election by attacking the "diehards", or lefties, on the NEC; he sees them as "the kind of forces of conservatism that Tony Blair said Labour was organised against" because of the NEC decision to reject an appeal by a certain Joe Goldberg, another Blair loyalist, over what he claimed to be the rigged election that prevented him from having a second term as chairman of Labour students. How brave of Balders to take this heroic stand over such an obscure matter. As for Mr Goldberg, who was campaign manager during the NEC elections for a Mr Tony Baldrick (and who we gather is going out with Mr Tony Baldrick's daughter Laura), we wish him well in the post-student world.

The victory of Tony "Robinson" Baldrick in the Minor Television Personality section of the NEC ballot was a delight for all who believe that what New Labour needs is more second-rate actors sucking up to Mr Tony. One's suspicion that Mr Baldrick is an important political thinker in the making was reinforced when he celebrated his election by attacking the "diehards", or lefties, on the NEC; he sees them as "the kind of forces of conservatism that Tony Blair said Labour was organised against" because of the NEC decision to reject an appeal by a certain Joe Goldberg, another Blair loyalist, over what he claimed to be the rigged election that prevented him from having a second term as chairman of Labour students. How brave of Balders to take this heroic stand over such an obscure matter. As for Mr Goldberg, who was campaign manager during the NEC elections for a Mr Tony Baldrick (and who we gather is going out with Mr Tony Baldrick's daughter Laura), we wish him well in the post-student world.

London Transport advertises a terrific money saving wheeze at tube stations. Holders of one-day travelcards can get two-for-the-price-of-one entry to various museums and art galleries, the poster reveals, including the new Tate Modern, Tate Britain and the National Portrait Gallery. Marvellous. Only a pedantic sneerer would point out that they are all free to enter anyway.

Following Mr Tony's WI reception, my colleague Richard Adams rings Downing Street, and is passed to the bored sounding fellow who seems to have special responsibility for the Diary. Richard is barely halfway through asking his question - whether there is any truth in the rumour that Mr Tony Blair is thinking of cancelling his planned address to the Tufty club - when the pup interrupts. "I suggest you speak to Mike White or Patrick Wintour," he says. But neither have joined the Downing Street press office? "No, but they've both just been to the briefing." Click, brrrrr.

Fans of the lord chancellor are disappointed at his quietude on the matter of elitism in education. What is the point having such a sagacious adviser (albeit one with bright red cheeks and - when bewigged - a startling resemblance to Deputy Dawg) if he doesn't share his thoughts on the hottest topic of the day? Ah well, it's early days. By the way, does anyone know whether it was one son that Derry sent to St Paul's, or two?

At Prime Minister's Questions, meanwhile, Tory David Amess announced his widely predicted candidacy for Stupidest MP 2000 with a question too mind-numbingly dull to remember, let alone repeat. He is the third David to join the contest, alongside messrs Winnick, defending champion from the Wilson era, and Wilshire. The latter, you will recall, is trying to sue Labour agent Harold Trace for remarks in a letter to the Heathrow Villager when defending the hospital treating him for cancer from the MP's alleged scaremongering. Mr Trace has written to Mr Wilshire asking if he now intends to sue us too, and the MP has replied to say: "Unless I decide to link you to any action I may take against any other publications, such action would be a matter between me and them." I think Mr Amess is going to have to raise his game to stay in this race.

A contender for most amusing press release arrives from the Countrywide Alliance Campaign for Shooting. It concerns the latest DTI annual figures on accidents. "There were only 176 shotgun accidents and 254 rifle accidents," the document observes, "compared with an astonishing 6,093 accidents involving goalposts." Let's hope the posts turn on Luis Figo and give him a hiding when England play Portugal. Total shooting accidents of 3,379, it goes on, "compare to 7,265 recorded casualties with cotton wool buds". A very good point. Something must be done about those buds before they kill again.

fields.headline: Brought to book
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
The Burren, Ireland

There he was - pirouetting on a limestone rock. He didn't manage the full 360 degrees of the ballet dancer but he did an elegant 180, his red and green head with a white band and bronze, purple, green body flashing in the sunlight: an apparition from Stravinsky's the Firebird? And indeed, as we know, his ancestors came from the Caucasus and from China, being introduced to Europe during the middle ages.

I was privileged to have the cock pheasant all to myself as he added colour and beauty to our limestone landscape. After his ballet display he turned tail, stepped down from his rocky stage, made his exit between the stoney grykes (fissures) until he rose skywards and disappeared into the treetops.

Liam Moore came to fix a water leak and told me he was taking the art college students out to the Rine, that arm of land that stretches into the Bay, to show them at ebb-tide the graves under the sand of Spanish Armada sailors. A new piece of information for me.

Recently, all the people who since 1987 supplied me with the lore for my diaries gathered together. They arrived for the launch of my book A Burren Journal. It was such a happy evening and I wished readers of the Country Diaries could have been there. Like the pheasant, I did a pirouette, at Whitehorn restaurant looking onto the bay. I read to a marvellously responsive audience and had a sore wrist after signing copies.

The book, beautifully illustrated in watercolours by Anne Korff and Gordon D'Arcy, is a pleasingly cooperative effort: German, English, northern and southern Irish. My last reading, as the sun sank was from my August 1999 diary, quoting John Milton, "And now the Sun had stretched out all the hills, And now was dropt into the western bay".

fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText:
• Infectious
A survey conducted by Lloyd's showed 75% of firms have no e-commerce insurance cover against damage caused by computer hackers and viruses. Of the 161 business risk managers and insurance professionals surveyed, half have had businesses affected by computer viruses and 12% have experienced problems with hacking, Lloyd's said.

webTitle: Filmgroup abandons float as valuation misses target

fields.headline: Filmgroup abandons float as valuation misses target
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Filmgroup, the video-on-demand company which had been gearing up for a £260m flotation, yesterday suffered the fate of its rival Yes Television and abandoned its plans.
fields.body:
Filmgroup, the video-on-demand company which had been gearing up for a £260m flotation, yesterday suffered the fate of its rival Yes Television and abandoned its plans.

The sentiment flowing against hi-tech stocks also caused a further delay to the flotation of pan-European internet group Chello.

The Filmgroup float is understood to have been pulled as it became apparent the company was having difficulty achieving the valuation it was hoping for.

The decision will be a heavy blow given that Filmgroup sought a conservative valuation compared to the £800m Yes TV was aiming for. Yes TV pulled its flotation last month after two attempts.

A source close to Filmgroup said: "Initially it seemed like there was a lot of support out there among investors but when it came to the crunch pens weren't going to cheques. There is a real reluctance to back young hi-tech companies."

The company was being advised by investment bank NM Rothschild and trading in Filmgroup shares had been due to commence on June 14.

The combined difficulties of Filmgroup and Yes TV in attracting investors could prove damaging for other video-on-demand companies seeking to raise finance. Another, Video Networks, was considering plans to join the market but now appears to have retreated from the idea.

The troubles will fuel cynicism in the market toward the ability of video-on-demand companies to compete against existing cable and pay-TV suppliers.

A statement from Filmgroup strove to remain upbeat and said that despite interest in the company "it will be more appropriate to float Filmgroup following further developments within the business". A return to the market has not been ruled out.

Simon Franks, Filmgroup's 28-year-old founder and chief executive, said the company was continuing to develop its product and added that the increased profile it gained during the marketing process had resulted in a number of new opportunities.

Fimgroup has tried to differentiate itself from other fledgling video-on-demand firms by aggressively tying up content deals in the belief that the technology will ultimately become a commodity.

Video on demand allows movies and TV programmes to be viewed at will, paused, fast forwarded or rewound.

Chello said the second postponement of its float had been prompted by "strategic talks" which are believed to have involved British cable operator Telewest taking a stake in the company. Sources close to the Dutch business said enthusiasm for shares had not been strong, however.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Challenge to exchanges link
Ten stock exchanges, from Europe, Asia and the US, yesterday announced plans for an alliance that will allow for 24-hour trading in stocks worth more than $20 trillion (£12.6 trillion).
fields.body:
Challenge to exchanges link
Ten stock exchanges, from Europe, Asia and the US, yesterday announced plans for an alliance that will allow for 24-hour trading in stocks worth more than $20 trillion (£12.6 trillion).

The move will be a direct challenge to the planned three way grouping of London, Frankfurt and Nasdaq in the US. The initiative involves the New York stock exchange, Euronext and the stock markets in Hong Kong, Australia, Mexico, Brazil, Tokyo and Toronto.

Castaway in Dutch court
Endemol Entertainment said yesterday that a Dutch court had rejected a claim from British television company Castaway that the Dutch television production company had stolen its idea for Endemol's soap, Big Brother.

Castaway, part-owned by musician Bob Geldof, said in March the voyeuristic Big Brother show was a rip-off of its own Survive!.

Shares in Endemol, which is being bought by Spanish telecommunications company Telefonica for €5.5bn (£3.47bn), fell 2.3% to €129.65 yesterday.

Leeson helps website launch
Rogue trader Nick Leeson, famed for running up the longest losing streak in the history of gambling, yesterday helped to launch an internet betting service.

Mr Leeson, who went on to lose £325m for Barings Bank in the futures market gave his full backing to the paddypower.com site as it went online in Dublin.

"This opens up the world of betting to a much wider audience. The dabbler can have great fun with novelty bets," he said.

EC sex bias directive
The European commission said it was putting forward a draft directive which could make companies liable if they failed to provide a workplace free of sexual harassment.

The directive needs approval of the EU ministers and of the European parliament. The directive builds on the 1976 equal opportunities directive by considering sexual harassment is a form of sexual discrimination, the commission said.

1st Line calls it quits in Wales
Controversial Wales-based mobile phones company, 1st Line, last night bowed to financial pressures and ceased trading, making up to 2,000 staff in its call centres at Swansea and Cardiff redundant.

Call centres have been hailed as key parts of the modern Welsh economy. The company stunned staff, which had suffered a series of pay-cuts and bullying tactics from managers, by declaring that a major creditor had withdrawn its support.

Jobs to go at Tarmac
Mining and resources group Anglo American said yesterday that its building materials Tarmac subsidiary would be cutting 200 jobs in England.

The job losses follow a review of central functions carried out in the two offices in the Wolverhampton area. The firm said it has decided to retain a strong strategic presence in the area but added more jobs would go next year.

fields.headline: Making news
fields.standfirst: Granada puts ITN float on agenda
fields.trailText: Shareholders in ITN, the television and radio news producer, are considering a stock market flotation of the company.
fields.body:
Shareholders in ITN, the television and radio news producer, are considering a stock market flotation of the company.

Granada, which owns 20%, is understood to have raised the issue as a means of negotiating the rules governing the restructuring of ITV.

Other shareholders include United News & Media and Carlton Communications with 20% each. Granada's ambitions to take over one or the other would breach the limit on how much of ITN any single investor can hold. A flotation would enable it to reduce its stake. Reuters and Daily Mail & General Trust own the remainder.

Flotation could raise funds to fuel the ambitions of ITN, which is planning a 24-hour TV news channel in partnership with cable company NTL. It is also aiming to extend its reach in the US and Europe.

Advisers said that any decision was still "a long way down the agenda".

ITN has annual revenues of about £100m and generates profits of £10m from supplying news to ITV, Channel 4, Channel 5 (left) Independent Radio News and other radio services.

webTitle: Lawyers seek freeze on Abacha bank accounts

fields.headline: Lawyers seek freeze on Abacha bank accounts
fields.trailText: Lawyers preparing to freeze at least $450m held in accounts in Britain by the late Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha have warned the banks involved that they will face prosecution if they allow the money to leave the country before formal criminal proceedings are brought in British courts later this month.
fields.body:
Lawyers preparing to freeze at least $450m held in accounts in Britain by the late Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha have warned the banks involved that they will face prosecution if they allow the money to leave the country before formal criminal proceedings are brought in British courts later this month.

"If the money moves and the banks accept to let it move without checking on the customer and their origins, these banks will be exposed to civil and criminal penalties for money laundering under British law", one of the Swiss-based lawyers acting for Nigeria's government said yesterday.

The Nigerian authorities are trying to recover billions of dollars siphoned from Nigeria's economy during the five years of General Abacha's military dictatorship. So far more than $1.2bn has been frozen in banks in Switzerland and Luxembourg, but Britain is believed to have been the focal point of transactions that spanned more than 100 accounts in several countries.

Nigerian sources say they have evidence that some of the 20-30 accounts held in Britain were in General Abacha's own name. On the basis of a list of more than 500 transactions, most of the funds are thought to be in branches of the Midland (now HSBC), Barclays, Citibank and the French bank Crédit Agricole-Indosuez. The rest of the British-based assets are in subsidiaries of two Nigerian banks as well as four other European banks.

Some of the accounts were held by associates and Abacha family members, as well as three companies owned by the Abacha clan.

The sources hope the British accounts will provide evidence of corruption in Nigeria involving foreign companies, although they have no proof so far that British firms were involved.

"All the companies that did official business in Nigeria during that period can be suspected of paying commissions. We suspect large companies will be implicated," one source said.

Assets frozen in Switzerland and Luxembourg turned out to be 10 times greater than expected.

The rest of the British-based assets are in subsidiaries of two Nigerian banks as well as four other European banks. Some of the accounts were held by associates and Abacha family members, as well as three companies owned by the Abacha clan. The sources hope the British accounts will provide evidence of corruption in Nigeria involving foreign companies, although they have no proof so far that British firms were involved. "All the companies that did official business in Nigeria during that period can be suspected of paying commissions. We suspect large companies will be implicated," one source said. Assets frozen in Switzerland and Luxembourg turned out to be 10 times greater than expected.

fields.headline: No tears for multinational whingers
fields.standfirst: Cross-border tax treatment
fields.trailText: Ask a captain of industry about the Budget changes to the tax treatment of multinationals and the responses fall into two broad categories. There are those who sigh quietly and state that it is not the actual measures which rankle but simply the fact that they were introduced out of the blue, giving businesses little time to reorganise their affairs. Then there are the blusterers, spouting such slogans as: "Do you think it's right that a company should be taxed twice?"
fields.body:
Ask a captain of industry about the Budget changes to the tax treatment of multinationals and the responses fall into two broad categories. There are those who sigh quietly and state that it is not the actual measures which rankle but simply the fact that they were introduced out of the blue, giving businesses little time to reorganise their affairs. Then there are the blusterers, spouting such slogans as: "Do you think it's right that a company should be taxed twice?"

Unsurprisingly, those doing the barking tend to hog the airwaves and fill the columns of print.

But along the way, big successful companies such as Vodafone and some of our most prestigious accountants have let the assumption take hold that the whole row over multinational taxation flared because the Treasury and Inland Revenue were too stupid to understand how international finance operates in the modern world. The received wisdom is that British companies are being prevented from pursuing legitimate cross-border tax planning, rather than tax avoidance or, heaven forfend, actually evading tax.

The truth, of course, is a little more complex, as illustrated by the details on these pages indicating that Vodafone, having pulled off the biggest hostile bid the world has ever seen, was planning another quick corporate trick by directing the Mannesmann profit stream somewhere into the economic ether of Luxembourg or Dublin's self-styled International Financial Centre.

Companies are under a duty to shareholders to minimise their tax payments, but they should also act responsibly towards the societies which constitute the markets for their goods. That is not a piece of corporate greenery, it is just good business sense.

Futures tense

Those serving alcohol within and around the City of London know all about seasonal drinking habits. There's the February lull when professionals give the liver a rest (it's the shortest month) and there is the pre-Christmas rush of amateur imbibers, which can do serious damage to regular, ongoing trade.

But the weather is rather less predictable, and as the bar and pavement table culture continues to grow in the Square Mile it has become a financial issue. So Corney & Barrow, the City wine bar chain, has applied a bit of financial wizardry to the problem - buying a weather derivative hedge from Speedwell Weather Derivatives, a firm that is rather more used to doing work for energy firms.

The use of derivatives in all shapes and sizes is expected to take another twist this morning when Liffe, the London international financial futures exchange, reveals more details about its plans to split its exchange business from the computer software operation which is growing up behind it.

While there is some chatter that Liffe could float its exchange business on the stock market as a "dot.com", what is expected to happen more immediately is that Liffe signs up big users for its software. The idea appears to be that big companies - such as utilities which trade huge amounts of national resources between each other - could adopt the software to develop a more sophisticated trading environment through which they could auction their wares.

Liffe looked close to death last year after losing much of its business to its German rival, Eurex. But we could be about to watch a dramatic, innovative, comeback.

Sum cheek

So it's two cheers for open government then, as the statistics commission begins running its slide rule over some of the government's more sensitive pieces of data. A cheer for "StatWatch's" wide ranging brief including hospital waiting lists and class sizes and another for the promise to name and shame departments whose figures do not meet its test of integrity and independence. But no cheers for the decision by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, decision to keep control over the retail prices index. Why the RPI should be treated differently from every other economic statistic is baffling, as the Treasury select committee pointed out when the draft national statistics framework was published more than a year ago.

The principle that ministers get to decide what comes under the commission's brief is still an affront, even though most have chosen to let auditors in. The focus now will be on the numbers which Labour set themselves up to be judged by - the New Deal, class sizes and waiting lists. Cynics may be forgiven for thinking they are happy to have outside scrutiny because they know they will meet their election pledges. A truly open government would let the statistics commission decide its own remit.

fields.headline: Byers warns boardrooms
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, yesterday signalled that he is prepared to force companies to reveal how they affect the environment and wider community.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, yesterday signalled that he is prepared to force companies to reveal how they affect the environment and wider community.

But he squashed hopes for a change in company law to dilute the power of shareholders, provoking attacks from the TUC and pressure groups.

Mr Byers told a conference organised by the TUC and the Institute for Public Policy Research that the law was inadequate because it allowed directors to focus on short-term, narrow financial interests.

"The present situation in which directors have a very narrow remit has to change. We must ensure that the framework of company law allows and encourages directors to take wider responsibilities into account. We need an approach which actually recognises the needs of stakeholders."

But he dismissed ideas for introducing representatives of employees and other non-shareholder groups into boardrooms, or giving directors a legal duty to consider non-financial interests.

Mr Byers stressed the importance of the three-year project being carried out by the DTI-led company law review committee. "Company law and corporate governance are at the heart of the debate about the kind of society we want and the nature of our economy."

Mr Byers hinted that he would go further than the latest proposals for voluntary disclosure of non-financial issues, possibly requiring companies to undergo "social audits", to examine their social environmental performance.

"I believe the way forward is to look at disclosure," he said , suggesting that it might be the main plank of a new companies act in the next parliament.

Issues to be included would be relations with suppliers, customers and employees, environmental, social and ethical policies. He had not made up his mind on the desirability of social audits, but voluntary disclosure by companies might not be enough.

Brendan Barber, TUC deputy general secretary, said his organisation would not be able to support the legislation if it went no further than voluntary disclosure. He demanded mandatory reporting on environmental issues and relations with stakeholder groups.

fields.headline: Western steps up Hyder campaign
fields.trailText: Western Power Distribution, the US group, yesterday stepped up its campaign to win political backing for its £464m bid for Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility, by promising far better returns for investors and minimal job losses.
fields.body:
Western Power Distribution, the US group, yesterday stepped up its campaign to win political backing for its £464m bid for Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility, by promising far better returns for investors and minimal job losses.

On the eve of formal talks with members of the national assembly, who tend to support the rival £403m offer from Japanese bank Nomura, Robert Symons, WPD chief executive, said: "We know this business well; we run utilities; we are not investment bankers."

Mr Symons said in Cardiff: "I am convinced we can produce improved performance for both customers and for employees ... We are not the problem but a solution. We want to make these businesses - Welsh Water and electricity distributor Swalec - successful again."

Hyder shares, which peaked at £10.49 in 1998, fell to a low of £1.79 this year.

The rival Nomura bid, pitched at 260p per share compared with WPD's 300p, has been recommended by the Hyder board and has won political support because the Japanese bank has promised to keep Hyder intact, with its main headquarters in Cardiff, and has accused WPD of embarking on a break-up strategy.

Nomura yesterday won clearance for its bid when the government said it would not refer it to the competition commission.

The Japanese bank is considering increasing its bid, but no move is expected before the regulators rule on the rival offer - likely to be the end of this month at the earliest.

webTitle: Will Bush heed a cry from death row?

fields.headline: Will Bush heed a cry from death row?
fields.standfirst:
With evidence in his favour still unheard, a convict has two weeks to win clemency

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Gary Graham will not go tamely to his death. As his day of execution approaches he vows he will "fight every step", as will his supporters across Texas. His message to Governor George W Bush is that this is one death warrant the world is going to hear about.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in the Terrell Unit, Death Row, Texas
fields.body:
Gary Graham will not go tamely to his death. As his day of execution approaches he vows he will "fight every step", as will his supporters across Texas. His message to Governor George W Bush is that this is one death warrant the world is going to hear about.

From his cell on death row, Graham has just over two weeks to convince the American public he is an innocent man who has been denied a fair trial in the hope of forcing the Republican presidential contender to bestow clemency.

But the statistics are discouraging. Since being elected in 1994, Mr Bush has granted one temporary reprieve, commuted one death penalty to life imprisonment, and signed 131 death warrants - a US record which has made Texas the execution capital of the western world.

"You're dealing with a factory here. This killing is out of control," Graham told The Guardian at the Terrell Unit prison near Livingston - a squat, concrete complex in the east Texas countryside where 248 prisoners currently await lethal injections.

The US remains broadly in favour of the death penalty, but it is beginning to betray traces of doubt. In recent years, DNA tests and fresh evidence have exonerated 87 death-row inmates and shaken many Americans' faith in US justice. Illinois has suspended its death penalty following a series of miscarriages of justice and a dozen states are considering following suit.

Meanwhile in Texas, Governor Bush's confident assertion that the state has never executed an innocent man on his watch is coming under scrutiny, which is bound to intensify as Graham's execution date draws close. He was sentenced to death in the absence of any physical evidence, on the word of a single witness whose testimony is open to question.

His bizarre story and his coming showdown with the would-be president may push capital punishment to the forefront of the national political agenda for the first time in a generation. "We're going to raise as much hell as we can in the streets," the 36-year-old convict vowed.

Through the thick concrete walls, other inmates could be heard singing gospel, but he was not distracted for a moment. His years on death row have left him coiled and intense. His stare through the reinforced glass of his cubicle is implacable.

"You see a lot of men break down in the process. And I've had some difficult moments. But you have to stay strong. You have to fight back," he said.

Graham has had a long time to prepare for this moment. He was convicted of shooting a man outside a Houston supermarket in 1981, when he was 17 years old, legally a child. In most of the US, that is not necessarily a barrier to execution.

Close to execution
He has been on the brink of execution five times and once come within four hours before his sentence was postponed pending appeals. But he has no more appeals left to make. Last month, the US supreme court refused to hear his case, and any further judicial delays are highly improbable. Only clemency from the governor can save him now.

As far as the prosecutors and much of the Texas press are concerned, Graham is just a habitual criminal trying to foment political unrest to escape the consequences of his actions. They point out that in his 19 years in jail, he has had more than 30 separate court proceedings.

"Actually, Graham's attorneys and diehard supporters should thank God for the American justice system providing due process and technical safeguards against swift punishment for condemned murderers," argued an opinion piece in the Houston Chronicle last month. "Gary Graham has won court battles to stay alive, but he should lose the war."

On closer examination, looking through the court records and talking to surviving witnesses, Graham's legal marathon represents not so much a guarantee of justice as a Kafka-esque labyrinth of legal quirks and absurdities. It raises troubling question about how the Texas system of justice sends prisoners to their deaths. No physical evidence tied Graham to the shooting of Bobby Lambert, a white suspected drug dealer, in a Safeway car park on a summer night in north-west Houston. There were no fingerprints, no murder weapon, no blood or residue on Graham's clothes.

He was sentenced to death on the strength of the testimony of one woman, who witnessed the shooting. The witness, Bernadine Skillern, had told the police that the killer had a short "afro" and was clean shaven. She was shown 10 photographs, including one of Graham, who had been arrested for a string of armed robberies in which two people were injured. Out of the 10 mug shots, only Graham's came close to her description. The others had moustaches or bushy hair. According to the police report, Mrs Skillern said Graham resembled the murderer "except the complexion of the suspect she saw was darker and his face was thinner".

The next day she was called into the police station and showed a lineup of five men including Graham. He was the only person to appear in both the photo spread and the lineup, so his face would have been familiar to her whether he had been at the scene of the crime or not. She identified him as the killer. Yet in the course of the two-day trial, the extraordinary nature of his identification went unchallenged. And his court-appointed lawyer, Ron Mock, failed to point out that there had been another witness at the police lineup, who did not identify Graham.

His name was Ron Hubbard, a Safeway worker who had been rounding up supermarket trolleys in the car park when Lambert was shot, and came within a few feet of the gunman. "He was about five foot five. He was a dark-skinned guy with a short afro, and a short, white, waist-length jacket," he said. "He looked about the same size as my mother. I could look down on top of him."

His description was echoed by Sherian Etuk, who was working on a Safeway cash register at the time of the killing. Both witnesses have seen photographs of Graham, who is five-foot ten, and are adamant he was not the man they saw. "His face is too wide," Ms Etuk said. "This guy had a narrow face and was really dark."

Witnesses not called
The two witnesses were nearer to the scene of the shooting than Mrs Skillern but the jury never heard from them. Moreover, the prosecution told the jury (of 11 whites and one black) that Mr Lambert had been killed with a .22-calibre pistol, like the gun Graham had in his possession when he was arrested. But they were never told that a police ballistics test had ruled out his pistol as the murder weapon.

During the past week, Mr Mock has failed to respond to a string of telephone requests to talk about his conduct in the Graham case and his failure to present exculpatory evidence. However, the investigator who worked with him on the case, Mervyn West, has shed some light on what happened. In an affidavit in 1993, Mr West testified: "Ron Mock was extremely busy during the period of time that Gary's case was pending. Since we both assumed Gary was guilty, I decided not to waste time trying to substantiate his alibi. I really didn't think Gary had much hope, so I just went through the motions."

Chester Thornton, Mr Mock's co-counsel in the original trial, said: "I was shocked when I learned that the investigation that I believed had been done had not... I have serious concerns as to whether or not Gary Graham received effective assistance of counsel. As a member of the defence team, I consider myself partially responsible."

Graham's representation at his first round of appeals was similarly inadequate. It was only in 1993, with a new set of lawyers that the witness and ballistics testimony was presented. But at a pivotal appeal at a Texas state court that year, the judge turned down the request for a new evidentiary hearing. Richard Burr, Mr Graham's current lawyer, is certain the judge never even read the defence case. Only a few hours before his ruling, the judge had told one of Mr Burr's colleagues he had not had time to look at it.

"I find it difficult to continue to work in a system which cannot do the most elemental thing that justice requires - a full hearing of the evidence," Mr Burr said. "In Gary Graham's case, no court has ever done that."

Every time a prisoner at the Terrell Unit is executed the details of his final meal are posted on a state website. Gary Graham has been asked to choose his meal five times already and each time he has refused. This time he will do the same; accepting the meal is like accepting their justice, he said. "I'm not going to play their game," he said.

Whether he plays or not, this game is approaching its end. His execution may add to the deepening unease around the country and perhaps even help galvanise a fundamental reassessment of the system. But by then, of course, it will be too late for Gary Graham.

Top 10 execution states since Jan 17 1995, when Governor George W Bush took office in Texas:

State Number of executions

Texas 131
Virginia 52
Missouri 31
Oklahoma 23
South Carolina 20
Arizona 18
Arkansas 13
Florida 13
Alabama 13
Illinois 10

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The pressure remained on top stocks in London, with dealers ignoring the monetary policy committee's decision to leave interest rates unchanged. In what was described as flat trading, the FTSE 100 drifted 43 points lower to 6,503.8 at the close, having touched a low of 6,474 at one stage.
fields.body:
The pressure remained on top stocks in London, with dealers ignoring the monetary policy committee's decision to leave interest rates unchanged. In what was described as flat trading, the FTSE 100 drifted 43 points lower to 6,503.8 at the close, having touched a low of 6,474 at one stage.

Oil group BP Amoco was a particular pull as the shares fell from 624p to 607p - worth about 17 Footsie points. But there was some heavy business under way in Burmah Castrol , which is in the process of being taken over by BP. Several big blocks of stock were said to be on the move through brokers Cazenove, but the share price held unchanged at £16.51.

Quite a few eyes were on the technology sector after Logica failed to impress the market with its latest trading statement. Its shares fell from £19.80 to £17.38.

Software rival Sema gave up £10 to 944p in sympathy, CMG lost 74p to £10.55 and financial software specialist Misys declined 40p to 560p.

BSkyB dropped from £12.85 to £12.11 in anticipation of 24% shareholder Vivendi selling part of its stake to pay for the French group's phone adventures. German group Kirch sold part of its stake on Tuesday. At one stage shares in the satellite broadcaster were trading at £11.60.

Reed International continued its advance, up a further 26p to 526p. Traders said investors were reacting to a conference speech by chief executive Crispin Davis which painted a rosy picture of the publishing firm's internet developments.

With the Techmark 100 down 123.1 points at 3,516, some of the more volatile constituents were falling fast. Israeli software group Geo Interactive , for example, which greeted last week's move by investors back into technology stocks with a 30% jump, yesterday saw its price fall back 125p to £10. That compares with the year's high of £36.70.

Similarly, Filtronic , which specialises in technology for mobile phone networks, shed 105p to 982.5p.

There was the smell of burnt flesh in the market for Feedback, a little electronics manufacturer. The shares have been clicking higher over recent sessions, moving up from a low of 62p in mid-May to 102.5p on Tuesday evening. Yesterday the price slumped 23p to 79.5p after warning that its year-end figures would not meet market expectations.

Eskmuir Properties said it was considering a capital reduction, buying in stock at a "small premium" to its 1998 flotation price of 220p. The share price jumped from 167.5p to 205p in response.

webTitle: Traffic fumes could cut crop yields by 20%, study suggests

fields.headline: Traffic fumes could cut crop yields by 20%, study suggests
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Traffic exhaust fumes are costing farmers hundreds of millions of pounds in lost crop yield, according to a 10-year field study .
fields.body:
Traffic exhaust fumes are costing farmers hundreds of millions of pounds in lost crop yield, according to a 10-year field study .

Government, European and UN agencies have been alerted to the data from Newcastle university, which challenges previous laboratory findings and suggests that wheat, white clover and oilseed rape are being devastated by pollution from the roads.

Flowering shoots and ears of crops were consistently fewer in trial crops exposed by scientists to ozone pollution. And primarily it is road traffic, with power station emissions as a secondary source, that causes the pollution. Seed yield in the most sensitive strain of oilseed rape used in the trial fell by 14% and in winter wheat by 13% - losses that translate financially into more than £145 an hectare for growers.

John Ollerenshaw, head of the research team, said that the effects had been masked in laboratory tests because of ozone's "stealth" effect. Weakened crops showed no visible foliage damage but suffered from reduced photosynthesis. Some rape plants partly compensated by producing more and larger seeds per pod, but the overall yield and oil content were down.

The findings are contributing to the government's policies on dealing with atmospheric pollution. They are likely to cause immediate consternation in Europe. The scientists discovered a link between damage levels and warm weather, findings replicated in experiments in Spain.

"In a wet and cold summer there will be a limited effect from ozone pollution, but in a hot, dry summer, ozone levels could reduce the yield of some crops by up to 20%," said Dr Ollerenshaw. "In the UK - with the current situation in our farming - that could push out of business some of the arable farmers who are on the edge. It will certainly have a big impact on all the others."

The Spanish study was conducted by Jeremy Barnes, an agricultural scientist also at Newcastle who worked with researchers from the Spanish ministry of science. The Spanish team found yield falls of up to 39% in water melons, which faced ozone pollution far above UN critical guidelines.

In the first year of field trials, the Spanish project recorded ozone double the UN level and in the second, hotter year, five times over the critical level.

"This shows clearly that the current critical levels, which determine when intervention may be considered necessary to protect crops, are not valid for many of Europe's climatic conditions. The findings draw attention to the need for more study of the relationships between crops, the climate and pollution," said Dr Barnes.

The British team is pressing for tighter pollution limits to cut nitric oxide in exhaust fumes. Dr Ollerenshaw said that, in the UK, catalytic convertors could help, and more could be done to cut power stations' emissions.

webTitle: Russians turn to Europe to thwart US missile plan

fields.headline: Russians turn to Europe to thwart US missile plan
fields.standfirst:
Russia predicts nuclear chaos if US scraps treaty

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, is poised to broaden his campaign to isolate the US over its divisive missile shield scheme with a flurry of moves in the next week aimed at enlisting European public opinion in the battle against America's National Missile Defence (NMD) project.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in Moscow and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, is poised to broaden his campaign to isolate the US over its divisive missile shield scheme with a flurry of moves in the next week aimed at enlisting European public opinion in the battle against America's National Missile Defence (NMD) project.

For the first time in more than a year, Russia's defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, travels to Brussels today for talks with Nato leaders, a relationship that the Russians severed last year in protest at the war in Yugoslavia.

Mr Sergeyev is expected to put some flesh on the bones of Mr Putin's calls for joint development of anti-missile defences by the US, Nato and Russia, although the Russian proposals appear vague - more political and diplomatic than military.

After clashing with President Bill Clinton over the "son of star wars" scheme at a Moscow summit at the weekend, Mr Putin promptly went to Rome where he called for joint expansion of missile defence to cover all of Europe and Russia as well as America.

On his first official trip to Berlin next week Mr Putin is expected to step up the propaganda war against NMD, seeking to exploit European differences with the Americans on the issue.

NMD "is viewed negatively not just by Russia, but also by France, Germany and Italy", said Colonel-General Vladimir Yakovlev, the commander of Russia's strategic missile forces.

The ghost of Greenham Common has suddenly returned to haunt the arms control agenda, in what is perceived as the biggest threat to strategic stability in 20 years. But the big differences from the battles of the 1970s and 80s are that Russia lost the cold war and does not constitute the threat then posed by the Soviet Union, while Helmut Schmidt's and Helmut Kohl's firm siding with the US then is not now replicated by the Berlin government of Social Democrats and Greens.

"What Putin is trying to do is play the European card, but he's also anxious not to confront the US," said Pavel Podvig, a researcher at Moscow's Centre for Arms Control Studies.

Experts are sceptical about Mr Putin's alternative proposals, which centre on tactical rather than strategic missile defences, using modernised rockets to destroy "rogue state" ballistic missiles shortly after launch. This would comply with the 1972 US-Soviet anti-ballistic missiles treaty which Russia wants to preserve, whereas the US scheme to destroy incoming missiles in space requires withdrawal from or changes in the treaty.

However, European defence sources say the technology behind Mr Putin's proposal was even more complicated and uncertain than the NMD project.

A breakdown of negotiations and unilateral American ditching of the ABM treaty could, warned Gen Yakovlev, turn strategic stability into "utter unpredictability". "The whole system of nuclear arms control will change," he told the Moscow newspaper Kommersant.

The Russian national security elite believes the US talk of ballistic missile threats from rogue states like North Korea is nonsense, but Mr Putin made a crucial concession at the weekend summit by admitting that there is such a threat.

"From a position of opposing missile defence absolutely, Mr Putin is now saying missile defence is good as long as Russia is part of the club. But the Russian military does not want that," said Mr Podvig.

The shift has rattled China which feels vulnerable to the US plan and was counting on Moscow as an ally.

China's foreign ministry spokeswoman Zhang Qiyue said on Tuesday that adherence to the ABM treaty "conforms with the strategic balance and stability".

"Any efforts to amend the ABM treaty or to withdraw from the ABM treaty would not only threaten the nuclear disarmament process but would also shatter the basis for nuclear non-proliferation and will give rise to a new arms race, including an arms race in outer space," she said.

In Moscow at the weekend, Strobe Talbott, the US deputy secretary of state, said that Mr Putin's alternative proposals could be discussed, but only to supplement and not supplant NMD, since the North Korean challenge was too urgent and the Russian scheme would take too long to develop.

"The world covered by the ABM treaty changed very vividly on August 31 1998 when the North Koreans fired that missile," he said. "Can the ABM treaty, can the US-Russian strategic relationship, change to take account of those new realities?"

However, America's Nato allies - including senior officials in Britain's Ministry of Defence - remain deeply sceptical about the US plan for a national missile shield. They believe the US is exaggerating the threat from so-called rogue states and that the project, far from adding to world security, would be destabilising.

A key test firing of US missile "interceptors" is due to take place later this month. But European diplomats now believe Mr Clinton will leave a decision on whether, or how, to go ahead with the project to his successor.

fields.headline: Sri Lanka suicide bomber kills 22
fields.trailText: A senior government minister and 21 other people were killed yesterday by a suicide bomb blast in a southern suburb of the Sri Lankan capital, Colombo, as the country remembered its war dead with a two-minute silence.
fields.body:
A senior government minister and 21 other people were killed yesterday by a suicide bomb blast in a southern suburb of the Sri Lankan capital, Colombo, as the country remembered its war dead with a two-minute silence.

The silence was broken by a deafening explosion as a suicide bomber blew himself up in Ratmalana, instantly killing the industrial development minister, C V Gunaratne.

The minister died as he mingled with crowds during his party's procession to mark War Heroes Day honouring soldiers killed in the long-running war against the Tamil Tigers, who are fighting for a separate homeland in the north of the country.

At least 60 people were injured, 15 of them seriously, in the blast, said Dr W G Gunawardena, a director at the hospital where the casualties were taken. The minister's wife was also critically injured in the blast and was being operated on, he said.

"I heard a huge explosion and then saw parts of bodies flying around. I can't remember what happened immediately after that," a witness said.

Dismembered bodies and shattered glass covered the blast site, less than a mile from Ratmalana airport, which is used by the air force. Police cordoned off the area and reinforcements were sent in.

The latest blast came just after the president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, who escaped a Tamil assassination attempt last December, thanked families of the soldiers killed in the war. In a message to the war-weary nation she said there was no military solution to the conflict.

"Let us bow our heads in homage to those who are making the supreme sacrifice, so that you and I may live in comfort and peace," Ms Kumaratunga said.

webTitle: Atom power gives grip to gecko toes

fields.headline: Atom power gives grip to gecko toes
fields.trailText: Atomic energy gives the gecko the stickiest toes in nature, researchers reported in the journal Nature yesterday.
fields.body:
Atomic energy gives the gecko the stickiest toes in nature, researchers reported in the journal Nature yesterday.

They are looking at ways to duplicate the nocturnal lizard's ability to cling to smooth surfaces as it scuttles across walls and ceilings. A super-efficient artificial adhesive using the same principles could be worth millions.

Biologists and engineers at the University of California at Berkeley showed that geckos, common in southern Europe and the tropics, employ a form of atomic energy called Van der Waals forces, which produce an attraction between molecules.

Normally these forces, caused by unbalanced electrical charges, are so weak they are swamped by stronger forces in nature. They come into play only when surfaces get close to each other. They are, for instance, responsible for the attraction between layers of graphite.

In the case of the gecko, the millions of microscopic hairs on its toes are each tipped by a thousand pads, the molecules of which get so close to a surface that Van der Waals forces become significant, and its feet can stick to mirror-smooth surfaces.

Robert Full, one of the researchers, said the gecko "rolls these hairs on to the surface then peels them off again, just like tape. But it's better than tape."

Press assocation

fields.headline: Aitken's friend guilty of contempt
fields.standfirst: The Aitken affair: special report
fields.trailText: The friend of Jonathan Aitken who escaped prosecution for perverting the course of justice after the former cabinet minister's failed libel action was found guilty yesterday of contempt of court in a $220m legal dispute with a Saudi Arabian prince.
fields.body:
The friend of Jonathan Aitken who escaped prosecution for perverting the course of justice after the former cabinet minister's failed libel action was found guilty yesterday of contempt of court in a $220m legal dispute with a Saudi Arabian prince.

Said Ayas, former business manager of Prince Mohammed bin Fahd, was given 14 days to produce powers of attorney allowing the prince to seize some of his assets in the south of France. Prince Mohammed claims that Mr Ayas stole the money from him over 12 years.

If he fails to comply Mr Ayas and his French wife could be arrested and sent to prison.

The hearing in the high court, before Mr Justice Timothy Walker, was an attempt by the prince's lawyers to force Mr Ayas to honour agreements he made to settle the dispute. In May last year he signed a settlement with the prince, admitting he took the money, and was ordered to pay it back.

But in his ruling the judge said Mr Ayas had made "serious and deliberate breaches of the order in a classical case of brinkmanship to postpone the evil day". He had obstructed the sale of apartments in the US and of a £20m yacht in the south of France. Only on Monday had Mr Ayas provided powers of attorney over his properties in France and Italy.

The final documents will have to be obtained from Mr Ayas's Canadian lawyers, who are directors of several Ayas companies.

In his defence Mr Ayas claimed that he reached the agreement with the prince and made a public apology under duress. "I have never misappropriated funds from the prince," he said.

He said he was in fear of his life and worried about the safety of his wife and five children - all living in London - after he was put under house arrest by the prince in Saudi Arabia in 1997. He later escaped across the desert.

"I have been watched and followed," he said. "Every time I went out my wife would stand at the window and wonder if I was coming back."

Mr Ayas claimed that the prince's Saudi lawyer, in a secret agreement to save the prince's pride, had agreed not to seize his assets. But the judge said he found Mr Ayas's explanations and allegations against the prince incredible.

In March last year the crown prosecution service decided not to proceed with criminal charges against Mr Ayas after it emerged that he had signed a false statement supporting Aitken in his libel action against the Guardian and Granada TV. The CPS said the statement, like that of Aitken's daughter Victoria, had been drawn up by Aitken himself.

webTitle: Anglican clergy told to offer healing services

fields.headline: Anglican clergy told to offer healing services
fields.standfirst:
Senior clerics cite gospel imperative to cure - sometimes miraculously - in an attempt to develop ministries and thwart rise of alternative medicine

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Senior clerics cite gospel imperative to cure - sometimes miraculously - in an attempt to develop ministries and thwart rise of alternative medicine
fields.body:
Anglican clergy are to be instructed that they should offer healing to their congregations alongside the NHS, that miraculous cures should not be ruled out and that in some circumstances diocesan exorcists may need to be called in.

Leaflets suggesting that the vicar may be able to help in curing the sick are recommended to be placed in church pews across the country from today in an attempt to head off public credulity about alternative medicines.

The clergy are being offered "practical guidelines" to develop healing ministries in their parishes with the instruction that healing the sick is a gospel imperative.

The Rt Rev Dominic Walker, Bishop of Reading, one of the authors of the report, A Time to Heal, claimed: "There is a huge spiritual quest especially among younger people and they often do not know where to look, which makes them very vulnerable.

"They believe anything at all. New Age is like a supermarket trolley allowing them to pick one thing after another off the shelves and we want to help them find a real spiritual life."

A 58 page report outlining how to conduct a healing ministry is to be circulated to all vicars, extrapolated from a fuller 400 page document which clergymen will need to buy separately for fuller details.

The booklet offers practical advice as well as spiritual guidance, suggesting safety tips such as that healing should always take place on a carpet in case the patient falls to the floor so that they do not injure themselves.

Miracles are not ruled out by the Church of England but the report advises that those who think they are cured should go on taking their medication just in case.

Clergy are told that the role of tender loving care should not be ignored in spiritual ministrations.

The report, produced by a working party including senior clergy, theologians, psychiatrists and doctors, is the first guidance of its sort that the church has issued for 42 years.

The Rt Rev John Perry, Bishop of Chelmsford, who chaired the group, said: "There is nothing predictable in the ministry of healing except the assurance of God's love and care. Where physical healing does not take place, a healing on an emotional, psychological or spiritual level may be the primary need."

A chapter on deliverance from evil warns vicars not to try freelance exorcism at home but does suggest that an exorcist, appointed in each diocese, might have to be called in.

The panel seems uncertain whether people really are possessed of the devil. They said there was a possibility that evils such as poverty, racism, cruelty and discrimination could be overlooked in the quest to cast out demons from disturbed congregants.

"There is a danger that exorcism can become a form of Christian magic and a means of denying evil rather than encountering it and doing something practical about it," the report warned.

Similarly it was cautious about miracles without ruling them out altogether: "We seem to be moving towards the view that, whatever happened in the past, today God does not normally work through that which can be defined as miraculous.

"A Christian may claim to have experienced a miracle and if the experience strengthened their faith, that claim should be treated with respect. If a claimant declares that they are going to throw away their medicine as a result of their experience, they should be warned to consult their doctor first."

The curative power of faith

The healing ministry is available in the following ways:

 Publicly as part of church services

 At healing services and in institutions such as hospitals and residential homes

 Privately, within the home and discreetly in side chapels

 Ecumenically across denominations

 In cooperation with the medical and caring professions.

The most common forms of healing:

 Public and private prayers

 Laying on of hands

 Anointing with oil

Healing may help:

 To carry people through prolonged illness or disability

 To make a more rapid recovery than expected

 To drive out, with God's love, fear of death

fields.headline: Jobcentre 'wrong' to ban advert
fields.trailText: The employment service last night admitted jobcentre staff had made the "wrong decision" by banning a job advert seeking "hard working and enthusiastic" applicants.
fields.body:
The employment service last night admitted jobcentre staff had made the "wrong decision" by banning a job advert seeking "hard working and enthusiastic" applicants.

A spokesman said Walsall jobcentre, which "doctored" the advert to remove the offending words, had been told to accept the original ad placed by businessmen Jason Pitt and Bill Wood.

The admission came after the employment secretary, David Blunkett, condemned the jobcentre's ruling - made on the grounds that the terms might breach the Disability Discrimination Act - as insulting to the disabled.

A spokesman last night said the jobcentre would en sure that the censored advert was replaced with the original, which requested industrious staff.

The spokesman said: "The Disability Discrimination Act guidelines for jobcentres do not say that the words 'hardworking' or 'enthusiastic' should not be used when employers place a vacancy. In this instance the jobcentre made the wrong decision."

Disabled charities had attacked the decision as "patronising" and "absurd". Mr Pitt and Mr Wood said they were flabbergasted after the jobcentre told them they could not place the advert for a management trainee post.

The two men, who yesterday said they were glad common sense had prevailed, described the original ruling as political correctness gone mad.

Mr Wood, 51, said: "When we tried to phone through the advert we were stopped in our tracks after uttering the word 'hardworking' and they told us: 'You can't put that, it's discrimination'. When we asked if we could put enthusiastic, she said we couldn't use that either."

Earlier, Mr Blunkett said the case was a nonsense. He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that he had "sorted" the row. "I've fought gesturism all my life and I will continue to do so," he added.

fields.headline: Warning over cancer cure claim
fields.trailText: A breast cancer charity yesterday issued a warning against a book which claims that women with the disease could be cured if they cut out dairy products.
fields.body:
A breast cancer charity yesterday issued a warning against a book which claims that women with the disease could be cured if they cut out dairy products.

The author, Jane Plant, claims that a dairy free diet helped to cure her breast cancer after she had been given only months to live.

In Your Life in Your Hands, published yesterday, Professor Plant, a geochemist and chief scientist at the British Geological Survey, said: "I believe that the evidence suggests that consuming dairy products (milk and meat) does indeed increase the risk of breast and prostate cancer in exposed populations.

"When I eliminated dairy products from my diet, a large 'secondary' tumour in the lymph nodes in my neck, thought to be incurable, disappeared in weeks."

She claimed that the 63 breast cancer victims who had adopted her programme had remained cancer free.

But Delyth Morgan, chief executive of the Breakthrough Breast Cancer charity, said: "With all due respect, her views are not based on scientific evidence.

"Adopting a healthy diet and lifestyle can help to reduce the risk of developing cancer in general, but we do not yet have the evidence to promote the exclusion of specific foods to protect against breast cancer."

webTitle: Proust fails to excite art market

fields.headline: Proust fails to excite art market
fields.trailText: A handwritten manuscript of Marcel Proust's masterpiece, Remembrance of Times Past, has been sold for just over half what experts thought the lost proof might fetch.
fields.body:
A handwritten manuscript of Marcel Proust's masterpiece, Remembrance of Times Past, has been sold for just over half what experts thought the lost proof might fetch.

Christie's had hoped the heavily reworked version of Swann's Way - the first volume of his mammoth meditation on the hidden depths that lurk in the trivial - would fetch up to £1m. It was bought yesterday by the Fondation Martin Bodmer, a Geneva library, for £663,750. The draft, which disappeared in 1935, gave an insight into how Proust endlessly revised, and how his dallying over a title threw up such unlikely contenders as The Frazzled Pigeon, The Stalagmites of the Past, and Gardens in a Cup of Tea.
