webTitle: Vote defeat may mark beginning of end for Barak

fields.headline: Vote defeat may mark beginning of end for Barak
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, took a body blow in a parliamentary vote in favour of early elections yesterday that could mortally weaken him during a critical juncture of the Middle East peace process.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, took a body blow in a parliamentary vote in favour of early elections yesterday that could mortally weaken him during a critical juncture of the Middle East peace process.

The 61-48 vote to pass a bill for fresh elections made it painfully obvious that while the decorated general is not short on the political courage to make peace with the Palestinians, he is woefully lacking in the skills needed to rein in the hawks.

Three parties - representing 26 members from Mr Barak's imploded coalition of 68 - voted in favour of the opposition bill calling for the knesset to disband.

The legislation must survive three more votes, which still leaves Mr Barak a faint chance of ending the feud with the Shas party, his largest coalition partner. The party, which represents religious Jews of Middle Eastern descent, spearheaded the rebellion leading to his defeat yesterday.

Many believe yesterday marked the beginning of the end of Mr Barak's 11-month tenure. "It is true that what happened today is only a preliminary reading, but certainly a Pandora's box was opened," said Arye Carmon, the president of the Israel Democracy Institute.

"Sooner or later this is going to become a very serious threat to his regime and I would not be surprised if Israel finds itself again in an early unscheduled election."

Mr Barak faces some very unpalatable options. He could give in to Shas, which has held his coalition hostage to demands for more money for its bankrupt and corrupt Orthodox school system, and limp along with the present coalition.

If he could stomach that surrender, he might manage to reach a deal with the Palestinians before Yasser Arafat declares an independent state on September 13.

Or he could scramble for ways to build a more viable coalition. Mr Barak's confidants say he is exploring the possibility of jettisoning Shas, another religious party and a party representing immigrants from the former Soviet Union, who have led a rearguard campaign against territorial concessions to the Palestinians, as punishment for voting against him.

"The prime minister has decided to put a stop to a situation in which ministers warm their cabinet seats but act as though they're in the opposition," his office said in a statement at the start of the parliamentary session.

Mr Barak is hoping to emerge phoenix-like with a narrow and hopefully more cohesive coalition by enlisting the ardently secular Shinui party, and roping in outside support from 10 Arab MPs who are expected to vote in favour of his peace efforts.

But while a coalition with Shinui would give him more solid support for negotiations with the Palestinians and Syria, it would also destroy Mr Barak's claim when he was elected that he would be representing the whole country at the bargaining table.

"He changes from being the prime minister of everybody to the prime minister of nobody," said Silvan Shalom, a leader of the rightwing opposition Likud party. He said Mr Barak had lost his legitimacy to negotiate on Israel's behalf.

It also remains uncertain whether Mr Barak has reached the end of the road with Shas, whose followers bow to no authority but the flamboyantly attired Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef.

For months, Mr Barak has been fatally distracted from the peace process by demands that he bail out the Orthodox Jewish school system that forms the bedrock of Shas's popular support.

Despite yesterday's outcome, the Shas health minister, Shlomo Ben-Izri, said the party was not eager to face the electorate any time soon.

"We don't want to topple the government," Mr Ben-Izri said. "No one wants to go to early elections and the ball is now back in the prime minister's court... If he wants to sit down seriously and solve the crisis, then he is welcome."

Nor does the opposition Likud party relish the thought of early elections at a time when its standard bearer, Binyamin Netanyahu, is facing trial on corruption charges.

"The big news is, in my view, that nothing will happen," said the irreverent Tommy Lapid of the Shinui party. "The day will pass and then we will have holidays and then something important will happen in the world and in one week's time nobody will remember this hullabaloo and the present government will continue to misconduct this country."

webTitle: Centuries of laurels for the great and the good

fields.headline: Centuries of laurels for the great and the good
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Universities have long mixed the high ideals of learning with the necessary art of winning friends. The Oxford University archivist records how Lionel Woodville, Dean of Exeter and brother-in-law of Edward IV, was offered a doctorate in canon law, in either 1478 or 1479.
fields.body:
Universities have long mixed the high ideals of learning with the necessary art of winning friends. The Oxford University archivist records how Lionel Woodville, Dean of Exeter and brother-in-law of Edward IV, was offered a doctorate in canon law, in either 1478 or 1479.

Woodville already had the degree of bachelor of canon law, but was offered the degree "without the usual academic exercises", the archivist reports. "It was clearly an attempt to honour and obtain the favour of a man with great influence."

Woodville is the first recorded honorary graduate at Oxford - but then, as the archivist puts it, "honorary degrees appear to have arisen out of the practice of granting dispensations from some particular academic requirement, a practice which is as old as the university".

Woodville was perhaps still not quite as close to the seat of power as Cherie Booth QC, honorand of John Moores University in Liverpool and the Open University. The Prince of Wales has 15 honorary degrees, including a professorship from Kainar University, Kazakhstan.

The poet John Skelton got an honorary degree from Cambridge in 1493, the first on record of what the university says is the "highest honour the university can give". Often recipients have a link with the area. But not always.

Sometimes they have a strong link with the university, either in academia, or yes, some will concede, in giving money. Cambridge is giving an honorary degree this year to Peter Beckwith, who has given "several million" to the law faculty and the Judge Institute of Management Studies. Paul Judge, who founded the institute, is another who has given millions and also received an honorary degree.

A university spokeswoman said the degree was not being given for Mr Beckwith's financial generosity but added: "I am sure his support for the university would be taken into account."

At Cambridge, as generally elsewhere, honorands are nominated by academic staff, go before the vice-chancellor and a committee, and then for final approval by the university's professional body. Oxford famously refused an honorary civil law doctorate to Lady Thatcher in 1985.

Cambridge's criteria - you must either be a British subject "of conspicuous merit" or who has served the university, or a foreigner of "distinction", or simply a member of the royal family - are shared by other universities.

There is a certain mutual backrubbing, part emotion, part sentimentality, part public relations. The criteria are wide and flexible as they can be, which helps when it comes to nice pictures of celebrities in academic gowns.

Pop star Mick Hucknall is an honorary graduate of Umist in Manchester and Paul Lawrie, the 1999 open golf champion, of Robert Gordon University in Aberdeen. The Queen of Denmark, Margrethe II, was awarded an honorary doctorate from Edinburgh. Educated at an English boarding school, she said: "Scotland has always held a distinctive place on my mental map."

Boxer Lennox Lewis's degree from the University of North London looks at first like pure showbiz until a spokeswoman explains that it was at least in part in recognition of the college he founded in his name in Hackney, offering disaffected youngsters training and support.

Sir David Attenborough and Sir Claus Moser have at least 19 honorary degrees each. And who would turn one down? Some do. Alan Bennett rejected the offer from his old university Oxford in protest at it allowing Rupert Murdoch to endow a chair of language and communication.

Additional research by Rebecca Ley

fields.headline: They must be barking
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones is amazed by what he finds at the Henry Moore Institute
fields.trailText: The Henry Moore Institute, a "centre for the study of sculpture", has the tricky job of relating the old idea of sculpture to the way art happens now.
fields.body:
The Henry Moore Institute, a "centre for the study of sculpture", has the tricky job of relating the old idea of sculpture to the way art happens now.

Under its late director Robert Hopper it used the world "sculpture" to describe cut and manipulated felt by Robert Morris. It even recognised the "sculptural" qualities in Jeff Wall's photographs.

Now it has an exhibition of marble dogs. This is sculpture. Figures on plinths. Statues, even. Exquisitely carved bodies. Taut marble skin. Rippling icy muscles.

Hounds in Leash: the Dog in 18th- and 19th-century Sculpture collects some of the most amazingly opulent monuments the rich once erected to their pets. Memories of their doggies weren't enough.

If you were Serpent, "a favourite dog of Lady Stepney's", which died in 1750, you were far more likely to be immortalised in art than the rural workers who appear as faceless smudges in the background of 18th-century landscape paintings. Serpent had his likeness carved on top of a classical pedestal with a verse celebrating his happiness in the love of his "mistress true".

No blurred anonymity, either, for Maida, the famous highland greyhound that belonged to Walter Scott. The novelist's dog was made to pose so frequently for artists that it was said he used to run away whenever he saw a pencil.

William Scoular's marble sculpture of Sir Walter Scott and His Dog (c1838) embodies what is so peculiar about this exhibition. The meticulously carved dog, looking up lovingly at his master, is unlikely enough with his curly tail shaped out of hard geology. But he draws attention to how odd Scott himself looks sitting there, frozen and dead, on a bookcase loaded with chilly books.

When you look at a marble dog in an art gallery, you begin to grasp how absolutely different the idea of "art" was 200 years ago. There was painting and there was sculpture. These categories were defined by a type of activity rather than a type of thinking. You didn't have to think at all to make a sculpture of a dog. It had a history and it had a market.

The Leeds-born sculptor Joseph Gott (1786-1860) had a studio in Rome where he specialised in making dogs to sell to aristocrats on the Grand Tour. There had been spectacular discoveries of ancient Roman sculptures of greyhounds, and that was all the justification clients needed to have their own hairy chums immortalised.

Gott's greyhounds have shoulder bones and vertebrae tight against their smooth white skins. They are alert, they are poised. But they mostly lack the dynamism and tension to make the dogs come alive.

They are relics of an aristocratic culture that 13had giant stone hounds guarding the grounds and a terracotta replica of the mistress's late terrier next to the fireplace. These people lived with the dog; they knew the dog.

And in this world of uninhibited animal-human relations some perverse fantasies flourished. Hands were licked, heads were stroked. Richard James Wyatt's Nymph Removing a Thorn from a Greyhound's Foot (1850) has a phallic hound standing erect and licking, with slavering gratitude, the smooth flesh of a nude nymph.

The wild animal is unleashed in a more decorous way in the best work of art here, Grégoire Giraud's Hound (1827) from the Louvre, a sumptuously muscled creature whose claim to this statuesque status is illustrated in a frieze round the base. It shows the hound bringing down a stag with his teeth clamped into its stomach, attacking a bull (baiting bulls with dogs was thought to improve the taste of the meat) and saving a baby from snakes. What a dog!

This may be the most subversive exhibition the Henry Moore Institute has ever staged. Sculpture has rarely looked so unhealthily sensuous. All those pets, all that frozen love.

Hounds in Leash is at the Henry Moore Institute, Leeds (0113-246 7467), till August 27.

If you were Serpent, "a favourite dog of Lady Stepney's", which died in 1750, you were far more likely to be immortalised in art than the rural workers who appear as faceless smudges in the background of 18th-century landscape paintings. Serpent had his likeness carved on top of a classical pedestal with a verse celebrating his happiness in the love of his "mistress true". No blurred anonymity, either, for Maida, the famous highland greyhound that belonged to Walter Scott. The novelist's dog was made to pose so frequently for artists that it was said he used to run away whenever he saw a pencil. William Scoular's marble sculpture of Sir Walter Scott and His Dog (c1838) embodies what is so peculiar about this exhibition. The meticulously carved dog, looking up lovingly at his master, is unlikely enough with his curly tail shaped out of hard geology. But he draws attention to how odd Scott himself looks sitting there, frozen and dead, on a bookcase loaded with chilly books. When you look at a marble dog in an art gallery, you begin to grasp how absolutely different the idea of "art" was 200 years ago. There was painting and there was sculpture. These categories were defined by a type of activity rather than a type of thinking. You didn't have to think at all to make a sculpture of a dog. It had a history and it had a market. The Leeds-born sculptor Joseph Gott (1786-1860) had a studio in Rome where he specialised in making dogs to sell to aristocrats on the Grand Tour. There had been spectacular discoveries of ancient Roman sculptures of greyhounds, and that was all the justification clients needed to have their own hairy chums immortalised. Gott's greyhounds have shoulder bones and vertebrae tight against their smooth white skins. They are alert, they are poised. But they mostly lack the dynamism and tension to make the dogs come alive. They are relics of an aristocratic culture that 13had giant stone hounds guarding the grounds and a terracotta replica of the mistress's late terrier next to the fireplace. These people lived with the dog; they knew the dog. And in this world of uninhibited animal-human relations some perverse fantasies flourished. Hands were licked, heads were stroked. Richard James Wyatt's Nymph Removing a Thorn from a Greyhound's Foot (1850) has a phallic hound standing erect and licking, with slavering gratitude, the smooth flesh of a nude nymph. The wild animal is unleashed in a more decorous way in the best work of art here, Grégoire Giraud's Hound (1827) from the Louvre, a sumptuously muscled creature whose claim to this statuesque status is illustrated in a frieze round the base. It shows the hound bringing down a stag with his teeth clamped into its stomach, attacking a bull (baiting bulls with dogs was thought to improve the taste of the meat) and saving a baby from snakes. What a dog! This may be the most subversive exhibition the Henry Moore Institute has ever staged. Sculpture has rarely looked so unhealthily sensuous. All those pets, all that frozen love. Hounds in Leash is at the Henry Moore Institute, Leeds (0113-246 7467), till August 27.

fields.headline: University may rescue pop centre
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The troubled National Centre for Popular Music, which has been trying to stave off bankruptcy after disastrous visitor numbers, may be forced to become part of a local university to survive.
fields.body:
The troubled National Centre for Popular Music, which has been trying to stave off bankruptcy after disastrous visitor numbers, may be forced to become part of a local university to survive.

Talks are being held by the organisers of the £15m project and Sheffield Hallam university, which has been looking for a new site for its expanding department of cultural studies. The Arts Council, which gave £11m in national lottery funding for the shrine to rock, jazz and pop music, is also involved in the discussions.

Last year the centre made staff cuts and reduced prices in an agreement with creditors but has faced continuing financial struggles. The distinctive building in central Sheffield, with four stainless steel drums surrounding a hi-tech courtyard, is likely to know its fate at the end of this month.

The management has taken revised proposals to the Arts Council. These could lead to "shared activities" with Hallam. The university, whose campus is next to the centre, said that the plans were designed to "contribute to the continuing regeneration of Sheffield city centre and the cultural industries quarter".

Hallam university has been planning to move its cultural studies department into a building close to the music centre. Use of the centre would fit into the university's pattern of land ownership, which includes an undeveloped site next to it temporarily used as a car park.

The music centre has had mixed reviews since opening in March last year. Visitors have voted with their feet, however, and the optimistic initial visitor targets common to most big lottery projects were scaled down from 400,000 to 150,000 at the creditors' meeting in November.

fields.headline: Born in a storm
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Nancy Banks-Smith
fields.trailText: Last night's TV: Coronation Street
fields.body:
In nine weeks or so, Monica, the most elegant creature in Coronation Street (ITV), will give birth. Octuplets are predicted. Throughout this sensational affair Monica has retained her customary well-bred air of being a cut above all that. She will not, you feel, have any comment for the press. Of course, it's easier to look down your nose when you're a greyhound. When Monica looks down her nose, the look reaches you five minutes later.

After last night's terrible to-do ("Weatherfield woman in baby-snatch horror"), I am a wrung-out rag emotionally, and uncertain how much more baby trauma I can take.

Weatherfield General is one of those singularly inept and understaffed hospitals found, you hope, mostly in soaps. Martin Platt works there as a nurse but, as he is currently in flagrante with another nurse, Rebecca, staffing levels seem reduced to one midwife and Sharon, the chaplain. Sarah-Louise Platt, who is only 13, and Alison Webster, who, let's face it, is a bit odd, are having babies in this hellhole.

Sarah-Louise's baby, Britney, is thriving and, appropriately enough, in good voice. (It's soap practice to name helpless children after pop stars. Hence Toyah in Coronation Street, Courtney in EastEnders and Kylie in Brookside.) Alison's baby, however, is dying.

Alison and Kevin are never going to win the Procter and Gamble prize for Grasping the Situation in a Flash. You could almost pity the bloke with a beard ("I'm Dr Phillips, the consultant paediatrician") who struggles to explain the baby's condition to them.

Kevin: "I don't understand." The doctor mentions a very serious condition. Kevin: "What do you mean - serious?" The doctor says it's an infection. Alison: "An infection?" The doctor sighs visibly. He explains the nature of the infection. Kevin: "What the hell does that mean?" There's a problem here with language itself. Kevin put it later, in his own words, in his own way. "He'll never play for City now."

That night, drifting through the darkened hospital like a ghost, the bereaved Alison meets an exhausted young Sarah-Louise, offers to look after Britney while she rests and walks out with the baby.

Around now, you feel an urgent need to kick somebody in authority. And a kindly fate provides him, complete with supercilious spectacles ("I'm Paul Birch, chief exec of the Hospital Trust"). Paul is clearly a posh person, and in any soap that's like pinning "Kick Me" on your back. Martin Platt, Britney's grandfather, can accelerate from nought to 90 in two seconds, and he now breaks his own record.

"Don't you Martin me! If you're expecting me to hush this up for the sake of the Trust, you've another thing coming. If anything goes wrong here, anything, I'm going to blow the gaff on you, pal. Big Time." Many people would say several things had already gone badly wrong.

All the Platts now join in. Martin's wife Gail, his mother-in-law Audrey, and Sarah-Louise. You could only be grateful for Britney's unavoidable absence. Wherever two or three Platts are gathered together, it's like getting your head caught between the cymbals during a noisy bit of Beethoven. ("That's it! Come on! Out! Get out!" "Martin, calm down!" "Typical!" "There she goes again!" "Will you just think before you open your mouth!" "Shurrup!"). We can hardly wait for Gail to find out about Rebecca.

It is, of course, Monica, that sagacious greyhound, who finds Alison. I am not surprised. Frankly, Alison has always had the look of a rabbit - without the ears, naturally. Charming, but, essentially, prey. Her huge eyes, which seem to be set on either side of her head, expect trouble over 360 degrees and are rarely disappointed. Life, the predator, has it in for Alison.

She hands the baby back to Kevin and throws herself under a juggernaut.

I was talking to Coronation Street about this week's programmes. Wednesday was an hour special, so Friday, I supposed, would be something of a mop and bucket job, cleaning up the mess? There was a strangulated sort of sound from Manchester.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Demetrius And The Gladiators/The Beast Of War/Buffalo 66/Afterglow
fields.body:
Demetrius And The Gladiators

(Delmer Daves, 1954)

1pm, Carlton Cinema

You thrilled to Russell Crowe's king of the Colosseum in Gladiator, now see the original in action. Victor Mature's Demetrius is as impassive and physically imposing as Crowe and also plays a slave-turned-gladiator adept at carving up men and beasts in the arena. But this being 20th Century-Fox's sequel to its biblical hit The Robe, there's a religious battle too, as Demetrius is torn between his faith and desire for Susan Hayward's Messalina in the court of mad Caligula.

The Beast Of War

(Kevin Reynolds, 1988)

10pm, FilmFour

A spare, savage look at the horrors of war, with a Russian tank crew lost and pursued by vengeful rebels in Afghanistan's Valley of the Jackals. Despite the cute American actors - Jason Patric, Stephen Baldwin - there's a tough, no-nonsense edge to the action, and an intelligent subtext about the moral contradictions of the conflict.

Buffalo 66

(Vincent Gallo, 1997)

12.25am, Sky Premier

Gallo's Billy, straight from jail, goes home to Buffalo, NY, and kidnaps Christina Ricci's Layla so she can pretend to be his wife in a meeting with his feckless uninterested apathetic parents (Ben Gazzara, Anjelica Huston): and so one of the most touching of screen romances is born. Gallo's directorial debut is fresh, funny and utterly individual.

Afterglow

(Alan Rudolph, 1997)

2.15am, Sky Premier

A leisurely, painfully comic study of two failing marriages. Jonny Lee Miller is an ambitious twentysomething, sure that everything is fine at home, but his sexually frustrated wife Lara Flynn Boyle is far from happy and she is instantly attracted

to philandering repairman Nick Nolte, husband of Julie Christie's fragile ex-movie actress (pictured). Relationships are finely drawn in Rudolph's witty, perceptive script: "You're the most fascinating woman I've met in my entire life," Miller tells Christie. "Yes, I know," she replies.

fields.headline: 'Deranged' Mugabe to seize more land
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe said yesterday that his government would seize all the country's land and if any whites were allowed to continue farming it would be out of "our own charity".
fields.body:
Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe said yesterday that his government would seize all the country's land and if any whites were allowed to continue farming it would be out of "our own charity".

He was giving a pep talk to his party's 120 candidates for the parliamentary elections due on June 24 and 25. Mr Mugabe told leaders of Zanu-PF that his government is planning to take more than the 841 farms it has already designated for redistribution.

"It's not just the 841 farms we are looking at," Mr Mugabe said. "We are looking at the totality of our land. If we allow others to have portions of it, that must be on the basis of our own will, our own desire, our own charity. It will not be on the basis of our colonial history."

He said the government had succeeded in its campaign to take land away from white farmers as a result of help from the veterans of the war against Rhodesian rule.

"Thanks to our veterans and the nation must thank them," Mr Mugabe said to enthusiastic applause.

His statements were attacked by the leading opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC). Its president, Morgan Tsvangirai, dismissed Mr Mugabe's pledge to seize all farmland as "deranged".

"The land policy is being determined by a man who is no longer rational," Mr Tsvangirai said.

He said the illegal occupation of 1,400 white-owned farms by the war veterans and other Zanu-PF supporters was planned by Mr Mugabe. "It was an orchestrated plan to invade the farms and intimidate the opposition. The war veterans and other Zanu-PF thugs carried out those orders. But the majority of the war veterans are law-abiding people who respect order."

Three prospective MDC candidates for parliament were killed by Zanu-PF supporters last month and Mr Tsvangirai said that several of the opposition party's new candidates have been threatened.

"Zanu-PF and state operatives are targeting some of our candidates," he said. "They are not safe and we are taking steps to protect them. We face a resurgence of violence to dissuade voters from voting."

The MDC's secretary general, Welshman Ncube, excoriated Mr Mugabe's praise of the war veterans. "It is irrational to ask Zimbabweans who have lost 29 lives to political violence to thank the so-called war veterans responsible for that violence," Mr Ncube said.

"It is irrational to expect the families of the women who have been raped to thank the war veterans. The 7,000 to 10,000 people who are homeless in their own country as a result of violence will not thank the war veterans. Nor will the thousands of teachers who have had to flee their schools. All the people who have suffered intimidation and have been beaten have no reason to thank the so-called war veterans."

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who will be the first to play themselves in a film?
fields.trailText: Who will be the first to play themselves in a film?
fields.body:
Geri Halliwell 3/1

Gwyneth Paltrow 10/1

Tom Cruise 25/1

Brad Pitt 25/1

Drew Barrymore 25/1

It takes more than one quirky film to start a trend. But Chris Isaak, David Hasselhoff and Ben Stiller are following the lead of Malkovich in Being John Malkovich and playing themselves in films.

Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler, has been casting his eye over who will be the next star to tread the narcissistic boards. He thinks the lives of both Geri Halliwell and Tom Cruise would make interesting films.

"Cruise is a long shot", says Ed. "Geri, on the other hand, is almost a certainty, having been in Spiceworld and that much discussed documentary. But what are the odds that anyone would watch it?" In fact, Halliwell recently announced at Cannes that she is signed to do a film with some parallels to her life - playing a mental patient that has an affair with her shrink in Therapy.

Word has it that Gwyneth Paltrow - recently voted the most overrated Actress/Actor by Jane magazine - has the ego to put herself forward for a movie based on her life. "But why do it when you're Miramax's princess?" queries Ed. "She has so many films in the pipeline, that I doubt she'd have the time in the next few years."

Brad Pitt has already played himself in Being John Malkovich, and with a recent lack of commercial success, he might be well advised to do a film about how great he is. "Preferably with his kit off for all his female fans," suggests Ed.

Drew Barrymore's mum, Jaid, is reportedly trying to sell the story of her life and loves to the highest bidder, which includes shovelling the dirt on Jim Morrison, Kiefer Sutherland and James Taylor - any film adaptation would surely top the ratings for saucy revelations.

"Allegedly, there is mention of a mom-daughter-Warren Beatty threesome," reveals Ed, adding: "Somehow I can't see Drew wanting to play herself in that movie. But that would certainly be one of the most interesting film plots for an actor or actress to play themselves in."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Gray's Elegy/Leading Edge
fields.body:
If you regard Shakespeare's depiction of Richard III as the last word in historical accuracy you're immune to health warnings about dramatic licence. Others might view Gray's Elegy (2.15pm, Radio 4) as a highly personal gloss by playwright Stephen Wyatt on the creation of one of English letters' most famous monuments. Thomas Gray's quarrel with Horace Walpole during their grand tour is well-attested. From there on, Wyatt's entertaining and well-crafted script winds creatively o'er almost any old lea in sight.

One of the tangential problems of dealing with the Aids epidemic is that it lends itself so readily to conspiracy theories. The debate about how the HIV virus jumped from monkeys to humans is now being denounced by some politicians as a racist attempt to blame Africa for the disease. Geoff Watts (pictured) explores the controversy in Leading Edge (9.0pm, Radio 4), asking if the furore will delay medical treatment for that continent's millions of victims.

webTitle: Financier in record bid for Senate

fields.headline: Financier in record bid for Senate
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: A Wall Street financier with no political experience has spent a record $33m (£21.6m) of his own money to win the Democratic nomination for the New Jersey Senate race. Then Jon Corzine, 53, and a former co-chairman of Goldman Sachs, joined the growing clamour for limits on election spending.
fields.body:
A Wall Street financier with no political experience has spent a record $33m (£21.6m) of his own money to win the Democratic nomination for the New Jersey Senate race. Then Jon Corzine, 53, and a former co-chairman of Goldman Sachs, joined the growing clamour for limits on election spending.

"We need campaign finance reform," said Mr Corzine whose spending amounted to 75% of his income of $44m last year. He spent $2m on polling day alone for the primary election, taking 58% of the vote against 42% for his opponent, the former state governor Jim Florio.

Mr Florio, outspent by 10-to-one and damaged by memories of the state's biggest income tax increase imposed while he was governor, had accused Mr Corzine of buying the nomination and said he was a threat to democracy.

The winner spent about $140 on each vote, nearly all of it from his personal fortune of $400m. But big spenders do not always win.

"The number of wealthy candidates who have spent their money and gone down in flames is as great if not greater than the ones who have spent their money and won," said Stephen Salmore, a Republican campaign consultant.

Mr Corzine ran on a liberal platform with popular plans for big spending on social programmes.

He opposes the death penalty and supports gay rights and mandatory gun licensing, and proposes universal healthcare, free college tuition for average students and long-term care for the elderly and disabled.

"Make no mistake," Mr Corzine said in his victory speech, "I want to invest in America. That's what this campaign will be about."

webTitle: The fine art of collecting honorary degrees

fields.headline: The fine art of collecting honorary degrees
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Competition between British universities for big name honorary graduates will reach a peak today at a televised ceremony in Leeds, when the country's best known cultural pundit drapes a gown over its most popular living artist.
fields.body:
Competition between British universities for big name honorary graduates will reach a peak today at a televised ceremony in Leeds, when the country's best known cultural pundit drapes a gown over its most popular living artist.

Outsiders are being invited to watch an internet broadcast of Lord Bragg bestowing a Leeds University doctorate of letters on David Hockney, in what colleagues have dubbed a cross between University Challenge and Stars in their Eyes.

Lord Bragg will be installed as chancellor before conferring a clutch of honorary degrees. "I was pressured into this by Melvyn," Hockney said while preparing to join the leading theatre director Jude Kelly and biographer Lord Bullock in the ceremony at the university's Great Hall.

The coup has come just in time for Leeds as far as the artist is concerned. Like other sought-after honorary targets, Dr Hockney D Litt (Bradford) PhD (Royal College of Art) D Litt (Oxon) is beginning to feel degreed-out.

"Yes, this is it," he said, ruling out further awards. "It might sound grand to be a four times doctor, but you cannot write out prescriptions for your own drugs on this."

The Leeds list, which also includes the astrophysicist and broadcaster Jocelyn Bell Burnell, is counterbalanced by a local philanthropist, Robert Ogden, and the university's former pro-chancellor Colonel Alan Roberts.

Hockney, born and educated in Bradford, added that he finally fell in with Lord Bragg "only because I feel it's local". Neither party has much prospect of longer term gains from the degree, the artist added, assuring that the honour would affect neither his life nor his work and would lead him to show only "slightly more interest" in the university.

But more involving and student-related honorary degrees could become a pattern in future, according to Ms Kelly, who heads the West Yorkshire Playhouse in Leeds. Another four times doctor, she said: "The one I value most is from Dartington College, because the students voted for me to get it. But this one means a lot because it comes from the city I live in, the place I've been trying to contribute to for the last 11 years."

Useful link
www.leeds.ac.uk (including live broadcast of ceremony at 2.45pm)

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Colin Newman, musician
fields.trailText: Colin Newman, musician
fields.body:
If anyone had told me a year ago that I would spend the first six months of this year engaged in various activities with my old cohorts Wire, I would have at least expressed mild surprise. No, make that dumb disbelief. Such has been the pattern of my so-called professional life that I've travelled far from my erstwhile roots. Yet it's interesting to indulge in some familiar musical interplay while gently nudging the "old jalopy" into a more rewarding (and familiar to me) contemporary arena.

Wire now stands at the end of a pretty frantically active period by its own stop-start standards. It's actually played live 15 times this year, including a US tour, and it's only June! So what's going on? Here is a band who have only actually worked together for less than 10 years of their 23-year (count 'em!) history, who have never had any kind of hit record, and who no longer have (nor have any interest in) a record deal.

Yet they can fill the Royal Festival Hall and ram certain high-profile US venues way beyond their fire capacities with audiences of which a considerable number are less than half their own (not that inconsiderable) age. It's a mystery and an enigma to us all, yet is perhaps proof positive that an ensemble who have only ever tried to make an impression (somewhat naively perhaps) by just being as good and diverse as they can be, can have a lasting effect beyond being an "influence".

So what's next? For me, I'm off to Sonar, an electronic music festival in Barcelona to do a little DJ set to present my label swim ~ then after that I may or may not be touring North America again, this time in my DJ guise. And for Wire there will be a re-convening later in the year to see if we can cook up some more delights; meanwhile Wire's own pinkflag.com mail-order label will be releasing the third in its current series - a version of the US set recorded and mixed at Steve Albini's "Electric" studio in Chicago.

webTitle: EU to help sexually harassed women

fields.headline: EU to help sexually harassed women
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Sexual harassment at work is to be banned across Europe, bringing countries such as Portugal and Greece - where no laws exist against abusive bosses - in line with the strictest.
fields.body:
Sexual harassment at work is to be banned across Europe, bringing countries such as Portugal and Greece - where no laws exist against abusive bosses - in line with the strictest.

Under a new EU directive spearheaded by Anna Diamantopoulou, the Greek commissioner for social affairs who yesterday revealed that as a teenager she was forced to leave a job after being sexually harassed, companies that fail to protect female workers from unwanted advances will face the courts.

Britain will have to extend its legislation to the level of France and Belgium, the only two EU countries with a full set of sexual harassment laws.

"Sexual harassment is a form of sexual discrimination and thus entails a risk of liability for employers who fail to provide a workplace free of harassment," the European commission warned.

The European parliament and member state governments will need to give their backing to the new proposals before they can take effect and may opt to make some changes. The commission has set a deadline of January 1 2002 for all 15 EU countries to enact the new rules.

The initiative will usher in a Europe-wide definition of exactly what kind of behaviour constitutes sexual harassment. Once agreed, it will be incorporated into the EU's equal opportunities directive, which has not been altered for nearly 25 years.

"The fact that we are announcing that there will be a European policy on sexual harassment will give women the internal courage to stand up and have their say," Ms Diamantopoulou said.

The commissioner said that she had suffered from sexual harassment in a part-time job while a 19-year-old student studying civil engineering. "I had no redress and I had to give up. The only conclusion at the time was that there was nothing I could do. There was no framework in place," she said.

Under the new directive, member states will be obliged to create independent bodies to investigate complaints.

fields.headline: Eye on the ball
fields.standfirst: The BBC is reckons it's all about simple, no-frills coverage. Meanwhile, ITV is lining up some state-of-the art 3D-graphics. Who is going to give us the best-looking coverage for Euro 2000?  Rupert Smith  investigates
fields.trailText: The BBC is reckons it's all about simple, no-frills coverage. Meanwhile, ITV is lining up some state-of-the art 3D-graphics. Who is going to give us the best-looking coverage for Euro 2000?
fields.body:
Forget England v Germany - the real Euro 2000 contest is being fought out on virtual turf between BBC1 and ITV. The two main terrestrial broadcasters go head to head with their coverage of the tournament - and, for once, without pesky intervention from Sky Sports - to become the channel of choice for the viewing millions. Obviously, they're wheeling out the big guns for this TV derby; the BBC boasts a huge "battle bus" containing an entire broadcasting facility that can travel between grounds, while ITV is fielding some tasty new graphics packages to keep us on the edge of our seats.

But how much difference can these trappings really make? Because however they dress it up, both channels are stuck with the same basic feed from the host broadcasters, a combination of Belgian and Dutch TV stations. The matches themselves are carved up fairly evenly between BBC1 and ITV, but when it comes to those few occasions when both are showing the same match live, what's to choose between them? There has to be more to this than a straightforward Lineker/Lynam grudge fight.

Ultimately, the only area in which BBC1 and ITV can compete is in the way they dress up the "dirty feed" from the host broadcasters. And that comes down, basically, to studio presentation and the all-important graphics. ITV promises "cutting edge graphics" from the £250,000 Everest package, which allows them to generate seemingly three-dimensional images on screen. These can be anything from boxes that hold the commentator's name through to drop-down menus full of statistics, or little clocks that announce "Goal" when occasion demands.

"They won't scream 'Goal! Goal! Goal!' like they do on Sky," says Rick Waumsley, executive producer of ITV's Euro 2000 coverage. "We'd like to think that our coverage is a bit more restrained than that. You won't be blitzed with thousands of statistics popping up all over the screen and getting in the way of the match itself. But I'd like to think that our graphics will give it a more modern, brighter, streamlined appearance, without clashing with the basic feed."

As well as eye-popping moulded graphics, ITV will also wheel out the mighty ORAD machine - the gizmo that allows them to grab an image from the field and translate it into a virtual image. This is particularly useful for possible offsides, or for assessing whether the ball went over the line; it's also fun for recreating spectacular moments. "We used it to demonstrate a couple of Ryan Giggs's wondergoals against Arsenal," says Waumsley. "You can track the player running up the field, with lines in front of him or behind him to indicate where he's going. Obviously with a piece of kit like this it's tempting to go mad, but we use it only when it's really necessary."

The BBC, however, has dispensed with such measures. According to ITV's Waumsley, the BBC sports department bought an ORAD machine but never used it and eventually sold it. "There's a danger of style winning out over content," says Paul McNamara, executive producer for BBC1's Euro 2000 coverage. "If you go into a clever graphic, you're left at the end having to drop back into the host feed, and they could be doing absolutely anything. It's not going to look seamless.

"And of course there's always the danger that while you're getting busy with your graphics, you miss the actual goal. If we had the luxury of 20 of our own cameras at the side of every ground, then maybe we could go down that road, but out in Belgium and the Netherlands we don't have the necessary degree of control. We thought long and hard about doing digital reconstructions for Euro 2000, and in the end we decided not to. It would just be TV for TV's sake."

The choice, then, seems simple enough: BBC1 for the no-frills coverage, plus Gary Lineker, Alan Hansen and roving reporter Johann Cruyff; ITV for a souped-up version with bright, sparkly graphics plus Des Lynam, Bob Wilson and Gabby Yorath. You might expect a more aggressive rivalry between the two channels - but the enforced truce seems more a result of limited opportunity than a sudden outbreak of amicability. Each broadcaster can only squeeze a couple of their own cameras into each ground, and they'll be busy customising the coverage for British audiences. If Prince Charles or Victoria Beckham turns up at the ground, they'll follow them; if an English player does something of special interest to domestic viewers, they can zoom in. Short of mutual sabotage, there's little else they can do.

As the big sporting fixtures float off to other broadcasters, this may be one of the last times that BBC1 and ITV have the chance to compete so directly over what is basically identical coverage. If England are knocked out at an early stage, both will be relying on their presentation style to keep viewers tuning in to their particular matches. When it comes to the final, which both channels cover live, viewing decisions will be made on which style we've learned to love more. But with so little room to manoeuvre, it may come down to a straightforward battle of the pundits after all.

fields.headline: Mr Blair gets the bird
fields.standfirst: The magic has gone. Now he has to fight
fields.trailText: Things have come to a pretty pass when a prime minister is heckled by the Women's Institute. A body whose name has been a byword for courtesy and decorum resorting to a slow handclap and a walkout - and inflicting this punishment on no less than the head of the British government.
fields.body:
Things have come to a pretty pass when a prime minister is heckled by the Women's Institute. A body whose name has been a byword for courtesy and decorum resorting to a slow handclap and a walkout - and inflicting this punishment on no less than the head of the British government. Perhaps this episode, even more than the notorious nude calendar, will rid the WI forever of its jam-and-Jerusalem image. An essay is due on the Women's Institute's journey from tea and jumble sales to activism and in-your-face conviction.

But a more pressing subject has to be addressed: something is going wrong with this government. Friends of Labour will hope this is only a bad case of mid-term blues, but the patient is looking very peaky. Since the Millennium Dome chaos of New Year's eve, the government has endured six months of persistent misfortune. A flu crisis exposed the creakiness of the NHS; a stand-off with Ken Livingstone held up for public view the control-freakery of the Labour machine. The Conservative opposition, for more than two years the invisible men of British politics, began to make an impact. William Hague's interventions on asylum and crime have been crude, but they have landed punches. Unhappily, the last fortnight's debate on elitism seems to have lost Labour more friends than it has won. What it all adds up to is the sense that the winning coalition put together by Tony Blair in 1997 is coming apart - with middle Britain fleeing the New Labour tent in droves. Yesterday's scenes in Wembley Arena - replayed on television and relished in this morning's newspapers - have now given that feeling its signature image. According to Mr Hague, Mr Blair has abandoned Middle Britain and yesterday came proof that Middle Britain is abandoning him.

Of course there are specific circumstances. The WI women may not have been annoyed at Mr Blair's message so much as his effrontery in delivering it at all: they do not like party-political harangues and they do not like to be used as backdrops for the TV news. The PM should have judged his audience better. What he served up yesterday - long catalogues of spending figures and policy targets - did not fit the bill at all.

There are two questions which Downing Street should now ponder. The first is the message. Yesterday's speech was simply not good enough; it lacked the intellectual coherence to qualify as the mission statement it clearly purported to be. There was some reheated communitarianism, but that idea always falls at the same hurdle: everyone likes community, but how exactly can we foster more of it? Besides, the speech failed to make the link between "community" and the battery of government programmes Mr Blair dutifully listed.

The connection between opportunity and responsibility did not come off either. It is clear why, politically, Mr Blair would want to invoke both - balancing left and right - but he failed to make an intellectual bridge between the two. Equal opportunity is a good rallying cry, but it needs much sturdier thought if it is to become the logical thread which ties together the assorted elements of the government's activity.

The second query relates to the messenger. For six years Labour has held Mr Blair to be the unassailable asset, the supreme leader whose healing balm can be made to assuage any situation, no matter how tricky. His reception yesterday suggests that the Blair effect no longer applies. He does not walk on water; he has to swim in it along with politics' lesser mortals - and swim hard.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Borough chief faces inquiry
fields.body:
Borough chief faces inquiry

A council chief executive suspended in February over allegations of bullying is to be investigated by an independent person appointed by the government. Sari Conway is alleged to have bullied staff at Eastbourne borough council, East Sussex.

Two held over missing mother

Two men have been arrested over the murder of a mother of two missing for 18 months. Lynsey Quy's husband Mitchell and father-in-law Michael Quy were being questioned, it was understood. The 21-year-old was last seen at her home in Southport, Merseyside, at Christmas 1998, when her husband said she walked out.

Breakthrough in termite battle

Scientists yesterday said they were winning the war against Britain's only known termite colony, discovered six years ago at Saunton, north Devon. In April last year a government termite eradication team laid a specially licensed chemical and they say there has been a dramatic drop in the termite population since.

Duke of York takes FA post

The Duke of York is to take over as president of the Football Association in August, succeeding the Duke of Kent, who is stepping down after almost 30 years in the FA presidency.

Glasgow's 15th heroin death

The mystery illness affecting heroin users has taken a 15th life in Glasgow, the city health board said yesterday. There have now been 33 people affected in the area. There have been eight deaths in Dublin and seven in England and Wales.

webTitle: Yates libel win for deceit allegation

fields.headline: Yates libel win for deceit allegation
fields.trailText: Paula Yates yesterday accepted substantial libel damages over allegations that she deliberately and "deceitfully" became pregnant by her partner, Michael Hutchence, to ensnare him into a permanent relationship.
fields.body:
Paula Yates yesterday accepted substantial libel damages over allegations that she deliberately and "deceitfully" became pregnant by her partner, Michael Hutchence, to ensnare him into a permanent relationship.

Ms Yates was present at the high court in London to hear her solicitor, Anthony Burton, tell Mr Justice Eady that she had suffered "serious injury to her reputation" and had been "caused acute hurt, distress and embarrassment" by publication of the allegations - taken from a book about Mr Hutchence - in the Mail on Sunday last year.

Mr Burton said Ms Yates, a celebrity "best known as a television presenter and author" was the partner of Mr Hutchence, lead singer with rock group INXS, from 1994 until his death in November 1997. On July 22 1996 the couple had a child, Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily.

Mr Burton told the court that the allegations were published in the Mail on Sunday's Night and Day magazine on April 11 last year in the first of two serialisations from a book entitled Michael Hutchence, written by Vince Lovegrove and published in Australia.

It was alleged, he said, that "Paula Yates deceitfully and without the knowledge of her partner Michael Hutchence deliberately became pregnant by him in order to entrap or ensnare him into a permanent relationship".

It was also alleged that she then "tried to cover up what she had done by deceitfully and tastelessly creating and giving publicity to a false story after Mr Hutchence's death that they had had fertility treatment to conceive their child".

The defendant, Associated Newspapers, the publisher of the Mail on Sunday, "published the serialisation of Mr Lovegrove's book in reliance on a warranty from Faber & Faber, the book's English publisher that the matters contained in it were true. Faber & Faber had a warranty from the Australian publishers."

He added: "The defendant now accepts that the allegations it published were false and should not have been published and is here to set the record straight and to publicly apologise to the claimant."

Mr Burton said the defendant, Faber & Faber and the Australian book publishers "have between them agreed to pay substantial damages to the claimant and her legal costs in settlement of her claims".

Ms Yates's principal concern was to show that Tiger was a wanted baby, he said.

Liz Hartley, solicitor for Associated Newspapers, told the judge: "The newspaper agreed to publish a two part serialisation of Mr Lovegrove's book on the understanding that the matters contained within [it] were true and capable of legal proof." The newspaper accepted that the "allegations are untrue and should never have been published and apologises to the claimant".

Ms Yates said: "I am happy. I think when people start to tell lies about a three-year-old child who has lost her father anyone would take action."

webTitle: 'Young actors often look divine. But then they open their little traps, and you think: Oh dear'

fields.headline: 'Young actors often look divine. But then they open their little traps, and you think: Oh dear'
fields.standfirst: As Barbara Jefford prepares to star in Coriolanus, she talks to  Veronica Lee
fields.trailText: As Barbara Jefford prepares to star in Coriolanus, she talks to Veronica Lee
fields.body:
The programme for the Almeida's new production of Coriolanus sets out its stall: warrior hero and jealous rival, played by Ralph Fiennes and Linus Roache, square up across the front page.

It's a boys' play, right? Well, no actually. At the heart of the work is the relationship between Coriolanus and his destructive mother, Volumnia. In Coriolanus Shakespeare covered a subject that keeps many a therapist in business - an obsessive love between mother and son that leads to the destruction of both.

How and why did she produce this angry young man convinced of his own invincibility, off to battle at the drop of a hat, but who hangs on her every word, while his wife is merely "my gracious silence"? For Jonathan Kent, who is directing the Almeida production, the key to understanding Coriolanus is Volumnia.

"She has created this killing machine who has an almost Pavlovian response to battle and bloodshed. But at the end, in persuading him on a course of action that will eventually lead to his death, she destroys him, and she knows she's doing it," he says.

According to Kent, Volumnia is a strong woman who survives in a male society by adopting all the masculine virtues. In Barbara Jefford, one our most experienced Shakepeareans, Kent has found a sparkling Volumnia. "She would have made a great soldier herself," Jefford says, "but lives vicariously through her son. He is her life and there is an almost unnatural love between them - she is totally fulfilled by him. He is her work of art."

Volumnia may be considered the baddie - she even encourages her young grandson to crush butterflies - but Jefford does not share that view. "I wouldn't call her evil. She doesn't incite people to murder, like Lady Macbeth, say. She's so obsessed with her son that she might be considered unbalanced, but that's what makes her fascinating."

Jefford explains: "I suppose one could say it's a one-parent family. Her husband, a soldier, was killed while her son was very young. As soon as he was old enough to hold a sword he was in battle, not just playing soldiers. He has to die to save his homeland and she knows that, but she persuades him to do the 'right' thing. I feel it is the only thing she can do."

It is strange that Shakespeare examined the mother-son dynamic only in this play. Jefford points out that Shakespeare wrote Coriolanus at the time of his mother's death. "We have no way of knowing what she was like, or how he felt about her - but that's interesting, don't you think?"

Jefford, now 59, has appeared in 52 Shakespearean productions. She made her debut as Isabella in Measure for Measure, opposite John Gielgud, and was part of the postwar golden age at Stratford with Michael Redgrave, Peggy Ashcroft and Anthony Quayle. After stints at the Old Vic and National Theatre, in films and TV, Jefford returned to Stratford 11 years ago, where she played Volumnia opposite Charles Dance.

"It's a chance you don't often get," Jefford says. "To be able to go back to a role after a decade is just marvellous. You know what works, but having lived that bit more, you do have a new take on the role."

She has also played Fiennes's mother before, in Six Characters in Search of an Author, at the National in 1987, and admires his work. "I like his straight-down-the-line approach. It think it's how all great actors work."

Jefford is unusually busy for an actress of her age, but while Hollywood and television may cast aside older actors, in the Shakespeare scene it's a positive boon to have packed a few years in.

"I'm far too old to play Volumnia really, but you can only play Shakespeare when you have reached a certain stage of technical expertise. So often you will see performances by very young actors who look divine, but then they open their little traps, and you think, 'Oh dear.' "

It is also true that Shakespeare almost has to be age-blind, partly because no teenage actress could play, say, Juliet with any great acting expertise, and partly because the roles require some experience of life. "The last time I played Portia I was 43, having played her in my 20s and 30s," says Jefford. "I think I was better at it when I was older.

"And I'm not so frightened now. It's strange: when you're young you don't have nerves because you don't know what the pitfalls are. Then the more you do, the more is expected of you. But now I'm more confident. I know I can do certain things and I'm not stuck in a rut."

Which would explain her latest film, Roman Polanski's The Ninth Gate, in which she plays a rather bizarre role, a scientist complete with withered arm, wheelchair and mittel-European accent.

Most actors would rush to work with Polanski, but Jefford first turned the role down, saying she was too busy. "Then Polanski himself rang me. It was like that Pete 'n' Dud sketch: 'It's only that bloody Roman Polanski on the phone.' It seemed rude not to, so I was on the set within a couple of days."

She found it good fun, but has been around long enough to see through Polanski's wiles. "It seemed to me that he would put aside a day for his tantrums. It's transparent that it's drummed up, but he still does it."

Does she now feel able to upbraid a difficult director? "Oh no. In films I still feel that I'm way behind, having done my first at the age of 36. As for theatre, I honestly haven't worked with a difficult director for years, but then age does command some sort of respect. They don't make you their whipping boy because the company would rise up and say, 'How dare you be nasty to Bar?' "

Like Gielgud, Jefford wants to work until her last breath. "I feel it's like food and drink - it's part of one's existence. I know a lot of people reach a stage where it isn't as gripping as it used to be. But it's nice to go on showing off a bit, because that's what actors are in it for really."

Coriolanus is in rep at the Gainsborough Studios, London N1 (020-7359 4404), from Wednesday till August 5.

webTitle: Eurotrash star's husband arrested over her death

fields.headline: Eurotrash star's husband arrested over her death
fields.trailText: French police investigating the death of Lolo Ferrari, the surgically-enhanced actress, singer and Channel 4 television presenter best known as the woman with the largest breasts in the world, yesterday arrested her husband.
fields.body:
French police investigating the death of Lolo Ferrari, the surgically-enhanced actress, singer and Channel 4 television presenter best known as the woman with the largest breasts in the world, yesterday arrested her husband.

Ferrari, a one-time porn star who underwent more than 30 operations to transform her face and body, was found dead in early March at her home in the south of France.

She was known to be taking large quantities of antidepressants and an initial autopsy concluded she died from an overdose of prescription drugs.

Police in Grasse arrested Eric Vigne, 52, her husband and manager of 13 years, on suspicion of failing to assist a person in danger. He will be questioned over the coming days, a spokesman said.

Mr Vigne has strongly denied any part in the death of his wife who, with her record bust - measured at 54G by the Guinness Book of Records - became a cult figure in Britain as the co-presenter of Channel 4's Eurotrash programme.

"When I devoted my time to stopping my wife committing suicide, I got called a pimp," he said.

"Now they're going to try to tell me I didn't do enough to save her. They're hard to bear, all these suspicions. Why would I kill my reason for existing?"

His lawyer, Serge Pautot, said many people could be charged with failing to help Ferrari: "Her husband, certainly, who shared her life and managed her career, but also the doctors, surgeons and psychiatrists who may have poorly evaluated the impact on her of her operations, her career and her dependence on drugs."

Born Eve Valois, Lolo Ferrari grew up in a middle-class family in the chic Breton resort town of La Baule. In interviews before she died, she said her gradual transition into a cruelly inflated Barbie doll was inspired by a desire to escape a cruel mother and deeply unhappy childhood.

Her breasts, designed by an aircraft engineer, each contained three litres of surgical serum. She had to wear a specially constructed bra day and night, could not sleep on her stomach or back because their weight made breathing difficult, and was afraid of flying because she thought they might explode.

Several psychologists have said she may have suffered from body dysmorphia, a rare condition in which sufferers feel compelled to continually alter their bodies.

Mr Vigne, a businessman who met Ferrari when she was 17, has in the past been accused of exploiting her for his financial gain.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Civilians killed in Congo battle
More than 50 civilians, including at least 19 children, have been killed and more than 100 wounded in three days of fighting between Rwandan and Ugandan troops in the Congolese city of Kisangani, UN and aid workers have said.
fields.body:
Civilians killed in Congo battle
More than 50 civilians, including at least 19 children, have been killed and more than 100 wounded in three days of fighting between Rwandan and Ugandan troops in the Congolese city of Kisangani, UN and aid workers have said.

UN officials said a school was hit yesterday as the two sides fired mortar shells across the city. It was not clear if children from the school were injured.
Reuters, Kisangani

Herb caused kidney damage
A Chinese herb mistakenly put in weight-loss pills damaged the kidneys of 105 patients at a Belgian clinic and may have caused 18 cases of cancer, according to a report in today's New England Journal of Medicine.

The US has announced it will ban imports of herbs in the Aristolochia family. Herbs of this type have also caused kidney failure in Britain when used to treat a skin condition.
Associated Press

Attila's palace to be rebuilt
The palace of Attila, king of the Huns, will be rebuilt on its supposed original site in Tapioszentmarton, Hungary, the town's mayor, Janos Toth, said yesterday.

He told a Hungarian news agency, MTI, that building work should begin this year.
Reuters, Budapest

Billy Graham quits tours
Evangelist Billy Graham this week said an Amsterdam conference for 10,000 church leaders next month will be his last international rally because of failing health. The 81-year-old American Baptist minister has Parkinson's disease but he made clear he intends to carry on preaching to the end.
Stephen Bates

webTitle: MEPs under fire fleeing coup island

fields.headline: MEPs under fire fleeing coup island
fields.trailText: Rebel gunmen yesterday fired at a plane carrying Glenys Kinnock and another member of the European parliament, John Corrie, as they escaped from the Solomon Islands.
fields.body:
Rebel gunmen yesterday fired at a plane carrying Glenys Kinnock and another member of the European parliament, John Corrie, as they escaped from the Solomon Islands.

Mr Corrie and Mrs Kinnock had been on a fact-finding mission, but were trapped in the capital, Honiara, on Tuesday as fighting developed between rebel factions after Monday's inconclusive coup attempt.

The pilot of their chartered plane made two attempts to leave because of gunfire.

Mr Corrie said: "When we taxied down the runway there was a tremendous fusillade of shots at us. A small part of the aircraft stopped functioning and we had to go back into the terminal. But the second time there were no problems. We took off and have safely arrived in Papua New Guinea."

Mrs Kinnock said the situation was "completely lawless".

"The police just seemed to concede to the [rebel] gunmen of the Malaita Eagle Force under Andrew Nori," she said. "There were armed men roaming around with home-made weapons and the streets were blocked and the airport closed."
Agencies

fields.headline: Green-eyed monsters
fields.standfirst: This week, Jennifer Ehle and Rosemary Harris were both up for the Tony Award for Best Actress. So? So they are mother and daughter, and one of them won.  Terri Apter examines female envy
fields.trailText: This week, Jennifer Ehle and Rosemary Harris were both up for the Tony Award for Best Actress. So? So they are mother and daughter, and one of them won.  Terri Apter examines female envy
fields.body:
Amother's love yields high expectations: it is selfless and it is total. When, instead, we feel tired, fed up, irritable, unloving, we are flooded with guilt. Other parents can assure us that it's normal, that it doesn't mean you're a bad mother. But suppose the love remains tainted even after a good night's sleep? Suppose a mother feels resentment rather than pride when her daughter is successful?

Throughout the last century, psychologists argued that mother envy, especially towards a daughter, is not only normal but inevitable. In 1945, Helene Deutsche claimed that women observe a daughter's adolescent blooming as a sign of their own decline. Pushed out of the sexual limelight, they experience an exquisite envy, which they disguise with protectiveness. When a mother says: "Don't do that, it's not safe," what Deutsche hears her saying is: "Don't you dare enjoy your youth, because I envy it."

More recently, Susie Orbach and others have argued that young women's expanding career opportunities can arouse a mother's envy. The daughters then keep themselves back, terrified that, if they surpass her, they will be forced to eat of those proverbial poisoned apples.

So when Jaid Barrymore, who allegedly tried to steal away daughter Drew's boyfriends, jostles for the limelight again with her own no-holds-barred account of family life, it is easy to sympathise with Drew's embarrassment and fear. And when Zadie Smith, author of Orange Prize-nominated White Teeth, claims her mother resents the fact that she earned so much by "doing nothing, just writing a book", we hear a familiar tune. Daughters run the last mile trying to please a mother, but their success doesn't give pleasure, only the sickly pain of envy.

Are we witnessing individual relationships that have gone tragically wrong, or an inevitable flaw in the mother-daughter bond? Envy has two very different measures: what the envious person feels and what the envied one fears. The thought that a mother may be envious of her own daughter awakens infantile terrors of being abandoned by someone we need. What we fear then is distorted and exaggerated.

But mothers, thinking they should take unalloyed pleasure in a daughter's development, are likely to deny their own envy, even to themselves. The only way we can measure it is to listen to mothers and daughters speak as honestly as they can, and to make the observation that their bond is complicated by the close identification each woman has with the other, alongside the need each has to be her own person, with her own admirers and her own satisfactions.

When a mother gives up her own pursuit of success on behalf of a child, she may have mixed feelings as her maternal investments generate pay-offs for her daughter. She is proud, but may also fear her daughter will leave her behind. She may be gratified, but also feel taken for granted.

Mother-envy is often cited as the cause of problems women have with competition, self-confidence, desire to win. The old fear: "What if I arouse my mother's envy?" becomes: "What if I make my friend envious of me?" While men seem happy to jostle for status and compete with friends, women often feel uneasy. It's not that girls don't feel competitive - they do. But they are less open about it and it is in this secrecy that envy breeds.

The suffering incurred by envy is increased by guilt: "What a shit to want to scream when your friend does so well." Though we learn to express envy in a joking way - "You look great! I hate you!" - we aren't supposed to feel unsettled by admiration. We're supposed to want our friends to be successful and beautiful. When we don't, we feel ashamed and worthless. And so, knowing the power of the envy they feel for others, girls are often frightened of the envy they might arouse in others. The self-denigration often observed in girl talk ("Oh, this old thing" or "If you think I'm pretty, you should look in the mirror") is a tactic for waylaying other girls' envy.

Our fear of envy and our shame at feeling it make it impossible for us to see it clearly. But envy is not something that necessarily obliterates good feeling; it can be layered with pleasure in others' triumphs. Several mothers and daughters have been in competition with one another this week and all parties disclaim envy.

Mary Hoffman and Rhiannon Lassiter both have a children's book published and, inevitably, compare their early careers. Hoffman was 25 when she wrote her first novel, 30 when she published it. Lassiter was 19 when she wrote her first book - and 19 when she won a contract for its publication. But when she made her remarkably early debut, her mother felt only one thing: fantastic pride.

Of course there might be situations in which competition (and envy) rear their heads. What if, for example, you are up against your daughter for a prize, which means only one wins and the other loses? fields.headline: Cheeky!
fields.standfirst: On the right is the cover of a modern men's magazine. Remind you of anything?  Ekow Eshun explains what Kylie's bottom means to him
fields.trailText: On the right is the cover of a modern men's magazine. Remind you of anything?  Ekow Eshun explains what Kylie's bottom means to him
fields.body:
In homage to the famous old Athena poster of a knickerless tennis player, this month's GQ cover features Kylie Minogue hitching up her skirt on court and scratching her bare bottom. Taken by top fashion photographer Terry Richardson, the image is supposed to be provocative, flirty and, of course, ironic.

It is knowing and detached, where the original was just horny soft-core fantasy. Personally, I prefer the original because it comes from a time before men learnt how to have their cheesecake and eat it, too, by replacing lust with arch, self-mocking humour. Anyone for postmodern tennis, as GQ editor Dylan Jones asks of the Kylie snaps.

Maybe I'm just showing my age, though. Perhaps to a teenager today, the Kylie cover carries all the mysterious eroticism that Athena poster held to me as a girl-shy adolescent. The difference between the 70s and now is that sex is no longer just the stuff of fantasy. The tennis girl was exciting in her time, and remains memorable today, because she seemed to offer a glimpse into a closed-off world of adult sexuality.

Sex is no longer so inaccessible. In fact it's unavoidable. You can see soft porn and strip shows on Channel 5 and cable TV, buy men's magazines with pouting lingerie shots of soap stars and read revelations about the sex lives of celebrities in the tabloids. None of this is quite what I imagined as a 13-year-old when I gazed longingly at the tennis girl. I made a correlation then between sex and adulthood, but what marks our present-day preoccupation with sex is its infantilism. That's certainly a very male trait. We've all learnt the lesson of laddism that leering at women on men's magazine covers is OK as long as you do so with a nod and a wink and an acknowledgement that men are "basically sad".

But if that attitude makes my heart sink, so too does the crassness of Denise Van Outen's Something For The Weekend, with its willy gags and vibrator games. And for that matter, all the puerile euphemisms that run through the Bridget Jones school of women's fiction, where heroines never have sex, make love or even fuck, but are more likely to have a "shag" or "bonk", as if sex itself were devoid of carnality or sweat.

In that context, Kylie baring her bottom feels like another playground gesture. It's harmless, cheeky fun. So why does it leave me so gloomy?

Now that the sun's out, I spend as much time as any other man watching women walk down the street. Which is to say, a lot. In the summer, watching girls go by is the prime male spectator sport. We imagine ourselves connoisseurs of the female form. Each time we gaze at a passing figure, we're totting up length of legs, size of breasts, width of hips as though Eric Morley just swore us in to judge this year's Miss World contest.

Men are fantasists. We are all potential formula one drivers, fighter pilots and red hot at-it-all-night lovers, never mind that the huge demand for Viagra might suggest for some us quite the opposite is true. But then, we've never needed reality to match our dreams. Quite the contrary. We often rely on the latter as a way to fuel and motivate our way through the former.

But looking at GQ's cover, it seems depressingly clear to me that, in terms of sex, we've become content to feed our fantasies, rather than reach further and grapple with the complexities and possibilities of adult sexual relationships. Lad and ladette culture has left us fixated with tits and bums. We find it easier to joke about sex than take our own desires seriously. We take Denise Van Outen and her dirty jokes or Kylie and her postmodern bum and see in them symbols of our sophistication. It all reminds me of being 13 years old again. Only then I could tell when I was being childish.
