fields.headline: Glen where history begins in 1951
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It is a damp Tuesday morning, in a scruffy service station on the M8, halfway between Edinburgh and Glasgow. The smell of fried food is wafting around the Roadchef restaurant, but the handful of customers are paying little attention to their breakfast.
fields.body:
It is a damp Tuesday morning, in a scruffy service station on the M8, halfway between Edinburgh and Glasgow. The smell of fried food is wafting around the Roadchef restaurant, but the handful of customers are paying little attention to their breakfast.

In one corner, a man from Flextech is on his mobile phone, having a loud but impenetrable discussion about bandwidths. Two men in suits are opposite, apparently thrashing out the details of a government grant. By the window, a woman is poring over a presentation, which includes a set of glossy pictures of electronic components.

This is the heart of Silicon Glen - the central belt of Scotland, which is home to one of the biggest clusters of hi-tech companies in Europe.

Tartan, heather and bagpipes are not much in evidence here. Neither are the traditional Scottish heavy industries of shipbuilding and mining. The undulating land between the country's two biggest cities is like a giant science park, dotted with the glossy glass and chrome buildings favoured by start-up companies.

Many have big ambitions. Brendan Hyland, chief executive of a new optoelectronics firm, Kymata, says: "We can bring to the central belt of Scotland what shipbuilding brought in the 1900s."

Already, Scotland produces 28% of Europe's personal computers and 7% of the entire world's. The electronics industry employs 40,500 people directly, with a further 29,500 in the supply infrastructure. The software sector employs a further 20,000 people, and has a turnover of £1.5bn.

Driven by need for data
Of all the areas of Britain poised to benefit from the growth of the internet and the new economy, central Scotland is perhaps the most promising.

The emphasis here is not on the much-hyped front-end consumer internet services, such as Lastminute.com and Freeserve. Instead, the region's role is more as the engine room of new technology. It houses companies producing the chips, lasers and circuits which allow information to travel instantly through the world wide web and across mobile phone networks.

Neil Martin, chief executive of a Glasgow-based start-up, Compound Semiconductor Technologies, says: "It's all about the net round here. Things are being driven by the need for data, driven by the convergence of computer companies and telecoms."

That is not to say that hi-tech businesses are new to Scotland. The electronics industry took root during the second world war, when companies shifted north to avoid the bombs dropping on English factories. Some geographical advantages quickly became clear. Central Scotland has a plentiful supply of water - essential for any kind of manufacturing. Transport connections are excellent, with two big cities on the doorstep and good air and sea links.

Among the first big corporations to locate in the region was IBM, which arrived in Greenock - the port just west of Glasgow - in 1951.

An influx in the 1960s was led by National Semiconductor, Hewlett Packard and Motorola. They were followed by Compaq in the 1970s, NEC in the 1980s and more recently, Cisco - the internet network specialist which briefly became the world's most valuable company this year.

Delivering aftercare
The presence of all these big employers has encouraged local universities - particularly Heriot-Watt, Glasgow and Strathclyde - to become centres of excellence in electronics and engineering. They are producing spin-out companies with unique intellectual property, in addition to a steady supply of graduates to fuel the growth of existing businesses.

Bill Gold, senior manager at NEC's plant in Livingston, says: "If you've got good whisky and golf, you've got a good supply of water and land."

He adds: "If I'm very honest, West Lothian and East Lanarkshire is not the most attractive area but it does have its advantages - it's only 20 minutes from here to each city."

The evolution of NEC is typical of many such companies. In 1981, the firm began making memory chips in Livingston. Profit margins are enormous - an 8in silicon wafer costing £15 can be turned into chips worth more than £1,000.

The problem is that the market for memory chips is highly volatile - prices collapsed in the late 1990s, partly due to the slump in Asian markets. Mobile phones have fuelled a revival - the liquid crystal display on phones is driven by semiconductor chips. NEC is moving more towards logic products - used to transmit digital messages - which are less liable to be considered commodities which can be transferred overseas.

Similarly, IBM in Greenock has shifted its emphasis from making personal compuetrs to delivering customer support and e-commerce solutions. Of 5,000 staff on site, only 1,000 remain in manufacturing roles.

Site director Charles Morrison says: "I want my folk to be spending time not screwing things together but adding intellectual value. Every company out there is going to have to change its business model as a result of the web. We used to concentrate on making computers. But the web is about how to put PCs together. We're now trying to provide end-to-end solutions."

Initiatives have sprung up across the region to encourage hi-tech start-ups. One is the Alba Centre in Livingston, run by Scottish Enterprise. The centre has set up a components exchange, allowing local companies to buy and sell each other's intellectual property, helping them to fill the gaps in their own technology.

The centre is running a four-year doctorate programme in systems integration, and is building a new block - Integration House - containing office space and communal areas. Its director says: "We have to keep increasing the knowledge base. We need to act as a magnet to bring in overseas companies."

The town of Livingston is enjoying the benefits. A former mining area, much of the new development is on reclaimed land. The landscape is bleak, uniform grassland with new housing estates situated on complicated ringroad networks.

The town has a new hospital and a new college. A shopping centre, the Almondvale Centre, is buzzing with people and has a high concentration of shops selling pricey electrical goods.

Closer to Glasgow, Compound Semiconductor Technology has been established as an incubator for new companies. It takes designs from entrepreneurs and produces working prototypes of optoelectronics and chips.

Biotechnology has joined the technology boom - among the local companies is PPL Therapeutics, the company best known for cloning Dolly the Sheep.

Few would claim that the benefits of the hi-tech economy have yet trickled down to all the areas of urban deprivation in Glasgow. However, the "new economy" looks set to keep Scotland in chips for years to come.

fields.headline: Those wrangling royals
fields.standfirst: The palace is buzzing with disputation
fields.trailText: First we have Prince Charles's mystical musings on genetic modification, then his sister disagrees, then dad weighs in with a broadside contrasting GM with exotic grey squirrels, and finally his sister backtracks, trying to play peacemaker between warring familial egos, declaring the jury is still out on GM after all.
fields.body:
First we have Prince Charles's mystical musings on genetic modification, then his sister disagrees, then dad weighs in with a broadside contrasting GM with exotic grey squirrels, and finally his sister backtracks, trying to play peacemaker between warring familial egos, declaring the jury is still out on GM after all. What has poured across newspaper columns these past few days is an echo of conversations around dinner tables, bars and coffee machines. For once, the Windsors' comments may be more informed than those of many of their subjects. The three are statistically rare in Britain for having some experience of farming on their estates. The Duke of Edinburgh took his responsibilities at the World Wildlife Fund seriously, as does the Princess Royal as head of Save the Children and the Prince of Wales has long had an interest in environmentalism.

But for all their qualifications to speak and their passionately held views, it does not look good to have the royal family airing their disagreements in public. It smacks too much of older emotional feuds being played out in proxy - Prince Philip has never had much time for his son's "romanticism", as he politely describes it. This kind of skirmishing deals another blow to a constitutional monarchy whose unique selling point for much of the last century was family unity.

It is hard to see now how the Firm can ensure this kind of public bust-up does not happen again. Monthly meetings over lunch with a list of controversial issues to divvy up? "Charles, you do endangered butterflies and architects, I'll do Africa's starving and child labour," the Princess Royal might suggest - only for an unseemly squabble to ensue about whether GM is endangering the butterflies but could feed Africa's children. And then there is the tricky question of who gets invited: does the Queen Mother have views on GM? And is Princess Margaret poised to tell us of its impact on Mustique?

webTitle: Still a chance of a deal

fields.headline: Still a chance of a deal
fields.standfirst: Mr Barak could do with new allies
fields.trailText: With Israel finally out of Lebanon, it becomes more and more difficult to justify Syria's continuing presence there.
fields.body:
With Israel finally out of Lebanon, it becomes more and more difficult to justify Syria's continuing presence there. UN resolution 425, passed in 1978, with which Ehud Barak's government is now in all but complete compliance, calls for the withdrawal of all foreign forces, not just Israeli. Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, referred directly to Syria's 35,000-strong military garrison when she demanded yesterday in Cairo that "all parties follow through on their obligations" to pull out. Despite the absence of a peace settlement and predictions of imminent Armageddon, Israel's northern border has been quieter these past two weeks than at any time in recent memory. For this, Syria deserves some credit. The Israeli prime minister warns that Damascus is planning to use Lebanon-based Palestinians to create new trouble. But there is no firm evidence of this so far. In any case, President Hafez Assad would be far better employed finding a way out of the hole he dug for himself at his March summit with the US in Geneva. A good beginning would be a Syrian military build-down in Lebanon.

Mr Assad has precious little to show after 11 months of desultory, on-off contacts with the new Israeli leadership. Having dug in its heels on the Galilee shore, Syria is now further from regaining the Golan Heights than when Mr Barak first took office. With his Lebanon pledge redeemed, the Israeli PM's gaze has meanwhile shifted elsewhere. Next week, at Ms Albright's bidding, the Israeli-Palestinian talks will move to the US. The whole focus is on reaching an agreement by the September deadline. This, says Ms Albright, is now Bill Clinton's number one foreign policy priority. The issues of settlements, borders, and Jerusalem are as intractable as ever, and doubts grow about Yasser Arafat's (and Mr Barak's) ability to sell an inevitably unsatisfactory compromise. But much spadework has been quietly done in talks in Stockholm. A deal is still do-able.

The cause of peace was hardly helped by yesterday's posturing by religious parties in the Knesset. Their support for a call for early elections was as fatuous as it was, for now at least, non-binding. It distracts Mr Barak but does not dish him. If need be, he should dispense with these self-serving, blinkered coalition partners and seek secular and Arab parliamentary allies. The end justifies such unorthodox means.

fields.headline: Wreckers of democracy
fields.standfirst:
As bigots unite against the parliament, devolution in Scotland goes hideously wrong

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Trevor Royle: As bigots unite against the parliament, devolution in Scotland goes hideously wrong
fields.body:
Twelve months ago, when the US television evangelist Pat Robertson informed his audience that homosexuality could take Scotland "right back to darkness", he was very quickly reminded that Scots do not like being lectured to by middle-aged born-again Christians with too much money and not enough commonsense.

Besides, his ranting went against the mood of the time. Scotland was on the verge of regaining its parliament, and a sense of optimism was in the air. Church leaders and politicians joined forces with homosexual rights groups to kick his comments into touch. An embarrassed Bank of Scotland was forced to pull out of a lucrative £30m direct banking deal with Robertson's television channel. In the process it lost several million pounds as well as the loyalty of its account holders, more than 5,000 of whom took their business away.

The people of Scotland had made clear their feelings. But it was not the end of the matter - far from it. A year has gone by, and the Scottish parliament has come into being with high hopes of engendering a workable social democracy. But the questions of tolerance and sexual orientation refuse to go away.

The repeal of the anti-homosexual Section 28 has been Labour policy since 1988. This time round, though, opposition comes not in the form of a manicured television host on the other side of the Atlantic, but closer to home in the more substantial figures of Cardinal Thomas Winning and Brian Souter, the millionaire owner of Stagecoach.

The two men have sent Scotland into such a spectacular spin that the parliament seems incapable of controlling it.

So hard-hitting has the hostility been and so muddled the response of the executive - the government - that Wendy Alexander, the minister for social inclusion and local government, admits that with hindsight she and her colleagues "could have done differently and done better".

Her mea culpa followed the public opinion poll financed by Souter, which revealed that 28% of Scots supported the retention of Section 28, and the publication of Winning's remarks that the parliament was an "utter failure" and that he was "ashamed of politicians and the way they behave".

Between them and their media advisers, Winning and Souter have thoroughly unsettled Scotland by placing moral fundamentalism at the heart of mainstream politics.

Indeed, so confident does Souter feel about imposing his own standards on the country that there is talk of him funding candidates to stand against politicians opposed to his views. (George Galloway, MP for Kelvin, has already challenged Souter to run against him if he was "hard enough".)

Souter's aides insist that, having forced the executive into a number of amendments, their moral campaign has the power to challenge the political agenda.

If it does, the venture hangs on Souter's millions. While his referendum was nothing more than a privately funded opinion poll, its success depended on a lavish advertising campaign, some slick promotion of "family values" and the aggressively homophobic support of the Scottish tabloid, the Daily Record.

According to the Souter camp, the message to the executive is clear: because more than 1m people "voted" in favour of keeping Section 28, their wishes should be taken into account before it is repealed in three weeks' time.

Even if the parliament ignores the findings - and why should it pay any heed, 72% having failed to vote in favour? - Souter makes it clear that he is intent on launching a crusade to keep marriage sacrosanct and maintain the "family values" that he believes are being eroded by the forces of the politically correct.

This can only mean one thing: that Scottish politics is in danger of being turned into a battleground between the existing political parties and a coalition of religious evangelicals and fundamentalists.

They will not lack ammunition. Scotland's parliament has plans to simplify divorce, to end discrimination against children born outside marriage and to introduce various measures aimed at changing sex education in schools and providing better contraceptive care for teenagers.

Any of these issues could provide a cause for a moral crusade that would find backers not just from within Souter's broad church but also from Catholics and Muslims and anti-abortion pro-life groups.

The Roman Catholic Cardinal Winning's intervention has also dismayed many Scots. In equal measures admired and detested for his stand on sexual morality, especially for his opposition to abortion, Winning is a powerful orator who prefers confrontation to consensus. He has never been averse to grabbing headlines. The Church of Scotland has condemned his comments and there was widespread consternation when he appeared to be attacking the parliament for pursuing a "very liberal agenda".

Was this not what Scotland had in mind when it voted to restore its parliament in a referendum in which Winning was a key supporter? Does the new Scotland want to free itself from religious intolerance and bigotry of all kinds - or does it want to have its mind made up for it by a millionaire with a fat chequebook and a church leader who has used his position to denounce a parliament because it does not agree with his agenda?

Not that the executive is free from blame. This parliament was supposed to be a new beginning, a chamber in which fresh and coherent ideas would be debated within a Scottish context, freed from the grip of centralist Westminster policies. In other words, it would be an exemplar for the whole principle of devolution.

Now it is all going hideously wrong, merely because it has allowed itself to be wrongfooted by a well-meaning attempt to end discrimination against homosexuals. The executive has made so many muddled attempts at appeasement by introducing new guidelines on marriage and sex education that no one can fathom its policy at all. It should have stuck to its word, instead of playing into the hands of self-appointed guardians of public morality.

Inexperience is one reason. Many MSPs schooled in local authority politics have failed to make the transition to a larger scale. Lack of firm leadership is another and the executive has not been helped by the absence through illness of the first minster, Donald Dewar. But the main reason is that the debate has been hijacked by the one thing which renascent Scotland wanted to avoid - a row fuelled by bigotry.

Last weekend, a group of scholars and politicians met in Aberdeen to study the links between Scotland and Ireland. But as one representative put it, given the current predicament within the country the comparison might be better made with Iran.

TRoyle9123@aol.com

Trevor Royle is a historian and associate editor of the Glasgow Sunday Herald

webTitle: Beijing tries, but fails, to gag internet hosts

fields.headline: Beijing tries, but fails, to gag internet hosts
fields.trailText: China redoubled its efforts to censor the internet yesterday by saying it would charge a web host who defiantly posted details of human rights abuses on his website.
fields.body:
China redoubled its efforts to censor the internet yesterday by saying it would charge a web host who defiantly posted details of human rights abuses on his website.

Huang Qi is accused of subverting state power, a crime which could see him jailed for up to 10 years, according to the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy.

But authorities in the south-western city of Chengdu were unable to shut down his web site, which gives details of banned subjects such as the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre and the crackdown against the Falun Gong sect, because - although it is registered in China - it is physically located on an internet service provider in the US. Nor could they stop surfers in China from viewing it through overseas proxies or "mirror sites", which replicate its contents.

Mr Huang and his wife, Zeng Li, were detained last Saturday after posting articles on the sensitive Tiananmen Square massacre anniversary of June 4 1989, on his website at www.6-4tianwang.com. These included a call by the dissident Ding Zilin, who lost her son in the military crackdown, for the trial of Li Peng, China's premier at the time who is widely seen as one of the prime instigators in the use of force against the unarmed students.

"June 4 is a political scheme carefully plotted by the Chinese Communist party's conservative faction," said one article. Other articles documented allegations of official corruption and the death of a Falun Gong follower in jail after being beaten by police.

Ms Zeng has since been released but was told yesterday that her husband would be facing charges, although these have yet to be laid.

Mr Huang had previously been praised by Beijing for his internet activities. His first website, established last June, shot to fame after it helped reunite 10,000 people with their families, mostly women abducted into sex slavery, an increasingly serious problem in China.

The site brought praise from the People's Daily, the official mouthpiece of the Communist party. But then the website plunged into controversy by exposing the story of a fisherman, Zeng Quanfu, who had his appendix removed on the orders of a Chinese employment agency, to forestall any liability for his medical bills while at sea.

The resulting scandal attracted nationwide attention and reportedly brought the website to the attention of China's top authorities, including the prime minister, Zhu Rongji.

It was closed by police on March 31 but reopened on April 14, using servers in the US to evade Chinese censorship. Mr Huang's game of cat and mouse with the authorities highlights the increasing difficulties Beijing faces in maintaining its tight grip on the flow of cyber information; the number of internet users in China has now topped 10m.

In recent months the internet has been supplanted as a source of news by popular Chinese web chat rooms, which have repeatedly broken major stories that had been censored by the state-run press.

These included a huge corruption scandal in the coastal city of Xiamen involving billions of pounds-worth of smuggled goods and the murder of a Beijing University student, Qiu Qingfeng, which provoked rare protests about the inadequate security that allegedly contributed to her death.

Authorities have struck back with regulations to limit the news posted on popular sites. There have also been harsh penalties for those who use the internet to facilitate anti-government activities, including a two-year jail term imposed on Shanghai computer engineer Lin Hai, after he passed 30,000 email addresses to a dissident group.

fields.headline: The spectre of the euro
fields.trailText: Hugo Young is right to say of the euro referendum that "preventing it is a key part of [the anti-euro campaign's] strategy". But our fears have nothing to do with arguments over the euro. What we are really frightened of is the prospect of a huge and abusive campaign that uses the government machine and public and European Commission money against the privately-funded No campaign.
fields.body:
Hugo Young is right to say of the euro referendum that "preventing it is a key part of [the anti-euro campaign's] strategy". But our fears have nothing to do with arguments over the euro. What we are really frightened of is the prospect of a huge and abusive campaign that uses the government machine and public and European Commission money against the privately-funded No campaign.

Alastair Campbell and Philip Gould agree with Gordon Brown that in the year before the next election it would be madness to talk about something as deeply unpopular as the euro. Also, unlike in 1975, the majority of business opposes the euro, which will make it difficult for the government to win the key arguments on jobs and future prosperity. Their biggest fear, however, is that the Hugo Young-Bob Worcester plan for "fear to stalk the land", and the portrayal of all opponents as lunatics, may not be possible this time. We think they're right.

Dominic Cummings
Business for Sterling
dominic@bfors.com

 In 1975 the debate was about coming out the common market. That is not the agenda today, reflecting the fact that Britain has reversed post-war decline. The referendum is about whether we should take a significant step towards a single European state. Given the odds against changing public opinion, the prime minister might be loath to call a referendum in the next parliament. If he loses, either the government will have to resign, or else it will stagger on broken-backed - as did John Major's administration after ejection from the ERM - and wait for the electorate to take retribution.

Frank Field MP

webTitle: Sexism still rife in the Met

fields.headline: Sexism still rife in the Met
fields.trailText: I was enraged to read the Metropolitan police's comments in the wake of the £1m settlement to WPC Sarah Locker (Met's £1m hate campaign pay-out, June 6). As an employee with an unblemished service record working for the Met for over 20 years, I know it is simply not true that the Met has "moved forward" since the events six years ago. I and another black colleague have been subjected to a concerted campaign of harassment, since we blew the whistle on corrupt practices at our place of work in relation to falsifying annual leave and flexi-time. Since making a stand, our lives have been made absolute hell and both of us have been prescribed anti-depressants to help us deal with this. This has affected both our families badly.
fields.body:
I was enraged to read the Metropolitan police's comments in the wake of the £1m settlement to WPC Sarah Locker (Met's £1m hate campaign pay-out, June 6). As an employee with an unblemished service record working for the Met for over 20 years, I know it is simply not true that the Met has "moved forward" since the events six years ago. I and another black colleague have been subjected to a concerted campaign of harassment, since we blew the whistle on corrupt practices at our place of work in relation to falsifying annual leave and flexi-time. Since making a stand, our lives have been made absolute hell and both of us have been prescribed anti-depressants to help us deal with this. This has affected both our families badly.

Many things have been done to discredit us in the workplace, but we are determined to continue fighting because we want people to know what is going on in the Met. Only if the organisation is truly called to account will the Met police service be able to say that things have genuinely moved forward.

Name and address supplied

 Again we hear that London's police are paying out the taxpayers' money in order to silence criticism, but it was not an admission of guilt or wrongdoing. It's high time this farce was done away with. London's new mayor should ensure that the Met defends in court every case when it thinks no wrongdoing has occurred and equally it should apologise and pay compensation if it believes it is in the wrong. Every lost case or apology should trigger an inquiry and it appropriate disciplinary proceedings.

Alan Mathison
Harrow, Middx
alan.mathison@ntlworld.com

 Sarah Locker's tearful denouncement of her former boss and employer, John Grieve and the Metropolitan police, was just another tragic and expensive milestone in the long history of discrimination against women in our police service. The truth is that little has changed in the 10 years since I started my own equality action against Merseyside police. Sadly, the evidence suggests the determination to vigorously defend discrimination cases is growing, regardless of the trauma or humiliation heaped on the victim or the cost to the public.

Sarah Locker has shown grit and determination by forcing a financial settlement and demonstrating the continued reluctance of chief officers to enter the witness box. There is a deep and inexplicable resentment within police managerial culture that refuses to acknowledge any trace of discriminatory or unethical behaviour towards women officers. There is less difficulty in admitting racist behaviour, as the Macpherson enquiry has proved.

The Locker settlement is just the tip of the financial iceberg when all internal costs are calculated. Officers we pay to uphold the law use the public purse to resolve management failures. Senior officers walk away unscathed, and although the victim gains some recompense, nothing substantive changes. Chief officers will only amend their behaviour when faced with external political pressure. Jack Straw must demand a Lawrence-type inquiry to establish the facts and bring about a commitment to resolve the ingrained culture of sexism in British police forces.

Alison Halford AM
National Assembly for Wales

 Police victims are paid from our taxes. When I was in the army we paid "barrack damages", a levy on all in the unit to pay for damage done which could not be attributed to individuals. Pay damages out of police salaries and watch the incidences of racial and sexual abuse fall.

Saltburn-by-the-Sea, Cleveland

Many things have been done to discredit us in the workplace, but we are determined to continue fighting because we want people to know what is going on in the Met. webTitle: Give us the cash - and we'll spend more time at home

fields.headline: Give us the cash - and we'll spend more time at home
fields.trailText: The proportion of consultants doing private practice is much higher than Polly Toynbee states (Comment, June 7), the usually quoted figure being at least 70%. This in no way detracts from the general points she is making. There are interesting ideas being discussed which could settle once and for all the contractual problem, to the great benefit of the health service. The NHS Consultants' Association has long argued for proper recognition, including financial, of total commitment to the NHS, which has been eroded since changes made in 1980.
fields.body:
The proportion of consultants doing private practice is much higher than Polly Toynbee states (Comment, June 7), the usually quoted figure being at least 70%. This in no way detracts from the general points she is making. There are interesting ideas being discussed which could settle once and for all the contractual problem, to the great benefit of the health service. The NHS Consultants' Association has long argued for proper recognition, including financial, of total commitment to the NHS, which has been eroded since changes made in 1980.

An "NHS-only" contract should be the norm, with any variants which might be negotiated allowing private practice, as concessions.

Peter Fisher
President, NHSCA
nhsca@pop3.poptel.org.uk

 Many consultants would jump at a realistic NHS salary in exchange for giving up private practice. But the result would be more time spent with families rather than seeing more patients - and the government knows this. Two years ago the independent Doctors and Dentists Review Body commissioned a survey of consultant workload. This found that on average consultants worked 10 hours a week for the NHS in excess of their contracted (about 38) hours - irrespective of whether they carried out any private practice. Many breached the European working time directive.

This means about one-third of all care delivered by NHS consultants is effectively "unpaid overtime". In short, the average British consultant is not in a position to work any more hours for the NHS. What is required is an expansion, to the levels of our neighbours, of beds, facilities and consultant, nursing and paramedical numbers.

Dr Michael Austin
Swansea

 The plan to buy out NHS consultants will thrill thousands of laboratory scientific officers, medical technicians, cytologists and other health professionals whose NHS starting pay is little more than one-third of the additional £30,000 that could be showered upon the consultants. This comes at a crucial point in the development of a job evaluation scheme which addresses the pay and grading anomolies in the NHS. The answer to fixing the consultants lies not in an additional £630m, but in ensuring that managers manage consultants in accordance with the requirements laid down in an agreement accepted by the BMA in 1990.

Barrie Brown
NHS section, MSF
wardl@msf.org.uk

 Attractive as the idea of "hip-replacement factories" (Leader, June 6) may be, they are major operations performed on older people more likely to suffer complications. The best place to have a major operation is in an NHS hospital. Before moving these operations from NHS hospitals, we should remember that the consequences of botched operations are very painful and distressing for the patient, but expensive and time consuming for the NHS.

Paul Goodings
Chester
paul@surfbird.co.uk

fields.headline: AW Cleeve Barr
fields.standfirst: Architect and powerful advocate of public housing who fought an unsuccessful rearguard action against the spread of the high-rises
fields.trailText: The production of high-rise council flats was at its height in the 1960s when AW Cleeve Barr, who has died at the age of 89, rose to be the most powerful housing architect in British government service. As such he fought, but failed, to control the proliferation of contractor-led housing systems, and his reputation was tarnished by public reaction after the collapse in 1968 of Ronan Point. A technocrat with an instinct for social justice and a streak of obstinacy, he had enthusiasms that belied his puritan convictions.
fields.body:
The production of high-rise council flats was at its height in the 1960s when AW Cleeve Barr, who has died at the age of 89, rose to be the most powerful housing architect in British government service. As such he fought, but failed, to control the proliferation of contractor-led housing systems, and his reputation was tarnished by public reaction after the collapse in 1968 of Ronan Point. A technocrat with an instinct for social justice and a streak of obstinacy, he had enthusiasms that belied his puritan convictions.

Cleeve Barr was born with the name of Albert Babey. He was brought up by an army widow and educated at Sir William Borlase's School, Marlow. After training in the Bank of England, he left with an associateship of the Institute of Bankers, a new name and a contempt for bowlers and umbrellas. A short spell in 1934 at the Liverpool School of Architecture was followed by work for Charles Holden, mainly on the Senate House of London University.

Imbued with socialist ideals, Barr became in 1936 secretary of the Association of Architects, Surveyors and Technical Assistants. The first trades union for building professionals, the AASTA opposed the Royal Institute of British Architects and believed architecture should be all about social welfare. Barr co-ordinated campaigns, notably one against jerry-built private housing. In the early part of the war, he was among the socialists who agitated in the East End in favour of better shelters.

After Hitler invaded the USSR, Barr was co-opted into RAF intelligence and became a liaison officer to the Russian air force. He helped establish the route for the delivery of Catalina flying boats to the Russians, and was posted to Iran and later Berlin, where his knowledge of Russian was put to use during the four-power talks.

By 1948, Barr finally qualified as an architect and went to work for Hertfordshire county council, then developing its famous programme of primary schools. He was given two to design, one of which, Templewood at Welwyn Garden City, was the Hertfordshire school chosen for the RIBA's Medal in 1950, and visited by Le Corbusier, who merely remarked: "C'est jolie".

This was a happy period of his career. But his rebellions were not quite over. Dissatisfied by conditions of work, Barr and three others, among them Oliver Cox, left in a group for the housing branch of the London County Council's architect's department, then being energised by Robert Matthew. Barr and Cox wanted the LCC to "do a Herts" - to set up a group to work out a standard prefabricated "language" from which housing architects would make their own designs. They got some way, through Barr's persistence and Cox's fertility in designing. However, housing was not like schools, nor was the giant LCC like Herts. There were too many fingers in the pie, and they lacked the unconditional support of Leslie Martin, who succeeded Matthew in 1953. The principal monument of the group was the Alton East or Portsmouth Road section of the LCC's celebrated Roehampton Estate. Its critics - principally the designers of the adjacent Corbusian slabs at Alton West - liked to dismiss the informal melange of Alton East as "Scandinavian" or "humanist". But though less spectacular to look at, it was always the better housing.

By the mid-50s, Cleeve Barr was becoming locked into issues of housing production and technique. His Picton Street, Camberwell, probably the first estate in the country laid out to suit the path of the travelling crane that built it, was none the better-looking for it. He was notorious for his technical obsessions. One such, relevant in those days when coal was still king and the miners were to be supported, was "shunt flues", meaning European methods of bringing flues in flats together to avoid the English absurdity of many separate chimneys.

He left the LCC in 1957 for a short spell as the Ministry of Education's development group architect. But the appearance in the following year of Public Authority Housing, written in his spare time, showed where his real passion lay.

In 1959 he became chief architect to the Ministry of Housing and Local Government. Harold Macmillan had risen to power on the strength of a housing programme, and one in every five British families by then was in public housing. With a new push for numbers on, the position seemed promising. Barr set about forming a development group, which Oliver Cox came to run, again with the hope that exemplary, mainly low-rise projects using prefabricated techniques could be built and then taken up by local authorities. A few were built, notably a timber-framed estate at West Ham - close to Ronan Point.

But in reality the chances for architects to control public housing were slipping away. The subsidy rules had shifted in favour of high-rise building. Worse, the big contractors had begun to take licences of continental systems for tall flats in heavy concrete, geared to speedy erection and profit alone.

In 1964 Sir Donald Gibson, then in charge of technical development at Geoffrey Rippon's short-lived Ministry of Public Buildings and Works, set up the National Building Agency. The idea was to advise industry and local authorities on efficiency and productivity in building, and to put a rein on the rampant new private systems of housing.

Cleeve Barr became chief architect and later managing director of the NBA. But the new quango never lived up to its expectations. The high-rise systems escaped its control, and there was much bickering between ministries, except in Scotland, where the NBA architects did some useful development work.

The private sector was now dominant, while many architects were heartily sick of designing buildings in series. The collapse of Ronan Point in 1968 ushered in the era of vilification for the twin ideals of prefabrication and public housing. Architects now found out how little political influence they had really enjoyed. Barr defended his patch but was wounded. The NBA shifted to nurturing housing associations, in particular the UK Housing Association, in which Barr took personal interest. It also pressed metrication on a reluctant construction industry, and developed the then new techniques of project management for rescuing big building schemes in trouble on site.

Having stepped down in 1975, Barr pent two years indulging a passion by running a film-making unit for the NBA, before retiring to Walton on Thames.

He could be formidable in committee and was sometimes feared, despite a private simplicity and humility which enabled him to face setbacks with stoicism. He painted, sculpted and potted, and was involved with community activities.

His first wife, Edith, with whom he had a son and a daughter, died in 1965. His second wife, Mary, survives him.

Albert William Cleeve Barr, architect, born October 5 1910; died May 30 2000

fields.headline: Appreciation: Andrew Faulds
fields.trailText: Nicholas Fogg writes: At this year's Shakespeare Birthday Luncheon in Stratford-upon-Avon, Des Barrett told me he thought he'd seen Andrew Faulds (Obituary, June 1) watching the procession through the window of 18 Old Town. If so, it was Andrew's farewell to the place he loved above all others. An inveterate and tasteful collector, pride of place went to his vast albums, that seemed to contain every postcard ever issued of Stratford, and the paintings by the local artist William Quartremaine on his walls, for which his main rival collectors were both millionaires.
fields.body:
Nicholas Fogg writes: At this year's Shakespeare Birthday Luncheon in Stratford-upon-Avon, Des Barrett told me he thought he'd seen Andrew Faulds (Obituary, June 1) watching the procession through the window of 18 Old Town. If so, it was Andrew's farewell to the place he loved above all others. An inveterate and tasteful collector, pride of place went to his vast albums, that seemed to contain every postcard ever issued of Stratford, and the paintings by the local artist William Quartremaine on his walls, for which his main rival collectors were both millionaires.

Andrew's adhesion to Stratford, like Marie Corelli's, took practical form. In the 1950s, he tried to save the 17th-century house in Church Street of his in-laws, the Whitfields, from destruction by civic philistines. Despite the publicity he was able to generate through his fame, he lost, but it was a shot across the bows for those who are reckless of the local environment.

After serving in the Fleet Air Arm, Andrew was invited to Stratford by Robert Atkins in 1944, for the first of his four seasons at the theatre; the last was in 1956, when he played Laertes to Alan Badel's Hamlet. By then, he was a household name, as Jet Morgan in Journey into Space.

It has been suggested that Paul Robeson goaded Andrew into political activism as they watched the Tory landslide of 1959 together. This may be so, but he had in fact been active in that campaign. I heard what may have been his first political speech, in a draughty hall in Tiddington in support of the Labour candidate. He was a great find for the moribund local Labour party and soon became its chairman. In those days he supported CND, and I remember waving a banner on a "Ban the Bomb" march he organised with Jacquetta Hawkes.

Andrew's first electoral foray came in Alveston Ward in 1960. He lost, but increased the interest and turn-out massively. I canvassed for him, and still have the book of prints he gave me, inscribed: "From Andrew Faulds - failed councillor".

The "failed councillor" was destined for higher things. Andrew possessed that quality essential for both actors and politicians - to be in the right place at the right time. He was adopted for Stratford, and would certainly have fought a quixotic campaign in this safe Tory seat, but the Profumo affair of 1963 led to the most high-profile byelection for years. He came so close to winning that he could pronounce that "there are defeats that have the taste of victory." To Andrew's credit, he never referred to the scandal during his campaign.

Although Andrew was too tempestuous a parliamentary performer to be constrained by office (in Norman St John Stevas's words, "the best arts minister we never had"), local people knew him as a brilliant constituency MP. In a House of Commons increasingly devoid of characters, he retained the integrity of his Presbyterian heritage. You could agree or disagree with his firm views, but I doubt if he ever said anything he didn't believe.

At last year's birthday lunch, Andrew wryly lamented to me that the Labour party had not seen fit to send him to the Lords: "I suppose I'm still too controversial." Of course, if there is any justification for that body, it is as a place where people can freely express what they feel needs to be said. That's what Andrew Faulds was all about.

Andy Foster writes: There was a long background to Andrew Faulds' criticism of Enoch Powell. In August 1963, he stood in a famous byelection at Stratford, and reduced the Tory majority to 3,000 in one of their safest seats. This made him a hot political property, but he insisted on fighting Stratford again in the 1964 general election. At that election, against the national swing, Patrick Gordon Walker lost Smethwick to the Tories in the most racist election ever fought in this country: the Tories went round getting the kids to chant "For a nigger for a neighbour, vote Labour." They took Birmingham Perry Barr from Labour on the same night.

Faulds courageously sought the nomination for Smethwick to wipe away the stain of the 1964 result, and his victory in 1966 was sweet. Enoch Powell's 1968 speech was made in Birmingham, and immensely popular in the area. Faulds's resolute attack was, like standing in Smethwick, more courageous than it now appears.

In 1974, he did not "switch to a safer Warley". Warley East was the whole of his old Smethwick seat, plus part of the very marginal Oldbury and Halesowen. On paper it was distinctly less good for Labour than Smethwick. He made it a safe seat until his retirement.

Leon E Cook writes: As secretary of Perry Barr ward Labour party, I wrote to Andrew Faulds in 1966 to ask him if he would accept our nomination as candidate in the coming general election. Perry Barr, with Eton and Slough, and Smethwick, was one of the only three seats which Labour lost in the 1964 general election, all through racial issues. Perry Barr was a sure thing to return to Labour in 1966, and would be a gift to anyone who became the candidate. Andrew was in Spain at the time making a film with Orson Welles, The Chimes at Midnight. He wrote back to tell me that he was honoured by Perry Barr's request, but had to decline. He said that he hoped for nomination at Smethwick constituency as he had the ambition to take back the seat from Peter Griffiths, and avenge the defeat of Patrick Gordon Walker. Which of course he did.

At that election, against the national swing, Patrick Gordon Walker lost Smethwick to the Tories in the most racist election ever fought in this country: the Tories went round getting the kids to chant "For a nigger for a neighbour, vote Labour." They took Birmingham Perry Barr from Labour on the same night. Faulds courageously sought the nomination for Smethwick to wipe away the stain of the 1964 result, and his victory in 1966 was sweet. Enoch Powell's 1968 speech was made in Birmingham, and immensely popular in the area. Faulds's resolute attack was, like standing in Smethwick, more courageous than it now appears. In 1974, he did not "switch to a safer Warley". Warley East was the whole of his old Smethwick seat, plus part of the very marginal Oldbury and Halesowen. On paper it was distinctly less good for Labour than Smethwick. He made it a safe seat until his retirement. Leon E Cook writes: As secretary of Perry Barr ward Labour party, I wrote to Andrew Faulds in 1966 to ask him if he would accept our nomination as candidate in the coming general election. Perry Barr, with Eton and Slough, and Smethwick, was one of the only three seats which Labour lost in the 1964 general election, all through racial issues. Perry Barr was a sure thing to return to Labour in 1966, and would be a gift to anyone who became the candidate. Andrew was in Spain at the time making a film with Orson Welles, The Chimes at Midnight. He wrote back to tell me that he was honoured by Perry Barr's request, but had to decline. He said that he hoped for nomination at Smethwick constituency as he had the ambition to take back the seat from Peter Griffiths, and avenge the defeat of Patrick Gordon Walker. Which of course he did.

webTitle: Being against GM is not anti-science

fields.headline: Being against GM is not anti-science
fields.trailText: I am the "anti-GM university biologist" Conrad Lichtenstein referred to in his article on the GM controversy (Comment, June 6). The debate he described was arranged by the US Embassy for biotechnologist, Dr CS Prakash, sent by the US state department to promote GM agriculture in Europe. I agreed to participate because I believe in promoting critical public understanding of science and to draw attention to well-known and relevant scientific knowledge that is being ignored.
fields.body:
I am the "anti-GM university biologist" Conrad Lichtenstein referred to in his article on the GM controversy (Comment, June 6). The debate he described was arranged by the US Embassy for biotechnologist, Dr CS Prakash, sent by the US state department to promote GM agriculture in Europe. I agreed to participate because I believe in promoting critical public understanding of science and to draw attention to well-known and relevant scientific knowledge that is being ignored.

Almost by definition, genetic engineering organisms involves designing GM constructs which invade genomes and overcome natural processes that break down foreign genetic material. Due to their highly mixed origins, however, GM constructs are more unstable than natural genetic material as well as more invasive; and may therefore be more likely to spread to unrelated species.

Those points were not challenged by Prakash because these basic principles and observations of genetic engineering are covered in text books and are also areas of active research. I answered Lichtenstein's questions in full and referred him to our website (www.i-sis.org), where the relevant scientific papers are cited and where more than 300 scientists from 39 countries, including many molecular geneticists who share my concerns, are demanding a moratorium on releases of GM organisms. There is genuine scientific dissent among scientists and the public are not served by those who continue to misrepresent the GM debate as science versus anti-science.

Dr Mae-Wan Ho
Open University
m.w.ho@open.ac.uk

 It is possible to teach science as Michael Rennie suggests (Comment, June 6). We have been enthusiastically teaching a pilot AS level, called Science for Public Understanding, in preparation for Curriculum 2000. Students from all backgrounds have enjoyed and benefited from the opportunity to debate controversial science issues and make informed decisions, after weighing evidence.

Angela Melamed
Barnet College, London

fields.headline: Robert Fryer
fields.standfirst: Resourceful producer straddling the worlds of Broadway and Hollywood
fields.trailText: Film and theatre producer Robert Fryer, whose successes included The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie, The Shining, The Boys From Brazil and Travels With My Aunt, has died aged 78. "Movies pay the rent but stage is my true love," he once said. However, he often acted as a highly resourceful bridge between both worlds, producing some of Broadway's most famous musicals, many of which were turned into films.
fields.body:
Film and theatre producer Robert Fryer, whose successes included The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie, The Shining, The Boys From Brazil and Travels With My Aunt, has died aged 78. "Movies pay the rent but stage is my true love," he once said. However, he often acted as a highly resourceful bridge between both worlds, producing some of Broadway's most famous musicals, many of which were turned into films.

Fryer came up at a time when a Broadway musical could be made out of street smarts and luck. Take the example of Wonderful Town: Fryer bought the rights to the play My Sister Eileen, and told both director George Abbott and Rosalind Russell that each had agreed to work on the show, even though they hadn't. Both signed on, believing the other was on board.

The first score had to be scrapped - Abbott didn't like it - but Leonard Bernstein was free and in need of money, and his old On the Town collaborators, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, were also interested. There were still problems: it had to be written inside six weeks and, as the legend goes, both Green and Bernstein were to have elective surgery. They arranged to recover in the same hospital room, allowing them to work on the show in their compromised state. Thus, the world now has songs such as 100 Easy Ways to Lose a Man and Conga, neither of them Bernstein classics, but even now fun to encounter in a show that can still surprise and charm.

This would suggest Fryer was an extremely lucky man, but luck alone can't account for a string of hits whose casts read like a near-comprehensive list of Broadway divas. He also worked with Russell in her signature role in Auntie Mame; went on to produce the musical adaptation Mame that made a Broadway star out of Angela Lansbury, and then assembled two of the greatest collaborations between Gwen Verdon and Bob Fosse - Sweet Charity and Chicago.

If there is any fault to be found in his starry list of credits - which also includes the Michael Frayn plays Noises Off and Wild Honey, plus any number of Neil Simon stage works - it was his tendency to get too much mileage out of a given property. The world definitely didn't need the much-reviled movie version of Mame (which nearly ended the career of its star, Lucille Ball) nor the reputedly iffy TV version of Wonderful Town. Yet his best known ventures for the big screen tended to win Oscars.

Fryer was born in Washington, DC, and educated at Western Reserve University in Cleveland. He began his show-business career as a casting director with CBS television but, in migrating to the stage, learned the intricacies of that world from the master, George Abbott. It was with Abbott that he co-produced A Tree Grows in Brooklyn in 1951, launching his career on Broadway, which climaxed with two Stephen Sondheim/Harold Prince shows: Sweeney Todd and the much-revised flop Merrily We Roll Along.

During the 1970s and 80s, Fryer put the Ahmanson Theatre at the Los Angeles Music Centre on the national theatrical map. Here he provided a forum for those who, like him, moved in both worlds (such as Rex Harrison, Maggie Smith and Katharine Hepburn) and for convincing movie talents such as Elizabeth Taylor to try the stage.

Thanks to Fryer, Taylor had her one stage triumph in Lilian Hellman's The Little Foxes. His hallmark was understanding the insecurities of those with big talent: "My heart goes out to the great stars - they feel a deep sense of responsibility to the audience."

He was good with writers, too: Neil Simon tried out five plays in Los Angeles with Fryer, who was prized for his taste, direction and tactful way of projecting it on to others. His plays won 37 Tony awards and 36 Los Angeles Drama Critics Circle awards. Last year, he was given a lifetime achievement citation from the Ovation awards in Los Angeles.

Robert Fryer, producer, born 1921; died May 28 2000

fields.headline: Paula Wessely
fields.standfirst: Austrian actress haunted by her role for the Nazis
fields.trailText: Paula Wessely, who has died aged 93, was Austria's most distinguished stage actress of the 20th century and a representative figure for her country's troubled cultural identity. The controversy surrounding her cooperation with the Nazi regime and her swift rehabilitation after the second world war reflected an uneasy relationship with the past at almost every level of Austrian society.
fields.body:
Paula Wessely, who has died aged 93, was Austria's most distinguished stage actress of the 20th century and a representative figure for her country's troubled cultural identity. The controversy surrounding her cooperation with the Nazi regime and her swift rehabilitation after the second world war reflected an uneasy relationship with the past at almost every level of Austrian society.

Generations of Viennese theatregoers were enchanted by Wessely's apparently simple, restrained performances at the Burgtheater. The daughter of a theatre-loving butcher, she trained at the city's Max-Reinhardt- Seminar. Her first professional appearance was at Vienna's Volkstheater in 1924, but she waited eight years before she caught the eye of Alfred Kerr, Germany's most influential critic, in Gerhard Hauptmann's Rose Bernd at the Deutsches Theater in Berlin. "Wonderful is the only possible word," he wrote.

Wessely owed much of her appeal to the extraordinary timbre of her voice, at once brittle and resonating, lending an odd, singsong quality to her perfectly enunciated speech. But her easy, subdued performances, often of independent, self-assured women, struck an emotional chord. Thomas Mann wrote: "She holds a place in the small gallery of women who, unwittingly, have moved my heart."

After celebrated perfor mances as Gretchen in Max Reinhardt's production of Faust in Salzburg and as St Joan, she appeared in some of Germany's first talking movies, and in 1934 was invited to go to Hollywood. Wessely, however, had fallen in love with a young actor, Attila Hoerbiger, and she decided to stay in Vienna, where they married the following year. After the German annexation of Austria in 1938, the couple became favourites of the Nazi leadership.

The film that was to haunt Wessely for the rest of her life was Heimkehr (Homecoming), a piece of anti-Semitic propaganda produced in 1941. Set among the German minority in Poland a few months before the outbreak of the second world war, the film portrayed Hitler as the saviour of ethnic Germans persecuted by Poles and Jews. In the film's final monologue, Wessely's character makes a tearful, impassioned plea for a Germany "free of Jews" as a giant image of Hitler fills the screen. In 1948, Wessely persuaded US intelligence officers that refusing to take part could have led to her imprisonment. Wessely returned to the Viennese stage in March 1946 in a production of Brecht's Good Woman of Szechuan, and two years later she starred in a film called Der Engel mit der Posaune (The Angel with the Trumpet) as a Jewish woman persecuted by the Nazis.

In 1985 the playwright Elfriede Jelinek made Wessely's Nazi relationship the subject of her play Burgtheater, which features an old actress, already dead, speaking about the support she gave the Nazi regime.

Wessely, in a public statement, said: "Yes, I regret that I didn't find the courage at that time to refuse to be used by this regime; that I didn't find the courage simply to interrupt the filming of Heimkehr. But perhaps I made amends for some of this by giving concrete help during this time to other people, Jewish colleagues and friends."

Wessely never appeared on stage after her husband's death in 1987, and spent her final years in seclusion outside Vienna. She is survived by three actress daughters.

Paula Wessely, actress, born January 20 1907; died May 11 2000
